fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Fragrances
fields.trailText: Fragrances
fields.body:
Buying perfumes on the net should be as easy as choosing the size of the bottle. But the experience doesn't quite match up to an afternoon spent in Harrods or Harvey Nichols, and many manufacturers have been less than happy for their fragrance to be sold on the net.

www.theperfumeshop.com launched earlier this month with around 300 fragrances to buy online - approximately two thirds of the range available in the company's high street stores. It's great if you want to check out prices or buy some of the "exclusive" fragrances available only through the Perfume Shop, but many of the better known brands aren't available yet; Calvin Klein is one exception - you can buy Contradiction, CK One and Obsession. The absence of a proper search facility - or a list detailing precisely which products can be bought online - is an oversight on a site that prides itself on size.

www.ovs.net is a small fragrance discounter with a limited product range, but some reasonable prices: Emporio by Armani 50ml eau de parfum (£21.25); Joop 50ml eau de toilette (£29.75); Miss Dior 50ml eau de toilette (£31.02).The site is hardly the last word in web design, but nervous shoppers should be reassured by the site's membership of the Which web trader scheme.

www.scentpacking.com is an altogether more sophisticated affair. There are around 200 products and the discounts are good. Before you get too carried away though, do read the terms and conditions, which warn that you may be liable for any tax or duty charged on import. Searching is straightforward and the range includes newer fragrances such as Romance by Ralph Lauren (50ml eau de toilette, £27.95), Allure for Men (50ml eau de toilette, £22.95) and L'Eau d'Issey (50ml eau de toilette, £33.95). If you're not happy with your purchase, there's a 100% money-back guarantee.

fields.headline: Angelica
fields.standfirst:
**
The Monarch, London
fields.trailText:
**
The Monarch, London
fields.body:
Girl pop has rarely been less prepossessing. The choices these days boil down to factory-farmed mannequins like Atomic Kitten or fourth-generation copies of Hole that Courtney Love herself couldn't condone. Angelica's waifish prettiness qualifies them for the mannequin category, but their hearts are with the indie noisemakers, and the result is a banging din executed by four women with Nicky Clarke hair.

It's not a particularly satisfying compromise, but that's the way it is, because this country has yet to produce a credible female rock group who can consistently write strong songs, sing them without sounding flat and not have their inadequacies excused with the sop, "But they've got great attitude."

Lancaster's Angelica can be allowed some slack on the grounds that none of them is over 20, but at the moment they're relying on attitude to carry them until they find a musical voice of their own. The one they currently have recalls Hole and Riot Grrrl, but lacks the political agenda, leaving a residue of sticky-floored indie pop about nothing in particular.

All right, that's not altogether true. Concubine Blues, which singer Holly Ross dedicates to "the concubine massive" - presumably the vanload of Lancaster fans who have followed the band to the Monarch, the UK's centre of indie activity - addresses Chinese foot-binding, and Bring Back Her Head, with its devilish chorus "Take out the carving knife and cut, cut, cut off her head", is about visiting mayhem on a love rival. The latter is one of their more outstanding live numbers because it slows down the guitars and makes a virtue of Ross and Brigit Colton's chiffon-light harmonies.

But what is Sea Shanty all about, other than an excuse to emulate Throwing Muses' boring spikiness? And it's hard to care about the sardonic lyrical processes behind Why Did You Let My Kitten Die? when all you can hear is a lead vocal that goes beyond cool restraint to plain old flatness.

Which brings us back to attitude. Angelica have plenty of it, and it bubbles over during the between-song heckling sessions, where mutual insults bond them with their people. Kenickie, Britain's last moderately significant girl band, were also good at this kind of thing. But while attitude may get you onto Steve Lamacq's Radio 1 show (where their debut album, The End of a Beautiful Career, is getting the star treatment), sooner or later you've got to write a great song or three.

webTitle: 6-3 split in vote to hold interest rates

fields.headline: 6-3 split in vote to hold interest rates
fields.trailText: Three members of the Bank of England's key interest-rate setting body voted for higher rates this month as the monetary policy committee split over its response to Britain's twin-track economy, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Three members of the Bank of England's key interest-rate setting body voted for higher rates this month as the monetary policy committee split over its response to Britain's twin-track economy, it was revealed yesterday.

Mervyn King, one of the bank's deputy-governors, chief economist John Vickers and Willem Buiter, one of the four outside members of the nine-strong MPC, called for a quarter-point rise in rates to stop the booming domestic economy from putting the government's 2.5% inflation target at jeopardy.

However, the bulk of the committee - including the governor, Eddie George - preferred to adopt a wait-and-see stance, warning that higher interest rates could exacerbate the imbalance in the economy between the strong service sector and the weakness in manufacturing.

Minutes of the MPC meeting held on April 5-6 showed that the committee took a relaxed view of Gordon Brown's boost to public spending in the March budget, saying "the impact on future activity and inflation from the budget seemed unlikely to be large over the next two years."

The more hawkish group on the MPC said that domestic demand was growing rapidly and that although this was being offset in the short run by the burgeoning trade gap, the position was not sustainable over the medium term.

According to the minutes, they argued that "the labour market remained tight and, whether or not higher earnings fed through into firms' prices directly, they would add to disposable incomes and hence to demand pressures."

The majority of MPC members said pressures from the labour market needed further study, and that volatility in stock markets meant a decision to raise rates might have to be reversed quickly. They also agreed that the fall in manufacturing production had aggravated the imbalances in the economy.

"An increase might exacerbate these imbalances and it was possible that the weakness in some sector might feed through into the rest of the economy. With inflation running below target, and expected to do so for a while, there was no pressing need to raise rates straightaway."

Figures released by the office for national statistics yesterday showed that average earnings are growing at an annual rate of 6% compared to 4.5% a year ago.

Unemployment, according to the Labour Force Survey - which uses an internationally-agreed measure for calculating the number of jobless people looking for work - stood at 1,715,000, down 25,000 on the quarter ending in February.

Over the latest quarter, employment rose by 59,000, but this resulted from a 75,000 rise in part-time jobs coupled with a fall of 16,000 in the full-time workforce.

One of Britain's leading economic thinktanks, the National Institute for Economic and Social Research, will announce today that the Budget was likely to lead to a strong pound but keep interest rate increases to a minimum.

"The loosening of fiscal policy keeps the pound higher; this means that pressure for further short-term interest rate rises is less than it might be. We now expect the Bank of England to raise the base rate to 6.25% rather than 6.5% this year," it has reported.

The thinktank also says it believes the inflation target will be comfortably met despite fears that the labour market was overheating.

"The share of the working age population not in work remains above the low level it reached in 1990, recent reductions in claimant unemployment have been concentrated among the long-term unemployed, and the number of vacancies per claimant is more evenly distributed around the country," the institute has concluded.

webTitle: Diving dot.coms can't go to the ball

fields.headline: Diving dot.coms can't go to the ball
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A gala event at the Natural History Museum which set out to be the "Oscars" for Britain's internet industry has been cancelled because of the recent plunge in dot.com share prices.
fields.body:
A gala event at the Natural History Museum which set out to be the "Oscars" for Britain's internet industry has been cancelled because of the recent plunge in dot.com share prices.

Organisers of the Netshake Awards said it was inappropriate to hold the ball when many people, particularly small investors, were "being hammered".

Netshake's founder, Oscar Jenkins, said more than 300 tickets had been sold at £165 each. He pledged that everyone would get a full refund, admitting: "We will take a small hit on it."

Among Netshake's supporters was Tim Jackson, the founder of QXL.com, who had agreed to serve on the judging panel.

Netshake claims it also had a "verbal agreement" from Baltimore Technologies to sponsor the event, although Baltimore yesterday insisted it had merely made an enquiry about providing backing.

The winners were announced at a low-key breakfast yesterday morning.

A prize for oustanding individual achievement went to Mike Lynch, chief executive of Autonomy Corporation. S

tart-up of the year was the houses, cars and jobs search site, Fish4.co.uk; QXL.com was named best dot.com flotation.

Mr Jenkins set up Netshake as a networking organisation for dot.com entrepreneurs. He said he wanted to include "both commercial and non-commercial" players, unlike the rival organisation, First Tuesday.

webTitle: SmithKline acts to ease EC competition worries

fields.headline: SmithKline acts to ease EC competition worries
fields.trailText: SmithKline Beecham has offered to dispose of drugs production for herpes and nausea in an attempt to satisfy competitive concerns over its merger with Glaxo Wellcome.
fields.body:
SmithKline Beecham has offered to dispose of drugs production for herpes and nausea in an attempt to satisfy competitive concerns over its merger with Glaxo Wellcome.

The products, Kytril and Famvir, are in areas where both groups have leading treatments; the suggestion is understood to have been made this week in a submission to the European commission.

The pharmaceuticals companies are optimistic that the proposal will avert the need for a lengthy regulatory investigation. The sale could net up to £600m.

On Tuesday the EC extended the deadline for its "phase one" ruling on the merger by two weeks until May 8. It is thought unlikely to launch a detailed "phase two" inquiry, which could take months longer.

Glaxo Wellcome owns the world's leading treatment for herpes, Zovirax, which had sales of £412m last year. Zovirax has recently gone off-patent but the company is eager to hang on to its successor product, Valtrax. This competes directly with SmithKline's Famvir, which generated revenue of £130m.

Paul Diggle, an analyst at SG Securities, said SmithKline should be able to sell Famvir for a sum equivalent to about two years of sales - although he added: "Obviously, other companies out there will know they're under a bit of pressure to sell."

SmithKline's Kytril - used to prevent vomiting in patients undergoing chemotherapy - had sales of £416m last year. It is a rival to Glaxo's Zofran.

In addition to negotiations with the EC, the two companies are discussing the deal with the United States federal trade commission.

If regulators give the green light the companies will send out full offer documents; extraordinary general meetings to vote on the tie-up are likely to be in June.

There were initially suggestions that the groups might overlap on smoking cessation products. But regulators are believed to be taking the view that Glaxo's prescription pill, Zyban, is in a different market from SmithKline's smokers' chewing gum, Nicorette, and skin patch Nicoderm.

Analysts believe there is still an outside chance that competition authorities could raise concern over aspects of the groups' research pipeline.

Both are preparing an assault on the virtually untapped market for irritable bowel syndrome - a condition which is estimated to affect a fifth of the world's adult population.

However, this is not thought to have caused a problem in negotiations so far, because the chances of both reaching the market are relatively low.

SmithKline and Glaxo are due to announce quarterly results today.

At its annual meeting, scheduled for next week, SmithKline will take a step closer to the deal when chief executive Jan Leschly stands down to make way for Jean-Pierre Garnier, who has been designated chief executive of the combined group.

fields.headline: Differing approaches
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia/Ashkenazy
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia/Ashkenazy
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.body:
The combination of pianist Evgeny Kissin and Vladimir Ashkenazy in Beethoven's Third Piano Concerto could have proved fairly unbeatable. Ashkenazy has recorded the work three times, both as soloist and conductor; the composer is similarly central to the mercurially dazzling Kissin's repertoire. Yet this performance took ages to cohere, and one was, at times, conscious of a colossal disparity in approach.

Ashkenazy's drive towards elegance and restraint sits uneasily with Kissin's fiery intensity. Ashkenazy keeps the voltage down during the long introduction, but the moment Kissin enters - his opening phrases lurching upwards with stroppy hauteur - we're jolted into very different territory. Thereafter, pianist and conductor seem almost in opposition, rendering the tone of the whole uncertain. Kissin's cadenza, dazzlingly flamboyant and weighty, pushes us finally into dark Romanticism.

When we get to the slow movement, it all mercifully comes together. Kissin is wonderfully moody and rhapsodic. Ashkenazy finally broadens the orchestral sound into genuine lushness, with some gorgeous string playing and caressing woodwind solos. The finale, bracing and exhilarating, dazzles from start to finish. Kissin's starry status is such that the audience went wild the moment it was over and wouldn't let him go until he'd played an encore, one of Brahms's Hungarian Dances, flung out with exuberance.

After the interval, Ashkenazy essayed Mahler's Ninth Symphony, another performance that roused mixed feelings. He pitches the emotional level extremely high - this is not so much a painful farewell to life as a desperate clinging to the shattered fragments of a fading existence. The approach is valid, and one that many other conductors have adopted. The problem here, however, is a sameness of tone, an unremitting hysteria. The whole needs more moments of respite and lyricism if its full tragic stature is to be felt.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Keep it in the family
fields.standfirst:
Boss Hog
LA2, London
***
fields.trailText:
Boss Hog
LA2, London
***
fields.body:
The collaboration of Jon Spencer, he of the Blues Explosion and Elvis fixation, and wife Cristina Martinez, with her Courtney Love screaming and a propensity for shedding her clothes, is an odd but strong one. Ten years after their debut, Cold Hands, Boss Hog have made their best album yet, the short but shimmering Whiteout. Diverse, with everything from gospel to goth to 60s garage, it's the band's most polished, poppy performance.

But it's still all about attitude. Martinez sashays on to the stage, a New York princess in low-slung leather trousers. She looks like Alanis Morrisette's evil twin sister as she rips into Strawberry, grinning dementedly and lurching towards the crowd. From the sweetness of Nursery Rhyme to the pleading pop of Fear For You, Martinez purrs, struts and coos.

Spencer seems more than happy to let his wife take the glory, too busy orchestrating the funky punk-blues fusion to look up from his guitar. Which is a shame, because it's when the couple share vocal duties that Boss Hog's songs really come alive. Chocolate is a sleazy doublehander, as Martinez sings about "my baby" and Spencer fixates on a "dirty movie", while during Jaguar they yearn to "pull out the big guns, baby". Together they are the Richard and Judy of cool. The rest of the band, especially new boy Mark Boyce on the Hammond organ and Hollis Queens on drums, add weight and coherence to the Boss Hog sound, but it's the Spencer household that are true stars.

The intensity doesn't let up until Martinez announces "We're taking a lil' break right now," and the band leave the stage, returning moments later to play Whiteout, a spiralling gospel tinged epic that manages to be catchy and uplifting without losing the grubbiness that Spencer does so well.

webTitle: Judge lifts lid on work tribunals

fields.headline: Judge lifts lid on work tribunals
fields.standfirst: Court victory for whistleblowers
fields.trailText: A high court judge yesterday lifted the veil of government secrecy from 100,000 unfair dismissal, sex and race discrimination and other tribunal claims brought by employees each year.
fields.body:
A high court judge yesterday lifted the veil of government secrecy from 100,000 unfair dismissal, sex and race discrimination and other tribunal claims brought by employees each year.

Mr Justice Jackson ruled that full details of claims filed at employment tribunals should be open to inspection. "As a matter of public policy, litigation should be conducted under public gaze and scrutiny," he said.

The judge held that the central office of the employment tribunals acted unlawfully in allowing access only to the names of the parties and a bare description of claims.

He said parliament had laid down in the Employment Tribunals Act that the public had the right to inspect particulars of cases.

The ruling, on the day before the government's much-criticised freedom of information bill has its second reading in the House of Lords, is a victory for the whistleblowers' charity Public Concern at Work.

The charity wanted details of claims brought by whistleblowers alleging victimisation, so it could monitor how the Public Interest Disclosure Act was working.

The act, which came into force last summer, protects whistleblowers against sacking and allows them to bring victimisation claims.

Public Concern at Work challenged the employment tribunal service's refusal to give it the information.

In the high court the tribunal service, represented by government lawyers, argued that publicity would hinder Acas, the advisory, conciliation and arbitration service, in trying to settle cases before they reached the tribunal.

The service also claimed it would be administratively difficult to provide the details.

webTitle: Derivatives descend to the common man

fields.headline: Derivatives descend to the common man
fields.trailText: There was a time, not too long ago, when financial derivatives were considered to be just too dangerous for ordinary members of the investing public.
fields.body:
There was a time, not too long ago, when financial derivatives were considered to be just too dangerous for ordinary members of the investing public.

Stockbrokers would have to get their private clients to fill in special 10-page forms if they wanted to play the futures and options game. The accompanying warnings went on and on about the heightened risks associated with leveraged investment.

Punters really did risk losing all their money, and they had to be aware of this - and there were always real life examples, such as Nick Leeson breaking Barings, if anyone questioned this.

Thankfully, the world has moved on. Derivatives themselves, in their many shapes and forms, have become much more sophisticated. In truth, most investors do not realise that they are actually buying them when they make what are assumed to be low risk investment decisions.

The latest synthetic stock market flavour was launched by Barclays yesterday, using a separate company named iShares.

Under the marketing slogan, "The way you invest now. Only Better", the first so-called "exchange traded" fund in Britain is called iFTSE 100.

One iShares director, John Demaine, was moved to declare, no less, that this "marks the beginning of a change in the investment landscape in the UK".

Like a regular tracker fund, the iFTSE 100 will give holders exposure to the Top 100 index. But unlike the position with unit trusts, investors will be able to deal in the paper as if it were a regular share, dealing at any time the market is open through their regular stockbroker.

Also, unlike an investment trust, this new vehicle should not trade at a substantial discount to the value of the underlying assets.

Importantly, investors using iShares will not be liable to stamp duty, annual management charges will be pitched at just 0.35% and the paper will be eligible for inclusion in an ISA. Initially, shares in iFTSE 100 will be priced at £10.

Another dozen iShares are promised over the next year or so.

Barclays Global Investors, the high street bank's fund management arm which specialises in so-called passive management and runs about £500bn of investors' money, already has a series of exchange traded funds called iUnits in Canada, and its experience there has encouraged plans to launch 47 new iShares in the United States some time later this year.

The traded fund concept is already big in the US, attracting around $35bn of investors money since they first appeared in 1993.

fields.headline: A be-bop ceilidh
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Now!
Traverse Theatre/Henry's Cellar Bar, Edinburgh
****
fields.trailText:
Jazz Now!
Traverse Theatre/Henry's Cellar Bar, Edinburgh
****
fields.body:
As a musical movement, Scottish jazz has been building since the preternaturally gifted 16-year-old saxophonist Tommy Smith strolled out of Edinburgh's housing schemes onto the world stage in the 80s. Thankfully, the snapshot offered at Jazz Now! was far removed from the creaky official Edinburgh Jazz Festival, embracing everything from the celtic bodhran to drum'n'bass.

At the end of last year, a band called AAB won the Radio 3 jazz album of 1999 with Cold Fusion. This was a bit of a shock, as they had never played London. While no one was looking, a groundswell of young Scots had become a serious enclave that now had its own Edinburgh-based label Caber Records, whose latest release, launched during Jazz Now!, is Nemesis from the Paul Harrison Trio. Pianist Harrison's urgent compositions jilted an unsuspecting Traverse audience and introduced an explosive new talent in drummer Paddy Flaherty, whose breakneck rhythmic invention drove the band to exultant heights.

AAB were a startling pointer to a new club-friendly jazz sound. The trio moved from the jumping staccato Repetitious Song to a Zeppelinesque trip-hammer epic, Kashmir, deconstructed into white noise and jagged saxophone permutations. In contrast, a new acoustic duo, guitarist Don Patterson and pianist Dave Milligan, wound hypnotic improvisational exchanges around stripped-down folk reels and cool laments.

Sporting kilts, John Rae's Celtic Feet moulded jazz breaks and the swirl of traditional dance into a playful if patchy banter between ceilidh and be-bop. The consistently brilliant pianist Brian Kellock, along with drummer Rae and the flowing Brazilian bassist Mario Caribe (now based in west Calder), locked the rhythms in place as Simon Thoumire span out intricate improvisations from, of all things, a tiny, buttoned concertina. A Scottish-Brazilian improvisation on a Jimmy Shand theme? Now I've heard everything.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Wall Street net trading chief takes $45m bath

fields.headline: Wall Street net trading chief takes $45m bath
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Baruch Israel Hertz learned the hard way that practising what you preach has its down side. The chief executive of a US online trading company was forced to liquidate almost half his stake in the company this week after facing margin calls of $45m (£28.4m).
fields.body:
Baruch Israel Hertz learned the hard way that practising what you preach has its down side. The chief executive of a US online trading company was forced to liquidate almost half his stake in the company this week after facing margin calls of $45m (£28.4m).

Mr Hertz, the head of Track Data, a financial information and trading firm, stacked up the losses during last week's 25% decline in Nasdaq. The margin calls from four different brokerage firms are understood to add up to one of the biggest made for an individual on Wall Street.

Track Data has been one of the most aggressive advertisers for online trading in recent years. Mr Hertz himself appears on the company website to push "myTrack", its online trading service, by proclaiming: "You don't have to be a pro to trade like one."

Mr Hertz was unavailable for comment yesterday but Rafi Reguer, the company's marketing director, said that the company had not been involved in the margin calls.

The trading in "several large companies" was carried out in Mr Hertz's own account, he said. "The debt is entirely his own, and not an obligation of Track Data."

webTitle: Now it's the great wireless internet auction

fields.headline: Now it's the great wireless internet auction
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The government's highly lucrative carve-up of Britain's airwaves moved to a new level yesterday as it announced plans to auction spectrum that allows the delivery of high-speed internet access without a phone line.
fields.body:
The government's highly lucrative carve-up of Britain's airwaves moved to a new level yesterday as it announced plans to auction spectrum that allows the delivery of high-speed internet access without a phone line.

The auction in September is expected to raise about £2bn for the Treasury's coffers but could raise much more. This will be in addition to the income from the present sale of third generation mobile phone licences, which has now passed £22bn.

Both UK and international telecom operators are said to be interested in the latest sale of spectrum to deliver fast internet and multimedia access by wireless links rather than telephone lines. Operators will be able to bypass both BT and the cable networks to provide such services to the small and medium-sized businesses. Colt, Energis, Cable & Wireless, MCI WorldCom are understood to be among those interested.

Janice Hughes, managing director of Spectrum Strategy Consultants, said of the government's latest auction: "Clearly it's going to be worth several billion."

She pointed to the government's auction of third generation spectrum which raised "much more than they thought".

The government is expected to auction up to 60 licences covering 20 regions for transmission in the 28GHz spectrum. The licences will last for 10 years,

A further auction of spectrum offering even higher speed broadband services at 40GHz, which would enable television and video conferencing on computers, may also be auctioned this year.

Patricia Hewitt, the minister for e-commerce, said that she wanted the new services to be developed as quickly as possible. Britain is already behind Switzerland, Finland, Portugal, Spain, Ireland and Germany, which have already auctioned off their licences for broadband wireless communications.

Switzerland's auction of about 13 licences last month is understood to have raised about £150m.

News of the latest spectrum auction came as the telecommunications watchdog, Oftel, warned that broadband services must be competitively priced.

David Edmonds, director general of telecommunications, said that prices were so far satisfactory in comparison with other European countries but that availability of broadband services in the UK needed to improved.

BT's improved network, which is being upgraded to provide digital services such as high speed internet access and video on demand, will be opened up to competitors by 2001.

Separately, the government's auction of the five licences for third generation mobile phone services continued. This technology will enable services such as video conferencing on mobile phones.

The bids totalled £22.2bn yesterday, with Vodafone AirTouch and British Telecommunications battling it out for licence B.

Vodafone held off BT with a high offer of £5.96bn. Canada's TIW offered £4.38bn for licence A, France Telecom-backed NTL Mobile offered £3.97bn for licence D. BT and Orange bid £3.94bn for licences D and E respectively.

The auction resumes on Tuesday.

Likely contenders

Orange, Cable & Wireless and Energis are among the suspects expected to enter the auction for wireless broadband communications.

Their deep pockets are expected to pitch them against other telcos and internet providers such as Broadnet , Winstar , Atlantic Telecom , Freeserve , Formus , Colt and MCI WorldCom , who are likely to bid for the right to beam high-speed internet and video signals into small and medium sized businesses across the country.

Some of the likely bidders refusedto discuss their plans yesterday - fearful of prejudicing their chance of winning one of the licences in September's auction.

The attraction for ISPs is that they could cut net access charges by bypassing both BT and cable nets.

Services using the new spectrum are also likely to be faster than those using BT's ADSL format.

webTitle: I'd like to leave but don't want to let anyone down

fields.headline: I'd like to leave but don't want to let anyone down
fields.standfirst: What to do when you've just started a new job and you're offered more money to work elsewhere
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I got a Saturday job through my best mate (her mum manages the shop) and I started about five weeks ago. The only trouble is it's crap pay and I really want to get some experience working in a theatre. I don't want to let my mate's mum down and land her in a mess so I'm trying to stay on as long as possible. I have been offered a job at a chemist and it's closer with a lot better pay, although it doesn't start until September. Shall I take it and give my employer notice or shall I stay on until I've worked there long enough? and how long would you say is long enough to stay?

The solution

You need to explain to your mate's mum that you have been offered a job with better pay that is nearer to your home. No reasonable person would expect you to turn this offer down just out of loyalty because your boss happens to be someone you know. However, you do need to acknowledge the break that this woman gave you - getting your first job is the first step on the working ladder and you should always be grateful to her for helping you when you needed it.

But, you are able to give her five months notice, which is more than enough for her to be able to find your replacement. I think that giving her such long notice is a great way of showing your appreciation to her and I'm sure that she will neither have a problem with your leaving nor have any difficulty recruiting someone else by September.

As far as your dream of working in the theatre goes, there may be one or two openings in areas such as ushering or selling programmes, but it might be a good idea to try and get some unpaid experience just to give you some insight into the workings of a theatre production. Write to your local theatres and offer to help out, even if it's just making the tea or being a runner. If they say no, wait a decent interval then write again. Good luck.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Tesco takes aim at Barclays ATMs

fields.headline: Tesco takes aim at Barclays ATMs
fields.trailText: Tesco banished Barclays cash machines from 74 of its supermarkets yesterday as it launched an attack against the bank's controversial plan to charge a £1 disloyalty fee to withdraw money.
fields.body:
Tesco banished Barclays cash machines from 74 of its supermarkets yesterday as it launched an attack against the bank's controversial plan to charge a £1 disloyalty fee to withdraw money.

Andrew Higginson, Tesco's finance director, also issued a warning to other banks with cash machines in its stores, particularly HSBC and Abbey National, that if they introduced punitive charges they would receive similar treatment. The cash machine sites are rented by the banks from the store. Not all Barclays machines came up for tender in this tranche.

The supermarket's publicity seeking move was announced at a time which will maximise the negative public image of Barclays, already dogged by cash machine charging, branch closures and executives' pay.

"It's a double whammy. The banks roll out ATMS as one of the excuses for closing branches and then charge for withdrawing cash," said Mr Higginson. As a result of the recent controversy about the charges for cash machines withdrawals, Mr Higginson said customers were already "voting with their plastic".

Demand for cash back at the checkout had increased 28% and Mr Higginson said the store was working with the bank to increase the maximum cashback to £100 from £50.

Barclays, which will retain 125 cash machines in Tesco stores, said Tesco had not expressed any concerns about the charging policy, saying it had not tendered enough for the sites.

With its fees due to be introduced next year, Barclays is yet to set the definite level of any "surcharge" it levies for its rivals' customers using its machines, but has said a level of £1 is a "stake in the ground".

Lloyds TSB has set its level at 50p. The surcharges are set to replace disloyalty fees, which had previously been charged by some members of the Link cash machine network.

Tesco said it would install its own Tesco Personal Finance machines in the holes left by Barclays machines.

fields.headline: Poise and subtlety
fields.standfirst:
RPO/Gatti/Kempf
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
RPO/Gatti/Kempf
Barbican Hall, London
****
fields.body:
It's a cliche to talk of young artists bringing youthful vision to a performance, but there is something special, a raw vitality, in young pianist Freddy Kempf's playing. This performance of Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto, part of the RPO's Beethoven-Stravinsky series, didn't find him at his peak technically, but each phrase was compulsive listening.

Beneath the sublimely enjoyable surface of the Fourth Concerto, there's a great deal for a pianist to get stuck into. Kempf was keen to bring the inner voices to our attention; occasionally he made them so prominent that the outer semiquaver lines were too soft. Yet his dancing melodic lines and throwaway scales were a delight. Daniele Gatti, still a dominant force rather than just a cue-giver, drew a soft bloom from the string section for their first entry. A palpable sense of tension built up at the end of the second movement; in the closing Rondo the violas made their two-part melody into a moment of glory.

Sharing Beethoven's ambitious scope and breadth of vision if nothing else, Stravinsky made him a vibrant companion on the programme. However, the Coriolan Overture was too dark and the concerto too unconventional to represent the kind of classicism to which Stravinsky held up a cracked mirror in his Symphony in C.

In this work it is the rhythm and a single melodic gesture that prove irrepressible. Gatti approached the work with poise and subtlety, shaping each successive textural episode to form part of a satisfying whole.

Stravinsky's Circus Polka rounded off the programme. Commissioned by the choreographer George Balanchine, it was first played by a circus band to accompany a ballet of 50 elephants "dancing" alongside Balanchine's wife. Following a broadcast of the orchestral arrangement, Stravinsky claimed that one of these elephants sent him a congratulatory telegram. All the Barbican audience could do was applaud.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

Commissioned by the choreographer George Balanchine, it was first played by a circus band to accompany a ballet of 50 elephants "dancing" alongside Balanchine's wife. Following a broadcast of the orchestral arrangement, Stravinsky claimed that one of these elephants sent him a congratulatory telegram. All the Barbican audience could do was applaud. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Anelka alarm bells ringing for United

fields.headline: Anelka alarm bells ringing for United
fields.standfirst: Ferguson's men must cope with Frenchman's injection of Real pace
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson does not have the look of a man who suffers from nightmares. Yet if there is one image calculated to give the manager of Manchester United a restless sleep it is surely a recollection of Nicolas Anelka's ability to go by Jaap Stam like a passing breeze.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson does not have the look of a man who suffers from nightmares. Yet if there is one image calculated to give the manager of Manchester United a restless sleep it is surely a recollection of Nicolas Anelka's ability to go by Jaap Stam like a passing breeze.

Tonight Anelka, back in favour after his walkout at the Bernabeu, will haunt United's attempt to reach the semi- finals of the Champions League at the expense of Real Madrid.

In theory a scoreless first leg should favour United's chances of winning the tie at Old Trafford, but with away goals counting double in the event of a draw Real will need to find the net only once to begin to loosen United's hold on the trophy.

Vicente del Bosque, Real's coach, is well aware of the potential threat that Anelka's speed poses to United's central defenders, who were never happy when they encountered the young French striker in Arsenal's colours. Lack of acceleration near goal from Raul and Fernando Morientes blunted Real's attack at the Bernabeu and, though Anelka is expected to start tonight's game on the bench, Del Bosque intends bringing him on at some stage.

"Anelka will play," the Real coach confirmed yesterday, "but I don't know when: maybe the middle, the beginning or the end. He has now been back in the squad for 15 days after going through an awkward stage like all players do."

Ferguson said: "We know enough about Anelka to be aware of him but Real have a number of talented strikers." They also have Steve McManaman, who might have won the first match for Real had it not been for the alertness and agility of Mark Bosnich, the United goalkeeper.

Bosnich, suffering from a stomach strain, was taken off during United's 4-0 victory over Sunderland and was yesterday declared by Ferguson to be his one big doubt. Then again Ryan Giggs appeared in Madrid after similar managerial misgivings, so perhaps Bosnich will play after all.

Ferguson watched Real Madrid's 1-0 win away to Real Zaragoza at the weekend on television and saw Anelka brought down by the Zaragoza goalkeeper to earn the late penalty from which Raul scored his 100th league goal for the club. It was Real's fifth clean sheet in six matches and an indication that United can ill afford to squander the sort of opportunities spurned by Andy Cole at the Bernabeu.

"I realise that Real have conceded very few goals in recent games," said Ferguson, "but if we do create chances then hopefully we can take them." Del Bosque has marked down Giggs and David Beckham as United's principal threats. "Most of their goals come from the wings," he noted.

It promises to be a tricky evening for the holders, who still have not shaken off the habit of conceding early goals at home. Two seasons ago, at a similar stage of the Champions League, United brought a 0-0 draw back from Monaco, who then proceeded to go through on an away goal after David Trezeguet gave them an early lead at Old Trafford.

Having scored 19 times in their last four Premiership fixtures, a run which has set them up to complete their sixth championship in eight seasons over Easter, it is hard to envisage Ferguson's side failing to find the net tonight. Giggs and Beckham are in especially good form and the influence in midfield of Roy Keane and Paul Scholes should be equally crucial.

"We're well used to having some hair-raising experiences at this place," Ferguson reflected. "If we score first I'll be really delighted but even a 5-4 win would not have me jumping off Barton Bridge."

Yet a timely and effective appearance by Anelka might conceivably leave United's European bridges burning. At least the fact that the referee, Italy's Pierluigi Collina, was in charge of last season's final is a happy omen for the holders.

 Bayern Munich will be without their playmaker and captain Stefan Effenberg as well as the full-back Bixente Lizarazu, both injured, when they meet Porto tonight in their quarter-final second leg after drawing 1-1 in Portugal.

Manchester United (probable; 4-4-2): Bosnich; G Neville, Berg, Stam, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Cole, Yorke.

Real Madrid (probable; 4-3-1-2): Casillas; Salgado, Ivan Campo, Karanka, Roberto Carlos; McManaman, Helguera, Redondo, Savio; Morientes, Raul.

Referee : P Collina (Italy).

fields.headline: 100 Premier players earn over £1m each
fields.trailText: The stock market may be creaking but the boom for England's leading players shows no sign of bottoming out. A survey published yesterday reveals that the average Premiership wage is £409,000 a year. About 100 players earn more than £1m.
fields.body:
The stock market may be creaking but the boom for England's leading players shows no sign of bottoming out. A survey published yesterday reveals that the average Premiership wage is £409,000 a year. About 100 players earn more than £1m.

The figures, which apply to players over 20, show that 36% of top-flight footballers take home more than £500,000 a year. That means they earn more in a month - before sponsorship deals and endorsements - than the average Third Division player does in a year (£37,000).

The dramatic disparity in pay reflects the growing financial gap between the best and the rest. The First Division average wage is £128,000, the Second Division £52,000. But even so many clubs are overstretching themselves.

"Because of the disparity in income, in trying to keep pace or hang on to the top clubs' coat-tails, there have been an increasing number of Football League clubs battling to survive," said Gordon Taylor, chief executive of the Professional Footballers' Association which carried out the survey in conjunction with the Independent.

Galatasaray's players will wear black armbands during the second leg of their Uefa Cup semi-final at Leeds tomorrow as a mark of respect to the two Leeds fans stabbed to death in Istanbul.

Sam Hammam has completed the sale of his remaining shares in Wimbledon to the club's Norwegian owner Bjorn Gjelsten.

 Port Vale's slim hopes of avoiding relegation from the First Division were dashed last night by two goals from David Kelly, his second in the last minute giving Tranmere a 2-1 home win. David Healy, a striker on loan from Manchester United who is in the Northern Ireland squad to play Hungary at Windor Park a week today, had put Vale ahead on 41 minutes before Kelly equalised on the hour.

webTitle: Ganguly gets his wobbly dobbers working

fields.headline: Ganguly gets his wobbly dobbers working
fields.standfirst: Durham 53-8 Lancashire 55-1 Lancashire won by nine wickets
fields.trailText: Lancashire did not sign Sourav Ganguly for his ability to bowl tight two-over spells in rain-ruined matches, but the Bengali's wobbly medium pace put them back on course for the quarter-finals yesterday.
fields.body:
Lancashire did not sign Sourav Ganguly for his ability to bowl tight two-over spells in rain-ruined matches, but the Bengali's wobbly medium pace put them back on course for the quarter-finals yesterday.

It had been a hugely frustrating day for a sparse but stoical crowd as it took the umpires and captains five inspections to decide that the wet patches on the square that had prevented any play could be covered by matting.

There was then a further hour's delay before they deigned to start a 10-over slog, although there was little smiting in the Durham innings. Peter Martin had already sent back the openers, including their new Australian Simon Katich who has now managed three runs in as many knocks, when Ganguly took over.

The Indian batsman had impressed with the ball rather than the bat in his previous two appearances since arriving in Manchester last week, claiming three for 31 in Sunday's defeat in Yorkshire but scoring only five to go with Saturday's duck.

Here he took three for seven as Durham struggled even to bat out their 10 overs, then stroked an unbeaten 22 to help Lancashire cruise to victory with 19 balls - almost a third of their innings - to spare.

The gold award, with its prize of £300, is unlikely to take pride of place in Ganguly's honours collection, which includes a Mercedes, but the flicked six and driven four with which he completed the victory hinted at treats to come at Old Trafford. Lancashire now probably need only one more win to advance.

 Worcestershire stayed top of the Midlands Division after rain at New Road presented them with their second no- result point in three games. The holders Gloucestershire had raced to 57 for one in only 10 overs before the decisive deluge.

 With no play possible against Northamptonshire at Edgbaston , Warwickshire's second abandoned match in three, the home captain Neil Smith fears his side will be eliminated from the Midlands Division by rain. "Do we really need to start the season so early?" he said. Bad weather in South Africa also forced Warwickshire home early from their pre-season tour.

webTitle: Fans all shook up as the king comes to town

fields.headline: Fans all shook up as the king comes to town
fields.standfirst: Warne frenzy hits Hampshire as spin wizard arrives for county debut
fields.trailText: It was the biggest media scramble the Hampshire scorer Vic Isaacs had seen in Southampton since Kevin Keegan took up residence at the Dell.
fields.body:
It was the biggest media scramble the Hampshire scorer Vic Isaacs had seen in Southampton since Kevin Keegan took up residence at the Dell.

Shane Warne, the finest twirler of them all, the most prolific Australian Test wicket-taker and the fourth best cricketer of the past century in Wisden's estimation, makes his debut for Hampshire at Chelmsford today.

After landing at Heathrow early yesterday he was driven through pouring rain to the County Ground where, rather nervously, he met his new team-mates. He was looking forward to getting to know them better over a few quiet beers in the evening.

For now, though, at around lunchtime, he was being presented to the media by a club chairman exuding all the beaming jollity of a gardener who had just grown the world's biggest marrow and was keen to put it on show. What a cracking signing, one more than fit to rank with the names of Barry Richards, Gordon Greenidge and Malcolm Marshall who had preceded him as overseas players at Hampshire.

The response in the county since it was revealed that the most charismatic cricketer of his generation was coming has been overwhelming. Membership has risen by 10% and is sure to go up more now that he has actually arrived. Isaacs is itching to get a digital photograph for the club's website.

On the day Hampshire announced the signing, hits on the website went up tenfold. It was an astounding catch as Warne, plagued by injuries to his right shoulder and middle finger, had long resisted the lure of a season around the shires.

But Robin Smith, the Hampshire captain, approached him during the World Cup last summer and floated the idea of him joining the club. It was, Smith said, forward-looking, with a new ground for 2001, great facilities and a talented young side. But above all, he went on, there existed a team spirit the likes of which he had not experienced during his time at Hampshire.

It was the clincher. Warne loves his cricket but he does so in a rounded way, valuing the friendships he makes so that in 10 years' time, as he puts it, it will be these, rather than wickets taken or runs scored, that they talk about over the barbie.

"It appealed to me," he said, "because the sides I've been involved with, Victoria and Australia, have had wonderful team spirit. The bottom line is that we have enjoyed it and, if you do that, when the tight situations come along you can generally get through them."

Warne confessed that he had always had a hankering to play county cricket and did not subscribe to the view that the first-class game in Britain is not up to scratch. There are things to be learned, even for an old hand, about bowling in different conditions.

"You never stop learning. I don't think I've played too many games in April with the cold and a bit of drizzle. It might be a bit difficult to bowl some quality leg-breaks to start, but we'll be trying."

He is looking forward to helping Hampshire's younger players, working not only with the first team but with the second team and development squads. The kids must be slavering at the prospect.

So too ought Chris Schofield, the young Lancashire leg-spinner now on contract to England. For where wrist-spinning is concerned Warne, rather than keep the mysteries to himself, is an evangelist.

It gives him a buzz to spread the word, and on May 24 Hampshire play Lancashire in the County Championship. It is an unmissable opportunity and the England coach Duncan Fletcher must insist that Schofield plays.

"I've only seen him in the nets," Warne said of Schofield, "but he looks like he's got all the toys. But it's all about knowing when and why to bowl them, about setting the batsman up for the flipper or wrong 'un.

"You don't just bowl them because you haven't used it for a couple of overs. He's young, with a big future, but it's up to him: how hard he wants to work, how he performs under pressure and how well he gets to know himself. That's the key. You have to know what you need to perform."

 The Australian paceman Glenn McGrath, Warne's regular partner in crime, flew into England yesterday and is expected to make his debut for Worcestershire against Somerset in Taunton on Friday.

webTitle: Bishop calls the shots as Sussex fizzle in the drizzle

fields.headline: Bishop calls the shots as Sussex fizzle in the drizzle
fields.standfirst: Sussex 97 Surrey 61-1 Surrey won by 35 runs on D/L method
fields.trailText: The rapturous applause, which was only vaguely sarcastic, was due reward for a sweep shot by the Sussex seamer Mark Robinson, the only chap on the circuit who could profitably take batting lessons from Bugs Bunny.
fields.body:
The rapturous applause, which was only vaguely sarcastic, was due reward for a sweep shot by the Sussex seamer Mark Robinson, the only chap on the circuit who could profitably take batting lessons from Bugs Bunny.

On another rotten day for the willow-wielders, that was the high point for the hosts as Surrey strolled to a victory as inevitable as it was assured.

Given that both sides were taking up the cudgels for the first time this season, rustiness was predictably rampant. But it was hardly an excuse for the litany of errors that followed.

As Sussex staggered towards their lowest B&H score for 22 years, the accuracy of foot-shooting was relentless. Richard Montgomerie and Nick Wilton fell shouldering arms, Chris Adams biffed a catch to extra-cover to succumb for a duck, and Robinson himself was run out after being called for a second that existed solely in James Kirtley's imagination, ending the final and most prolonged stand of the innings.

Kinder, perhaps, to credit the bowlers, of whom Ian Bishop, the man of the match, and Jason Ratcliffe, purveyor of dandy dobbers, inflicted most of the damage.

After a minute's silence in memory of Peter Eaton, who died in February after tending the square here for 36 devoted years, Adam Hollioake had earlier put Sussex in. Neither Martin Bicknell nor Alex Tudor found a consistent line but when Bishop began surging down the hill the contest changed tack abruptly, nine wickets toppling inside 19 overs.

Blond, brisk and bullish, Bishop defrocked Adams then bowled Bas Zuiderent with a peach that darted away off the pitch. Tudor returned to trap Montgomerie and Tony Cottey, and Robin Martin-Jenkins greeted Ratcliffe with a smear that would have turned his father's face a darker shade of crimson.

Alistair Brown commenced Surrey's meagre run-chase with some typically lusty lashes, and Mark Butcher and Alec Stewart were moving serenely home when drizzle begat deluge. So whose bright idea was it to start the term before Easter, eh?

 A spectacular day for the Kent all-rounder Mark Ealham ended in despair when he was bowled off the last ball of the match against Essex at Canterbury, handing the visitors a thrilling two-run victory. Having followed up a four-wicket haul with a hard-hitting 61 scored at more than a run a ball, Ealham was bowled by Mark Ilott needing to score three from the final delivery.

fields.headline: Man Utd 2 Real Madrid 3
fields.trailText:
Man Utd: Van Der Gouw, G. Neville, Stam, Berg, Irwin, Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs, Yorke, Cole. Subs: Culkin, Butt, Sheringham, P. Neville, Cruyff, Solskjaer, Silvestre.
Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Karanka, Campo, Carlos, McManaman, Redondo, Helguera, Savio, Raul, Morientes. Subs: Illgner, Dorado, Anelka, Baljic, Geremi, Karembeu, Julio Cesar.
Referee: Perluigi Collina (Italy)
fields.body:
Man Utd: Van Der Gouw, G. Neville, Stam, Berg, Irwin, Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs, Yorke, Cole. Subs: Culkin, Butt, Sheringham, P. Neville, Cruyff, Solskjaer, Silvestre.
Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Karanka, Campo, Carlos, McManaman, Redondo, Helguera, Savio, Raul, Morientes. Subs: Illgner, Dorado, Anelka, Baljic, Geremi, Karembeu, Julio Cesar.
Referee: Perluigi Collina (Italy)

1st minute Real kick off. United quickly win possession and look to set to attack from the off.
2 Whatever United's intentions, the first chance of the match falls to Real. A quick break finds Roberto Carlos, who started the game in midfield, in space on the left wing. His low cross is hit early, curls beyond the entire United defence, but misses the Madrid forwards too.
3 A direct run from Ryan Giggs is brought to an end by Ivan Helguera at the expense of a corner. The resulting kick from David Beckham comes to nothing.
5 Again United break down the left, the ball moving from Andy Cole to Ryan Giggs whose cross is cleared unconditionally by Aitor Karanka.
6 Swift interplay between Raul and Fernando Morientes forces Gary Neville into a sliding tackle in the box. Fortunately for the United man, it is a clean one.
9 The ball is stuck in the midfield third and shows no sign on leaving. Both sides seem unable to unpick the opposing defence just yet.
12 Gary Neville misses a header from an Ivan Campo long ball. The ball falls to Roberto Carlos who rockets off toward the United area. His pass finds Morientes, but the striker get the ball caught under his feet and his tame shot falls straight into Raimond van der Gouw's arms.
15 Another run from Ryan Giggs, this time with a cross attached. He cuts the ball back from just in front of the touchline, but Dwight Yorke gets his angles wrong and his header flashes wide.
16 Roberto Carlos pops up in the United area seizing on a loose ball from Neville. Carlos almost nutmegs van der Gouw, but the veteran Dutchman manages to dive over the ball before the Brazilian has a chance to strike.
19 Another cross from the United left, this time from Denis Irwin, almost finds Paul Scholes in the box.
20 GOAL! Man Utd 0 - 1 Real Madrid Referee Collina plays an advantage and allows McManaman to slip the ball to Helguera. The full back plays a quick cross from the right which looks dangerous. Roy Keane goes to intercept the ball before the near post but only succeeds in putting the ball through his own net. An unfortunate way to concede an away goal.
23 Another Giggs cross comes in, but Dwight Yorke fails to make anything out of it.
25 Giggs finds Scholes whose sly pass picks out David Beckham on the left-hand side of the box. Beckham advances on Iker Casillas who palms away his left-foot shot.
26 Another cross from Giggs creates a chance that is spurned by Yorke, whose knockdown this time misses Andy Cole by some 10 yards.
29 A flick from Cole on the edge of the box finds a typically marauding Keane. He controls the ball well and shoots, but Casillas stands up well. United may be down, but at least they are finding some penetration at last.
32 A lunging tackle from Keane on Savio gives away a free kick on the edge of the box. A certain thick-legged Brazilian takes it, but his characteristically rocket-powered shot scuds wide.
33 A chain of one-touch passing brings United to the edge of the Real area. Irwin gives the ball to Yorke and continues into the box. Yorke looks to play the one-two but his touch lets him down once more and the pass runs straight to Casillas.
36 Ryan Giggs is on fire. For about the fourth time in this first half he gives the run around to more than one Real defender. On this occasion he wins a corner, but the Welshman looks United's best bet of creating a real opening.
37 United win another corner, delivered by Beckham. Yorke meets it at the far post and his looping header eludes Casillas. The ball comes to Cole but he can only head over the bar.
42 United almost hand Real another goal. A cross from Michel Salgado whips across the box and Jaap Stam fails to clear. His toepoke ends up at the feet of Morinetes but he blazes over.
46 A minute into stoppage time and Real break. Raul tears at the heart of the United defence before playing in McManaman. His cross deflects off Stam and misses the bar by inches.
47 Half time.

Second half
45 United substitution: Silvestre for Irwin. United kick off. 46 Two successive United crosses force first a saving header from Roberto Carlos and then a desperate punch from Casillas. Both Yorke and Cole are yet to get a strike on goal.
47 GOAL! Man Utd 0 - 2 Real Madrid United are punished on the break barely three minutes into the second half. United are busy banging the ball into the Real box when McManaman intercepts. He races off into the United half leaving half the home team stranded. The former Liverpool man's left-foot pass finds Raul advancing on the right. He drags Silvestre to the edge of the box, cuts inside him and fires an unstoppable shot inside the post for his eigth Champions League goal of the season.
50 Now in a potentially desperate position, United must score. Giggs duly tears forward and finds Cole in the box. His deft touch sets up Keane for United's clearest chance of the game. Keane leans back and fires over. It is not his day.
52 GOAL! Man Utd 0 - 3 Real Madrid Another goal on the break but this time United cannot really blame themselves. A phenomenal piece of skill from Fernando Redondo makes the whole thing possible, playing the ball around Henning Berg with a back heel and then advancing past the flummoxed Norwegian. It is then a simple case of slotting the ball across the box and finding the waiting Raul for the finish. The Argentinian duly does so, to the exhiliration of his teammates. United are in real trouble now.
60 Paul Scholes is booked for a foul. He will miss United's next European match.
62 Man Utd substitution: Sheringham and Solskjaer for Berg and Cole. Real Madrid substitution: Geremi for Savio. United's saviours last summer take their place on the field. The United crowd is not too impressed, booing the withdrawal of Andy Cole.
65 GOAL! Man Utd 1 - 3 Real Madrid David Beckham has his say. The United winger pops up on the edge of the box and with a sleight of feet for which he is not renowned, jinks past two Real defenders and blasts an unstoppable shot into the roof of the net.
68 United have built up a head of steam following the goal, and a sweeping forward move almost lets Ole Solskjaer in on goal. Unfortunately for the Norwegian he tumbles over the ball seconds after controlling it immaculately.
71 Real Madrid substitution: Anelka for Morientes. Good evening M Anelka.
76 The clock continues to count down and United continue to throw everything at Real without much return. The closest United have come to adding to their score is a long-range drive from Paul Scholes which bobbles wide of Casillas' post.
80 A great save from Casillas denies Solskjaer from close range. The 18-year-old keeper has played beyond his years.
83 Solskjaer strikes again. A through ball from Keane give the Norwegian time to turn on the edge of the box, but his shot curls past the post.
85 United remain camped around the Real area. But the Spanish defence refuses to budge, mopping up Beckham crosses as if they faced them every week.
87 GOAL! Man Utd 2 - 3 Real Madrid With only three minutes remaining, McManaman bundles over Keane in the box. Penalty. Paul Scholes steps up and slams it home.
93 Full time. A great game, on a terribly disappointing night for United. Steve McManaman seems pleased though.

Barcelona 5 Rivaldo 24 99pen, Figo 45, Dani 83, Kluivert 104 Chelsea 1 Flo 60
Barcelona win 6-4 on agg after extra-time
fields.trailText: Chelsea heroically lost the numbers game last night as the real Barcelona finally stood up to be counted. Gianluca Vialli's side, outclassed and largely outfought, could only watch helplessly as their 3-1 lead from the first leg disappeared before their eyes and those of the 98,000 crowd packed into a cacophonous Nou Camp.
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe at the Nou Camp
fields.body:
Chelsea heroically lost the numbers game last night as the real Barcelona finally stood up to be counted. Gianluca Vialli's side, outclassed and largely outfought, could only watch helplessly as their 3-1 lead from the first leg disappeared before their eyes and those of the 98,000 crowd packed into a cacophonous Nou Camp.

The pride of Catalonia came into this game on the back of a dismal run of results but their pedigree remained unquestioned. Unfortunately for Chelsea its full force was unleashed just when it mattered, to steer a stylish path into an all Spanish semi-final against Valencia.

For Vialli's team to reach this far in Europe's premier club tournament is quite an achievement and something on which the Italian can build. But he knows that in the end Chelsea lack the class to succeed at this level and serious thought will be required in the summer transfer market.

"We didn't impose ourselves in the first half," he said. "We did what we didn't want to do: defend negatively. But we are proud of what we achieved in getting this far."

Barcelona's dominance of a game packed with drama contrasted starkly with their off night at Stamford Bridge a fortnight ago. Had not Rivaldo missed a penalty and Ed de Goey once again conjured up a series of defiant saves, the Spanish side's margin of victory would have been embarrassing and there would have been no extra-time.

Hard as they worked, Chelsea struggled throughout to contain Barcelona's verve and early in extra-time Celestine Babayaro was sent off for ending Luis Figo's weaving run on goal with a desperate tackle from behind, conceding a penalty which Rivaldo did convert.

Although the 10 men fought gamely to the finish, this was destined not to be another night of Premiership triumph in the cauldron where Manchester United lifted the European Cup last season.

Chelsea's two-goal cushion from the first leg had disappeared by half-time and, though they regained the aggregate lead after a mistake by the Barcelona keeper Ruud Hesp, the home side's quality told in the end.

Barcelona's 3-4-3 formation emphasised their need to attack and find the early goal to settle their nerves and tighten Chelsea's. Almost on cue they forced the breakthrough on 24 minutes having dominated the game until then. webTitle: Turkish fans to defy Uefa ban

fields.headline: Turkish fans to defy Uefa ban
fields.trailText: English-based Galatasaray fans will defy Uefa's ban on away supporters and attend tomorrow's game against Leeds United.
fields.body:
English-based Galatasaray fans will defy Uefa's ban on away supporters and attend tomorrow's game against Leeds United.

One London based Turk in his early twenties told Football Unlimited that several of his friends had acquired tickets in the home section of the ground from their English acquaintances.

The man - who gave his name as Haci - said that although the Galatasaray fans wouldn't instigate trouble themselves, they are fully expecting some Leeds supporters to start something after the match.

"I think Leeds are very angry," he said. "There will be trouble tomorrow. But we've got some mad supporters. They would go to Elland Road even if they knew they were going to die. Some of them are very, very fanatical."

But several other English-based Turks have changed their minds about going because they fear reprisals.

"I am a Leeds supporter, and want to go to the game to lay red flowers as a tribute to the two dead men" said a Turkish teenager named Denis. "I also wish that both teams would come together before kick-off and shake hands to show that football can rise above nationalism.

"But I'm scared. Since the deaths of the Leeds fans there have been several attacks. Last week a Kurdish guy from Northern Iraq was beaten up in London by a gang of white youths because they thought he was Turkish. In that climate nobody is safe."

After the deaths of Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight, the Galatasaray Social Club in Stoke Newington hastily changed its name to the Rainbow Club because they were worried that English supporters would be out for revenge.

"So far we haven't had any trouble," said the owner. "But I do worry about what will happen after tomorrow night's match."

"Even though I support Galatasary I don't want them to win because if that happens the trouble will escalate," he said. "Maybe 1-0 to Leeds would be a good score to satisfy everybody. But if Galatasaray win there will be big trouble everywhere."

fields.headline: Great white hopes dashed
fields.standfirst: Endangered species convention refuses protection for basking, whale and white sharks
fields.trailText: The future  of one visitor regularly seeking asylum on our shores didn't look very bright today.  The basking shark, which is partial to the waters around Cornwall, Devon and Scotland,  was refused protection by the UN Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species yesterday. White and whale sharks met with a similar fate.
fields.body:
The future of one visitor regularly seeking asylum on our shores didn't look very bright today. The basking shark, which is partial to the waters around Cornwall, Devon and Scotland, was refused protection by the UN Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species yesterday. White and whale sharks met with a similar fate.

The proposals before the Nairobi conference were aimed at restricting and controlling basking and whale shark fisheries and their trade worldwide but, like measures aimed at outlawing direct hunting of the great white, they failed to attain the required two-thirds majority.

The numbers of basking sharks are estimated to have dropped by up to 50% over the past decade. It takes up to 20 years for females to reach sexual maturity and gestation is thought to last between 12 and 36 months; with two to four years lapse between each pregnancy. The plankton-feeding whale and basking sharks, harmless to humans, are two of the largest creatures in the sea. Colin Speedie, a trustee of the Plymouth-based Shark Trust international conservation charity, said basking sharks - which can grow up to 30ft long and weigh seven tons - were protected in UK waters up to the 12-mile limit.

After that they were vulnerable to foreign fisheries seeking their valuable fins and huge, oily livers - and the protection of CITES would have helped diminish such exploitation.

Mr Speedie said it was impossible to say how the rejection of protection for the basking sharks would affect its appearances in waters off the UK, but added: "Precedents are not good."

The Shark Trust said the main opposition to the conservation proposals came from nations whose fisheries or markets placed a huge demand for shark fins, which can fetch £15,000 dollars each in parts of the Far East.
