fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst:
The Question: One in three children are bullied, according to a survey out this week. What can parents do to protect their kids?
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Question: One in three children are bullied, according to a survey out this week. What can parents do to protect their kids?
fields.body:
John Coe, National Association for Primary Education

You need to watch for signs that your child is being bullied. They might not tell you, so be alert: children may be reluctant to go to school, they may seem anxious, they may have mysterious tummy aches, there may be sudden changes in their friendship patterns, their work may deteriorate. If you suspect it's happening - whether your child admits it or not - talk to the teacher. Be open and honest, and try not to approach the school in a spirit of blame. Talk about ways of monitoring what's going on outside of lesson time: it's important people are vigilant at lunch and playtime.
Verdict: Talk to the teacher

Hereward Harrison, Childline

Prevention is the key - so it's best to raise the issue when it's not going on. Talk to your children about bullying: ask what they'd do if it happened to them. Who would they talk to? Rehearse what they'd do if it happened. When children are bullied, they want to talk to someone - but the trouble is that it's a problem that often defies one-stop intervention. So you need to keep on talking about it to your child: keep on raising it as a topic, ask about the details of your children's day. Also, be aware that when one sort of bullying stops, it can reappear in another form.
Verdict: Talk about it early

Helen Cowie, Research professor in psychology at University of Surrey

Schools are required to have an anti-bullying policy. If you haven't heard of it, ask why not. Bullying is complex; it's important schools deal with it on many levels. It needs to be regularly monitored and evaluated; it should be an active part of the school's strategy. All children need to be made aware of bullying - most are bystanders when it is carried out, but they don't like it and can be empowered to change from bystanders to protectors of the bullied. Bullying happens everywhere. You need to know your children's school is equipped to deal with it.
Verdict: Check the school's bullying policy

Michele Elliott, Child safety charity Kidscape

Fight for your child. If you don't, no one else will. A lot of parents say: "I don't know if I can go in to school to talk about it." Please! Your kid can't deal with this - but you can. Kids who are picked on can't fight back. You must be willing to pitch in. If your initial attempts don't succeed, don't let it rest. If the school starts blaming your child and you know it isn't his or her fault, go to the governors or the LEA. Keep in mind that this isn't your child's fault. If your child has been bullied in the past, send him or her on one of our one-day Zap courses - call 020-7730 3300 for information.
Verdict: Fight like a tiger

Dr Anita Jamal, Education Otherwise, a home schooling group

Inform the school and cooperate fully. If nothing changes, you can call on the educational social worker or pupil support office at your LEA, and on your GP and child psychologist. The next resort is to consider a school move, a restricted timetable or withdrawing your child from school: an unusual but effective form of education if carried out wisely in the child's best interests. But you've still to address your child's needs. He or she will be anxious after what's happened and will need contact with other children, support, and educational input.
Verdict: As a last resort, home educate

Margaret McGowan, Centre for Advice on Education

Parents should never ignore bullying: sometimes they do because they fear that if they intervene, they'll make things worse for their child. Sadly, that is sometimes the case. But the important thing is to handle it sensitively. Go to see your child's teacher, and suggest a low-key approach initially at least. It's also important to write to your child's school so there's a letter in your child's file. That matters - because if your child snaps and turns on the bully, you'll have some evidence of what's been going on.
Verdict: Write to the school

fields.headline: Walking on Easter eggshells
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: The diary of a part-time father
fields.body:
There's been a bit of argy bargy over the Easter Bunny. Allow me to explain. Like those of Santa and the Tooth Fairy, visitations by the EB are governed by a fragile skein of custom and accord which is vulnerable to low parental cunning. Last year Gloria, Jed and Billy spent the holy half of the Easter break at their "other home" with their appalling mother Dilys and her twerpish partner Chris the Pillock. This year, therefore, they'll spend it with us.

Of course, the EB will bestow confectionary favours Chez Pillock as well: such double celebrations are integral to the state of diplomatic warfare sometimes dignified as our "co-parenting project". But the deal is that the grown-ups who do not have the children with them on Easter Sunday morning ensure the enigmatic rabbit keeps her merchandise strictly to herself until after she has serviced the siblings at the host house.

Are you keeping up? It boils down to this: if I find out that so much as a Kinder Surprise has passed those children's lips prior to their arrival on Good Friday, Dilys and Chris will be toast.

My suspicions were aroused during the three children's last stint under this roof. It was Billy, six, who leaked, of course.

He said: "Er, Joe."

I said: "Yes, er, Billy."

He said: "You know Chris?"

I said: "In a manner of speaking."

He said: "Next week when there's no school he's going to teach us all about the Rites of Spring."

"What?"

"He told us that's what Easter's really all about."

Horrible visions rushed through my head. I saw pagan rituals in ancient woodland. I saw Dilys reclining among bluebells. I saw Chris in a fluffy suit, shaking floppy ears and waggling a cotton tail. And I saw Gloria, Jed and Billy gorging on Easter eggs.

I shared this dreadful picture with Angie. Given our growing - and slightly gleeful - suspicions that fertility might have become An Issue with the children's "other dad", it seemed only too likely that he'd crave spiritual communion with nature's rising sap. And it all smacked of vintage Dilys deviousness: if she couldn't have the kids for Easter, she'd have Chris contrive a pre-emptive alternative.

We tried to find out what was up, but not with much success. Billy was reliably hopeless about details, while Jed, as ever, refused to be drawn. He simply announced his disbelief in the EB's existence, and was unimpressed by my affected horror at such heresy. "Give me a break," he drawled without lifting his eyes from his Pokemon cards. Where should I conceal his chocolate Pikachu? Behind a radiator?

Angie didn't have any more luck with Gloria. "I don't want to hear about Easter!" she shrieked. "I don't want to talk about it! And I don't care about stupid Easter eggs!"

'What about sensible Easter eggs?" came Angie's tart reply, as she baled out of Gloria's bedroom. Gloria slammed the door behind her. Baby Estelle burst in to tears.

There were two reasons for this outburst. One was simply Gloria's adolescent sprouting. It's nice that she, at least, is harmonising with the season, but oestrogen has its dark side. The other reason was that she was perfectly aware that her mother is attempting to gazump somehow, but cannot bear to say so. To admit to me and Angie that Dilys was playing dirty would feel like a betrayal. Lost in a moral maze, she took refuge in a tantrum. And, frankly, who can blame her?

"I hope Easter Bunny didn't hear her any of that," I remarked grimly to my sons. But I'm afraid the EB had. That - whisper it - is because the EB is a clandestine combination of Angie and me. It is we who will rise at six on Sunday morning, we who will pull the glistening goodies from underneath our bed, and we who will tiptoe into the sodden garden to secrete those "stupid Easter eggs" among the pots and peonies.

And who will later look on anxiously as Gloria, Jed, Billy and Estelle rummage in the foliage? Who will be wondering if the eldest three are thinking to themselves that Easter had been more fun at their "other house" three days earlier - more fun with Dilys and Chris? Got it in one.

I said: "In a manner of speaking." He said: "Next week when there's no school he's going to teach us all about the Rites of Spring." "What?" "He told us that's what Easter's really all about." Horrible visions rushed through my head. I saw pagan rituals in ancient woodland. I saw Dilys reclining among bluebells. I saw Chris in a fluffy suit, shaking floppy ears and waggling a cotton tail. And I saw Gloria, Jed and Billy gorging on Easter eggs. I shared this dreadful picture with Angie. Given our growing - and slightly gleeful - suspicions that fertility might have become An Issue with the children's "other dad", it seemed only too likely that he'd crave spiritual communion with nature's rising sap. And it all smacked of vintage Dilys deviousness: if she couldn't have the kids for Easter, she'd have Chris contrive a pre-emptive alternative. We tried to find out what was up, but not with much success. Billy was reliably hopeless about details, while Jed, as ever, refused to be drawn. He simply announced his disbelief in the EB's existence, and was unimpressed by my affected horror at such heresy. "Give me a break," he drawled without lifting his eyes from his Pokemon cards. Where should I conceal his chocolate Pikachu? Behind a radiator? Angie didn't have any more luck with Gloria. "I don't want to hear about Easter!" she shrieked. "I don't want to talk about it! And I don't care about stupid Easter eggs!" 'What about sensible Easter eggs?" came Angie's tart reply, as she baled out of Gloria's bedroom. Gloria slammed the door behind her. Baby Estelle burst in to tears. There were two reasons for this outburst. One was simply Gloria's adolescent sprouting. It's nice that she, at least, is harmonising with the season, but oestrogen has its dark side. The other reason was that she was perfectly aware that her mother is attempting to gazump somehow, but cannot bear to say so. To admit to me and Angie that Dilys was playing dirty would feel like a betrayal. Lost in a moral maze, she took refuge in a tantrum. And, frankly, who can blame her? "I hope Easter Bunny didn't hear her any of that," I remarked grimly to my sons. But I'm afraid the EB had. That - whisper it - is because the EB is a clandestine combination of Angie and me. It is we who will rise at six on Sunday morning, we who will pull the glistening goodies from underneath our bed, and we who will tiptoe into the sodden garden to secrete those "stupid Easter eggs" among the pots and peonies. And who will later look on anxiously as Gloria, Jed, Billy and Estelle rummage in the foliage? Who will be wondering if the eldest three are thinking to themselves that Easter had been more fun at their "other house" three days earlier - more fun with Dilys and Chris? Got it in one.

fields.headline: American mom
fields.trailText: They call it "affluenza", and it is the latest disease to strike American children. Transmitted to them intentionally by their parents, symptoms include lavish buying sprees in toy stores, allowances in stock options instead of cash and flying to Disneyland for the day on Daddy's private plane.
fields.body:
They call it "affluenza", and it is the latest disease to strike American children. Transmitted to them intentionally by their parents, symptoms include lavish buying sprees in toy stores, allowances in stock options instead of cash and flying to Disneyland for the day on Daddy's private plane.

The culprit is the booming dot.com economy, where in certain parts of the US, notably San Francisco and New York, 60 new millionaires are created every day. Suddenly parents here who never earned more than six figures combined find themselves newly minted members of the luxury class after a successful internet takeover.

The problem, however, is how to impart values to kids who are raised in mansions and chauffeur-driven to school, and never fly commercial because the Learjet is on standby.

These parents need help, because word out of Silicon Valley is that affluenza or "sudden wealth syndrome" is creating a generation of children who think money does grow on trees and lack empathy for any child that doesn't live as large.

So five years after the internet boom began, filthy rich American parents are seeking help in raising their children, flocking to the Money, Meaning and Choices Institute in San Francisco, where classes are held on treating affluenza. Under the tutelage of psychologist Dr Stephen Goldbart, parents learn how to motivate their children, talk about money, give them allowances and chores and encourage community work and charity.

On Wall Street, rich clients of the investment house Merrill Lynch are also getting help parenting their cash-rich progeny. The company offers a "financial parenting" programme to its investors,who must have a minimum net worth of $100m (£60m) to qualify. So far 50 families across the US have availed themselves of the one-on-one counselling service.

"We talk to the parents and children about philanthropy, goal-setting and values," says a Merrill Lynch spokesman. "With children we teach them the ABCs of money and how money carries responsibilities."

Most importantly, counsellors teach parents how to answer those thorny questions from kids who get mutual funds as well as Lego for their birthdays. When one parent was asked by her child why they flew in their own plane instead of commercial, the mother, thanks to affluenza classes, knew the answer.

"We are very lucky," she said, just as she had been coached. "We have worked very hard for the money to buy this plane. But people who don't have their own planes are just as important."

webTitle: How could anyone kill their child?

fields.headline: How could anyone kill their child?
fields.standfirst: Up to 100 British children are murdered by one of their parents each year. This week it was two boys, killed by their father.  Emma Brockes  explores the motives behind these unthinkable crimes
fields.trailText: Up to 100 British children are murdered by one of their parents each year. This week it was two boys, killed by their father. Emma Brockes explores the motives behind these unthinkable crimes.
fields.body:
If the field of psychology rests on a need to understand odd behaviour, there is one circumstance that defies it: the child killed by its parent is persistently regarded, outside of the scientific community, as an incomprehensible anomaly. The reflex emotional response to a case such as that of the two boys, Christopher and Oliver Fairless, killed by their father in Lincolnshire this week, is that it must have been an act of random lunacy, an expression of derangement that can't be fitted into a wider pattern or mitigated by commonality.

The clinical response is more disturbing. It identifies a thread of behaviour that links the two boys' deaths to other killings that, although relatively few and far between, share enough characteristics to approach the level of a syndrome.

Christopher and Oliver's father, Frank Fairless, had recently split up with their mother, Claire. The self-employed builder faced losing the children, nine and six, in a custody battle and after killing his sons, killed himself. "My experience of these revenge-type killings of a child by a separated father is that they are often perpetrated by people who have appeared to be relatively normal, before the murder," says Dr Christopher Cordess, professor of forensic psychiatry at the University of Sheffield.

Dr Cordess is currently assessing a man whose estranged wife has identified him as a possible threat to their children. "He is slightly dependent, he can't accept that the marriage is over and someone else has moved in with his ex-wife and is now the father of the children. Often, the issue in these cases is not the man's failure to accept his ex-wife's new marriage, but to accept that he has lost his kids to another man. If there is no history of violence, it is difficult to make a prediction."

Statistically, the Fairless brothers were at low risk of being killed by their parents. Every year, between 70 and 100 children in England and Wales are murdered, the majority of them under the age of one and by their parents. Neonaticide, the killing of a baby in its first 24 hours of life, is most commonly perpetrated by the mother, but in the first year of its life, there is an even divide between babies killed by the mother and father. By the time a child is in its infancy, however, there has been a shift towards the culpability of the father.

"The motives are quite different when older children are killed by their parents," says Maureen Marks of the Maudsley Institute of Psychiatry. "For younger ones, it's most frequently a case of someone losing their temper with the children. When an older child is killed, the parent is more likely to be mentally ill." Within this category is a sub-division of children killed by their father in an apparent act of revenge against their mother - usually in the context of a bitter custody battle.

In October 1999, David Price from Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, gassed his eight-year-old daughter, his six-year-old son and himself, after splitting up with their mother. Two weeks previously, Peter Stafford had murdered his sons, aged six and two, his seven-year old-daughter and his 27-year-old wife, before killing himself in a house in Birmingham. His wife had walked out on him two weeks before. In April 1999, Stephen Carter, a factory manager from Weaver Hills, Staffordshire, killed himself and his three children after the break-up of his marriage. "Carter wanted to destroy everything he held of great value in his life," said the coroner, John Wain. "Regrettably, this included his own children."

Forensic psychiatrists estimate that, in Britain, there are roughly 10 children murdered in this fashion every year and that it is a vastly under-researched area. "If the estimated figures are right," says Dr Todd Hogue, a consultant psychologist, "it is more likely that your partner is going to kill your children when you leave him than that they are going to be killed by a stranger in the park."

The agonising factor in most of these killings is that the men who carry them out do not have a history of abusing their children, but maintain a love for them that is almost pathological. Police say there was no advance warning that Frank Fairless would harm his children. In 1994, Dr Sukhdev Sandhu strangled his two children before jumping from a tower block and killing himself. He had just learned that his estranged wife was seeing another man. "That their father could ever hurt them is unbelievable," said his wife, "but that he could end their lives is beyond comprehension." In February last year, Kenneth McKay of Fleetwood, Lancashire, cut the throats of his two children, who survived, and killed himself. "He had used violence before," said his ex-partner Tanya, "but he had never touched the children."

Experts insist, however, that the signs of latent mental illness are readable well before the crime is committed, without violence entering into it. "If a psychotherapist had talked to these people before, they would have known that they were capable of this," says Maureen Marks. "They would have noticed how the person reacted to things not going their way, how being spurned by the one they loved could stir up this rage."

They might have noticed that the father was mildly obsessive, that his identity was too dependent on his role as a provider, as the traditional man of the house, to withstand a seismic alteration."In retrospect, you'll say that these are very abnormal people," says Dr Cordess. "Not abnormal in that they have a psychiatric illness, but that they are possibly dependent men who can't imagine living alone, who regard their wives as possessions. They might describe their situation in the rubric of a stalker: that they can't fall out of love with their ex-wife, that she's a wonderful woman, therefore they follow everywhere. She experiences this as demonisation, but they might kill her saying they love her, they love her to bits."

The propensity of the courts to award custody to the mother has made this a father's crime. But there are occasionally cases involving the mother. In 1995, Susan Smith, 23, from South Carolina, USA, drove her car into a lake, drowning her two young sons. Smith, estranged from her husband David, concocted a story about the children being kidnapped, before admitting that she had killed them herself. The case attracted worldwide attention as Smith faced the death penalty.

In the event, she was sentenced to 30 years imprisonment, but a mitigating factor in her defence was the implication that she had tried to kill herself that day, too. The suicide of the killer parent, is seen to be proof not only of their derangement, but of the intensity with which they identify with their children - in a peverse way, the extent to which they love them - and, as such, is a powerful defence tactic for the shrewd survivor.

"Sometimes the suicide attempt is only half-hearted," says Dr Cordess. "Years ago, a man I was treating said to me, 'I bet you despise me for not killing myself after I killed my children.' He was right. I did." When the murderer does kill himself, it is with the aim of holding onto his children in death in a way that has been denied him in life - a gruesome acquisitiveness that even psychiatrists turn away from studying.

webTitle: Farmer jailed for life for murder of teenage intruder

fields.headline: Farmer jailed for life for murder of teenage intruder
fields.standfirst: Profile: the gypsy-hating loner who shot to kill
fields.trailText: Farmer Tony Martin has been jailed for life at Norwich crown court after being found guilty of murdering a 16-year-old burglar who broke into his Norfolk farm house.
fields.body:
Farmer Tony Martin has been jailed for life at Norwich crown court after being found guilty of murdering a 16-year-old burglar who broke into his Norfolk farm house.

Martin, 55, was also found guilty of wounding another intruder, 30-year-old Brendan Fearon, with intent to cause grievous bodily harm. Both were majority verdicts of 10-2. Earlier, the jury had cleared Martin of attempting to murder Mr Fearon and of possessing a weapon with intent to endanger life.

Fred Barras, who died almost immediately of shotgun wounds, and Fearon had broken into Martin's isolated farm near Emneth in Norfolk, on August 20 1999, intending to steal antiques they believed to be inside.

Fearon was seriously wounded in the upper thighs, but managed to escape and reach a neighbouring farmhouse to call for help. The two intruders had a total of 114 burglary convictions between them.

There was a loud cry of "yes" as the verdicts were read out in the crowded courtroom. The jury of six men and six women took nine hours and 36 minutes to return the guilty verdicts. As well as the life sentence for murder, the judge, Mr Justice Owen, told Martin he must serve 10 years for the wounding offence and 12 months for the possession of an illegal firearm. All the sentences will run concurrently.

The bachelor farmer, who admitted possessing a shotgun without a certificate, opened fire after confronting Barras and Fearon, both of Newark, Nottinghamshire, on his property. He was arrested at a hotel in Wisbech the next morning. Bleak House, the farm inhabited by Martin, was "booby-trapped" and had a home-made security system, the court heard.

Rosamund Horwood-Smart QC, prosecuting, said Martin had rigged up his own electricity system and lived in near darkness. She said he had also taken security measures and created a "booby-trap" on his staircase by removing the top and bottom steps.

"He also installed iron bars inside his doors and windows on the ground floor," she said. "He would also sleep entirely clothed wearing his boots in contemplation of something happening."

The roofs of outbuildings had ladders on them and Martin had set up a "lookout post" in a tree which had four long ladders lashed to its branches.

Martin denied that he had booby-trapped the house. He said the stairs were in a state of disrepair and that he used the ladders for trimming his oak tree and cleaning a chimney.

fields.headline: Straw says grass up hooligans
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw today urged people to blow the whistle on troublemakers in the run up to this summer's Euro 2000 football championships in Holland and Belgium.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw today urged people to blow the whistle on troublemakers in the run up to this summer's Euro 2000 football championships in Holland and Belgium.

Relaunching the National Criminal Intelligence Service football hooligan hotline, Mr Straw said: "The public can play a key role in preventing the mindless minority from spoiling what should be a great Euro 2000.

"My message, not just as home secretary, but as a football supporter and enthusiast, to every other football supporter and enthusiast is, if you know of people who are likely to cause trouble, please phone the hotline, and give NCIS the information.

"It can help ensure that the reputation England carries before it at Euro 2000 is for good football on the field, not bad behaviour off the field."

Mr Straw told a news conference at NCIS headquarters in London that the 1998 World Cup had been a great tournament - but for English football it was mainly remembered "for the terrible scenes witnessed in Marseilles".

He added: "That was the latest in a series of riots involving so-called England supporters."

Mr Straw said that sadly, no one could provide any guarantees.

"What we can do, however, is put in place better arrangements so as to ensure that if there is further trouble, it is dealt with as effectively as possible."

He was committed to ensuring the threat of violence was minimised "and that the lessons of Marseilles and more recent tragic events are taken on board".

He said it was agreed with the Dutch and Belgian hosts that policing operations must be based on international co-operation and sharing of intelligence.

Home office minister Lord Bassam had been to Eindhoven in Holland and Charleroi in Belgium where England will play their group games.

"He was assured that the police forces in both cities would not tolerate any behaviour which they felt was a threat to law and order.

"The Dutch and Belgian police have extensive public order powers and will not be slow to use them.

"They are ready, willing and able to deal with England supporters who breech the low policing tolerance levels."

He said any England hooligans convicted in either country could face 10-year bans on their return to England, a power which was not enforced during the troubles in Marseilles.

Bryan Drew, head of the NCIS strategic and specialist intelligence branch, said: "It is the time for decent fans to stand up and be counted and distance themselves from the small but criminal minority that shame the good names of the clubs in the country they purport to represent. The hotline is a key intelligence tool for us."

Commissioner Theo Brecklemans, leading the Dutch police operation, said he thought any potential for trouble would come from the mass of people attending the events, rather than English supporters.

Colonel Herman Bliki, in charge of the Belgian police operation, said: "We are certain that of the English supporters who are coming over to Charleroi, 95% of them are good supporters, and the local community will receive them as good supporters.

"As for the other 5%, we are doing our best together with NCIS to try to keep them away from the events."

Mr Straw was asked what his message was ahead of tomorrow night's UEFA cup semi-final second leg match between Leeds United and Galatasaray of Turkey at Elland Road, following the murders of two Leeds fans in clashes on the eve of the first leg in Istanbul two weeks ago.

Mr Straw said: "My message is very straightforward, that in the light of what happened in Turkey, I hope very much that the game is conducted in a safe and secure way, and that there is no disorder.

"I know that the West Yorkshire police service have put in place detailed plans to secure the safety of the public, as far as that is humanly possible."

 The hotline is: 0800 515 495.

webTitle: Improving housing, health, business and the environment in London

fields.headline: Improving housing, health, business and the environment in London
fields.standfirst: The main London mayoral candidates' promises and policies
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson, Labour
fields.body:
Frank Dobson, Labour

Housing
Labour's mayoral challenger wants to introduce 10,000 new low-cost homes for teachers and nurses to attract skilled staff who have been priced out of the capital's housing market back to London. He also promises to provide 80% of households with internet connections by 2004.

Health
Mr Dobson, a former health secretary, has launched plans for a London-wide lottery to raise up to £100m a year for health and education schemes in the capital. He says he will channel money raised from a weekly lottery to health and education projects such as specialist hospital equipment, care for old people, summer schools and homework clubs. He also wants a dedicated medical officer for London.

Environment
Mr Dobson argues that practical sustainable development comes through improving public transport and regenerating deprived areas - partly through reducing crime. His stated environmental priorities are to defend the green belt and promote the recycling of land through conversion or rebuilding on brownfield sites.

Business
Wants to see corporate tax on London firms cut as a way of increasing investment and jobs and has set a target of 100,000 more jobs in London within the next four years. He will also set up a task force to tackle black and Asian unemployment.

Steven Norris, Conservative

Housing
In a move well to the left of his fellow Conservatives, Steven Norris promises to demand a higher London weighting, from an average of £3,000 to £6,000, on the salaries of public sector workers to help them meet rising house prices. He also proposes to spearhead a new right-to-buy drive, encouraging London boroughs sell council homes at discounted prices to tenants who wish to buy.

Health
Will appoint a "commissioner for public health" and also ensure that London's streets are properly cleaned and free of rubbish.

Environment
Pledges to promote brownfield redevelopment and champion green jobs and, like Ken Livingstone, will set a target of creating 10,000 private-sector "green jobs" by 2005. He will also draw up a noise map and require commercial premises to invest in proper sound-proofing.

Business
Strongly opposed to Britain's entry into the euro, Mr Norris accepts that it would be "wholly unproductive for the mayor to obstruct" the single currency if London business comprehensively endorsed the single currency.

Susan Kramer, Liberal Democrat

Housing
Will campaign for more London weighting for public sector pay and introduce a "cost of living index" to expose how difficult it is for public sector workers to live in the capital. One of the Liberal Democrat candidate's big ideas is to set up community banks in deprived areas. Part of their role will cover schemes such as shared ownership of houses. Town managers will also be created to revitalise high streets.

Health
Proposes a London-wide audit of hosital beds to ensure the government keeps its promise to increase the number of hospital beds until the capital reaches the EU average.

Environment
Ms Kramer promises to open a state-of-the-art recycling plant to help promote a sustainable London. She will set a target to reduce traffic to 10% below 1990 levels by 2010 in order to reduce air pollution. Following the example of a house in Peckham which has produced more than 45% of its electricity needs from solar power, Ms Kramer aims to introduce planning guidance encouraging new homes and businesses to align their roofs to take advantage of solar energy when it becomes commercially viable in the near future.

Business
Ms Kramer's community banks will offer special help to small businesses, while giving women a genuine option to work through childcare initiatives will form a crucial part of her regeneration strategy. She also wants to break down large GLA contracts to enable smaller London businesses to compete for them.

Ken Livingstone, independent

Housing
Ken Livingstone will hold a three-month inquiry into London's needs for new affordable low cost housing and he promises work with business and the Empty Homes Agency in setting a target to reclaim the 100,000 empty homes across the capital. Mr Livingstone also says he will get the London Development Agency working with the Rough Sleepers Unit to encourage training for homeless people "to help them into employment and off the streets".

Health
Wants to meet the secretary of state for health "within a month" to discuss London's health needs. Proposes a Healthy London Commission to help the mayor and assembly draw up a "health improvement programme" for London. Will maintain "a stable funding base" for London's drug services and draw up "a London-wide strategy to reduce harm from drugs".

Environment
Promises to establish a sustainable development unit in the mayor's office and to set targets to recycle 25% of all household waste and establish 10,000 "green" jobs by 2005. Also proposes to draw up a biodiversity action plan to give full protection to London's wildlife sites, and save Rainham Marshes from development.

Business
Mr Livingstone's remark that the World Trade Organisation would not be welcome in London attracted much publicity, but he has otherwise assiduously cultivated support from London business as his manifesto's rhetoric (he will "support jobs and competitiveness in London") suggests. He will work with the London Development Agency to develop initiatives to back small businesses established by London's ethnic minority communities and ask it to prioritise new community businesses as part of the capital's regeneration.

fields.headline: White men bearing gifts
fields.standfirst: Modern Brazil was born out of violence and slavery.  As its dignitaries meet former colonisers for a 500th birthday party, Jan Rocha charts the ongoing rape of the Amazon
fields.trailText: Modern Brazil was born out of violence and slavery. As its dignitaries meet former colonisers for a 500th birthday party, Jan Rocha charts the ongoing rape of the Amazon
fields.body:
Five hundred years ago this Saturday, the smooth-skinned inhabitants of what was to become Brazil watched in astonishment as a group of hairy white men dressed in strange coverings arrived offshore in huge canoes, rowed to the beach and, unknown to them, claimed their territory for the Portuguese crown.

It must have been the equivalent of watching a flying saucer land and disgorge little green men from Mars. Even so, the indigenous people welcomed them, exchanging their bows and arrows for hats and bracelets, never guessing that the newcomers' lasting gift to them would be 500 years of slaughter, enslavement and disease.

Commemorating "the meeting of two civilisations", as the speechwriters are now calling it, is a bit like celebrating the meeting of German and Jewish cultures in the second world war, says Jose Saramargo, the Portuguese poet. At least 5m Indians, maybe as many as 15m, lived here when the white men arrived, but today they number a mere 330,000 out of Brazil's total population of 165m.

The slaughter was always ruthless: "It is after 10am when the group . . . reach the camp. They see children playing, women cutting firewood, an old blind woman sitting, a baby lying in a hammock. One man opens fire and the others follow, shooting at anyone, man, woman or child . . . the attackers search the huts, stabbing with their knives everyone they find there, injured and uninjured . . . Goiano Doido does not spare even a small baby lying in a hammock, wrapping it in a cloth and cutting it to pieces with a machete. The old blind woman is kicked to death."

A 16th-century chronicle? No, it's evidence given at the trial of a group of goldminers who in 1993 attacked a Yanomami village in the Amazon rainforest. Five hundred years after conquest, modern Brazil still shows little respect for the descendents of the original inhabitants or for their unique knowledge of the rainforest.

There is evidence that the Amazon basin had been densely populated when the Europeans arrived. Scientists now believe that the Indians had learnt not only how to survive in the hostile environment but how to cultivate it. Charles Clement, researcher at the government's Amazon research institute, INPA, says the Indians domesticated a large number of wild plants (one of them was the pineapple) to make them more productive. But the arrival of the Europeans led to the ruin of the Indians, and the rainforest reverted to wild.

European naturalists who trav elled to Brazil in the 18th and 19th centuries marvelled at the exuberance of the rainforest, which they saw as an empty paradise created by God without the intervention of man. Baron von Humboldt, one of the first European naturalists to visit the Amazon basin, wrote home to Germany in 1799: "What an extravagant country we are in. Amazing plants, electric eels, armadillos, monkeys, parrots . . . we have been running around like fools. For the first three days we could not settle on anything."

Charles Darwin spoke of his "rapture" as he wandered by himself through the forest: "I collected a great number of brilliantly coloured flowers, enough to make a florist go mad . . . the air is deliciously cool and soft."

The "empty" Amazon also attracted adventurers in search of El Dorado, like the ill-fated British colonel Percy Fawcett, who disappeared in 1925 while looking for a lost city, or, more recently, the thousands of wildcat prospectors who overran the Yanomami reserve in their frenzied hunt for gold. The turn of the century rubber boom made fortunes for a few, but for 30,000 Indians used as slave labour it all too often meant death, although it was the technology they had developed which produced the latex.

One hundred years later, Asian logging companies have joined the Americans and the Europeans in stripping the forest of mahogany and other hardwoods, and researchers from major pharmaceutical companies, eager to find the ingredients for new miracle drugs in Amazon plants, target the knowledge of indigenous communities, where shamans are the repositories of centuries of plant knowledge.

Successive Brazilian governments have seen the rainforest's unplanned exuberance as a challenge and tried to discipline it with roads and settlements, subsidising the burning of the forest to make way for cattle ranches; turning its giant rivers into waterways for huge grain barges: installing a free trade zone to swell the Amazon capital of Manaus with a sprawling circle of shantytowns, peopled by migrants from riverside villages.

Even environmentalists, who over the past 30 years have campaigned to save the rainforest, took time to acknowledge that it was inhabited.

For 500 years, the Indians have been seen as labour to be exploited, savages to be civilised or obstacles to development plans. Rarely have they been regarded as people whose knowledge is invaluable, whose culture should be respected, whose opinion should be sought about what to do with the rainforest.

Satellite surveys show that where indigenous reserves have remained intact, the forest has not been destroyed. Indian reserves now cover only 11% of Brazil's total land area, but they are under continuous attack from those who want to mine and log their resources and who claim that the reserves add up to "a lot of land for very few Indians".

Indigenous organisations have been given no say in Brazil's development policy. This week, while Brazilian and Portuguese dignitaries hold their solemnities on the Atlantic beach at Coroa Vermelha, where Pedro Alvares Cabral landed in 1500, the Indians are holding their own encounter to demand that, after 500 years, they should be heard.

 Jan Rocha, a former Guardian South American correspondent, presents The Brazilian Dream on Radio 4, tomorrow and on April 27, to mark the 500 years. Survival International and Indian representatives will launch a report on indigenous peoples in Brazil. Address: 11-15 Emerald Street, London, WC1N 3QL (tel 020 7242 1441; website: www.survival-international.org).

fields.headline: Too good to be true
fields.standfirst: Home is where the heartbreak is for workers lured by adverts promising big money. Simon Bowers reports
fields.trailText: Home is where the heartbreak is for workers lured by adverts promising big money. Simon Bowers reports
fields.body:
The tempting advert promises that you can earn £200 a week assembling jewellery boxes from flat-pack kits delivered to your door. All you have to do is send a joining fee of £15.

But when Joe Mann, a trading standards officer, responded to the advert as part of an investigation into the scheme, he received a bag of roughly cut plywood, a tube of glue and some indecipherable instructions. Unable to assemble a single box, he was forced to forfeit his joining fee.

The scam may seem painfully obvious, but last year saw an increase of over 60% in the numbers of desperate house-bound workers seduced by misleading get-rich-quick offers, according to the National Group on Homeworking.

Responding to adverts in the classified columns of newspapers, on supermarket bulletin boards, or flyers strapped to traffic-light poles, more and more of the estimated 1m homeworkers in Britain are being duped out of an up-front "registration fee" - or, if they complete the work, are receiving a pittance for their efforts.

Linda Devereux, director of NGH, says that the number of complaints against firms offering employment in the home increased from 6,737 in 1998 to 11,107 last year, but represented just a fraction of the total number of vulnerable homeworkers being targeted.

"Our phonelines are jammed and the calls we get are just the tip of the iceberg," she says. "We received 174 complaints about one company, but later found it had taken over 103,000 up-front payments in response to an advertisement campaign.

"Because regular homeworkers desperately need an income, many are afraid to complain when they get less than they hoped for from their wage packets.

"They are normally paid according to their output, based on a fair estimate of what can be achieved in an hour. On paper, this often works out slightly over the minimum wage. In practice, the estimates are unachievable and the homeworkers earn much less."

Vanessa Griffiths, a trading standards officer in Cheshire, says the increasing number of companies advertising misleading homeworking schemes makes legal action difficult.

"With one or two exceptions, it is a small number of complaints against a large number of companies," she says. "In most cases, the level of complaints and the amounts concerned are not enough for trading standards officers to justify enforcement action."

Private action through small claims courts was often equally fruitless and potential claimants could be put off by the cost of litigation, with no guarantee of getting their money back.

A spokesman for the Advertising Standards Authority, which has seen complaints about homeworking scams treble in the past two years, says adverts offering vast sums of money for what appears to be very little work were still very common.

"As a result, we asked for the withdrawal of 13 adverts for homeworking schemes in 1999," he says. "Unfortunately, the growing number of leaflet drops and postcards in shop windows are not covered by our regulations."

Trade secretary Stephen Byers's "modern markets" white paper last year recognised that current laws on fair trading were failing some homeworkers, and a spokeswoman for the DTI confirms that various ways of tackling the problem are still being considered.

Until then, homeworkers are told: if a job advert looks too good to be true, it probably is.

Poor rewards

Vanessa Wood recently gave up her job as a homeworker for Industrial Rubber Mouldings plc after six years. She says the final straw came when she was given a batch of particularly intricate work and was paid just £9 for what took her more than 11 hours to complete.

Three times a week, Wood, 36, from Gosport in Hampshire, took delivery of various rubber components from IRM - including stoppers for walking sticks and seals for gas-masks or inflatable lifeboats - and trimmed them to size in her living room. She says that the job had suited her circumstances as a mother of two young girls and kept her occupied when her husband, who is in the navy, was away.

"I can remember on some occasions, when my husband was at sea, that I'd work until the kids came in from school, then I would start work again about 9pm and carry on right through till about 3am," she says. "By the third night, I'd be absolutely shattered and have to go to bed at a reasonable time and then get up the following morning and rush like mad to get all the work done."

Wood fell out with IRM last year when they appeared to be disregarding new national minimum wage legislation.

Despite being an experienced trimmer, she has calculated that she never earned more than £2.50 an hour, because she couldn't keep up with IRM's estimated work rates.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Anyone who followed the media debate generated by the publication of the Macpherson report on the Stephen Lawrence case will be familiar with the concept of institutionalised racism. But even though the report's employment of the term was a refreshing antidote to more individualistic accounts of racism (the few-rotten-apples-in-a-barrel school of explanation), the airwaves were hardly besieged by social scientists wielding up-to-date research evidence of what it might mean in practice.

This came as no surprise to Nirmal Puwar, a sociologist at Northampton University. In a recent paper, she points out that in the last decade there has been a serious dearth of well-researched studies into institutional racism. Writers concerned with race have preferred to concentrate on theorising about such matters as "new ethnicities", rather than getting down to the hard graft of documenting how racism operates in the workplace.

Puwar has tried to remedy this situation by studying racism in an institution which is regarded as "the absolute apex of disembodied, neutral professionalism" - the British senior civil service.

Her first problem was finding any black senior civil servants to interview about their experiences. There are no members of ethnic minorities in the top two senior grades and only one in grade three (the under secretary level). In lower grades, the numbers increase, but even at this level black civil servants are much more likely to fill specialist positions (doctors, lawyers, statisticians) than the more highly regarded administrative posts.

This serious imbalance means that senior civil servants from ethnic minorities are regarded as "space invaders": they occupy positions that are seen as the natural preserve of whites.

fields.bodyText: Anyone who followed the media debate generated by the publication of the Macpherson report on the Stephen Lawrence case will be familiar with the concept of institutionalised racism. But even though the report's employment of the term was a refreshing antidote to more individualistic accounts of racism (the few-rotten-apples-in-a-barrel school of explanation), the airwaves were hardly besieged by social scientists wielding up-to-date research evidence of what it might mean in practice. This came as no surprise to Nirmal Puwar, a sociologist at Northampton University. In a recent paper, she points out that in the last decade there has been a serious dearth of well-researched studies into institutional racism. fields.headline: Weighting game
fields.standfirst: What do patients' organisations think of Nice's track record and potential? Three chief executive officers air their mixed feelings
fields.trailText: What do patients' organisations think of Nice's track record and potential? Three chief executive officers air their mixed feelings
fields.body:
 Peter Cardy, chief executive of the Multiple Sclerosis Society, is waiting with some trepidation for the results of the appraisal of beta interferon. The society lobbied parliament recently, voicing fears that beta interferon will effectively be banned from the NHS by Nice. "It looked to us, from the responses that ministers were giving in parliament and debates, as if they had not only written the questions for Nice but decided the answers as well," Cardy says. "That is quite alarming really. Nothing has happened [since the lobby] to make us change our minds.

"On behalf of the Neurological Alliance, I have been in correspondence with Nice about ways they can ensure that patient priorities and valuations of interventions are taken into account. I think it is one of the areas where the commitment and principle is good but the practice has a long way to go."

There has been no assurance from Nice, he says, that patient concerns about a medicine - whether it is useful, burdensome, whether the route of administration is acceptable, and so on - will be given equal weight by the appraisal committee as the views of doctors and pharmaceutical companies. "There will always be a lurking fear that patients will say, 'I have got to have this drug in limitless quantities.' That is not our experience. Patients don't always want everything that medical science can give them."

Cardy is not convinced that health authorities will necessarily implement Nice guidance if it means paying for all patients with a certain condition to get an expensive new drug. "I don't see anything that suggests health authorities will be asked to take into account Nice's recommendations as a national priority, rather than to balance them against local priorities," he says.

 Harry Cayton,chief executive of the Alzheimer's Association, which will be submitting evidence to Nice during the appraisal of three dementia drugs later this year, says: "I'm absolutely prepared to give Nice a clear run until it proves itself to not be worthy of our trust.

"If there is a concern I share with some of my colleagues it is that the rhetoric about patient involvement doesn't yet meet the actuality, and we want to be sure that they understand the importance of developing ways of working that genuinely involve patients in the scrutiny of treatments.

"In the appraisal of the flu drug there was no one representing patient interests on the panel, although their guidelines say there should be. I know it was the first one and they did it jolly quickly, but it didn't actually happen.

"The list of patient organisations that was sent out in relation to submitting evidence on the anti-dementia drugs included several that were not patients' organisations at all and had no relevance to Alzheimer's. They have not quite got it right yet."

 Jean Mossman, chief executive of CancerBacup, has been involved in the consultation process now taking place over the taxanes - the new group of cancer drugs on which Nice will deliver a verdict at the end of this month.

"I think in principle it is very good," she says, " though I have a hesitation about how quickly it can process all the things that are likely to be relevant to cancer patients.

"If the process is anticipated to take 10 months to a year, it is not going to mean faster access to modern treatment. I have a hesitation about how quickly they can embrace and appraise all the new products.

"I'm concerned that health authorities are taking the stance that they won't fund new drugs until they have been through Nice. They are starting to do that, although clinicians are resistant. It's an excuse for not allowing new products to be used.

"My third concern is that if we can't afford chemotherapy for cancers now unless more money is going to be available, how are we going to be able to afford it just because Nice says we should use it? We should have centralised, ring-fenced funding for products that Nice endorses. I don't see how else it can be done."

She says she would hate to see a situation where drug A is recommended by Nice for cancer B, so the health authority funds it and will not pay for treatment for cancer C instead. There should be money given to health authorities not in general terms to implement Nice recommendations - as Alan Milburn implied in his allocation of the first £600m of the new budget money - but specifically to pay for a named drug.

fields.headline: Spiral of debt
fields.standfirst: Niall Cooper on people who have to pay huge interest on loans to keep the family afloat
fields.trailText: Niall Cooper on people who have to pay huge interest on loans to keep the family afloat
fields.body:
Yesterday saw the launch of a new campaign network "for a fairer deal for those facing debt and financial exclusion in the UK". Jubilee 2000 has achieved much success in drawing the world's attention to the unpayable debts of the "two-thirds" world - but individuals and communities in the UK are struggling with debt too. For the poorest in society, the burden of debt is exacerbated by a lack of access to sources of affordable credit and other financial services.

"Debt on our Doorstep" is a coalition of over 20 agencies, including Church Action on Poverty, Help the Aged, New Economics Foundation, the Money Advice Association and Oxfam. They all share a common purpose: to stop the poorest from being consigned to a lifetime of high-interest borrowing and spiralling debt.

Barclay's high-profile branch closures last week were simply the latest round in a process which has seen over 6,000 bank branches disappear over the past 10 years.

As the high street lenders have pulled out of communities, "alternative" credit providers have been moving in - but at a price. Provident Financial ("the Provvy"), the UK's largest licensed moneylender, has seen the number of its customers rise by over 300,000 in the past four years.

And Shopacheck, another moneylender targeted at low income households, is rapidly developing a brand new branch network: 75 opened last year, with another 100 planned over the next two years. In excess of 3m households are now having to deal with the "alternative" credit market.

The Provident, Shopacheck and others like them specialise in high interest loans to low income households, typically at rates of between 100% and 500% APR. As the customer base increases, so too do profits. Provident and Shopacheck's owners, Cattles plc, made over £200m in pre-tax profits last year.

People are not turning to the alternative credit providers to pay for the holiday of a lifetime, or for CDs, designer clothes or sports cars. They are mostly borrowing for shoes for the kids; for basic bedding or furniture; for money to pay off other bills; in some cases for food and everyday essentials. It's here that the government has let them down.

Once upon a time, the state itself took on the role of "lender of last resort", with DSS grants available for people on benefits, to prevent the need for a new cooker becoming a major financial crisis.

But such days are now long gone. The social fund, introduced in 1988, largely replaced grants with a strictly cash-limited budget for loans. Yet loans simply stoke up the problems for those already trying to manage on meagre benefits.

Just about everyone agrees that the social fund is inadequate to the task, and is itself a major contributory factor to the tidal wave of debt which is now battering the doors of agencies such as the Citizens' Advice Bureau.

Families such as the Potters (not their real name), of High Wycombe, suffer the conseqences. An initial loan from the Provvy of £500 in 1998 to pay off rent arrears led to further debts and rapidly became a £1,000 loan. A social fund loan of £700 followed last year to replace their defunct cooker. To add to their woes, a £20 parking meter fine transformed itself into £290 bill when bailiffs became involved earlier this year. Over a third of their £144 per week income support is now consumed by debt payments and charges - leaving just £92 per week to live on. Not surprisingly, Mr Potter has recently been prescribed stress counselling by his doctor.

So is there any good news? Well, yes. Many communities are now taking the problem into their own hands by setting up credit unions, which offer their members both cheap loans and increased control over their own finances. They rank high on the list of the government's priorities for assistance.

But the country's 500 or so community-based credit unions currently serve only a tiny fraction of those who could benefit from their services. Undoubtedly they deserve a major boost, but it will be many years before they can bridge the gap left by the withdrawal of mainstream financial services.

 Niall Cooper is national coordinator of Church Action on Poverty and founder member of the Debt On Our Doorstep network. Further information and a free campaign pack can be obtained from Church Action on Poverty, Central Buildings, Oldham St, Manchester, M1 1JT (tel: 0161 236 9321 or via its website at www.church-poverty.org.uk)

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: • Protesters at the IMF/World Bank meeting in Washington have attracted the usual condemnation by British government ministers and media, but these critics should note what former World Bank chief economist Joseph Stiglitz has to say in a US magazine about the operation that likes to fix the economies of poor countries:
fields.body:
 Protesters at the IMF/World Bank meeting in Washington have attracted the usual condemnation by British government ministers and media, but these critics should note what former World Bank chief economist Joseph Stiglitz has to say in a US magazine about the operation that likes to fix the economies of poor countries:

The IMF likes to go about its business without asking too many questions. In theory, the fund supports democratic institutions in the nations it assists. In practice, it undermines the democratic process by imposing policies. Officially, of course, the IMF doesn't 'impose' anything. It 'negotiates' the conditions for receiving aid. But all the power in the negotiations is on one side - the IMF - and the fund rarely allows sufficient time for broad consensus-building or even consultations with parliaments or civil society. When the IMF decides to assist the country, it dispatches a mission of economists. These economists frequently lack extensive experience in the country; they are more likely to have first-hand knowledge of its five star hotels than of the villages that dot its countryside. They work hard, poring over numbers deep into the night. But their task is impossible. In a period of days or, at most, weeks, they are charged with developing a programme sensitive to the needs of the country. Needless to say, a little number crunching rarely provides adequate insights into the development strategy for an entire nation. Even worse, the number crunching isn't always good. The models that IMF uses are frequently flawed or out of date. Critics accuse the institution of taking a cookie-cutter approach to economics and they are right. Country teams have been known to compose draft reports before visiting. I heard stories of one incident when team members copied large parts of the text for one country's report and transferred them wholesale to another. They might have got away with it, except the 'search and replace' function on the word processor didn't work properly, leaving the original country's name in a few places. Oops. It is not fair to say that IMF economists don't care about developing nations. But the older men who staff the fund - and they are overwhelmingly older men - act as if they are shouldering Rudyard Kipling's white man's burden. IMF experts believe they are brighter, more educated and less politically motivated than the economists in the countries they visit. In fact, the economic leaders from those countries are, in many cases, brighter and better educated than IMF staff, which frequently consists of third-rank students from first-rate universities. Trust me: I've taught at Oxford, MIT, Yale, Stanford and Princeton universities and the IMF almost never succeeded in recruiting any of the best students.

 Spare a thought for Burito Cobaria of the U'wa tribe in the Colombian rainforest, who are fighting to keep US oil giant Oxy off their ancestral land. The intensely spiritual tribe famously sing the world into existence every morning, a point not missed by Vic Coppersmith, of the Earth Love Fund, which raises money for indigenous peoples. Yesterday Burito was wheeled in to a London recording studio, along with Liverpool girl band Jezebel and others. An album with Robbie Williams, All Saints and more should follow.

 Here's Gene Grabowski, a vice-president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, on why we should all eat GM foods: "The activists' ultimate goal is to bring down corporate America. It's an anti-progress agenda and the whole free enterprise system is at stake. Other forces, evil forces, are going to take over." Gene adds that we Europeans should "get down on our knees" thanking God that America was there for us during the war.

 Cheering news for campaigners against excessive use of antibiotics in farm livestock - sales of animal medicines fell for the first time last year. Sales of feed additives generally dropped by a fifth as farmers cut back in response to concerns among the public and scientists that excessive dosing with growth promoting drugs was increasing risks to human health by encouraging superbugs resistant to modern treatments. The industry is also reeling from the suspension of organophosphate sheep dips, amid claims farmers have suffered long-term illness after using them. Sam Black , the new chairman of the National Office of Animal Health, representing most companies in the business, thinks he knows where much of the blame for his industry's problems lies: "There is a balance between animal welfare on the one hand and consumer safety, user safety and environmental safety on the other. And I would suggest the scales have tipped too far."

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Vandals smashed up a launderette on a north London housing estate just hours after it was visited by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to highlight a campaign against anti-social behaviour
fields.body:
It won't wash: Vandals smashed up a launderette on a north London housing estate just hours after it was visited by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to highlight a campaign against anti-social behaviour.

Lack of foresight: Visitors to a clairvoyance festival in Staines, Surrey, found a notice on the door saying the event had been cancelled due to unforeseen circumstances.

Dirty pictures: A woman who sent off a film to be developed of her sister's wedding in Faversham, Kent, got back photographs of two women mud wrestlers.

Let's dance, baby: An expectant mother who wanted a natural birth chose to belly dance during labour at a Swansea hospital rather than have an epidural injection.

Argy bhajis: Undercover police officers in Gloucester are dining late at night in Indian and Chinese restaurants as part of an operation to crack down on customers who make racist remarks to staff.

Mail shot: Two teenage boys from Ipswich tried to blackmail their school into giving them a 'donation' of £199 by threatening to tell environmental health officers its kitchens were infested with cockroaches.

Brothers grim: Three young brothers who built a tree house at their home in Hordle, Hampshire, have been ordered by the local council to knock it down because they didn't get planning permission.

Deadly accurate: A keen gardener from Blackpool hates slugs so much that she has kept a tally of every one she has killed - all 94,026 of them.

Sounds suspicious: Regulars at a pub in Rayleigh, Essex, can ring their spouses from a customised phone box that produces sound effects such as keyboards being tapped or trains trundling over tracks.

Animal instinct: Burglars who broke into a house in Northampton fed the owner's two cats a meal of trout and shrimps before making off with electrical items and jewellery worth £1,600.

Family trait: Two parents were fined in their absence when they did not appear in court at Bury, Greater Manchester, to face summonses over the failure of their children to attend school regularly.

On yer bikes: Police in Hull are giving unclaimed lost and stolen bicycles to unemployed people so they can get to job interviews.

Art breakers: Cleaners wiped a newly-painted 25-foot mural off the wall of a youth centre in Aberdeen because they thought it was graffiti.

Browned off: The owner of a fish and chip shop in Winsford, Cheshire, has installed two sunbeds in an attempt to lure back customers who have been going to a local health club.

fields.headline: Happy days
fields.standfirst: Kate Mierins on a project that organises breaks, home or away, for children in care
fields.trailText: Kate Mierins on a project that organises breaks, home or away, for children in care
fields.body:
Giving holidays away? Free? What's the catch?" That's what I heard recently from a social worker who works with children in residential care homes.

When I started at the Family Holiday Association a year ago, I shared his incredulity. The FHA's director, Jenny Stephenson, had agreed to take on the challenge of turning a dream into reality: the dream of John Carter - at the time, the face of TV's Wish You Were Here - to offer a holiday to every child looked after in residential care homes by UK local authorities in the year 2000. The project was called Time2Care.

With the help of a well-known travel industry personality, Jeremy Muller, and the Abta president, Steven Freudmann, all the country's best known tour operators, including Airtours, Cosmos, First Choice, JMC, Panorama and Thomson, responded magnficently to the Time2Care appeal, as did PGL Adventure Holidays, British Holidays, and the Football Trust (for football holidays). Astonishingly, enough holidays for about 7,000 young people and carers have been donated, and Lunn Poly have dedicated a special bookings service free of charge.

The Association of Train Operating Companies, representing 25 different rail companies, also stepped in to offer, for the first time, national support for a charitable project, giving all Time2Care participants free rail travel to their holiday. And Travel & Personal Underwriters and Citybond set up a free travel insurance scheme.

National childcare organisations and the children and families committee of the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) responded with a mix of scepticism and, you guessed it, incredulity. But advice and support were readily on offer, especially from Gene Hill, on behalf of the ADSS. As a result, six pilot trips were staged, which quickly convinced all concerned of the huge benefits to be gained by participants.

When most of us think about getting away, we take it for granted that we're able to have a break, see new sights, travel with friends or family and take time out to rest, to become ourselves again.

For children who have been taken into local authority care because of family illness, abuse, psychiatric or behavioural difficulties at home, a holiday is not something they take for granted. In fact, there is no national standard of holiday provision for children in care homes.

On Time2Care pilot trips, I've seen young people from Leicester, Croydon and Northumberland touching and tasting the Mediterranean for the first time - in fact, one young person asked when the sea shut. They've been caravanning, had an activity holiday, stayed in a hotel and visited a theme park in France, just like everyone else.

After one pilot trip, a young person asked about how to train to become a kiddies' rep, while the whole group returned from Ibiza to school last September, proud to tell their schoolmates that they'd had a holiday abroad.

The social workers involved in the pilot trips see Time2Care as an opportunity to enhance their working relationships with the young people in their care. Others see it as a chance to assess their behaviour in a new and stimulating environment. And the Department of Health is assessing how a Time2Care holiday can contribute to promoting the health and educational objectives of children's services.

The public has responded to national press coverage about Time2Care in the most heart-warming ways. Private holiday homes, cottages and villas around the UK and Europe have been offered, so that social workers can take breaks with children who need a short quiet break at the last minute.

I got a call from a social worker in Northumberland recently, asking for a weekend caravanning break for a 13 year old and two social workers - the circumstances were pretty bad, but a few hours later they had a free luxury caravan for the weekend, with free passes to the activity park thrown in. Now that's generosity.

So, what's the catch? I can't find one. Except that the Time2Care offer from tour operators is linked to holiday availability - and the choices have been running out since January. So if you know any young people in residential care homes who could do with a free holiday this year, contact Time2Care on 0207-636 7563 or through our website at www.fhaonline.org.uk or send a 50p SAE for an information pack to Time2Care, Family Holiday Association, 16 Mortimer Street, London, W1N 7RD.

fields.headline: Seeds of doom
fields.standfirst: Sue Branford and  Nicole Freris on the latest scourge of Brazil's Indian lands: the humble soya bean
fields.trailText: Sue Branford and Nicole Freris on the latest scourge of Brazil's Indian lands: the humble soya bean
fields.body:
We were travelling in a rickety Brazilian bus on the way from Boa Vista, the capital of Roraima, in the north of the Amazon basin, to the Venezuelan frontier. Through the dust-covered window, we caught a glimpse of what appeared to be a small field of soya beans, Brazil's main export crop. "Yes, that's what it is," said a fellow passenger. "They're telling us it's going to be the wonder crop for our state. I might try it next year."

The process of change the Portuguese initiated is gathering momentum for a final, definitive assault on the Amazon basin. The globalised market is reaching one of its final outposts. Agribusiness is replacing the subsistence agriculture practised by Indians and peasant families, and monoculture is taking the place of diversity.

This process is supported by the Brazilian authorities. Three years ago, when he was in Manaus to open the Madeira-Amazon waterway, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso said: "This project will produce a new cycle of development for the region. From now on, Amazonia has to develop its agriculture and send its crops all over the world."

The crop that is spearheading the new development is soya beans. Over the past five years, soya farmers have moved, quietly but very rapidly, into the Amazon basin from the south. These farmers have already devastated much of the savannah and transitional rainforest of Mato Grosso.

At the front of the soya invasion is a tiny elite of extremely powerful Brazilian farmers, closely allied with local politicians. Their leader is 72-year-old Andre Maggi, the largest soya farmer in the world. In 1984, he visited a remote region inhabited by the Paresi Indians. "I realised straightaway," he said, "that, because of its location and its conditions, the Chapada dos Parecis could produce the cheapest soya beans in the world."

Largely as a result of Maggi's pioneering activities, Mato Grosso is fast becoming the most important soya growing region in Brazil. To help the farmers, the Brazilian government is constructing a vast network of waterways which will allow the beans to be transported by barge along the tributaries of the Amazon and then by bulk carrier out through the Amazon estuary to Europe and Japan. Ever quick to spot a new market opportunity, two of the world's largest trading companies, Cargill and ADM, are building new port facilities at Santarem, a town on the Amazon river.

The soya expansion is harming Indian communities. In 1998, the Maggi Group decided to shorten the export route for its soyabeans by building a 1,000-km road from Mato Grosso to the Madeira river. Illegally, part of the road crossed the reserve of the remote Enawene Nawe Indians, who number just 300. Soon after the building of the road, several Enawene Nawe died of pneumonia, a disease previously unknown. The women are begin ning to buy cotton for their weaving, instead of growing it. Aluminium pots are replacing the hand-made, clay ones.

Mining and oil companies, loggers and tourist operators have arrived, along with the soya farmers. And the difference in mentality between the pre-Columbian Indians and the modern farmers could not be more marked. The Indians built their civilisation on the rhythm of nature. Each year, a huge area of the Amazon basin floods. This flooding replenishes the soils, killing weeds and pathogens. The Indians always grew their staple foods on the newly enriched soils.

In contrast, today's soya farmers destroy the natural ecosystems and, through an arsenal of chemical inputs, impose their own mono culture. The forest is clear-cut and burnt, and the soil is sprayed with an insecticide, a fungicide and a herbicide. This kind of farming has a devastating impact on the environment. Harvests are beginning to decline as the soil loses its nutrients and crops become increasingly vulnerable to disease. Agrochemicals are seeping into the rivers, causing the loss of some fish species as well as the appearance of deformed fish.

With animals and birds being hunted into near-extinction, much of the forest is becoming eerily quiet. Within a few decades, the extraordinary diversity of the Amazon, with its unknown Indian tribes, its uncharted rivers and its teeming biodiversity, will have been lost for ever.

 This is an edited version of an article to be published in the May edition of the Ecologist.
