fields.headline: Listening to the pain
fields.standfirst: Sharing grief with a stranger can be healing, reports Pat Hagan
fields.trailText: Sharing grief with a stranger can be healing, reports Pat Hagan
fields.body:
They wore plain clothes and barely uttered a word. But when two policemen knocked on Mary Mitchell's door one morning in March 1990, she knew instinctively that tragedy had arrived to turn her life upside down. "They always say you know there's bad news coming," says Mitchell, a 40-year-old mother of two from Edinburgh. "When the police officers came in I said, 'She's dead, isn't she? He's killed her'."

Hours earlier, they confirmed, Mitchell's older sister Linda had been murdered by her estranged husband in an act of astonishing brutality.

In full view of their young son, he stabbed her 52 times as she returned to her car from the playground having completed the morning school run. He was jailed for life.

"They had only been married four months but had been together four years," Mitchell recalls. "She had left him because he had become very violent after they got wed." Ten years on, Mitchell's manner is composed and her voice is steady as she describes the trauma and emotion that engulfed her. But at the time, she says, her world "fell apart".

The pain was impervious to the comfort and kind words of friends and well-wishers and, thrust into a new role as de facto head of the family, she began to despair that she would ever get the chance to grieve properly.

Then she found the prop she needed. Under the heading "bereavement", Yellow Pages gave details of Cruse Bereavement Care - an agency dedicated to helping those left to cope with the aftermath of death. It was the beginning of a new chapter in her life in which she became so convinced of the benefits of bereavement counselling that she ended up as a fully trained Cruse counsellor herself - specialising in helping those affected by murder.

The demand for the services of organisations like Cruse - the largest bereavement charity in the UK - is rising. In some parts of the country, the number of people approaching it for help has risen by over 100% in the past 10 years. Another 100% rise is predicted in the next five years.

Society, it appears, has a growing need for a shoulder to cry on that will provide the emotional safety net once considered an integral part of the extended family and local community. Support groups are becoming increasingly specialised, customising their services to meet the nature of the bereavement- be it, for example, cot death, cancer or leukaemia.

Sharing your grief with a total stranger might once have seemed inappropriate, even odd. Now, according to some, it is seen as a positive advantage. "People kept saying things like, 'Oh, in time it will be OK.' But I didn't want any of their advice - I just wanted someone to listen. Every time I spoke to someone, my friends or neighbours, they tried to change it for the better," says Mitchell.

Within two days of contacting Cruse, she had a face-to-face meeting with a trained volunteer.

"I was in my own home. I could make a cup of tea if I wanted. I didn't have to be strong - I could just be me. I was crying a lot but I wasn't told everything would be fine. I was allowed to swear and get angry. I even asked for a cuddle."

According to some, this need for outside agencies to help us cope with death reflects the long-term fragmentation of traditional networks within society, as well as progress in medical science: falling mortality rates mean people have became less exposed to death.

"Child death is much less common than it used to be and many people tell us that the first bereavement they experience is in middle age," says Cruse's executive director, Dr Carole Easton. "They don't always need counselling, but are simply unsure how to respond, not only to their own bereavement but other people's as well.

"If people need to talk, then a stranger can sometimes be easier than someone you know. That's because you don't have to protect them from the way you feel. If you are talking to someone in your family, there comes a point where you think, 'If I go on like this, I'll make them upset too'."

According to Dr Jane Littlewood, from the department of social policy and politics at the University of London's Goldsmith College, death has become increasingly institutionalised. As a result, society has lost many of the skills it once had for coping with grief.

"A hundred years ago, if a baby died there would be two or three women in the same street who would have had a similar experience. But these days the child mortality rate is much less."

For a long time after her sister's death, Mitchell could not even bring herself to say the words "murder", "dead" or "knifed". Now, she is the rock on which others bereaved by murder lean for support.

 Cruse Bereavement Care can be contacted on 020-8940 4818.

fields.headline: Bitter pills to swallow
fields.standfirst: The jury is still out on whether the national institute for clinical excellence is the patients' champion or the bean counters' friend. A year after its much-trumpeted launch, Sarah Boseley talks to the chief executive with a tough balancing act
fields.trailText: The jury is still out on whether the national institute for clinical excellence is the patients' champion or the bean counters' friend. A year after its much-trumpeted launch, Sarah Boseley talks to the chief executive with a tough balancing act
fields.body:
It's a year now since Nice was launched in an atmosphere of frenzied expectation, full of hopes on some sides and fears on the other. What was this beast, the national institute for clinical excellence? A stealthy government-driven rationing machine or a humane and kindly uncle that would ensure all patients got the best new drugs by stamping out pernicious postcode prescribing?

Nice has so far produced only three judgments - the fast-tracked rejection of the anti-flu drug Relenza and, lately, guidance on hip joints and the removal of wisdom teeth. And since it has promised to look again, with less haste and more evidence, at Relenza in the summer, there is little we can conclude from that episode.

But crunch time is fast approach ing. Nice will shortly confront some of the biggest challenges it is likely ever to have to face when it publishes its verdict on the taxanes - the family of cancer drugs of which so much is expected by patients - and then beta interferon, which is the only drug that has any effect on multiple sclerosis sufferers.

The stakes are high. Patient groups are ready to damn Nice to perdition if they are not allowed the medicines they want on the NHS, while health authorities are consumed with worry about the possible consequences to their budgets. And don't imagine that the government is watching with equanimity.

At the heart of it, preparing to defend Nice to the hilt and deflect flak from the clinicians who must take the decisions, is Andrew Dillon, the chief executive. Some might think his job unenviable. He says it's great.

"There's huge enthusiasm here for what we're doing because it is something really important for the NHS," he says. "There's nobody who works here who doesn't come into it with their eyes open. All of the pressures, all of the influences on the process, are evident.

"The good thing about what we're doing is that we don't pretend the pressure is not there. And we're as clear as we honestly can be, based on our experience so far, as to how we're going to handle it to produce something that does have integrity, that does have value for the NHS."

He believes in transparency and openness. Cynics might say that is the only way to survive as piggy-in-the-middle between powerful vested interests such as the government and the pharmaceutical industry.

But Dillon is convinced that the appraisal committee - the high-powered group of scientists who must make a cost-effectiveness judgment on controversial new medicines and technologies - will not be swayed. They will make their decisions on the evidence, he says repeatedly, and will defuse the critics by being open about the way they came to their verdict.

"The one thing we've got to show is that we're consistent in the way we approach the analysis of the evidence and that we can show an audit trail that takes you from the evidence that we considered through to the decision that goes out," he insists. "We've got to be able to show how it's possible and appropriate to get from the evidence to the decision. And then we have to explain it."

But Nice's remit is not only clinical effectiveness, but cost effectiveness. So will it not be nothing more than a rationing mechanism? What about those hints in the early days from Sir Michael Rawlings, the chair, that Nice would have to live in the real world and cut its cloth according to NHS budgets? Will Nice take into account the amount of money the government is willing to spend on a new drug when it makes its decisions?

Dillon says the views of the Department of Health and of the national assembly for Wales must be taken into account during the consultation process - but only in the same way as the views of any other interested party.

"Half way through the process, we've got a draft of the appraisal and we send that out to patient groups and manufacturers and the department of health," Dillon explains. "So the department has, entirely appropriately, an opportunity to influence - just as everybody else does - the nature of the appraisal that comes out."

He denies that ministers' views might weigh more heavily than others - but the reality is that the department holds the purse strings.

So far, the government has not indicated that it has any spending limits in respect of the first 20 appraisals it has requested of Nice, says Dillon, but he accepts that it may happen.

"I don't know whether the department would, in any particular circumstances, be so specific as to say that there's a fixed amount - a net total increase - for this particular technology, but any of us can envisage circumstances in which they might, because no healthcare system can write a blank cheque," he admits. "They would know in the consultation process what it's likely to cost. The department would then be in a position to make an assumption about the impact that's going to have on their responsibility to make sure that all services are available to patients."

He could see the government asking whether a new drug might be restricted to the group of patients it would most benefit - which is what Frank Dobson unilaterally decided to do with Viagra. Or perhaps the government, he ponders optimistically, might consider making more money available.

The fact is, he acknowledges, that he is thinking on his feet about the way the process will work "because we don't really have any experience of it at all".

The sticky moments have not yet arrived. The crunch decisions have yet to be made. But it becomes clear in conversation that the absolute objectivity, the demonstrable scientific logic of the process that Dillon likes to emphasise are not the end of the story.

"The appraisal committee will be aware of the department's view, which, in an individual case, might be a view on the ability of the health service to afford what seems to be the emerging guidance," he says. "The committee members have got that information in front of them. So that view is one of a whole series of influences on the committee's thinking. The point of having the appraisal committee - this group of 24 people - is to enable the inevitably very human judgment to be made about how particular technology should be applied."

And so we have the human factor. Ministers will not be the only source of pressure. Other forceful influences will be brought to bear on the committee from patients who may be dying or hope for a better quality of life in the short time they have left. A new drug may offer them an extra year - at a huge cost to the NHS. But what price a year of life? It isn't difficult to anticipate the headlines.

"The committee members are human beings like you and me and like the editors of newspapers and have exactly the same thoughts about precisely that issue," Dillon says. "What they can do is combine that very human thinking and very human sensitivity to what it actually means to get this clinical benefit - they can add to that from their very specific skills and experience.

"So they can arrive at a judgment that can be seen to be informed by the evidence of clinical trials, but turned into advice for the institute by people who can themselves make the judgments human beings can make about benefit. And that simply can't be made on the basis of numbers crunched by a machine."

Whether that will wear with the patient groups if their drug is refused Nice's blessing for supply on the NHS is another matter, but Dillon is hopeful.

"By deliberately and genuinely trying to be open and inclusive, I think we've got to the point where patient groups are prepared to give us a go," he says. "They are sufficiently persuaded of the way we are doing things to take part in it. They haven't rejected the whole concept of Nice."

fields.bodyText: It's a year now since Nice was launched in an atmosphere of frenzied expectation, full of hopes on some sides and fears on the other. What was this beast, the national institute for clinical excellence? A stealthy government-driven rationing machine or a humane and kindly uncle that would ensure all patients got the best new drugs by stamping out pernicious postcode prescribing? Nice has so far produced only three judgments - the fast-tracked rejection of the anti-flu drug Relenza and, lately, guidance on hip joints and the removal of wisdom teeth. And since it has promised to look again, with less haste and more evidence, at Relenza in the summer, there is little we can conclude from that episode. But crunch time is fast approach ing. Nice will shortly confront some of the biggest challenges it is likely ever to have to face when it publishes its verdict on the taxanes - the family of cancer drugs of which so much is expected by patients - and then beta interferon, which is the only drug that has any effect on multiple sclerosis sufferers. The stakes are high. Patient groups are ready to damn Nice to perdition if they are not allowed the medicines they want on the NHS, while health authorities are consumed with worry about the possible consequences to their budgets. And don't imagine that the government is watching with equanimity. At the heart of it, preparing to defend Nice to the hilt and deflect flak from the clinicians who must take the decisions, is Andrew Dillon, the chief executive. Some might think his job unenviable. He says it's great. "There's huge enthusiasm here for what we're doing because it is something really important for the NHS," he says. "There's nobody who works here who doesn't come into it with their eyes open. All of the pressures, all of the influences on the process, are evident. "The good thing about what we're doing is that we don't pretend the pressure is not there. And we're as clear as we honestly can be, based on our experience so far, as to how we're going to handle it to produce something that does have integrity, that does have value for the NHS." He believes in transparency and openness. Cynics might say that is the only way to survive as piggy-in-the-middle between powerful vested interests such as the government and the pharmaceutical industry. But Dillon is convinced that the appraisal committee - the high-powered group of scientists who must make a cost-effectiveness judgment on controversial new medicines and technologies - will not be swayed. They will make their decisions on the evidence, he says repeatedly, and will defuse the critics by being open about the way they came to their verdict. "The one thing we've got to show is that we're consistent in the way we approach the analysis of the evidence and that we can show an audit trail that takes you from the evidence that we considered through to the decision that goes out," he insists. "We've got to be able to show how it's possible and appropriate to get from the evidence to the decision. And then we have to explain it." But Nice's remit is not only clinical effectiveness, but cost effectiveness. So will it not be nothing more than a rationing mechanism? What about those hints in the early days from Sir Michael Rawlings, the chair, that Nice would have to live in the real world and cut its cloth according to NHS budgets? Will Nice take into account the amount of money the government is willing to spend on a new drug when it makes its decisions? Dillon says the views of the Department of Health and of the national assembly for Wales must be taken into account during the consultation process - but only in the same way as the views of any other interested party. "Half way through the process, we've got a draft of the appraisal and we send that out to patient groups and manufacturers and the department of health," Dillon explains. "So the department has, entirely appropriately, an opportunity to influence - just as everybody else does - the nature of the appraisal that comes out." He denies that ministers' views might weigh more heavily than others - but the reality is that the department holds the purse strings. So far, the government has not indicated that it has any spending limits in respect of the first 20 appraisals it has requested of Nice, says Dillon, but he accepts that it may happen. "I don't know whether the department would, in any particular circumstances, be so specific as to say that there's a fixed amount - a net total increase - for this particular technology, but any of us can envisage circumstances in which they might, because no healthcare system can write a blank cheque," he admits. "They would know in the consultation process what it's likely to cost. He could see the government asking whether a new drug might be restricted to the group of patients it would most benefit - which is what Frank Dobson unilaterally decided to do with Viagra. Or perhaps the government, he ponders optimistically, might consider making more money available. The fact is, he acknowledges, that he is thinking on his feet about the way the process will work "because we don't really have any experience of it at all". The sticky moments have not yet arrived. The crunch decisions have yet to be made. But it becomes clear in conversation that the absolute objectivity, the demonstrable scientific logic of the process that Dillon likes to emphasise are not the end of the story. "The appraisal committee will be aware of the department's view, which, in an individual case, might be a view on the ability of the health service to afford what seems to be the emerging guidance," he says. "The committee members have got that information in front of them. So that view is one of a whole series of influences on the committee's thinking. The point of having the appraisal committee - this group of 24 people - is to enable the inevitably very human judgment to be made about how particular technology should be applied." And so we have the human factor. Ministers will not be the only source of pressure. Other forceful influences will be brought to bear on the committee from patients who may be dying or hope for a better quality of life in the short time they have left. A new drug may offer them an extra year - at a huge cost to the NHS. But what price a year of life? It isn't difficult to anticipate the headlines. "The committee members are human beings like you and me and like the editors of newspapers and have exactly the same thoughts about precisely that issue," Dillon says. "What they can do is combine that very human thinking and very human sensitivity to what it actually means to get this clinical benefit - they can add to that from their very specific skills and experience. "So they can arrive at a judgment that can be seen to be informed by the evidence of clinical trials, but turned into advice for the institute by people who can themselves make the judgments human beings can make about benefit. fields.headline: Biting wind of change
fields.standfirst: As the long-awaited disability rights commission is launched today, Liza Ramrayka meets the new leader, a man determined to make discrimination unacceptable
fields.trailText: As the long-awaited disability rights commission is launched today, Liza Ramrayka meets the new leader, a man determined to make discrimination unacceptable
fields.body:
Bert Massie is in bullish mood. "There isn't a single job in this country that a disabled person could not do," he states confidently. And as chair of the new disability rights commission, launched today, his job is to make sure this message reaches everyone - from employers to government- whose decisions affect the UK's 8.7m disabled people.

Massie, an experienced disability rights lobbyist, is hoping to use his powers of persuasion in his new role at the disability equivalent of the commission for racial equality. He and a team of 15 commissioners will work in partnership with a range of organisations to help eliminate discrimination against disabled people. Key to the DRC's brief will be enforcing the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA) 1995, which makes it illegal for employers and service providers like shops and restaurants to refuse or limit disabled people's access to goods or services because of their disability.

Like the CRE, the DRC is an independent public body funded by government. With an annual budget of £11m, it will open for business next Tuesday and will provide information and advice to employers, businesses and disabled people via case workers, a helpline and a website. It will also arrange conciliation, conduct research and bring discrimination cases.

As a wheelchair user himself due to childhood polio, Massie is acutely aware of how discrimination can affect the opportunities open to disabled people. "When I first started work in this field 30 years ago, it was quite normal to be turned away from cinemas and restaurants," he says. "And as for transport, forget it. If you took the train, you'd end up in the guard's van."

Massie acknowledges that much has changed since then. Driven in part by the DDA, public transport and buildings are becoming more accessible. Massie's own offices in London's Gray's Inn Road feature a PA system to broadcast office messages and bright red chairs chosen for their high visibility. But he is far from complacent. "There's still a long way to go and the biggest challenge will be getting people to ditch their prejudices and think creatively," he says.

This situation is not helped by the fact that the DDA only covers companies with 15 or more employees, which means around 90% of employers are currently exempt. And while the legislation covers providers of goods and services, it does not yet apply to schools and further or higher education, the police, fire and armed services or prisons.

But if the DDA was a "toothless poodle", as its critics claimed, Massie says the DRC intends to show it has real bite. If advice and conciliation don't work, the DRC has the power to represent individuals or organisations in court or to launch a formal investigation into any industry it believes is discriminating against disabled people. "We will start by using the force of argument," Massie says. "If that fails, we will use the argument of force."

While he hopes the DRC's work will prevent discrimination occurring, Massie says some people are best educated by being hit in the wallet. "What I don't want is for people to think we're a soft touch because we don't go to court," he says. "I've been a lobbyist too long to let that happen."

Massie, 50, began his career in disability rights in the1960s when he joined the campaign to get rid of the invalid car.

A Liverpudlian, he ran the local Phab club for disabledpeople and worked for the Liverpool Association for the Disabled. In 1978, he joined the London-based disability network, Radar, and became its director in 1990. Massie has worked with fellow civil rights campaigners to secure accessible taxis from 2012 and to negotiate an extra £195m from the government's New Deal programme to help disabled people on incapacity benefit into work.

As a member of the disability rights taskforce, he helped to draft the DDA regulations relating to service providers. These projects, he says, have given him extensive experience of collaborative working.

As well as liaising with disability charities, the DRC intends to work closely with the CRE and the equal opportunities commission to develop joint guidance materials on equal opportunity issues for employers and providers of goods and services. The DRC's information team and case workers will share office space with the EOC in Manchester, providing an opportunity to develop their relationship and share resources.

But despite being the new kid on the block, the DRC, Massie believes, will have some advantages over its sister councils, which were both set up in the 1970s.

"Whereas they were almost setting things up from scratch, we already have a large number and wide range of disability organisations, so we're not starting with an entirely blank sheet of paper," he explains.

But the DRC will share the same vision as its trailblazing sister councils. Massie warns: "We will make discrimination unacceptable, and make people realise exactly what we mean by discrimination."

 The DRC helpline number, from next Tuesday, is 0345-622633.

fields.headline: Access to justice
fields.standfirst: David Grayson argues that the DRC must develop a light touch - without becoming a soft touch
fields.trailText: David Grayson argues that the DRC must develop a light touch - without becoming a soft touch
fields.body:
The HIV-positive store manager dismissed by his employers because they feared his illness would put off customers. The deaf student unable to attend lectures because the lecturer refused to wear a radio mike. A deafblind person told that "people like you should not be travelling on a bus". There is no shortage of discrimination in Britain 2000 for the DRC to get its teeth into.

But the commission is starting life at a time when there is considerable caution both inside and outside government about too much regulation of business. Ministers have spoken of the DRC operating with a "light touch" - which must not be confused with being a soft touch - so it will have to use as many non-legal levers as possible to achieve its goal of ending discrimination against disabled people in Britain.

Last year, the forerunner of the DRC, the national disability council, commissioned the Demos think tank to identify what some of these levers might be. Ideas include:

 Exploiting advances in information and communications technologies. The commission could persuade a leading company to second a technology director to enable it to negotiate with the sector, electronic media, government and regulators on disability access.

 Tapping into the growing interest in socially responsible business behaviour, making disability a more integral part of this agenda.

 Taking advantage of the modernisation of government. A vocal and well-organised disability lobby could be a powerful force in compelling candidates for mayor of London and, subsequently, other cities to articulate disabled-friendly policies if they want the votes of disabled people.

 Building strategic alliances, or what the Demos report describes as "mutualism", so that in debates about the revitalisation of town centres, for instance, the commission could pilot the idea of disability access partnerships - analogous to local crime prevention or business/education partnerships - bringing together councils, town centre management associations, chambers of commerce and disability access committees to create "beacon" localities.

Such levers are not alternatives to effective laws, firmly enforced. Businesses and other providers of goods and services should be left in no doubt that those who persistently and knowingly discriminate against disabled people will be pilloried and made subject to effective legal sanctions.

We must, though, inspire employers and businesses to go beyond the legal minimum. I very much hope the DRC will follow the precept of, in descending order: educate, conciliate, litigate. And I hope the greater part of its budget and energies will start with the education role, taking test cases only when other channels have been exhausted.

The goal should be to inspire major companies not just to be exemplars in their own practice, but to promote this expertise to other organisations. Our aim should be that, by 2020, Britain will be the best place in the world for a disabled person to live. This means benchmarking us internationally in terms of education, employment, physical access, sense of inclusion and access to information. It will require a substantial and continuing research programme - well beyond DRC resources. The commission will, therefore, have to persuade one or more foundations to make research into disability issues one of its key themes - just as the Joseph Rowntree Foundation has in housing and community development.

The commission must be "fit for purpose for the 21st century", involving different stakeholders and making full use of the latest technologies, such as an interactive website. Bert Massie and other commissioners could be regularly interviewed live on the website; and it could also carry "town meetings" with commissioners around the country.

The DRC has to be an exemplar in its own operations. It might offer prestigious internships for talented young disabled people to work with it for six or 12 months, rather like stagiares at the EU Commission or White House interns. And its efforts must lead to significant and measurable improvements in the lives of disabled people. This could involve it commissioning an annual survey of how disabled people feel about key areas such as hospitals, schools and pubs.

Whatever the justice of our cause, getting "airtime" with media and policy-makers will only be achieved through constant, intensive networking; high-quality research and powerful arguments, well presented; and addressing the widespread ignorance and fear which exists about the Disability Discrimination Act and the problems which millions of disabled people face in our daily lives.

This means a DRC which is an organisation of disabled people, but equally one about which business will say: "These people are tough but fair; they talk our language; they understand our concerns and the issues we face; they are people we can do business with; and what's more, they have inspired us so that we want to do more - even though we know it will require us to change a great deal."

 David Grayson has chaired the national disability council since its inception in 1996. He is a director of Business in the Community and was last week appointed to the board of the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority, where he will particularly monitor disability access.

webTitle: Mother says boy hanged himself after 'goldfish' jibe by teacher

fields.headline: Mother says boy hanged himself after 'goldfish' jibe by teacher
fields.trailText: A boy of 12 hanged himself with a dressing gown cord after handing his mother a school report card which said he had the "attention span of a goldfish", an inquest in Leeds heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A boy of 12 hanged himself with a dressing gown cord after handing his mother a school report card which said he had the "attention span of a goldfish", an inquest in Leeds heard yesterday.

Daniel Overfield had been upset by the remark by an art teacher at Corpus Christi high school in Leeds. He hanged himself from his bunk bed last November.

Daniel's mother, Theresa, from Osmondthorpe, Leeds, said in a statement read to the inquest: "I think the comment by the teacher was totally inappropriate and could have been a factor in the incident. Dan is the only person who knows the real reasons, but I cannot think of anything else to explain his actions."

The inquest heard that Daniel was a "bright, active and likeable" boy who achieved good results in most of his subjects.

Mrs Overfield said: "His wish was that if he died we should donate his organs for transplant to give someone else a chance of life. He was such a generous, giving boy, so we allowed the transplant of his organs."

He had been in trouble at school and had been placed on report. The coroner, David Hinchliff, was told that Daniel disliked art.

As well as the comment on his attention span, his report card had two crosses which counted towards detention, although Daniel's headteacher had told him not to worry about them.

After Mrs Overfield found Daniel hanging, ambulance crews resuscitated him, but he died in Leeds general infirmary four days later having suffered irreversible brain damage.

Mr Hinchliff said the criticism and the possibility of a detention could have been preying on Daniel's mind, but he could not believe he had deliberately tried to kill himself. "It might have been to draw attention to himself." He recorded a verdict of death by misadventure.

Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said teachers faced a dilemma in judging their comments to children.

The teacher in this case "had no remote conception that he might have been writing out a death sentence".

webTitle: Farmer not guilty of attempted murder

fields.headline: Farmer not guilty of attempted murder
fields.standfirst: Profile: the gypsy-hating loner who shot to kill.
fields.trailText: Farmer Tony Martin was today found not guilty of the attempted murder of Brendan Fearon during an attempted break-in at his Norfolk farm in August 1999.
fields.body:
Farmer Tony Martin was today found not guilty of the attempted murder of Brendan Fearon during an attempted break-in at his Norfolk farm in August 1999.

Jurors at Norwich crown court also found Mr Martin not guilty of possessing a weapon with intent to endanger life. However, after seven hours of deliberations they told the judge they had been unable to reach a unanimous verdict on the remaining charges of the murder of Fred Barras and wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm.

Mr Martin, 55, is accused of murdering Mr Barras during an attempted break-in by Mr Barras, 16, and Mr Fearon, 30, at Bleak House, his isolated farm near Emneth. Mr Fearon was shot and seriously wounded in the incident; Mr Barras was shot in the back and found dead the following afternoon.

The judge told the jurors that they could return majority verdicts on the outstanding charges. A verdict is expected later this afternoon.

fields.headline: Tackling London's transport problems
fields.standfirst: The main London mayoral candidates' promises and policies
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson, Labour
fields.body:
Frank Dobson, Labour

Underground
As the official Labour candidate, Frank Dobson supports the government's policy of public-private partnership (PPP) for funding London Underground, but he will lobby central government for an extra £2.5bn, to finance a £7bn improvement to the Tube. He will set Tube performance targets and sack senior managers if they are not met. He also promises no "real terms" increase in ticket prices.

Roads
Rules out congestion charges in his first, four-year term, but remains cautiously in favour of the "stick" of road pricing once the "carrot" of public transport has been improved.

Buses
Free bus passes for under-18s.

Air
Will await the outcome of the public inquiry into the building of Heathrow Terminal 5 before deciding whether to back the project, although the decision whether to build it will be taken by central government.

Steven Norris, Conservative

Underground
Steven Norris has promised not to increase fares above inflation and wants to introduce a raft of measures to improve services including a 24-hour Tube (beginning with 24-hour opening on Fridays and Saturdays), phonecard-style electronic stored value tickets, refurbished air-conditioned trains, the reopening of public toilets on the Underground, an end to penalty fares and discount fares to encourage better use of the Tube at off-peak hours. In the long term, he backs the construction of a Chelsea-Hackney line.

Roads
Opposes congestion charges for motorists, but promises to "invest real resources in physically separating cyclists from road traffic" and doubling the number of London journeys by bicycle to 4% by 2004.

Buses
Promises a 70p flat fare for all bus journeys in London and the retention of conductors where they currently operate on Routemaster buses. Hopes to speed up services by ending drivers taking fares, with improved bus stops issuing tickets in advance. He also wants to improve the efficiency of bus lanes and allow motorcycles to use them.

Air
In favour of Heathrow Terminal 5.

Susan Kramer, Liberal Democrat

Underground
The Liberal Democrat candidate favours raising money through bonds to improve the Tube. Susan Kramer argues that, unlike Ken Livingstone, she will not be forced to change this policy, because bond-financing is a Lib Dem policy. She claims that her party's bonds policy will be £1bn cheaper than PPP on a total deal of £7bn. She promises to freeze tube fares in real terms, peg increases to inflation and introduce 24-hour tube travel on Friday and Saturday. She also proposes to help people know when buses and trains are due by delivering transport timetables over mobile phones.

Roads
Promises to introduce congestion charges on cars entering central London during weekday working hours. Says there will be an approximate £5 charge, with large lorries paying three times that amount. Included will be a free zone 1-2 travel card.

Buses
Promises "a carrot and stick approach" to the bus system, introducing permanent bus lanes with strict enforcement and bus priority schemes at junctions, but also a compensation scheme for people who do not get an adequate service. Also pledges a single flat adult fare of 70p and free bus travel on Sundays for her first year in office.

Air
The only candidate, apart from the Green party's Darren Johnson, to clearly oppose Heathrow Terminal 5.

Underground
Has long rejected the government's PPP for funding the modernising the Tube in favour of a public bond issue, similar to that which revitalised New York's subway, but his manifesto will only go so far as to promise to "argue that we should finance the investment needed to modernise the tube by the cheapest possible method, which the evidence indicates is raising bonds backed by a combination of fares and government grant." Mr Livingstone promises to freeze tube fares for four years.

Roads
Hopes to introduce congestion charges by "the middle of my term of office", but promises to "consult widely" about the best possible scheme, with the revenue generated earmarked for improving transport. Schemes previously mooted include a £5 daily charge on cars entering central London between 7am and 7pm. Mr Livingstone aims to reduce road traffic by 15% by 2010.

Buses
Promises to bring back bus conductors on all routes to speed up all services and introduce more, high-speed bus lanes with stiffer penalties if they are blocked. His manifesto commits him to commissioning a study to "investigate the feasibility" of introducing a 70p flat rate bus fare throughout London.

Air
Says Heathrow's Terminal 5 "will be approved". Has previously suggested an extra tax on tourists arriving at London's airports to fund free entry for Londoners into London Zoo and all museums.

webTitle: London fight hits support for mayors

fields.headline: London fight hits support for mayors
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Popular support for directly elected mayors in British cities outside the capital has slumped in the wake of the political battle for London, according to this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
Popular support for directly elected mayors in British cities outside the capital has slumped in the wake of the political battle for London, according to this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

The bitter campaign in London has helped to turn overwhelming majority support in February for directly elected mayors in cities like Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool into a majority firmly opposed to the idea.

The survey also shows that despite the politically difficult issues of Rover and asylum, Labour has actually increased its share of the vote over the month and is up one point on 45% - higher than the share of the vote they took in their historic landslide election victory in May 1997. Tony Blair still enjoys a 13 point lead over the Conservatives who remain unchanged on 32%.

The poll's findings on mayors comes as ministers are pushing through their local government bill which introduces pilot projects for elected mayors with executive powers in major cities. The legislation allows any council to propose a referendum on whether to have an elected mayor, or if 5% of registered voters demand a local poll on the issue.

But it appears that the "Ken and Frank show" in London has left the rest of the country deeply unimpressed with the idea. An ICM poll for the Local Government Network in February showed that 59% wanted the opportunity to directly elect the mayor or council leader of their local authority and 32% did not. This month's ICM poll shows that now only 22% want to have a directly elected mayor and 61% believe that local government should be left as it is.

But ministers can take comfort from the fact that on their first anniversary the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly are beginning to gather popular acceptance throughout Britain. The poll shows that 48% believe they have been a good idea and only 26% think they have not worked.

The Guardian/ICM monthly question on British attitudes towards joining the euro shows that opposition to the single currency remains as strong as ever. Some 63% say they would vote not to join the single european currency if there were a referendum tomorrow, which is up two points from last month.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,203 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between March 14-15 2000. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: We must answer the hard questions about asylum

fields.headline: We must answer the hard questions about asylum
fields.standfirst: Labour won't win if it tries to out-Widdecombe the ToriesRefugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: When it comes to asylum seekers, the right have always had the best tunes. The send 'em all home brigade in Smith Square are again drafting draconian policies to woo middle England. Tory strategists believe that on past form, their plans to lock up all immigrants in army barracks for six weeks will deliver an electoral revival. But the Tories have claimed victory by default on asylum. They have only won in the past because progressive opinion has opted out of the debate. The kneejerk reaction amongst liberals has been to condemn inflammatory language without answering the vexed question of how we deal with the huge increase in asylum applications. Now, the left is finally realising that it needs persuasive policies to counter the prison-camp rhetoric.
fields.body:
When it comes to asylum seekers, the right have always had the best tunes. The send 'em all home brigade in Smith Square are again drafting draconian policies to woo middle England. Tory strategists believe that on past form, their plans to lock up all immigrants in army barracks for six weeks will deliver an electoral revival. But the Tories have claimed victory by default on asylum. They have only won in the past because progressive opinion has opted out of the debate. The kneejerk reaction amongst liberals has been to condemn inflammatory language without answering the vexed question of how we deal with the huge increase in asylum applications. Now, the left is finally realising that it needs persuasive policies to counter the prison-camp rhetoric.

Immigration is always emotive and has real resonance in Labour's heartlands. But however much people complain about it, it isn't one of the bread-and-butter issues that will decide the Blair government's fate. Monthly polls organised by Mori show that only 4% of voters think it is the most important political issue. With political leadership, it should be possible to win on this issue, but Labour urgently needs a clear intellectual case. First, they must resist the kneejerk reaction against foreigners. The current climate treats all newcomers - economic migrant or asylum seeker, bogus or legitimate - as a problem. A new breed of politicians never tire of celebrating multicultural Britain, yet in the same breath, they refer to new refugees as a "burden".

This confusion - mixing up asylum and immigration and failing to develop a coherent approach to either - doesn't just betray our human rights and our history of global links. It fails to see that getting immigration right is vital to our success in the global knowledge economy.

On asylum, the xenophobic right must be prevented from hijacking our history. Our long tradition of providing refuge for the persecuted is often conveniently airbrushed out. Britain's protection of Huguenots persecuted by Louise XIV should be invoked by speech writers as often as the Battle of Britain. The Conservatives' attacks on asylum seekers can be easily resisted by glancing at the biographies of the upper echelons of the party. It's not just that Michael Portillo would not be in Britain today if Anne Widdecombe's policies had been adopted in the 1930s - Nigel Lawson, Leon Brittan and Keith Joseph would never have made it either.

Support for accepting genuine asylum seekers is undermined by a shambolic system which takes 13 months to process an average claim. Last year, Britain had 53% more asylum applications than in 1998 and now receives more than Germany. Numbers have increased tenfold in a decade - from 4,000 in 1989 to 46,000 in 1998 - not because Britain is a "soft touch" but because of the fallout at the end of the cold war. Britain has to fulfil its obligations under international treaties, but there is clearly a limit to the number that can be absorbed. The government should make a clear commitment every three years on the maximum number of asylum seekers - in the absence of a major catastrophe that might require negotiation. As the prime minister argues: "unless reasonable and tolerant people" deal with abuses in the system, the unreasonable and intolerant will seize control.

On immigration, we need to be guided by hardheaded economic analysis rather than the mental hangover of an ethnic colour bar. It is ironic that the tabloid furore has reached fever pitch at the same time that forecasters are calling for an increase in skilled immigrant labour. Economists and demographers are predicting a fiercely competitive international market for the best-educated migrants. Europe will struggle to support its pensioners as life spans stretch and birth rates slow. A dwindling band of young workers will have to pay for the pensions and healthcare of their parents and grandparents. Countries may be forced to offer cash incentives to import young wealth creators from Asia and the third world.

Immigrants have a proven track record of creating wealth wherever they go - and it isn't all down to hard work. Global markets have a constant thirst for new ideas, new products, new recipes, new ways of doing things. Immigrants shake up vested interests, take on bloated corporations and bring about new working practices.

But our negative stereotypes of immigrants stop us harnessing their potential. The tabloid assumption that they sign on the dole within hours of touchdown is replicated by official structures. Asylum seekers are not allowed to enter the employment market while their case is being investigated and the only advice they receive is how to access the social security network. Yet hard working migrants in search of a better life haven't come here to live on a sink estate on £40 a week. Gordon Brown could think about a new deal for immigrants with language training, work experience and advice on setting up a business.

The chancellor claims that 1m jobs are left vacant in the UK. But there has been no systematic attempt to identify where the skill shortages lie. The Department of Trade and Industry could also carry out a national skills audit to find out whom we need and where we need them. We should allow into the country a limited number of economic migrants based on proof of their skills. Canada has created a points system that scores would-be migrants according to their skills and qualifications. Every year 100,000 asylum seekers disappear from the radar screen during the protracted claims process. Most are working as cleaners, waiters and security guards. I have come across mini-cab drivers who are trained engineers, psychiatrists working as builders. We need a route to guide them back into the formal, taxed economy. Yasmin Alibhai-Brown has suggested that immigrants could be guaranteed citizenship if they were willing to use their qualifications.

Other European countries are waking up to the advantages of outsiders. Gerhard Schröder has unveiled a Green Card Scheme - allowing in up to 30,000 IT specialists from India and from European countries outside the EU without the bureaucratic nightmares. The US has been doing this for years. Cricket is now one of the fastest growing sports in Silicon Valley, as Indian programmers set up local teams.

Labour won't win if it tries to out-Widdecombe the Tories. But it can show that the Tories' attempts to wrap themselves in the flag betray this country's history and store up economic problems for the future. Labour's attempt to redefine Britishness will amount to nothing if it fails to inject some sanity into the asylum debate.

 Mark Leonard is director of the Foreign Policy Centre.

Mark@fpc.org.uk

webTitle: 145 Kosovans in mass trial for terrorism

fields.headline: 145 Kosovans in mass trial for terrorism
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The biggest mass trial so far of suspected former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army began in the southern Serbian city of Nis yesterday.
fields.body:
The biggest mass trial so far of suspected former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army began in the southern Serbian city of Nis yesterday.

Traffic was halted in the city as the 145 Albanian defendants, who are charged with terrorist activities, were driven in three buses to the heavily guarded court.

The Albanians, from the Kosovan town of Djakovica, are accused of "organising and participating in terrorist and enemy activities" - including the killing of police officers - against Serbian security forces stationed in Kosovo last year.

The use of the words "terrorist activities" in the indictment indicates that the authorities consider the defendants - mainly young men - to be former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army, which has since been officially disbanded.

Yesterday's proceedings were dominated by the taking of personal details from all 145 defendants: a task defence lawyers said would normally be carried out before the trial. Proceedings are expected to start in earnest today, with verdicts likely later this week.

The defendants were arrested in Djakovica, near the Albanian border, during Nato air strikes a year ago. They were among hundreds of Albanian prisoners held by the Serbian authorities in Kosovo until Belgrade ceded control of the province to Nato last June.

When the Yugoslav army and Serb police withdraw from Kosovo, they took with them more than 2,000 prisoners, mainly Kosovo Albanians charged with terrorism, and moved them to jails elsewhere in Serbia.

A number of prominent Albanians, including the paediatrician and women's activist Flora Brovina, and the student leader Albin Kurti have already been convicted of terrorism and sentenced to long prison terms at trials which drew criticism both locally and abroad.

The UN mission in Kosovo estimates that about 1,500 Kosovo Albanians remain in Serbian jails. International officials have called for them to be returned to Kosovo.

More than 20 lawyers are taking part in the defence of this latest group of Albanians, whose trial is being monitored by human rights activists. The lawyers say that the defendants were held from May to December without being informed of the reasons for their detention.

"This is a political trial through which the Belgrade regime is attempting to cover up the great tragedy it has provoked in Kosovo," said Natasa Kandic of the Humanitarian Law Centre in Belgrade. "These Albanians are innocent civilians who were not involved in armed actions and who were kidnapped on the streets of Djakovica."

The trial comes as Belgrade pursues a creeping clampdown on its opponents in politics and the media. The campaign is likely to be stepped up following an opposition protest rally last Friday for which more than 100,000 people turned out to demand an end to the regime of President Slobodan Milosevic.

The authorities are making full use of the malleable Serbian legal system to try to neutralise voices of dissent.

Opposition activists, former police officers and newspaper editors have all been brought to trial.

The criminal charges are intended to discredit opposition politicians, while heavy fines imposed on newspapers and broadcasters threaten to cripple financially the non-government press.

The control of public opinion in Serbia is vital, since local elections are due to be held by the end of the year.

The authorities have used telecommunications legislation to seize the equipment of a number of radio and television stations, and they are jamming the signal of the influential Studio B television channel in Belgrade, which is controlled by the opposition leader Vuk Draskovic.

Analysts in Belgrade suspect that President Milosevic may try to offer enticements to either Mr Draskovic or another opposition figure to break the newly established but fragile unity of the Serbian opposition.

fields.headline: Remembering Rhodesia
fields.standfirst:
Guardian columnist Simon Hoggart, who covered Rhodesia's transition to independence in 1980, recalls what it was like
Read the piece from 1980
fields.trailText: Guardian columnist Simon Hoggart, who covered Rhodesia's transition to independence in 1980, recalls what it was like.
fields.body:
For those of us who were there in Zimbabwe twenty years ago, it's agonising to see how quickly and steeply the country has descended into poverty, corruption and violence. In those days there was far more optimism than foreboding. The country was rich and fertile. With the Victoria Falls, Kariba and Wankie game park, it was sensationally beautiful and tourism was about to take off.

Race relations could only be thought good if you lived in blinkers, but they certainly lacked the bitterness of apartheid South Africa.

Even at the height of the civil war anyone, white or black, could walk round the capital - then called Salisbury - in perfect safety. Whites had hoped that the first free elections would be won by Bishop Abel Muzorewa, but he was seen as a tool of the white oppressors, and never stood a chance against Robert Mugabe. Even so, whites were prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt. After all, while he called himself a Marxist, he claimed he had learned the lesson of Mozambique, which was not to expel your white farmers.

Well, the farmers know better now. There was always something rather naive, sometimes engagingly so, about Zimbabwe's white people, the lost tribe of Africa. Some, mainly in the towns, were breathtakingly rude to their black employees ("munts" was the favoured term of disparagement), and gave the impression that they didn't even realise how humiliating they were. (Who in their right mind wants to be surrounded by people who detest you?)

The farmers often believed that they were deeply loved by their workers. They pointed to the accommodation, the schools and the full dinner plates and contrasted this comparative comfort and security with the spiralling descent of Zambia, just across the Zambezi.

Even the tiny handful of white Guardian Weekly-reading liberals were horrified at that decay. The distinctly unliberal majority had a simple world-view, expressed by Ian Smith, their spiritual as well as political leader, who told me that the capture of southern Africa was a straightforward communist plot, masterminded from Moscow, permitted by gullible and feeble Europeans.

It was then, as now, a land of the most puzzling contrasts. Two decades ago I sat in a beautiful, white-owned Salisbury garden, lunching with among others, Dumiso Dabengwa, then Joshua Nkomo's chief of staff, now the home affairs minister. "Mmm," he said with relish, as he sipped from his glass, "South African wine! Delicious! So much better than this Zimbabwean muck." I who would not have let a drop of South African wine sully my lips at home could only marvel about how much I had to learn about the continent.

webTitle: Livingstone faces ban on extra earnings

fields.headline: Livingstone faces ban on extra earnings
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone would be forced to sacrifice his lucrative media earnings if he is elected London mayor under stringent new ethical rules for the post.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone would be forced to sacrifice his lucrative media earnings if he is elected London mayor under stringent new ethical rules for the post.

The mayor and deputy will be banned from holding any company directorships, watched over by an ethics committee and must get all appointments approved by an "independent" figure, according to guidance placed in the Commons library yesterday by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

The government's restrictions would force Mr Livingstone to resign his directorship of Localaction, the company which receives his earnings from media work and after-dinner speaking. Mr Livingstone was forced to apologise to the Commons last month for failing to disclose £158,000 worth of income from his media engagements.

Parliamentary guidelines permit MPs to hold company directorships, provided they are logged in the register of members' interests. But the tougher rules for the London mayor reflects No 10's desire to keep Mr Livingstone on a short leash if, as opinion polls suggest, the former Labour MP is elected on May 4.

Meanwhile, Mr Livingstone continued his move away from the Labour party today by urging his supporters to back the Green party in the "top-up" section of the mayoral vote.

Mr Livingstone sees the Greens as potential partners for his independent mayoralty, which is likely to face criticism from the probable Labour majority in the assembly.

He praised the Greens' "cooperative" attitude, and said: "London's environmental pollution shortens the life of every Londoner. A strong Green contingent in the assembly is vital to clean up London."

Mr Livingstone recommended that people vote for Labour in the constituency section of the elections "because almost all of these contests are straight fights between Labour and the Tories".

His suggestion that his supporters should give their second choice votes to Frank Dobson, Labour's official candidate, is based on the calculation that the Tories' Steven Norris and the Liberal Democrats' Susan Kramer may pose a greater threat in the second round of the ballot. If no candidate wins 50% of the vote, the second-choice votes of the losing candidates are distributed between the top two to calculate the overall winner.

fields.headline: Yard to investigate match-fix claim
fields.trailText: The England and Wales Cricket Board last night called in the police to investigate allegations by the fast bowler Chris Lewis that three England players had been involved in match-fixing.
fields.body:
The England and Wales Cricket Board last night called in the police to investigate allegations by the fast bowler Chris Lewis that three England players had been involved in match-fixing.

The move came after Lewis was summoned by the ECB yesterday to explain his revelation in the News of the World that a sports promoter, Ashim Kheterpal, had told him of three "famous" England players who had taken cash to unfairly influence matches.

The ECB had hoped it would remain untarnished by a flurry of allegations following the sacking of the South African cricket captain Hansie Cronje last week. Cronje admitted "dishonesty" after receiving $8,200 (£5,100) from an Indian bookmaker, but denied match-fixing.

The board's decision to involve Scotland Yard indicates that it is aware of the complexity as well as the seriousness of the allegations.

ECB officials met Lewis at lunchtime. In a short statement at 7pm they said they would pass on Lewis's information to police while continuing their own investigation.

The statement read: "Mr Lewis indicated his desire to continue to cooperate fully with the board and has put all information in his possession into the hands of the board.

"The board will continue its investigation with a view to determining whether evidence exists in relation to betting and match-fixing which might justify disciplinary action."

It was thought that Lewis would get a rough ride from the board. But the length of the meeting would suggest the player and his solicitor gave as good as they got.

The development will do nothing to help the unease of England players, who have been implicated by Lewis's claims and had hoped to have been cleared yesterday.

Meanwhile, the former captain of India, Kapil Dev, said yesterday: "I was ashamed to be a cricketer on the day Hansie Cronje admitted taking cash from a bookmaker. I've never been approached by a bookmaker.

"Now we have a chance to clean up the game. Hansie can write one or two things to tell his experience. If he can tell how he became a weak person he will help a generation of people."

Last year Lewis told the ECB he was offered £300,000 - which he rejected out of hand - by an Indian sports agent to fix a match against New Zealand by getting the wicketkeeper Alec Stewart and bowler Alan Mullally to drop catches and bowl wide. They were unaware of the approach.

webTitle: Courts order war veteran leader to end occupations

fields.headline: Courts order war veteran leader to end occupations
fields.standfirst: State of emergency looms in Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Audio: hear Gary Younge in Harare
fields.body:
The Zimbabwe high court has convicted a war veterans' leader of contempt for inciting farm invasions after they had been declared illegal and gave him two weeks to order the occupations ended.

Judge David Bartlett gave war veterans' association leader Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi until May 3 to produce proof that he had actively sought to end the land invasion by thousands of his supporters.

Mr Hunzvi will face sentencing for civil contempt if he fails to satisfy the court by the judge's deadline that he has actively worked to end the invasions.

The court's action adds to the international pressure on President Robert Mugabe to end the farm invasions, that have seen a policeman and two white farmers killed by war veterans who have seized white-owned farms for redistribution to landless blacks.

Robin Cook today said it was "encouraging" that Zimbabwe had agreed to send a delegation to London to discuss the land reform crisis, following the intervention of UN secretary general Kofi Annan last night.

"We appear to have got an agreement from President Mugabe to return to dialogue," the foreign secretary said this morning. "I'm glad we now have a date when his delegation will now come to London for talks."

Zimbabwe agreed to send a delegation to London in eight days time after Mr Annan spoke to president Robert Mugabe by telephone yesterday and urged him to exercise restraint in the conflict between white land owners and black squatters.

Opposition politicians fear the crisis could worsen ahead of parliamentary elections, which are due to be called in May. They accuse Mr Mugabe of organising the violent occupations.

"He's been trying to create the conditions necessary for a state of emergency, because that's the only way he can postpone this election," said David Coltart, an official with the main opposition party the Movement for Democratic Change. "There's no doubt at all that he is behind all of this."

But Mr Cook rejected Conservative party calls to pressurise Mr Mugabe into calling off the war veterans by cutting aid.

Mr Cook said he had spoken to the white farmers' leader in Zimbabwe and it was not what they wanted. "If we beat Mugabe about the head, then he will beat them about the head," Mr Cook said.

He warned that the tension over land reform could threaten the stability of the entire southern African region, and asked neighbouring countries to get involved in the effort to negotiate a solution.

There was a need to bring home to Mr Mugabe that it was not just the international community which was concerned, but also his immediate neighbours, the foreign secretary said. "They are worried because if the situation in Zimbabwe continues o descend into chaos then it will have a negative impact on their own countries and possibility on the stability of the region," Mr Cook told the Today programme.

fields.headline: Straw defends record on refugees
fields.trailText: The government today defended its record on processing asylum applications - while attacking William Hague's plan to house asylum seekers in detention centres.
fields.body:
The government today defended its record on processing asylum applications - while attacking William Hague's plan to house asylum seekers in detention centres.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said a record 11,000 applications for asylum were processed in March - four times the number dealt with at the end of last year.

"What we are doing with one of the most intensely difficult issues in politics today, right across Europe, is dealing with it as fast and as quickly and as competently as we can," he said. "What the Conservatives are doing is seeking to exploit the issue, to play on people's anxieties."

Last night, Mr Hague attacked Labour for turning Britain into "a soft touch" for asylum seekers as he unveiled plans to house them in detention centres. The Conservative party leader, seeking to capitalise on what Tories feel is a vote-winning issue in the forthcoming local elections, said the present system was weak and arbitrary and losing public support.

But monthly polls organised by Mori show that only 4% of voters think it is the most important political issue, while the Refugee Council criticised the Tory plan as "draconian as well as being very expensive". It said that people who had fled persecution should not be treated as criminals.

Meanwhile, Mr Hague's plans have come under fire on practical grounds. Home Office officials say the punitive scheme was likely to involve building up to 20 detention centres at a cost of £40m each. Add running expenses and the total bill could double the £867m it costs to run the asylum system now.

Last month, thrown on to the defensive by the Tories, the government cut cash grants for asylum seekers and announced heavy fines for truckers caught smuggling illegal immigrants.

A TV poll revealed last night that two out of three people agree with Mr Hague's get tough policy towards refugees. The number of asylum applications rose from under 4,000 in 1988 to 71,000 last year, but the government rejected between 70% and 80% of them.

Today Mr Straw accused the Conservatives of using the issue of asylum seekers for electoral gain. "It is a cruel deception from a deeply cynical party," he said.

Despite the steady tabloid drumbeat on "bogus" asylum seekers, the EU estimates that 40m immigrants will be needed over the next 25 years as Europe struggles to support its pensioners with dwindling numbers of young workers.

Germany has unveiled a green card scheme, allowing entry to up to 30,000 IT specialists from outside the EU without the bureaucratic hassles.

fields.headline: Virtual newsreaders
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about virtual newsreaders on the net.
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about virtual newsreaders on the net.
fields.body:
1. Virtual newsreader Ananova makes her debut on the net today.

2. Even her name, which means "New Ana" in English, suggests she may replace human newsreaders such as John Humphrys or Anna Ford.

3. But for now she is content to be described as "a cross between Posh Spice and Carol Vorderman ... capable of delivering breaking news and information."

4. Ananova is a streaming animation package capable of turning text into speech quick enough to read the latest headlines. The designers, who researched the personality which most viewers prefer their newsreaders to have, boast that she has a full range of human characteristics.

5. She is designed to be attractive to women and men - but with her 24-hour availability, her youthful good looks the fact that she only speaks when she is told to, she has, not surprisingly, already gained a legion of male fans.

6. Her makers claim she is the world's first virtual newsreader, but actually they were pipped to the post by Vandrea, a cyber-journalist based on Channel 5's Andrea Catherwood, a human.

7. A wittier version of both may be found on the Canadian television station TVA - four interacting virtual newsreaders provide daily satire in Le JourNul de François Pérusse.

8. The technology behind Ananova and Vandrea may soon give us a human face on internet-compatible mobile phones and, from the brains behind their voices, we can expect many other advances such as speaking emails which look like the person (or virtual person) that sent them.

9. The virtual world has been with us a long time: virtual tourists, pets, villages and heroines such as cyber pin-up Lara Croft are all part and parcel of modern life.

10. For nostalgists, virtual newsreaders will never replace personalities and journalists such as ITN's Trevor McDonald. You can watch an interview with him right now. On the net, of course.

fields.headline: Galatasaray receive death threats
fields.trailText: Galatasaray defender Gica Popescu has claimed he and his team-mates have received death threats ahead of tomorrow night's Uefa Cup semi-final second leg in Leeds.
fields.body:
Galatasaray defender Gica Popescu has claimed he and his team-mates have received death threats ahead of tomorrow night's Uefa Cup semi-final second leg in Leeds.

Galatasaray supporters have already been barred from attending the game by Uefa, but Popescu's revelation heightens fears of reprisals against the team in the wake of the murders of Leeds fans Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight in Istanbul two weeks ago.

"At club headquarters we receive dozens of faxes and e-mails daily from England threatening to kill us if we come to Leeds," said Popescu. "There's more talk now about our safety than the match. Our families are worried."

Describing the deaths of Loftus and Speight as "regrettable", the 32-year-old ex-Spurs player added: "We were on the pitch and not on the streets."

Galatasaray are due to arrive in Leeds this afternoon. West Yorkshire Police have mounted a large security operation to ensure the safety of the Turkish team, and an elite force of Turkish anti-terrorist commandos will accompany the party.

Leeds, meanwhile, have started to remove the flowers, shirts, scarves and messages of sympathy from outside Elland Road, in order to lessen tension when the Turks arrive for training later today.

webTitle: Death at dawn: the agony of Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Death at dawn: the agony of Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe: special report
Hear Gary Younge report on the crisis in Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: For Martin Olds it was a chilling wake up call. At around 6am yesterday more than 100 squatters gathered at the white farmer's gate in Nyamandlovu, about 50 miles from Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city.
fields.body:
For Martin Olds it was a chilling wake up call. At around 6am yesterday more than 100 squatters gathered at the white farmer's gate in Nyamandlovu, about 50 miles from Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city.

They had come in a convoy of 14 cars and a tractor trailer, many of them carrying hunting weapons.

By 6.15am Olds, 42, was radioing the Commercial Farmers' Union, which represents white farmers, in a state of panic. "They're cutting through my fence," he said and warned the CFU that it looked as though the situation might turn ugly.

Within minutes it was out of control. The protesters had broken down his gate and were at his door. The homestead, which Olds had named Compensation, was surrounded.

The next time he called the CFU his message was short. "I've been shot, call an ambulance."

His appeal sent the airwaves crackling as the local white community got on their radios. Following the abduction and murder of the white farmer David Stevens in another part of the country, they had been worrying about where the protesters might strike next.

Rumours had been circulating in Matabeleland - which includes the area surrounding Bulawayo - that war veterans had been armed with AK-47s. What is more, Olds knew he might be a target; he had already been threatened at least once.

According to one local couple, last month he took "trespassers" on his land to the police station and had them arrested after a court ruled that the land occupations were illegal. The squatters warned him they would get even.

No sooner had the word gone out that one of their number was in trouble than white farmers in the area climbed into their pickup trucks and raced to Old's cattle farm to offer their assistance. One flew his private plane over the house to see what was happening.

But whenever they got close to the homestead they were shot at by the veterans who also, say the farmers, opened fire on an ambulance.

Back at the house Olds was engaged in a shootout with the squatters which some locals say lasted for three hours.

A spokesman for Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF, which has supported the squatters, said that Olds had fired at the veterans, hitting five of them with pellets, and it was only then that they shot back.

Farmers insist that Olds, a father of two, was simply defending his house by the same means that the squatters were trying to take it - through the barrel of a gun.

The police arrived at the scene while the gunfight was in full throttle but did not stop it. The stand-off ended when squatters threw molotov cocktails into the house.

Olds's home started to burn and when the heat became too intense inside he stumbled out into the hands of the veterans. They beat him severely and then shot him twice in the face at close range.

"They killed my son," said Gloria Olds, Martin's mother. "They beat him to a pulp."

Compensation crumbled to a cinder - a smouldering backdrop to its owner's corpse - and the squatters left as they had come: slowly, in a long, snaking convoy edging back towards Bulawayo.

No attempt was made to occupy the land they had just taken. Instead, they exchanged a few, casual words with the police as they left. The police here, say locals, are simply coathangers for uniforms. They did not make any arrests.

Crawford believes that the police's inaction makes them complicit in the occupations but he can provide no proof beyond anecdotal evidence.

The home affairs minister, Dumiso Dabengwa, denied knowledge of anyone supplying arms to protesters.

He agreed that the state of law and order in Zimbabwe left much to be desired but insisted that the police were doing all they could to stop the violence.

White farmers are not convinced. Despite the fact that they are hopelessly outnumbered and have little political clout, they have started issuing scarcely-veiled threats that they are ready to fight back.

"The farmers are now on alert and standing by," Mr Crawford said, adding that his members were taking "necessary security measures".

But on the ground, there is a mixture of bewilderment, frustration and despair rather than defiance.

Farmers in the area have decided to move women and children out immediately and are holding a meeting tomorrow to decide whether to remain or evacuate the area altogether, as happened in the Macheke area after David Stevens was killed at the weekend.

"This thing will escalate until somebody takes a stand to stop it," says Chris Jarrett, who has a farm nearby.

"What precautions can you take when 150 men break onto your land and burn down your house?" asked Harry Greaves who lives on the farm next to Compensation. "Especially if the police will not protect you."
