fields.headline: Cronje: the race angle
fields.trailText: This match-fixing hoopla is an issue of colour. Mr Black Preacher reads Mr Whiter-than-white¹s confession having been exposed by Officer Brown. Mr Black Outcast has accused three more Mr Whites (presumably). Two antipodean Mr Whites are counting their blessings. And numerous Mr Browns are sweating, some in the Caribbean and some in South Asia. Coloured, in the new cricketing vernacular, is what insiders call a scripted game, and colour is a vital component of this crisis.
fields.body:
This match-fixing hoopla is an issue of colour. Mr Black Preacher reads Mr Whiter-than-white¹s confession having been exposed by Officer Brown. Mr Black Outcast has accused three more Mr Whites (presumably). Two antipodean Mr Whites are counting their blessings. And numerous Mr Browns are sweating, some in the Caribbean and some in South Asia. Coloured, in the new cricketing vernacular, is what insiders call a scripted game, and colour is a vital component of this crisis.

The Asian view of Cronjegate is simple: shock and relief, in equal measure. Shock, because it now seems that the most conclusive evidence in cricket history is in the possession of the Indian police. Up to now, all the Asian scandals and inquiries have lacked one crucial element: proof. Shock, because all those lingering accusations are suddenly given immense weight. And, shock that a white cricketer, and one of Cronje¹s stature, has been exposed.

But therein lies the relief. Match-fixing had become an Asian disease; as if it was something Asians did, and the rest of the world should pity us for. The three Asian judicial inquiries might have been flawed, but they did provide enough information for a half-alert ICC to seize on. Shame, that never happened. Shame, too, that match-fixing remained an apparently Asian trait even though Shane Warne and Mark Waugh took money from bookies. Their transgression was labelled trifling. Did Cronje really do any worse? In this game of half-truths and partial confessions we may never know. But, certainly, Warne and Waugh are extremely fortunate that their board hushed up the affair with ICC¹s blessing, and that there are no taped conversations implicating them in something more serious.

Cronje¹s plight highlights the double standards in international cricket. Accuse an Asian cricketer of match-fixing and the reaction is that it is probably true; it is barely considered newsworthy. Accuse South Africa¹s captain of the same, and the blanket response is moral outrage; a plan cooked up by those awful brownies to deflect attention from their own corruption and abysmal form. Cronje is a religious man after all. But, as any South Asian will tell you, probably from personal experience, devout believers are capable of the most outrageous acts, and financial impropriety is one of them.

Once Cronje had confessed, his whiter-than-white front was shattered. I can understand the shock in South Africa. Partly because Asians have felt the same when our best players have been implicated, and partly because I have had an insight into the way Cronje was revered. It was after South Africa defeated Pakistan at Trent Bridge in last year¹s World Cup. At the post-match press conference, the South African media were embarrassing. It was clear that they worshipped Cronje and were in complete awe of their golden boy. They fawned over him, laughed at his dull jokes, and asked him the most ingratiating questions. No wonder, then, that they cannot believe his fall.

But it isn¹t just the South African media that has revealed its prejudicial view of justice. Australians and Englishmen have done the same, from broadsheets to tabloids to the internet. For example, Michael Henderson, who occupies the key position of cricket correspondent of The Daily Telegraph, concluded that England should stop playing India and Pakistan, as well as spurning any invitations to play at Sharjah. Excuse me, but where does Cronje come from? And what about Warne and Waugh? Or am I getting it wrong, and it is one rule for the white nations and another for the rest?

Indeed, it has to be the same rule for all, and the only way of ensuring that is for ICC to fulfil its mandate rather than remaining a pale imitation of an ineffectual branch of the UN. It should begin by poring over the findings of the Australian, Indian, and Pakistani inquiries. The Australians remain defensive and protective of their stars. The Indians, basking in their success over Cronje, are reopening the book on past indiscretions. While the Pakistanis are keeping suspiciously quiet. Judge Qayyum¹s report remains officially undisclosed, but its findings have been so widely leaked that the Pakistani authorities are simply making it look more like a cover-up with each passing day.

Echoes of the past are coming back to haunt us: the divide between Asia and the old cricketing powers; the legacy of bungled inquiries; and the impotence of ICC. One more lesson must be learned and that is about the treatment of whistleblowers. Manoj Prabakhar, Rashid Latif, and Amir Sohail have all suffered for making a stand. They have been dismissed as troublemakers and has-beens. They may be both, but their accusations are more powerful by the day. Chris Lewis has now reluctantly joined that group. He may have an axe to grind too, but he doesn¹t deserve a character assassination. Whistleblowers are generally treated like scoundrels and presumed to be liars. That is as foolish as believing all accusations.

The enigma of match-fixing is correctly identifying the villains and the heroes. The waters are rapidly clearing. And the reflex judgement that white is good and brown is bad is now less sustainable than it ever was. For that, at least, thank you, Hansie.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: You could be downloading Shakespeare in Love over the internet, Bret Easton Ellis muddies the American Psycho sequel waters, Rules of Engagement upsets Arab-American community, The Onion and Dreamworks collaborate over satanic story, and what films top last year's advertising spend?
fields.body:
Miramax Films are to release up to 12 of their movies over the internet, it was announced yesterday. The studio sees the internet as an alternative to video releases, and will charge a fee to download films such as The English Patient, Shakespeare in Love and Good Will Hunting. "We're going into it cautiously", says co-president of production Bob Osher. "We're going to see how it goes, learn from it and make sure the experience for customers is good."

Bret Easton Ellis is wreaking confusion over the likelihood of a sequel to Mary Harron's recent adaptation of his novel American Psycho. Ellis himself has publicly alleged in recent weeks that distributor Lions Gate is leaning on him to yield up the novel's cinematic sequel rights. Lions Gate exec Tom Ortenberg says no such discussions have taken place, not least because Lions Gate already owns the rights to any Psycho sequels.

Rules of Engagement, the US number one movie starring Tommy Lee Jones and Samuel L Jackson, is the latest film to upset members of the Arab-American community. William Friedkin's film involves an army officer facing trial for ordering his men to open fire on civilians storming the US embassy in Yemen. The American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee called the film's attitude 'uniformly negative' and expressed concern that it 'would portray a group of children as murderous, threatening and fanatical'.

The American comic newspaper The Onion is moving into movies. Onion writer Todd Hanson has signed a deal with DreamWorks Animation to script an adaptation of the spoof paper's story 10th Circle Added To Rapidly Growing Hell. The article dealt with the need for Satan to expand hell to accommodate a population explosion of evil-doers, including - reports Variety - "demographers, ad execs, tobacco lobbyists, monopoly law experts working for major corporations" and the creators of sitcoms set in the workplace."

Movie studios spent more than $1.5bn in advertising last year. Most profligate campaigns were Disney's $29m Tarzan binge and the $27.3m spent by MGM to promote The World Is Not Enough, according to a report released on Monday.

webTitle: Sale not Proust's cup of weak tea

fields.headline: Sale not Proust's cup of weak tea
fields.trailText: It would have horrified the great aesthete himself, but a long lost proof of Proust's masterpiece Remembrance Of Times Past, which reveals how he laboured for years over what to call it, may fetch £1m.
fields.body:
It would have horrified the great aesthete himself, but a long lost proof of Proust's masterpiece Remembrance Of Times Past, which reveals how he laboured for years over what to call it, may fetch £1m.

The handwritten manuscript shows how he endlessly reworked the first part of his 13-volume meditation on the minutiae of life, and agonised ad nauseam over a title.

Had good reason not finally prevailed, the greatest French novel of the 20th century might have been called The Frazzled Pigeon, The Stalagmites Of The Past, What One Sees In The Patina, or even more bizarrely, Gardens In A Cup Of Tea.

Proust took to his bed to write after suddenly recalling a childhood memory as he dipped a madeleine biscuit into a cup of weak tea. Nearly two decades later he finished it, but was still torn between calling it Les Intermittences du Coeur or A la Recherche du Temps Perdu.

The draft now being sold by Christie's in Paris details how he reluctantly plumped for the latter.

Having been rejected by pretty well every publisher in Paris, Proust printed the book himself, paying extra for his constant revisions.

The chopped and changed manuscript on sale forms all but one page of Du Cote de Chez Swann (Swann's Way), the first volume of his magnum opus, which somehow became detached from the rest of the Proust papers after the death of his brother Robert in 1935.

The sale would be doubly abhorrent to Proust, according to the writer Alain de Botton. "He would be appalled by it.

"Proust loathed the idea of people thinking of the book as a memoir rather than a novel. He was also very sarcastic about collectors and the type of people who rushed out to get first editions. It was what was in a book that was important, rather than what it was worth."

De Botton, author of the bestselling How Proust Can Change Your Life, said that even after all his procrastinations, Proust still hated the name.

"He tried all sorts of variations, The Delayed Days, Visit Of The Past Which Dawdles, even In Front Of Some Stalagmites Of Some Days Gone By. After all that, Remembrance Of Times Past seems quite good actually."

Verene de Soultrait, Christie's French book specialist, said the proofs were "incomparably" important.

Proust (1871-1922) has recently undergone something of a mini-boom on both sides of the Channel as a result of an exhibition at the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris and the release of Raul Ruiz's film Time Regained, based on his final volume.

However, he is not the only French literary great to have enjoyed an unlikely revival.

The essays of the 16th century philosopher Montaigne popped into the top 10 of internet bookseller Amazon's bestseller list this week, after being featured on De Botton's TV series The Consolations of Philosophy.

"I don't think he has been on a bestseller list for 400 years," said De Botton.

webTitle: Bollywood looks to Scotland to broaden its horizons

fields.headline: Bollywood looks to Scotland to broaden its horizons
fields.trailText: Scotland has usurped the Swiss Alps as the preferred location for Bollywood film producers, according to BBC reports. Caledonian landscapes emerged as top in a list of locations favoured by the Indian film industry as it seeks to broaden its range of backdrops and subject matter.
fields.body:
Scotland has usurped the Swiss Alps as the preferred location for Bollywood film producers, according to BBC reports. Caledonian landscapes emerged as top in a list of locations favoured by the Indian film industry as it seeks to broaden its range of backdrops and subject matter.

Rajiv Rai, India's Steven Spielberg, has chosen Scotland for his latest movie, Love, Love, Love. The UK at large is similarly in demand - another big-budget Bollywood movie is to be shot among the lions of Longleat House in Wiltshire later this year.

The Indian industry, estimated to be worth an annual £0.75bn, turns out 600 films a year - overtaking Hollywood in terms of film production.

Younger directors are reported to be keen to modernise Bollywood's traditional concern with happy endings and Indian family values. But whereas "the changing backdrops are making a huge difference", according to Indian cultural commentator Sangeeta Dutta, "there have been no exciting changes in narrative space."

fields.headline: Will a 'shorinji tempo' fighter be the new Darth Maul?
fields.trailText: Will a 'shorinji tempo' fighter be the new Darth Maul?
fields.body:
The fanboy community is buzzing with rumours surrounding George Lucas' Star Wars follow-up, as prospective goodies and baddies emerge from a far, far away casting director's imagination. AICN reports that Episode 2's Sith apprentice "the new Darth Maul, as it were" is to be played by a Japanese 'shorinji tempo' fighter Makiya Yamaguchi.

fields.headline: Cannes line-up 'satisfactory'
fields.trailText: The line-up for the 53rd Cannes film festival has been announced by director Gilles Jacob, who describes the selection as 'satisfactory'. The list, which includes 23 films in competition, features few high-profile Hollywood movies and a host of Asian pictures.
fields.body:
The line-up for the 53rd Cannes film festival has been announced by director Gilles Jacob, who describes the selection as 'satisfactory'. The list, which includes 23 films in competition, features few high-profile Hollywood movies and a host of Asian pictures.

Britain is represented by Ken Loach's LA union drama Bread and Roses and James Ivory's Henry James adaptation The Golden Bowl.

Jacob explained the big studios' low profile on his bill as a result of their 'not wanting to release the [films] that were up to quality'. By way of compensation for English-speaking audiences, the Festival will introduce electronic subtitles for the first time. Foreign-language films had previously been simultaneously translated over headphones.

Jacob's justified his underwhelming endorsement of the programme by arguing that two 'satisfactory' years in a row represented an improvement on Cannes' traditional good year/bad year pattern. 'This is something that hasn't happened in along time', he said.

The Festival runs from 10-21 May. The main films in competition are: Joel Coen's musical O Brother, Where Art Thou?, with George Clooney and John Turturro, Lars Von Trier's musical Dancer in the Dark, starring Bjork, Wong Kar-Wai's In the Mood for Love, and 20-year-old Iranian wunderkind Samira Makhmalbaf's second feature The Blackboard.

This year's jury is headed by Luc Besson and includes Jonathan Demme, Kristin Scott Thomas and Jeremy Irons. The Festival opens with Roland Joffe's Vatel, starring Gerard Depardieu, and closes with Stardom, directed by Denys Arcand.

webTitle: Public left out in rain for Beckham baby's zoo visit

fields.headline: Public left out in rain for Beckham baby's zoo visit
fields.trailText: Members of the public who had paid £9.50 admission were left in the rain while David and Victoria Beckham and their year-old son had the elephant, giraffe and chimpanzee houses at Chester zoo to themselves.
fields.body:
Members of the public who had paid £9.50 admission were left in the rain while David and Victoria Beckham and their year-old son had the elephant, giraffe and chimpanzee houses at Chester zoo to themselves.

Zoo officials claimed the couple's security staff requested privacy on the Monday afternoon visit because of previous kidnap attempts on their son. But this claim was denied by the Beckhams' spokeswoman yesterday.

Pat Cade, the zoo's public relations manager, said: "After Victoria fed the penguins and they visited an elephant house and a bat cave, their security man asked if it was possible for them to have a few minutes of privacy because of kidnap attempts on their baby."

She said the couple had been annoyed by the activities of several photographers. "They specifically asked for no press."

But the Beckhams' spokeswoman said no mention had been made of the kidnap attempt. "Victoria and David did not ask for anything like the zoo to be closed and they didn't want any special treatment. They would never do that and they will sue anybody who says otherwise.

"They didn't have any security with them for the visit - they were with their driver."

A spokesman for Chester zoo said: "We closed the houses to allow them some privacy. The poor things must be pursued by the paparazzi all the time."

He said one or two members of the public had complained but were pacified when they heard who was being shown around.

But Bob Clough-Parker, secretary of the Chester chamber of trade, said he thought it "a bit rich" for a couple enjoying their celebrity status to complain of media attention, and that paying visitors should not be treated that way.

webTitle: Elian badly needs rescuing, says doctor

fields.headline: Elian badly needs rescuing, says doctor
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: A claim by a leading US paediatrician that Elian Gonzalez was in "imminent danger" and in need of urgent rescue focused scrutiny yesterday on the Cuban boy's Miami relatives who are fighting to keep him in their care.
fields.body:
A claim by a leading US paediatrician that Elian Gonzalez was in "imminent danger" and in need of urgent rescue focused scrutiny yesterday on the Cuban boy's Miami relatives who are fighting to keep him in their care.

As the justice department waited for an appeal court ruling on whether Elian can be repatriated to Cuba, it released a letter by Irwin Redlener, a New York paediatrician, which appeared to pave the way for a government move to seize Elian from Miami and hand him over to his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez.

After seeing a videotape made last week by the Miami relatives, in which an apparently coached Elian demanded to be allowed to stay in the US, Dr Redlener wrote: "Elian Gonzalez is now in a state of imminent danger to his physical and emotional well-being in a home that I consider to be psychologically abusive."

Dr Redlener, a professor of paediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, said yesterday that the video showed that Elian "was under a significant amount of duress".

He expressed concern that Elian appeared to be a victim of "parental alienation", having been turned against his father as a result of constant pressure from the Miami relatives, who have been looking after him since he was shipwrecked and saw his mother drown off the Florida coast in November.

"The child needs to be rescued," he said. Elian's US relatives dispute Dr Redlener's findings, pointing out he has not examined Elian directly.

They have argued that Juan Miguel Gonzalez's is an unfit father and claimed that he had been abusive towards Elian and his mother. They have lodged an appeal against Elian's repatriation, due to be heard in an Atlanta court on May 11.

Most immigration and family law experts believe they stand little chance of winning their case. The evidence against Juan Miguel is weak and contradicted by testimony from friends and family in Cuba.

Meanwhile, the Miami branch of the family has its own troubled history.

Elian's great uncle Lazaro Gonzalez, the Little Havana car mechanic who has led the fight to keep the boy in Miami, has been arrested twice for drunk driving.

His 21-year-old daughter Marisleysis, who has presented herself as Elian's surrogate mother, has a record of psychological problems and has been in hospital repeatedly - both before and since Elian's arrival - for nervous exhaustion and stress.

The shifting cast of extended family members who have come and gone at Lazaro Gonzalez's small white stucco home reflect some of the darker side of the Cuban exile experience in Miami. Two of Elian's Miami cousins who have been photographed playing with him in the front garden have police records.

Jose Cid began a 13-year sentence for theft and forgery in January. His twin brother Luis was charged with mugging a tourist last year.

One of Lazaro's brothers, Delfin, also has convictions for drunk driving.

A third brother, Manolo, has been ostracised by the rest of the family for arguing that Elian should be returned to his father. Manolo Gonzalez left Cuba with Lazaro and his family in 1984, and lives only six blocks away from Lazaro, but the two brothers have not exchanged a word for months.

The Elian saga has catapulted Lazaro Gonzalez into the role of local hero, and he frequently emerges from his house to acknowledge the cheers of the crowd of supporters permanently installed around the house. But the constant scrutiny appears to be taking its toll.

"He's very volatile," said a Cornell University psychiatrist, Paulina Kernberg, who met the 49-year-old last week.

Lazaro Gonzalez's lawyers have insisted that he would not offer resistance in the event of a government raid on his house to take Elian to Washington, where his father is waiting. But there are no such guarantees from the extended family and the emotional crowd keeping a vigil outside the house.

fields.headline: Labouring a point about appointments
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Every four weeks, we have a precious quarter of an hour in the parliamentary timetable when MPs are allowed to ask questions about their favourite subject: themselves. It's a session with the snappy title "Oral Questions to the Lord President of the Council, the honourable member answering for the House of Commons commission, and the chairman of..." - well, you get the general idea.
fields.body:
Every four weeks, we have a precious quarter of an hour in the parliamentary timetable when MPs are allowed to ask questions about their favourite subject: themselves. It's a session with the snappy title "Oral Questions to the Lord President of the Council, the honourable member answering for the House of Commons commission, and the chairman of..." - well, you get the general idea.

Yesterday Owen Paterson (C, North Shropshire) wanted to know the cost of the new debates that started up in Westminster Hall last year. These are on topics for the most part so dreary, so trivial, so unimagineably boring, that they can't even be held in the main chamber for fear of stunning the poor clerks, who, as is well known, have boredom thresholds above the level of an educationally subnormal sloth.

"Increased incidence of potholes in the A3883 feeder road" is the sort of subject you are likely to hear being discussed between the MP for the A3883 and a junior minister, thrashing himself with barbed wire in order to stay awake.

Margaret Beckett, who trades as president of the council while not being leader of the house, said the room off Westminster Hall would have been renovated anyway, so it hadn't cost much to turn it into a small debating chamber, though £71,000 had gone on professional consulting fees. ("Why not put in some chairs?" "Hey, thanks, great idea.")

She said that the cost of operating the new mini-house was £13,000 a month. It permitted 200 more debates every year, which - I calculate - is just £780 per debate. This may seem a lot to hear a couple of speeches on yesterday's hot topic - "the exclusion of wards in Berwick-upon-Tweed and Berwickshire from the revised map of assisted areas" - but it's still less than you'd pay at some Premiership football matches.

Mr Paterson was appalled by the expense. The debates had been poorly attended and had no atmosphere. "My main memories are of bemused schoolchildren, and tourists in buses passing behind a minister's head." (I suspect he meant the tourists had been debouched from the buses, rather than that the buses had driven into the chamber: "Oy, mate, arm I supposed to get fru that?")

This topic finished, we moved on to the House of Lords, and the way that Tony Blair is able to influence the choice of new peers. This he will do through a body called the appointments commission, to which he will appoint the chairman. The situation was clarified for us by Paddy Tipping, not a skinhead's idea of Saturday night fun but Mrs Beckett's deputy.

He explained that the appointment of the appointments commission was making good progress.

Gordon Prentice (Lab, Pendle) thought this was "bizarre - the prime minister appoints the chair of the appointments commission, which in turn appoints members to the upper chamber!"

Mr Tipping bristled. "This is the first prime minister to lose, er, to reduce his powers with the appointment of an appointments commission," a remark that brought a ripple of cynical laughter even from the Labour side.

Sir Sydney Chapman kept up the theme. "There should be more modest appointments, when appointments are made by the appointments commission."

Robert Maclennan for the Lib Dems was outraged by the news that there would be appointees of all three main parties on the appointments commission. "Is he really saying that the appointments commission should appoint political appointees?"

I retired from the chamber at this point and stared glumly into my cup of tea.

webTitle: Mugabe stokes the fires of resentment

fields.headline: Mugabe stokes the fires of resentment
fields.standfirst: President tells threatened white farmers they are now the enemyZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe branded Zimbabwe's white farmers "enemies of the state" yesterday, inflaming an increasingly volatile situation that saw the second murder of a white farmer and attacks on opposition supporters.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum  and  Gary Younge in Harare
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe branded Zimbabwe's white farmers "enemies of the state" yesterday, inflaming an increasingly volatile situation that saw the second murder of a white farmer and attacks on opposition supporters.

As further violence engulfed the nation yesterday, on the 20th anniversary of its independence, a white farmer was killed by supporters of Mr Mugabe, a black foreman was reported to have been killed, another farmer was beaten and abducted and scores of civilians were intimidated by government agents.

Mr Mugabe used the anniversary to announce on state television and radio: "Our present state of mind is that you [white farmers] are now our enemies because you have really behaved as enemies of Zimbabwe.

"We are full of anger. Our entire community is angry and this is why you have the war veterans now, you know, seizing land. For [the farmers] to band together to a man in support of the opposition and to have coerced their labour to support the opposition has exposed them as enemies of the state. They are not just political enemies, they want to reverse our independence."

In his speech and in remarks afterwards, he also made frequent attacks on what he said were entrenched colonial attitudes among the country's 4,500 predominantly white commercial farmers, who had opposed his draft constitution - it was rejected by voters in February.

He also blamed Britain for many of his country's woes. "What we reject is the persistence of vestigial attitudes from the Rhodesian yesteryears," he said. "Attitudes of master race, master colour, master owner and master employer. We can understand the frustrations of the war veterans, just as we appreciate the pressures faced by the commercial farmers. Yesterday and today I have been meeting with the leadership of the farmers and the war veterans so we can reach some understanding," he added.

"We should be able to find a way forward, but one that recognises the urgent need for land reform. It is the last colonial question heavily qualifying our sovereignty. We are determined to resolve it once and for all."

Mr Mugabe also attacked the British government, saying that Labour had broken promises made by the previous Conservative administration: "After 1997 we also had to contend with the reluctance of the new Labour government, which did not want to honour commitments made by previous British governments on the land issue."

Mr Mugabe's address to the country for its independence day was pre-recorded. In past years he has always made the address to a stadium full of people but so bitter is the antipathy in Harare that he retreated to a studio.

Nine people have now died at the hands of supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party in the past two weeks. The police have not taken action to stop the crimes or to arrest the perpetrators.

Yesterday, a second white farmer, Martin Olds, 42, was shot dead in Nyamandlovu, 50 miles west of Bulawayo.

The attackers' connection to Mr Mugabe's government was made clear by the fact that police arrived at the property but did not attempt to stop a shootout between Mr Olds and the attackers, nor did they did they bother to follow the invaders' convoy of 15 vehicles when it headed back to Bulawayo. The Zanu-PF supporters did not put up a pretence of seizing land from Mr Olds. They broke into the property, killed him and left.

Mr Olds' murder comes three days after the killing of another farmer, David Stevens in the Macheke area, about 70 miles east of Harare. In that incident five other white farmers who tried to help him were beaten unconscious.

The police have not made any arrests in connection with the incidents, despite the fact that positive identifications were made.

Yesterday Mr Stevens' foreman, who is black, was found dead on his property, according to farmers' radio reports.

Another white farmer, Kevin Tinker, was abducted from his property yesterday in Christon Bank, about 20 miles west of Harare. About 15 men went to Mr Tinker's house on Monday and seized a pistol and some pamphlets for the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change. Mr Tinker reported the incident to the local police.

Yesterday the men came back and beat up Mr Tinker and took him away. He was released later in the day.

In the town of Chivu, about 100 miles south of Harare, residents reported that members of the central intelligence organisation (CIO) yesterday searched people's homes for MDC T-shirts and pamphlets and beat up people whom they believed to be opposition supporters. They also ordered people to attend a local rally supporting Zanu-PF, according to MDC officials.

The CIO is the domestic intelligence-gathering network which has agents throughout the country. Its officials have been convicted of abducting and shooting political opponents of the ruling party. It is widely believed they have been involved in the torture and disappearance of others.

CIO agents were also identified as having burned down the staff quarters yesterday at a farm in the Enterprise area 15 miles north of Harare.

"This is Zimbabwe's independence anniversary and we should be celebrating 20 years of black rule. It should be a day of happiness and a day when we are proud," said Trevor Ncube, editor of the Zimbabwe Independent. "Instead it is a day of shame. Blood is flowing all over the country. Fear and trepidation are rampant because Zanu-PF thugs are on the rampage."

Mr Ncube said his reporters had received threats because of the paper's criticism of Mr Mugabe's government. "My reporters are afraid to work overtime because they feel it is dangerous for them to travel home at night.

"These Zanu-PF gangsters are trying to stop people from exercising their constitutional right to make a free political choice. But this brutal political tactic will boomerang and backfire against them. People will pay lip service to Zanu-PF and the opposition will go underground. Zimbabwean people fought for the right to vote and when they go to the polls they will vote for who they want."
fields.bodyText: President Robert Mugabe branded Zimbabwe's white farmers "enemies of the state" yesterday, inflaming an increasingly volatile situation that saw the second murder of a white farmer and attacks on opposition supporters. As further violence engulfed the nation yesterday, on the 20th anniversary of its independence, a white farmer was killed by supporters of Mr Mugabe, a black foreman was reported to have been killed, another farmer was beaten and abducted and scores of civilians were intimidated by government agents. Mr Mugabe used the anniversary to announce on state television and radio: "Our present state of mind is that you [white farmers] are now our enemies because you have really behaved as enemies of Zimbabwe. "We are full of anger. Our entire community is angry and this is why you have the war veterans now, you know, seizing land. For [the farmers] to band together to a man in support of the opposition and to have coerced their labour to support the opposition has exposed them as enemies of the state. They are not just political enemies, they want to reverse our independence." In his speech and in remarks afterwards, he also made frequent attacks on what he said were entrenched colonial attitudes among the country's 4,500 predominantly white commercial farmers, who had opposed his draft constitution - it was rejected by voters in February. He also blamed Britain for many of his country's woes. "What we reject is the persistence of vestigial attitudes from the Rhodesian yesteryears," he said. "Attitudes of master race, master colour, master owner and master employer. We can understand the frustrations of the war veterans, just as we appreciate the pressures faced by the commercial farmers. Yesterday and today I have been meeting with the leadership of the farmers and the war veterans so we can reach some understanding," he added. "We should be able to find a way forward, but one that recognises the urgent need for land reform. It is the last colonial question heavily qualifying our sovereignty. We are determined to resolve it once and for all." Mr Mugabe also attacked the British government, saying that Labour had broken promises made by the previous Conservative administration: "After 1997 we also had to contend with the reluctance of the new Labour government, which did not want to honour commitments made by previous British governments on the land issue." Mr Mugabe's address to the country for its independence day was pre-recorded. In past years he has always made the address to a stadium full of people but so bitter is the antipathy in Harare that he retreated to a studio. Nine people have now died at the hands of supporters of Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party in the past two weeks. The police have not taken action to stop the crimes or to arrest the perpetrators. Yesterday, a second white farmer, Martin Olds, 42, was shot dead in Nyamandlovu, 50 miles west of Bulawayo. The attackers' connection to Mr Mugabe's government was made clear by the fact that police arrived at the property but did not attempt to stop a shootout between Mr Olds and the attackers, nor did they did they bother to follow the invaders' convoy of 15 vehicles when it headed back to Bulawayo. The Zanu-PF supporters did not put up a pretence of seizing land from Mr Olds. They broke into the property, killed him and left. Mr Olds' murder comes three days after the killing of another farmer, David Stevens in the Macheke area, about 70 miles east of Harare. In that incident five other white farmers who tried to help him were beaten unconscious. The police have not made any arrests in connection with the incidents, despite the fact that positive identifications were made. Yesterday Mr Stevens' foreman, who is black, was found dead on his property, according to farmers' radio reports. Another white farmer, Kevin Tinker, was abducted from his property yesterday in Christon Bank, about 20 miles west of Harare. About 15 men went to Mr Tinker's house on Monday and seized a pistol and some pamphlets for the opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change. Mr Tinker reported the incident to the local police. Yesterday the men came back and beat up Mr Tinker and took him away. He was released later in the day. In the town of Chivu, about 100 miles south of Harare, residents reported that members of the central intelligence organisation (CIO) yesterday searched people's homes for MDC T-shirts and pamphlets and beat up people whom they believed to be opposition supporters. They also ordered people to attend a local rally supporting Zanu-PF, according to MDC officials. The CIO is the domestic intelligence-gathering network which has agents throughout the country. Its officials have been convicted of abducting and shooting political opponents of the ruling party. It is widely believed they have been involved in the torture and disappearance of others. CIO agents were also identified as having burned down the staff quarters yesterday at a farm in the Enterprise area 15 miles north of Harare. "This is Zimbabwe's independence anniversary and we should be celebrating 20 years of black rule. It should be a day of happiness and a day when we are proud," said Trevor Ncube, editor of the Zimbabwe Independent. "Instead it is a day of shame. Blood is flowing all over the country. Fear and trepidation are rampant because Zanu-PF thugs are on the rampage." Mr Ncube said his reporters had received threats because of the paper's criticism of Mr Mugabe's government. "My reporters are afraid to work overtime because they feel it is dangerous for them to travel home at night. "These Zanu-PF gangsters are trying to stop people from exercising their constitutional right to make a free political choice. But this brutal political tactic will boomerang and backfire against them. People will pay lip service to Zanu-PF and the opposition will go underground. Zimbabwean people fought for the right to vote and when they go to the polls they will vote for who they want."

webTitle: Land aid tied to real reforms says Hain

fields.headline: Land aid tied to real reforms says Hain
fields.standfirst: Minister rebuffs accusations of blame and broken promisesZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign minister, Peter Hain, angrily denounced the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, yesterday for claiming Britain was to blame for the land reform crisis.
fields.body:
The foreign minister, Peter Hain, angrily denounced the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, yesterday for claiming Britain was to blame for the land reform crisis.

Mr Hain said no British money would be provided for land reform as long as farms were being given, as they had been for the past two years, to "cronies" of the Zimbabwean government.

He accused Harare of "playing the same old gramophone record" in accusing Britain of behaving as if it was still the colonial master.

Mr Mugabe said the Labour government had reneged on commitments to help fund land reform, allegedly given by the Conservative government when the Lancaster House agreement giving Zimbabwe independence was signed in 1980.

Mr Mugabe said: "After 1997 we also had to contend with the reluctance of the new Labour government which did not want to honour commitments made by previous British governments on the land issue."

But Mr Hain disputed this: "The Conservatives stopped funding land reform in the late 1980s after giving £44m because it was going off the rails. It was not being used to tackle the problems of the landless poor. In the last two years, the land has gone to cronies of the government and is not even being farmed."

He added: "We are only prepared to support a serious land reform programme, one that addresses the poor and is transparent."

There is nothing in the Lancaster House agreement about compensation for land reform, but Mr Mugabe has repeatedly insisted he was given a verbal promise by the then foreign secretary, Lord Carrington, who has been unable to substantiate the claim. According to the Foreign Office, Lord Carrington said he could not recall any such conversation.

The £44m was aimed at helping with land redistribution, buying up vacant land to give to the poor and to compensate farmers willing to sell.

There are 4,000 white farmers in Zimbabwe, mainly of British descent, who own 13m acres of prime commercial farmland - a third of the nation's total. Meanwhile, millions of blacks are crowded into communal areas on small holdings.

Squatters backed by the Zimbabwean government, some claiming to be veterans of the war for independence, have been occupying white-owned farms since February. Mr Mugabe insisted the aim was to force land redistribution, but his critics said it was to intimidate black rural voters ahead of national elections.

Mr Hain, giving evidence to the Commons' foreign affairs select committee, said that Zimbabwe faced the worst crisis in its short history and accused Mr Mugabe of failing to act against lawlessness and violence. He said: "When black African leaders abuse human rights that is no different from the old dictatorship of Ian Smith and it is important we should not have double standards."

Although pessimism about Zimbabwe's immediate future has engulfed the Foreign Office, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and Mr Hain remain hopeful that Mr Mugabe will send a delegation to Britain to discuss land reform. Mr Hain said a meeting could be as early as next week.

A further opportunity for discussion will be provided by the Commonwealth ministerial action group scheduled for London on May 2.

Mr Hain acknowleged there was huge unfairness in the distribution of land and stood ready to discuss what aid Britain could give to the land reform process. But there was no money set aside for the Zimbabwean authorities to claim and no question of Britain simply providing compensation for land seizures.

The department of international development funds programmes to help the poor in Zimbabwe but it bypasses the government.

Earlier, Zimbabwe's information minister, Chem Chimutengwende, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "What is going on in the country is a result of hundreds of years of racist oppression by the British settlers. What is happening now is the unfinished business of the liberation struggle."

Mr Hain described his comments as "the same old gramophone record trying to put Britain in the dock because it suits their purpose".

Mr Chimutengwende said the Zimbabwean government did not support attacks on white farmers, but added: "The attacks are the result of provocation. They were attacking the freedom fighters who had come to their farm."

He said: "Our president thought that the British and the white settlers in this country were going to be reasonable and were going to accept the new order, but they have not accepted it and have continued to be unreasonable and intransigent and all want to keep all of the wealth of this country to themselves."

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Liverpool FC. On a visit to the city Cherie Blair revealed that she wants her new baby to know its Liverpool roots. Asked whether she wanted the baby to follow in Tony Blair's footsteps and become a Newcastle United fan she said: "Oh no, it will have to be Liverpool - there is no question about that."

Bad day

Hampshire police. They spent the day trawling the streets in search of men for an identity parade. The spec was to find men with red beards, aged between 50 and 60, 5ft 5in to 5ft 11in. They could only find two. They did not though try the foreign office where 54-year-old, bearded and proud of it, Robin Cook is almost certainly unavailable.

Complaint of day

Tory peer Lord Bridgeman criticised the practice of requiring prisoners to make more than one and a quarter million pairs of socks. It's "not fulfilling or productive," he said.

Quote of day

The Conservative "caricature of rural issues as being no more than foxhunting, farming and green belt is an insult to the diverse communtities which live in the countryside" - Wrekin MP Peter Bradley launching a rural manifesto supported by 100 Labour backbenchers.

Today

Commons: PM's questions. Utilities bill, remaining stages. Lords: Debate on 30th anniversary of the Chronically Sick and Disabled Persons Act.

webTitle: 'Land redistribution is not robbery, but a necessity'

fields.headline: 'Land redistribution is not robbery, but a necessity'
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Edited commentary from the government-owned Zimbabwe Herald newspaper
fields.body:
Edited commentary from the government-owned Zimbabwe Herald newspaper

South Africa's President Thabo Mbeki had sober words for those hoping for a fall-out between his country and Zimbabwe over the issue of the farm invasions.

Questioned by journalists in Cuba this week, he instead urged dialogue, saying there is need for Zimbabwe and Britain to get together, back to the understanding reached when the independence of Zimbabwe was negotiated in 1979 and to solve the problem that way.

He rightly noted that Britain and the US had at the time committed themselves to funding the purchase of white-owned land.

President Mbeki's responses were to the obvious chagrin of those who misguidedly thought that Zimbabwe's powerful neighbour would bring pressure to bear on the government of Zimbabwe for the benefit of the status quo on land.

The land problem, which Morgan Tsvangirai and his Movement for Democratic Change would rather contemptuously treat as a periphery issue, was the major stumbling block at the Lancaster House conference in London in 1979. It remains the stumbling block to peace and security in Zimbabwe.

The constitutional agreement, signed on December 21 that year, placed restrictions on the first majority rule government's ability to redistribute land forcibly taken away from the blacks over some 90 years of colonial rule.

Election or no election, the land needs to be redistributed, and fast too, to correct the imbalance and bring the majority of the indigenous people out of subsistence farming in the virtually barren communal areas.

And these communal farmers are not where they are today through choice.

In the very early days of colonialism in the late 1890s, the first "reserves" created for the blacks were deliberately on land so poor and hostile that the colonials themselves did not want it.

And, for example, 38% of the black population of Matabeleland had been forced into such areas by 1898.

By 1931 a handful of whites had some 50m acres of prime land while vast numbers of blacks were herded onto just 21m acres.

This policy of keeping the black farmers poor and, therefore, subservient to the colonial masters, was to be carried further by successive colonial regimes, with the Land Apportionment Act of 1930 and the Land Tenure Act of 1969, in particular.

In Havana last week, President Mugabe was emphatic about the government's determination to acquire land from the white farmers, who own up to 75% of the best farmland, for redistribution to the disadvantaged black population. He stressed that the government would not allow any resistance to this. But, as he has done previously, he also assured that no farmer would be left without land.

As with past appeals long before the farm invasions by liberation war veterans, if the farmers want to have a secure future in this country they would be well advised to treat land redistribution not as "robbery" as they prefer to view it, but a virtual necessity. It is vitally important, for future peace and prosperity, that the farmers accept that a situation where they sit on vast acres of prime land - the result of colonial brutal actions on the blacks - is untenable.

Zimbabwe's economy is agriculture-based and a major advantage of putting more people on productive land will be a rise in output, with the resultant benefits to the economy.

The time should have long since passed when some of these farmers treat their farms as "little Rhodesias" where they, and only they, rule supreme, to the extent of disparaging anyone black, including the president and the government.

The passing of the constitutional amendment on land returns the responsibility to Britain of paying for land acquired from white commercial farmers as agreed at Lancaster in 1979.

The present distribution of land in this African country is untenable, with just a minute number of "European" farmers - up to 4,500 - owning upwards of 70% of the most fertile land.

Rather than hoping to cling on to it by sponsoring a political party they imagine can stem the tide, the white community would be best advised to work with the government for a permanent distribution that will bring prosperity through the land to the greater majority, and not just the few as at present.

It is foolish for any ethnic minority to throw all its eggs into one leaky basket by taking the extremist position of supporting to the hilt the opposition against a government, in a manner that absolutely has nothing to do with democracy.

What will the minority do when the opposition loses?

webTitle: Tory asylum camps could cost extra £850m

fields.headline: Tory asylum camps could cost extra £850m
fields.standfirst:
Camps could cost £850mTories in opposition: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's draconian new asylum policy was facing a severe credibility crisis even before its launch last night as preliminary estimates revealed it could double the cost of Britain's asylum system.
fields.byline: Alan Travis, Nicholas Watt  and  Lucy Ward
fields.body:
William Hague's draconian new asylum policy was facing a severe credibility crisis even before its launch last night as preliminary estimates revealed it could double the cost of Britain's asylum system.

The outline of the Tory plan to incarcerate all new asylum applicants and their families in secure detention centres was leaked without any detailed costings, in advance of Mr Hague speech to the Social Market Foundation.

But Home Office sources confirmed that the punitive scheme was likely to involve building up to 20 detention centres at a cost of £40m each and running costs of £11m a year for each 400-bed "secure facility". The total bill could double the £867m a year it costs to run the asylum system now.

But the Tories insisted that would be offset by the savings made as a result of the "significant deterrent effect" and by turning around applications within six weeks instead of the current 13 months.

Although he said it would be wrong to see such detention centres as prisons, Mr Hague said they would be secure enough to ensure that asylum-seekers would not be able to "disappear into the wider community". Asylum seekers would be fed, clothed and housed at the centres with schooling provided for their children.

The Conservative leader last night eschewed use of the word "bogus" and did not repeat the claim in his party's local elections manifesto that such asylum seekers were "flooding into Britain". Nevertheless ministers accused him of seeking to "stir up and exploit" the issue in the run-up to the local elections on May 4.

The Refugee Council described the Conservative plan as "draconian as well as being very expensive" and said that people who had fled persecution, human rights abuses and, in some cases, torture should not be treated like criminals. The experience in Germany was that such detention centres became the target for racist attacks.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees also condemned Mr Hague. Hope Hanlan, its London representative, said: "People have to stop riding this asylum horse right into the ground. Enough is enough."

But Mr Hague remained unmoved as he insisted that drastic action needed to be taken to toughen up Britain's "weak and arbitrary" system. In his widely trailed speech, he warned that Britain would turn into an "intolerant and unwelcome society" if the government did not crack down.

"Our proud tradition of offering sanctuary is now under threat as never before because a system to identify and protect refugees, which was designed half a century ago, is near collapse in today's utterly different world," he said.

The Tory leader confirmed that he would detain all asylum seekers in "secure reception centres" while their applications were processed and he pledged to establish a "removals agency" to eject anyone whose application was rejected.

"By ensuring that the centres are secure [we can] make sure that people who are trying to evade immigration controls are kept in one place and not allowed to disappear into the wider community," Mr Hague said. "I am convinced this policy will have a significant deterrent effect on those thinking of travelling here without a well founded case."

Other measures he announced included barring asylum seekers from countries which were "manifestly safe", including those that had been accepted for EU membership, and putting pressure on countries to abide by the Dublin Convention which stipulates that asylum seekers should be dealt with in the first coutry they enter.

Mr Hague qualified his hardline message by saying that he remained committed to Britain providing a haven to people in fear of their lives. "The tradition is rightly a source of national pride and it has brought important benefits to our country," he said.

fields.headline: Mugabe attacks 'white enemies'
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe launched his most furious onslaught yet on white farmers yesterday, branding them "enemies of Zimbabwe" and blaming Britain for his country's turmoil.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe launched his most furious onslaught yet on white farmers yesterday, branding them "enemies of Zimbabwe" and blaming Britain for his country's turmoil.

In two public statements marking the 20th anniversary of independence - one delivered in English, the other in Shona - he signalled divergent political messages. In English, he expressed regret for deaths on the farms. In the Shona version, he congratulated war veteran squatters.

White farmers, he said, perpetuated "vestigial atti tudes from the Rhodesian yesteryears".

His words came shortly after a second white farmer, Martin Olds, had been shot dead and an other farmer abducted and then later released.

"After 1997," Mr Mugabe said, "we also had to contend with the reluctance of the new Labour government which did not want to honour commitments made by previous British governments on the land issue."

Mac Crawford, head of the farmers' union in the south-western Bulawayo area, accused Mr Mugabe's government of arming the veterans.

In two public statements marking the 20th anniversary of independence - one delivered in English, the other in Shona - he signalled divergent political messages. In English, he expressed regret for deaths on the farms. In the Shona version, he congratulated war veteran squatters. White farmers, he said, perpetuated "vestigial atti tudes from the Rhodesian yesteryears". His words came shortly after a second white farmer, Martin Olds, had been shot dead and an other farmer abducted and then later released. "After 1997," Mr Mugabe said, "we also had to contend with the reluctance of the new Labour government which did not want to honour commitments made by previous British governments on the land issue." Mac Crawford, head of the farmers' union in the south-western Bulawayo area, accused Mr Mugabe's government of arming the veterans.

fields.headline: Ulster blueprint takes shape
fields.standfirst:
Blair in talks with Ahern to save faltering peace deal

The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: The battle to save the ailing Good Friday agreement switched to Dublin last night as Tony Blair held talks with Bertie Ahern, his Irish counterpart, after meeting the main players in the Northern Ireland peace process to figure out their bottom line for forthcoming negotiations.
fields.body:
The battle to save the ailing Good Friday agreement switched to Dublin last night as Tony Blair held talks with Bertie Ahern, his Irish counterpart, after meeting the main players in the Northern Ireland peace process to figure out their bottom line for forthcoming negotiations.

Mr Blair had unscheduled second meetings with both Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists as he sounded them out on a possible solution towards restoring devolution.

Its key plank is to persuade the IRA to issue an as yet unspecified statement to boost Ulster Unionists' confidence.

The IRA is expected to deliver its customary message tomorrow to mark the 1916 Easter Rising in An Phoblacht (Republican News). But indications from republican sources last night were that no initiatives would be announced in it.

The two governments, close to an agreed approach, have given up on even a start to paramilitary decommissioning before May 22, the deadline in the agreement for its completion. They are prepared to give terrorist groups more time, providing the IRA delivers the required statement.

But they are desperate to restore before them the institutions of devolved government suspended two months ago by Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary.

The blueprint that is taking shape would involve another round of sequencing.

Republicans will be asked to say more than they have on arms. But David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, may be required to accept that the government will never again restore direct rule from Westminister. He appeared to pour cold water on that suggestion last night.

As he arrived at Hillsborough Castle in Co Down, Mr Blair made clear that he remained committed to the agreement, now two years old.

His last visit to Northern Ireland nine months ago had failed to signal a breakthrough to the long-standing impasse over paramilitary arms.

The prime minister called on political leaders to do their best to break the deadlock. It would be tragic and foolish to pass up the prospects of lasting peace.

He said: "The Good Friday agreement remains the only show in town. There's not going to be another, and when people say that the agreement is in tatters, it is nonsense.

"The basis of the Good Friday agreement remains. There was an issue there revolving around how we make sure that there is proper confidence that violence is a thing of the past. It is an issue that remains and still has to be dealt with."

Mr Blair avoided any direct reference to weapons decommissioning. He spoke instead about building confidence that violence was over for good.

Although he said there were possibilities of a breakthrough, he was playing down expectations of that being im minent.

He reiterated that he was simply taking stock, but sources from several parties last night indicated he was instead testing the ground.

While demanding that Mr Blair put pressure on Mr Ahern to push republicans, Mr Trimble was fighting shy of using the decommissioning word.

He has said he would consider re-entering the exec utive with Sinn Fein before a start to IRA decommissioning if the conditions were right.

He emphasised the aim was to show political violence was over for good. He spoke of a "completely and irrevocably peaceful environment".

webTitle: Labour veteran vows to vote for Livingstone

fields.headline: Labour veteran vows to vote for Livingstone
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: A veteran trade union leader risks expulsion from the Labour party after vowing to vote for Ken Livingstone in next month's London mayor election.
fields.body:
A veteran trade union leader risks expulsion from the Labour party after vowing to vote for Ken Livingstone in next month's London mayor election.

Ron Todd, former head of the Transport and General Workers' union, and a party member for 53 years, is the most high-profile member to publicly back the rebel leftwinger.

Writing in tomorrow's Tribune, he openly declares he will vote for the independent Mr Livingstone instead of official Labour candidate Frank Dobson in a clear breach of the party's rules.

Walthamstow-born Mr Todd, 73, lives in Dagenham, east London, near the Ford car plant he used to represent. He speaks of his sadness over the government's direction, particularly its treatment of pensioners, and anger at Millbank's "alleged rigging" to stop the ex-GLC leader winning the party's nomination.

Supporting a candidate standing against Labour's own is considered "detrimental to the party" under Labour's rules and Mr Todd could face disciplinary action, including suspension or expulsion.

webTitle: Farmers ignore law by failing to report scrapie

fields.headline: Farmers ignore law by failing to report scrapie
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Farmers are hampering attempts to check whether BSE has spread from cows to sheep by failing to report a similar disease in their flocks, a report by government vets suggests .
fields.body:
Farmers are hampering attempts to check whether BSE has spread from cows to sheep by failing to report a similar disease in their flocks, a report by government vets suggests .

They conclude only about one in eight sheep farmers who suspect their livestock is suffering from scrapie is obeying the law by telling the authorities, raising concerns over the effectiveness of efforts to control the disease.

The vets, who surveyed more than 7,000 sheep farmers, also found that many who did not think any of their animals had experienced scrapie did not know the clinical signs of the disease - which include rubbing up against posts because of skin irritation, nervous and aggressive behaviour and an unsteady gait.

The investigation was demanded by scientific advisers on BSE and its fatal human equivalent, variant CJD, which is probably caused by eating infected beef. They want more checks on brains of slaughtered sheep to see whether they have BSE too, and improvements to scrapie surveillance.

BSE has never been proved to exist in sheep outside the laboratory, while scrapie has been endemic for more than 250 years and never linked to human disease.

But some scientists believe scrapie may have caused BSE through recycling of infected sheep in animal feed. The diseases are hard to distinguish and if BSE were found, the only method of control would be culling affected animals and their lambs.

There would be disastrous economic implications. Even with scrapie, the vets say "many farmers may be reluctant to report cases owing to the possible loss of markets, both national and international, and the potential loss of livelihood".

As with BSE and CJD, there is no test for live animals and the government is belatedly to introduce the compulsory tagging of sheep to improve checks on their provenance.

Failure to report scrapie can attract unlimited fines - although its true extent is difficult to establish. Last year there were 593 confirmed cases compared with 328 in 1993, 508 in 1997 and 499 in 1998.

That is a small proportion of the 40m sheep and lambs, and far fewer than the 2,250 BSE cases in cattle confirmed last year, but the disease is most likely to be a problem in the 20m breeding flock where the animals are older than most sold for slaughter.

Peter Smith, acting chairman of the spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee on BSE-like diseases, said: "We have always been aware scrapie was likely to be quite substantially under-reported.

"I don't think this came as a great shock to us. We are looking at ways to eradicate it from Britain and we would feel a lot more comfortable if it was not around."

The vets, from the government's veterinary laboratory agency and the institute of animal health in Compton, Berkshire, analysed responses to a questionnaire sent to farmers with flocks with more than 30 breeding ewes. Nearly 15% thought they had experienced scrapie and 2.7% thought they had had it in the past year.

A comparison with the number of farmers who reported suspect cases to the Ministry of Agriculture suggested only 13% of those with suspect cases were doing so.

The findings, published in the Veterinary Record, said flocks in Yorkshire, Humberside and the Shetland Islands appeared to be most at risk. These are areas involved in anti-scrapie measures, including attempts to breed resistant stock.

Officials believe the rise in scrapie cases recorded in recent years may be due to improved reporting. But the ministry said yesterday: "The reporting rate is unacceptably low."

In 1998, it introduced compensation for farmers whose suspect animals were destroyed, and it was issuing publicity material to increase awareness of the disease.

webTitle: Hague tough line hailed by supporters as on target

fields.headline: Hague tough line hailed by supporters as on target
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's decision to toughen up the Tories' asylum policy was hailed by his supporters last night as a powerful example of his ability to respond to the concerns of ordinary folk.
fields.body:
William Hague's decision to toughen up the Tories' asylum policy was hailed by his supporters last night as a powerful example of his ability to respond to the concerns of ordinary folk.

During a series of Keep the Pound rallies around Britain in recent months, the Tory leader is said to have been struck by the number of voters who have complained to him personally that the asylum crisis is the most pressing political issue facing Britain.

"We have pledged to listen to Britain and William's speech shows that we are doing just that," one senior Tory said.

Labour sources said, however, that the Tory leadership was deluding itself if it believed that the few hundred people who turned up at Keep the Pound rallies represented a broad swath of public opinion.

The rallies usually attract rightwing opponents of Europe who are even more determined to defend the pound than Mr Hague and are therefore likely to be deeply hostile to asylum seekers.

Allowing xenophobes at Eurosceptic rallies to dictate party policy provides another strong example of Mr Hague's lurch to the right, ministers believe.

The think this shows that the Tories have abandoned the political centre ground, where elections are won.

Mr Hague attempted to qualify the shrill tone of his speech by insisting that he remained committed to the British tradition of providing a safe haven for people genuinely fleeing persecution. However, his central message showed how the Tories show no signs of resembling an alternative government for two broad reasons.

Mr Hague's harsh language yesterday, in a speech that was leaked to the rightwing Daily Telegraph, Daily Mail and Sun, show that the Tory leadership is still only able to address its own constituency.

Tories hope that his pledge to detain all asylum seekers will prove to be a vote winner in next month's local elections, and in next year's general election.

However, Mr Hague appears not have learned the harsh lesson absorbed by Labour in the 1980s that a party which only addresses its core supporters will be repeatedly rejected by the voters.

Central Office makes great play of its attempts to reach out beyond its traditional white, middle class support base.

These efforts are likely now to be in tatters.

Mr Hague seems to have ignored another lesson which Labour eventually learnt in the 1980s: never outline a major shift in policy without subjecting it to a rigorous assessment of the costs.

Mr Hague's calculation that his plan would eventually save taxpayers £600m appears to be back of the envelope stuff, which was challenged by the Home Office yesterday.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, who has condemned both the Labour party and the Conservatives for their use of inflammatory language, summed up the charge against Mr Hague.

"I guess that the Hague speech is much less about the interests of refugees, asylum seekers or the British electorate than the interests of the Tory party," he said.

fields.headline: Flaws in Tories' asylum model
fields.standfirst:
Refugees Scheme to cut time for handling applications to six weeks with new detention centres seen as meeting public demandsTories in opposition: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's new asylum plans are based on the German system for asylum seekers but with a more optimistic timescale - six weeks - for resolving claims than even Berlin's bureaucratic efficiency can achieve.
fields.body:
William Hague's new asylum plans are based on the German system for asylum seekers but with a more optimistic timescale - six weeks - for resolving claims than even Berlin's bureaucratic efficiency can achieve.

Initial calculations - supported by Home Office estimates -show that Mr Hague's plan to house all new asylum seekers in secure detention centres while their applications are being resolved would double the £857m annual cost of Britain's asylum system.

Conservative Party spokesmen yesterday suggested that only "five or six reception centres holding between 300 to 400" would be needed.

But this would only create places for 2,400 asylum seekers. Applications are running at 6,000 to 7,000 a month.

Many cover families so the number of people applying for asylum each month probably exceeds 10,000.

The Conservatives say they intend to cut the time it takes to resolve a claim from the current average of 13 months to six weeks.

If, and it is a very big if, they achieved this target they would need a minimum of 9,000 places for applicants, although that excludes women and children who apply as part of families, in a network of more than 20 detention centres with about 400 places each.

The newly opened processing centre at Oakington, near Cambridge, has 400 places and cost £4m to convert from former army barracks. The running costs amount to £527 a week for each place or nearly £11m a year.

But there is not an inexhaustible supply of former army barracks around the country waiting to be converted into asylum detention centres.

The prison service has spent three years scouring the country for possible sites for such centres.

The Oakington camp only became available after a 2 year planning battle, and the service has exhausted possibilities of using other sites.

The service has had to turn to prison ships to bridge the gap.

These "floatels" could be an option for the Conservatives - they are used in Hamburg - but are regarded as only a short-term solution.

So the Tories would have to build most of the extra detention centres needed at a cost of £40m each, according to Home Office figures.

The total bill could easily top £900 million which would double the cost of the current system.

Mr Hague says he would make savings in the annual £600m cost in vouchers and accommodation by cutting the average waiting time to six weeks.

But most commentators are highly sceptical of Labour's promise to cut the current wait of 13 months to six months by next April.

When the shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe was immigration minister in the last government, the average wait was 23 months.

Labour has employed 400 extra case workers at the asylum division of the Home Office in Croydon in an attempt to achieve its target.

They are making decisions at the rate of 10,000 a month.

To get the wait down from 13 months to six weeks would require hundreds more staff.

webTitle: Third strike for Windows CE in Palm territory

fields.headline: Third strike for Windows CE in Palm territory
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft's partners will today announce their next attack on the palmtop computer/electronic organiser market currently dominated by an American company, Palm.
fields.body:
Microsoft's partners will today announce their next attack on the palmtop computer/electronic organiser market currently dominated by an American company, Palm.

At glitzy events in London and New York, Casio, Compaq and Hewlett-Packard are to announce new handheld Pocket PCs running the latest version of Microsoft's Windows CE operating system.

While CE has been adopted for uses from braille terminals to games consoles, and from in-car computers to petrol pumps, its showing in the handheld computer sector which it entered in 1996 has been dismal. CE machines have looked clunky alongside Palm systems that have been smaller, sleeker and simpler.

Still, industry analysts have noted that Microsoft Windows sales did not explode until Windows 3.0 appeared, and the same thing might happen with Windows CE 3.0. Diana Hwang, an analyst at American research company International Data Corporation, says: "Three times is a charm."

CE3 is certainly a vast improvement on earlier versions, and Microsoft says every pixel of the Pocket PC screen has been changed. It has a much cleaner appearance and is significantly easier to use.

Microsoft has also increased the functionality of the software, though it was already more powerful than the Palm's. It has thrown in Media Player software, so that Pocket PCs work as MP3 music players and video playback devices. It has thrown in ClearType electronic book software, so it can compete with machines like Rocket's eBook. It has thrown in a version of Microsoft Money, for tracking expenses and share prices. And while it hardly rivals Nintendo's Game Boy, the Pocket PC is much faster and is now very capable of playing games.

Since the software includes Pocket versions of Microsoft's Office programs, including Word and Excel, Microsoft claims it provides almost everything most users need.

Rogers Weed, director of marketing for Microsoft's mobile device division in Seattle, says: "The Pocket PC will define the state of the art in this category."

But Chris Letocq, principal analyst at Dataquest and a leading expert in the mobile computing field, has reservations, as most Pocket PCs will be bought for business use. "The music playing and picture viewing capabilities are nice to have, but they're not essential for getting the job done."

Letocq argues that the Pocket PC, while it does a good job of synchronising automatically with a desktop PC, falls short of providing a mobile version of Outlook, Microsoft's desktop information manager.

However, the software is only one factor in purchasing decisions, and Microsoft's hardware partners have made dramatic improvements in their offerings.

But while many analysts are bullish about the Pocket PC, no one seems to think it will displace Palm. Mobile Insights, for example, predicts Microsoft's share of the handheld market will grow from about 10% to 23% by 2003, but this will still leave it a long way behind.

In the computer industry, the best technology doesn't always win.

fields.headline: Pushyparent.co.uk going public
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Pushy parents will have a new weapon in the battle to keep their children on the top of their schooling. Goal, which offers a web-based service to test the academic performance of schoolchildren, will float on the alternative investment market next week.
fields.body:
Pushy parents will have a new weapon in the battle to keep their children on the top of their schooling. Goal, which offers a web-based service to test the academic performance of schoolchildren, will float on the alternative investment market next week.

By completing multiple-choice tests on national-curriculum subjects, the hapless youngsters can be graded in relation to their peers. The likelihood of their under performing at exams can be spotted earlier and sorted before they sit examinations proper.

The idea is the brainchild of Midlands entrepreneur Wynford Dore, and his cousin, former head teacher Gareth Newman, chairman and chief executive respectively. Goal's core market will be 31,000 schools in England and Wales, including independent ones. The Information and Communications Survey of state schools for the year ended March 31, 1999 showed that 93% of secondary schools and more than 60% of primary and special schools have internet connections.

The firm has developed a bank of multiple-choice questions to cover all attainment levels and all key stages of eight compulsory national curriculm subjects and will offer free trials to schools begining from next month.

The move will prepare the ground for the launch of a fee-based service in the autumn. Goal, based in Leamington Spa, hopes to exploit the government's enthusiasm for computer based learning to become Britain's main force in online testing, which it claims will allow schools to raise their exam scores sharply.

The company, which has joined Aim through a placing, is expected to raise around £10m through 4.5m shares priced at 225p each.The proceeds will be used to build sales and technical support teams and repay £430,000 of directors start-up loans. Following the placing, arranged by Williams de Broe, there will be 24.5m ordinary shares in issue valuing Goal at £55.12m at placing price. The dealing in ordinary shares begins on April 28.

Goal plans to sell access codes to schools to allow pupils to complete tests on eight national curriculum subjects. The results would be available within hours, where currently they can take months.

Parents will be able to buy a different version of the test for use at home to boost the level of their children's academic achievements.
