fields.headline: Thank you, England
fields.standfirst: Today it is Romanies and Kosovans. But a century ago it was Jews fleeing the pogroms. David Leigh's grandfather was one of them. And as the major parties vie to prove they are toughest on asylum, he wonders if Abraham Levack would be allowed into Britain today. Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Today it is Romanies and Kosovans. But a century ago it was Jews fleeing the pogroms.  David Leigh's grandfather was one of them. And as the major parties vie to prove they are toughest on asylum, he wonders if Abraham Levack would be allowed into Britain today.
fields.body:
In my grandfather's 1920 wedding photograph, he stands awkwardly, looking something of an impostor in an all too obviously rented topper and tails. That photo was taken in London several years after he successfully wormed his way (as some might put it these days) into Britain. Fetching the picture out now, I think: "Were you a bogus asylum seeker, grandpa?"

It is a dismaying question to find running through the mind, because I had always previously felt quite straightforwardly towards those in authority who had let my grandfather, Abraham Levack, in off the dockside. My longstanding emotion can be summed up very simply. Thank you, England.

Now the airwaves are heavy with the most malevolent descriptions of asylum seekers and their dirty ways. "Flooding" is the word I'm sure I heard Ann Widdecombe use on the radio one morning. The tabloids are baying, and a Labour home secretary is issuing demeaning vouchers and talking of tough measures against foreigners. William Hague promises a "removals agency" to speed the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers and the Daily Mail hires Paul Johnson as his cheerleader: "I salute Mr Hague for the courage and vigour with which he has broached the issue." Johnson assures respectable England in large type that "the problem of asylum seekers is now the biggest issue in British politics. It affects all of us".

Is it people like my family that he means to define as "the problem"? I suspect it is. When my grandfather arrived, he and his brothers could not speak a word of English. And they were not alone in that. The hired gun Paul Johnson himself, flying a much more tolerant flag in his book, A History of the Jews, describes vividly the apprehension he fancies to have been aroused by the appearance in the west of that vast crowd of would-be migrants from Russia: "These two million refugee Jews were overwhelmingly Yiddish-speaking, Orthodox or Hasidic, wild-eyed and frightened, superstitious, and desperately poor."

They were described as "alien hordes". This was the first modern mass refugee movement. Britain at the time had an open-door policy that allowed any destitute foreigner in without controls. But not for long. Soon it passed its very first immigration law - the Aliens Act of 1905. Its purpose was to exclude as many as possible of these poor Jews from Russia. To that extent, all the arriving "asylum seekers" were regarded as "bogus" (as we would put it today). They were not allowed to land without a permit from an immigration officer, and could thereafter be expelled for poverty, criminal convictions, or vagrancy.

Professor Saskia Sassen from the University of Chicago, one of the most authoritative analysts of world migration flows, points out: "This act made a distinction between refugees and immigrants; its perspective on refugees was one of political activists or revolutionaries suffering persecution, not masses of poor persecuted people. The Jews were not seen as refugees."

And the passage of the act had been promoted by years of violent press attacks on these "bogus" arrivals. In 1888 the Manchester City News wrote: "Their unclean habits, their wretched clothing and miserable food enables them to perpetuate existence upon a pittance... They have flooded the market with cheap labour."

The Mail of those times carried reportage about the arrival of my foreign family and those like them that was even more venomous than its equivalent today. In 1900, its reporter described the passenger liner Cheshire docking in Southampton with "600 so-called refugees" among its passengers.

"There were Russian Jews, Polish Jews, German Jews, Peruvian Jews: all kinds of Jews, all manner of Jews. They fought and jostled for the foremost place at the gangways; they rushed and pushed into the troopshed, where the mayor of Southampton... had provided free refreshments. They had breakfasted well on board, but they rushed as though starving at the food. They cursed if they were not quickly served, they helped themselves at will, they thrust the children to the background, they pushed the women... they jostled and upset the weak, they spilled coffee on the ground in wanton waste.

"Incredible as it may seem, the moment they were in the [rail] carriages they played all manners of games at cards, staking sovereigns on a single card. These were the penniless refugees, and when the relief committee passed by they hid their gold and fawned and whined and... asked for money for their train fare."

My grandfather - as you might expect - told a very different story. Although there were aspects of my own family's flight which did not fit perfectly with the preferred notion of the political refugee, their whole exodus was plainly brought about by the excesses of the Romanov regime and Tsar Nicolas II - "that wicked tyrant", as my grandfather referred to him.

Abraham Levack and his parents originally lived in Lipcon, outside the town of Kishinev, near the river Pruth which divided Romania from Ukraine as it ran down towards the Black Sea. Their lives were pretty hellish by the sound of it.

Successive tsars had sought to shore up the popularity of the crumbling Russian state by bullying and impoverishing the Jews, herding them into reservations, banning them from many occupations, blocking them from education, and conscripting their sons into the lowest ranks of the tsarist army.

In 1881 came a first wave of pogroms in Ukraine, with mobs attacking more than 100 Jewish communities. It reverberated as far as England itself, where humanitarian protests were met with the smooth tsarist explanation that popular hostility to the ways of the Jews had led to spontaneous misbehaviour. The authorities certainly intended to stamp it out, they said. The pogroms continued intermittently.

The hero of the family was my great-grandmother, Hannah Goldstein. It was she who ran the small holding, with the cow to make cheese for sale, on which the family subsisted. It was she who bore six children. And it was she who was left destitute - still breast-feeding my grandfather at the time - when her husband Solomon Levack injured his leg and contracted gangrene. In 1896, it took him a month to die in a primitive hospital.

Hannah Goldstein had got her eldest son out to London at the age of 18 to save him from being drafted into the Russian military. Her 16-year-old daughter followed. Finally, in 1901, she got herself out - illegally - with the rest of the young children. She bribed local Russians who we should today call racketeers, or human smugglers, and they hiked for three nights, until they got past the border guards and safe into Romania.

Hannah Goldstein had been wise to run. In 1903 came the big pogrom in Kishinev itself. The details are still commemorated in the history books. While police stood idly by, and Russian newspapers were censored, 45 Jews were killed, and nearly 600 injured and 1,500 homes destroyed by the mob.

Hannah's flight was the start of a desperate wandering through Europe that lasted for the next six years, first in Austria and then in Frankfurt, and finally in Holland, in Rotterdam. The plan was to sail to London. "They charged £5 per person," my grandfather Abraham recalled in later years. "That meant £25 for all of us, but we didn't possess that much." Another two years passed before the grown-up children in London could save the cash from their meagre wages and send it across.

The refugees' luckier compatriots made it to New York, the true destination of choice for those huddled masses yearning to breathe free. England was always second best. But at last my family got on the boat. They fetched up in the tenements around Brick Lane, part of the swarm of 200,000 Russian Jews who crammed for sanctuary into the east end of London. Thank you, England.

But how did the 12-year-old Abraham Levack, his brothers and his mother, beat the hostile provisions of the 1905 Aliens Act and talk their way in? I consulted Nicholas Blake QC, one of England's most prominent immigration lawyers. He pointed out they must have been able to persuade the authorities that they weren't going to be a burden on the state.

And they weren't. By God, they weren't! My illiterate grandfather went to school for the first time in his life - to the Jewish free school organised by his own community - for just two years, until he was 14. They taught him to read English, and offered to allow him to stay on until he was 16. It was a hard blow when Hannah Goldstein refused to let him have any more schooling. She needed him to earn money.

He wrote to me years later as an old man, saying sadly: "I very much regret that I had no opportunity to have the fortune of having a good English education, to which I was looking forward so much." He underlined the words "so much".

Instead came a lifetime of ill-paid work - as a shop boy on a bike; helping a cap manufacturer; and finally, 31 years in a hat factory. For that, he became entitled to the old-age pension and lived to the age of 90. Thank you, England.

The little Levack family clearly had an ambivalent status back at the dockside in 1907. Many of the general public certainly saw them as "bogus asylum seekers" - dirty, illiterate and dangerous; taking the bread out of English mouths. But the new regulations designed to shut them out were relatively porous. After demonstrating years of tenacity, and dragging themselves, sometimes illegally, across the whole breadth of Europe, my forebears did get in.

Would they be treated better or worse today, if they turned up on Jack Straw's doorstep? The Russian Jews would have received the same sort of hostile reaction from the Mail and the other tabloids that the Gypsies and the Kosovars get at present. My grandfather and his foreign-looking brothers would no doubt be once again accused these days of picking pockets in any spare time they had left over from raping English girls and spreading diseases.

But what about the government? Certainly in some respects, they'd have treated my family much worse while their cases were assessed. If the Home Office had their way, they'd be packed off to some remote part of the country far from friends and support; forced to live on inadequate and humiliating "asylo" vouchers; forbidden to work; and denied a speedy decision on their case.

As Nicholas Blake points out, the government would also now like to count against my family's request for asylum the two years they spent in Holland, waiting for the boat fare. "They'd say, 'No way, Jose' and suggest you went back there." With its large Jewish population for support and absence of persecution, Rotterdam would be classed as a safe haven. No need to come to England.

But it might nevertheless be possible to argue successfully against such a ruling, because we had two close family members already in the UK. In which case, everything would turn on whether we had a "well- founded fear of persecution". Poring over the checklist of the questions modern adjudicators must ask themselves, which the Home Office now publishes, I would have thought my grandfather must have had a sporting chance of success on those grounds. Every case has to be looked at "in the round", and there's plenty of room for discretion. But the Russian authorities were continuously mistreating the Jews in his "country of origin". No doubt of that.

All in all, then, my grandfather - who was an absolutely genuine refugee from persecution - would probably still get eventual asylum in this country if he arrived today, just as he did 93 years ago. But he would only be allowed in after enduring both a bad dose of media hostility, and treatment from the Labour government that is in some ways worse than that dished out to suffering migrants in the primitive days of 1907. For that, then, thank you, England.

First and second generation Britons talk to Pippa Crerar about how their families came to the United Kingdom

Zadie Smith novelist

"My mum grew up in Jamaica. Her mum left there when she was seven - to come here to work. Mum stayed behind and was brought up by her grandmother, who died in 1969. So then mum flew to England, aged 15, went to school for two years, then became a typist. She didn't feel England made things easy for her, but the feminist movement gave her different opportunities from what she would have had growing up in the Jamaican countryside. Mum always had problems getting a flat - it was the same after she married my dad, who's English.

Julia Neuberger rabbi

"My grandfather came over from Frankfurt in 1906 to work for his uncle's merchant bank, and my father was born here. My mother came from Germany fairly freely just before the war when she was 22, to be a domestic. Friends lent her money so her family could come over and wouldn't be reliant on the state.The rest of her family perished. I think if people are really fleeing from persecution and terror we are obliged to help them. If my parents had come to Britain under today's system, being white would have helped, and also my father's money."

webTitle: Vivendi allowed to keep Sky stake

fields.headline: Vivendi allowed to keep Sky stake
fields.standfirst:
Byers puts new strain on Murdoch relationship
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The government tested further its relations with Rupert Murdoch yesterday when Vivendi's acquisition of a 24.5% stake in BSkyB was given the green light by the competition commission.
fields.body:
The government tested further its relations with Rupert Murdoch yesterday when Vivendi's acquisition of a 24.5% stake in BSkyB was given the green light by the competition commission.

The clearance confounded conspiracy theorists who believed a behind the scenes deal had been brokered between Mr Murdoch and Tony Blair to oust the French company from BSkyB's share register.

Mr Murdoch is understood to have been rattled by Vivendi building up its stake in the pay television company, in which News Corporation has a 40% stake, last year.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said the investigation had found no reasons to block Vivendi from holding on to its stake in BSkyB. Concerns had been raised over the potential effect on the acquisition of sport and film rights through the shareholding.

The commission was due to report its findings on February 25 but extended its investigation last month, citing "important late evidence".

Mr Murdoch was angered last year when his attempt to acquire Manchester United football club was prevented by the government and reports two weeks ago suggested Mr Blair might be willing to intervene over Vivendi by way of compensation.

A statement from BSkyB yesterday said only that the company "welcomes Vivendi as an investor". Shares in BSkyB climbed 68p to £14.89 as dealers sighed with relief that the market would not be flooded with the company's stock.

Vivendi built its stake after the breakdown of a proposed merger between the French pay-TV group, Canal Plus, in which it has a 49% stake, and BSkyB. Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi's chief executive, recently called on Mr Murdoch to consider reopening negotiations.

There have been signals recently, however, that relations between News Corporation and Vivendi might be improving. Talks are said to be under way for Vivendi to take a stake in Mr Murdoch's planned merger of News Corp's global satellite interests, provisionally called Platco.

The discussions reportedly would see Vivendi's stake in BSkyB injected into the new company as well as a share of Canal Plus. They could also lead to BSkyB participating in Vivendi's mobile phone venture with Vodafone AirTouch.

Mr Byers said of Vivendi's stakebuilding: "Concerns expressed to the commission by third parties over the merger related mainly to the acquisition of broadcasting rights for sports and films and the supply of conditional access technology.

"The commission considers these concerns to be understandable given the position of BSkyB and Vivendi in the market. However, the commission takes the view that there are insufficient grounds to expect the merger adversely to affect competition or consumers in the UK."

 News Corp and Telecom Italia last night tightened their grips over Stream, the Italian pay-TV operator. They are acquiring the stakes held by Cecchi Gori, an Italian media group and SDS, a consortium of football clubs to take their holdings to 50% each. The deals are worth a total 380bn lire (£117m).

Mr Murdoch was angered last year when his attempt to acquire Manchester United football club was prevented by the government and reports two weeks ago suggested Mr Blair might be willing to intervene over Vivendi by way of compensation. A statement from BSkyB yesterday said only that the company "welcomes Vivendi as an investor". Shares in BSkyB climbed 68p to £14.89 as dealers sighed with relief that the market would not be flooded with the company's stock. Vivendi built its stake after the breakdown of a proposed merger between the French pay-TV group, Canal Plus, in which it has a 49% stake, and BSkyB. Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi's chief executive, recently called on Mr Murdoch to consider reopening negotiations. There have been signals recently, however, that relations between News Corporation and Vivendi might be improving. The discussions reportedly would see Vivendi's stake in BSkyB injected into the new company as well as a share of Canal Plus. They could also lead to BSkyB participating in Vivendi's mobile phone venture with Vodafone AirTouch. Mr Byers said of Vivendi's stakebuilding: "Concerns expressed to the commission by third parties over the merger related mainly to the acquisition of broadcasting rights for sports and films and the supply of conditional access technology. "The commission considers these concerns to be understandable given the position of BSkyB and Vivendi in the market. However, the commission takes the view that there are insufficient grounds to expect the merger adversely to affect competition or consumers in the UK."  News Corp and Telecom Italia last night tightened their grips over Stream, the Italian pay-TV operator. fields.headline: Granada jumps into web-TV fray
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Granada Media Group yesterday announced plans to shift the battle for Britain's internet users into the living room by providing full web access via the television.
fields.body:
Granada Media Group yesterday announced plans to shift the battle for Britain's internet users into the living room by providing full web access via the television.

The group which owns the Granada, Yorkshire, Tyne Tees and London Weekend ITV franchises is launching the service in July with a new, as yet undecided, consumer brand. A free set-top box would render web content for the TV screen and allow access to any content that could now be accessed by personal computers, the company said.

Many analysts believe that internet access moving to the more ubiquitous TV could have a dramatic effect on use of the net.

Users who enter the web through the Granada service will go through the home page of G-Wizz, the internet service provider the group launched three months ago.

"This really plays to the government agenda of getting over the e-divide," said Steve Morrison, chief executive of Granada Media. "Up to now, home internet access has been restricted to those who own computers and an estimated 70% of UK homes are not yet online. We are offering anyone who has a TV and a phone the opportunity to get online."

In a somewhat unusual business model, the company will offer access free of subscription charges in return for users filling in a monthly online survey of their spending habits. The data collected will then be sold on to the marketing departments of fast moving consumer goods companies. Time spent online will be charged at local call rates.

The venture is being launched in partnership with PowerChannel, an internet-based consumer research group which will subsidise the cost of the set-top boxes. As part of the deal, Granada is taking a 23.5% stake in the company for £13.5m.

The set-top box is similar in appearance to the hardware used by pay-TV subscribers. The box is plugged into the TV at one end and into a phone socket at the other. The set top boxes will be available for a £30 returnable deposit from any of Granada's 440 rental stores or direct from the company. An advertising push carrying a direct phone line will be launched in the autumn.

Mr Morrison said the service would accelerate the growth of e-commerce. "Because we are using a consumer friendly route that people are familiar with they will start buying over the web," he said.

Revenues from advertising, e-commerce, sponsorship and data sales will be shared between the two companies.

The theory that consumers will feel more comfortable buying goods and services from TV sets than they are via computers appears to be borne out by the experience of Open, the online service available on Sky Digital.

The Open service is a so-called "walled garden" and offers access only to a selected number of content providers including supermarket chain Asda, electrical goods retailer Comet, travel firm First Choice and insurer Cornhill. The service claims that more than 450,000 people have registered for e-mail services and that in the run-up to Christmas e-commerce revenues were running at up to £1m a week.

In a recent note, Mike Hilton, media analyst at ABN Amro forecast the service could have 3m active users by the end of the year suggesting that e-commerce will find a more natural home on the TV than the PC.

fields.headline: Orchestrating hysteria
fields.standfirst:
Mr Hague is too weak to resist temptationTories in opposition: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Could our asylum procedures be improved? They most certainly could. Future social historians will be shocked by the abject conditions which asylum seekers had to endure in such a prosperous society.
fields.body:
Could our asylum procedures be improved? They most certainly could. Future social historians will be shocked by the abject conditions which asylum seekers had to endure in such a prosperous society - the poor housing, difficulties in accessing health care, the 2,500 children not receiving any education, the lack of training opportunities for adults, the interminable delays (averaging 13 months) before decisions on applications are taken, the shameful backlog of 100,000 pending cases, the unnecessary detentions; and perhaps most pernicious of all, the government's demeaning vouchers which are replacing benefits.

Were any of these issues addressed by William Hague, the Conservative leader, in his widely leaked speech on asylum seekers yesterday? They were not. So what did he talk about? A nation under threat; a long tradition of extending hospitality to the persecuted that must be ended "not because our people have lost their sense of hospitality; not because we are unwilling to honour our obligations to genuine refugees; least of all because the British people are racist or xenophobic" - none of this: merely, and pathetically, because the 1951 Geneva Convention (drafted, remember, when there were millions of displaced people in Europe alone) was no longer appropriate.

To listen to Mr Hague, the uninformed might believe the Britain's floodgates were wide open. Nothing could be further from the truth. In the last six years there have been three asylum acts stiffening up procedures: the 1993 Act which tightened the appeal process; the 1996 Act which restricted benefits; and Labour's 1999 Act, designed to end all entitlement to benefits, extend the fines which can be imposed on airline and shipping companies that bring people here without valid travel documents, to gether with new powers to disperse refugees round the country. Few countries are harder to enter, since an even earlier asylum act in 1988 led to a fourfold increase in airline liaison officers stopping people with invalid documents from travelling to the UK.

So what is going on? Politics. Yesterday's speech had already been leaked to the main Tory cheerleaders - the Sun, Mail and Telegraph - where his proposal to detain all asylum applicants entering Britain until a decision is made received an ecstatic welcome: "The resilient unexciting man from Yorkshire is taking on the establishment" (Daily Telegraph). When the Tories have been in trouble - and their position in the polls has rarely been direr - they have turned to race. Andrew Lansley, former director of research at Central Office, admitted as much in 1995, noting immigration in the 1992 election and 1994 Euro elections "played particularly well in the tabloids". Now the Telegraph has joined them.

There are three fronts on which the Hague plan falls down: practical, financial, and ethical. It is based on using former army camps, but even supposing the 100,000 backlog was wiped out, he would need at least 20 centres to handle the 6,000 applicants a month. Home Office administrators have already surveyed former camps and found only one suitable. Each new centre would cost £40m to construct and £10m a year to run. Most serious of all is the breach to human rights: the presumption that most applicants are bogus, when 50% were accepted last year. The chief inspector of prisons has spoken of his concern about current centres, which house a mere 800 of the 100,000 backlog. Imagine the problems raised by housing 8,000. Mr Hague has dragged political debate down to a new low.

fields.headline: Bashir takes award
fields.trailText: Martin Bashir's interview with the Stephen Lawrence murder suspects was last night named the year's best piece of TV journalism at the Royal Television Society's Television Journalism Awards.
fields.body:
Martin Bashir's interview with the Stephen Lawrence murder suspects was last night named the year's best piece of TV journalism at the Royal Television Society's Television Journalism Awards.

Prime Suspects, an edition of ITV's Tonight, won programme of the year. But both Bashir and the Newsnight anchorman, Jeremy Paxman, lost out to BBC News 24's Tim Sebastian in the interviewer category.

Commenting on Bashir's win, the panel said: "It was a programme that created huge controversy, big headlines and undoubted public fascination.

"It was the story that every other journalist wanted."

Michael Brunson, formerly political editor at ITN, who has now been replaced by ex-BBC reporter John Sergeant, won the coveted judges' award in recognition of his career achievements.

And veteran BBC foreign correspondent John Simpson was named television journalist of the year for his uncompromising coverage of the Kosovo conflict from bomb-ravaged Belgrade.

The judges praised Simpson's "extraordinary skills in reporting from the heart of a country at war". Brunson was lauded for "getting it first and getting it right".

Sky News won the news event title for its live coverage of Kosovo Liberation Day, while Channel 4 News and London News Network took accolades for their overviews of the Paddington rail crash and Soho bombing respectively.

webTitle: Critics hated his motorbike exhibition. Now he aims to build a new $450m Guggenheim

fields.headline: Critics hated his motorbike exhibition. Now he aims to build a new $450m Guggenheim
fields.trailText: One of the last times the celebrated architect Frank Gehry collaborated with the Guggenheim, one of New York's great museums, it was on a display of motorcycles. Now they are working together to alter the cultural life of the city and with it one of the word's most readily identifiable skylines.
fields.body:
One of the last times the celebrated architect Frank Gehry collaborated with the Guggenheim, one of New York's great museums, it was on a display of motorcycles. Now they are working together to alter the cultural life of the city and with it one of the word's most readily identifiable skylines.

An exhibition of Mr Gehry's models for a new $450m (£285m) Guggenheim at one end of Wall Street overlooking the East river opens today at the institution's main building on Fifth Avenue.

It is a microcosm of a project that could work the Gehry transformation effect on a part of a big city dominated by steepling needles in much the same way as his Guggenheim did when it was built in Bilbao, a provincial city.

The new building on three piers jutting into the water in the direction of Brooklyn would allow the institution to split its collection, which includes work by Picasso, Van Gogh, Cézanne, Degas, Gauguin, Chagall, minimalist and conceptual art from the 1960s and 1970s and a horde of photographs started with a donation of 200 images from the Robert Mapplethorpe foundation. Art from 1945 to today would go to downtown Manhattan while the uptown Frank Lloyd Wright museum would be home to work from the late 19th century to the mid-20th.

The plans envisage 36 galleries of 1,300 sq ft to 20,000 sq ft on three levels around a 450ft tower, gardens, bridges, promenades, a cinema, a theatre, an ice rink with a sculpture by Claes Oldenburg and a dock for boats to a sculpture garden on nearby Governor's Island. The tower of 45 storeys would house offices, penthouses and perhaps a hotel.

Mr Gehry's main model, 12ft long and 5ft high, represents a building of swooping titanium wrappers on a roughly triangular structure of rollercoasters and ski-runs, an exclamation mark in front of grids of skyscrapers.

His installation The Art of the Motorcycle, more than 100 Harley-Davidsons, Indians, Moto Guzzis and Czech Bohmerlands, divided the critics 18 months ago but only in their means of expression.

"As between the noisy, nasty nuisance of motorcycles on the road and the noxious design ideas of Frank Gehry, it would be hard to say which I find more unappealing," wrote one. Another used longer words to say the same thing: "There has never been a more pathological display of institutional least-common-denominator braggadocio."

The public loved it, however: a record 3,000 a day paid to see the machines. While the plans for the new building have yet to stimulate such schisms, it is by no means certain that they will be ever be put into effect.

Up to $250m is said to have been promised by the Guggenheim's chairman, the insurance magnate Peter Lewis, but that still leaves its director, Thomas Krens, to find another $200m in competition with the Museum of Modern Art, which is raising $850m for an extension.

"How can you turn a project like this down, even if Krens has a long way to go to make it real?" said Mr Gehry. "It is such a compelling idea, any architect would die to do it." The idea received a fillip yesterday when the Robert Rauschenberg foundation said it would give more than 100 paintings and sculptures if it goes ahead.

But Mr Lewis acknowledges the problems ahead by saying: "This is a quixotic effort. We all think it is a spectacular idea but I despair of thinking there will be enough power and energy to get it done."

New York City's economic development corporation is also considering rival plans for a hotel, marina or berth for cruise ships. Two years ago a Gehry design for a Guggenheim on the other side of Manhattan was abandoned after local opposition.

But the Guggenheim has a history of overcoming obstacles. There was a furore in 1943 when Wright presented his spiral design for the uptown building which has been described as a citrus press, a mustard pot, a beehive and, by the architect Philip Johnson, as "one of the greatest rooms erected in the 20th century".

By the time it was finished 16 years later Wright had been dead for six months.

webTitle: A family's epic passion for art

fields.headline: A family's epic passion for art
fields.trailText: Solomon Guggenheim and his niece Peggy bought art on such an epic scale during most of the 20th century that their collections launched a fleet of galleries, each one world class.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Solomon Guggenheim and his niece Peggy bought art on such an epic scale during most of the 20th century that their collections launched a fleet of galleries, each one world class.

The money came from the unglamorous world of mining and minerals. The passion for collecting, striking in many of the richest European and American Jewish families, came from somewhere deeper.

In the late 1930s, as war approached, Peggy Guggenheim was said to be buying a work of art a day. In a few years she had spent $40,000 on the the project and acquired works by Constantin Brancusi, Alberto Giacometti and Max Ernst - to whom she was briefly married - which are now priceless.

The Guggenheims often bought cutting-edge art that would take years to become fashionable. They used advisers but also made purchases based on their own instincts.

Solomon Guggenheim's first New York gallery, the Museum of Non-Objective Painting, began life in 1937 in a former car showroom. In 1945, Frank Lloyd Wright unveiled his sensational model of a permanent home for the collection. Many doubted his spiral "temple of spirit" could be built. When it was completed in 1959 the building drew far larger crowds than the collection, just as the gleaming metal curves of Frank Gehry's Bilbao Guggenheim did when it opened in 1997.

Peggy Guggenheim's desire to create something equally startling was confounded by the second world war. She ran a string of temporary galleries, but failed to find a suitable permanent site in London or Paris. Eventually her collection found a haphazard base in her home in Venice.

The gallery has one of the most glamorous sites in the city, with a magnificent pillared gate on the Grand Canal left over from a Renaissance palazzo.

The new gallery would be the third Guggenheim in New York. As well as the Frank Lloyd Wright building, a smaller gallery in SoHo was opened in 1992.

In 1979, on her death, the Peggy Guggenheim Collection became part of the Guggenheim Foundation. Then in 1997 two new Guggenheims appeared. The Berlin Guggenheim, specialising in German collections reflecting the family's homeland, was developed in partnership with Deutsche Bank, and occupies the ground floor of its headquarters close to the Brandenburg Gate.

In the same year the Bilbao Guggenheim was launched and transformed the economy of the rundown post-industrial city at a stroke.
fields.bodyText: Solomon Guggenheim and his niece Peggy bought art on such an epic scale during most of the 20th century that their collections launched a fleet of galleries, each one world class. The money came from the unglamorous world of mining and minerals. The passion for collecting, striking in many of the richest European and American Jewish families, came from somewhere deeper. In the late 1930s, as war approached, Peggy Guggenheim was said to be buying a work of art a day. In a few years she had spent $40,000 on the the project and acquired works by Constantin Brancusi, Alberto Giacometti and Max Ernst - to whom she was briefly married - which are now priceless. The Guggenheims often bought cutting-edge art that would take years to become fashionable. They used advisers but also made purchases based on their own instincts. fields.headline: Mind the gap
fields.standfirst: The London tube makes no profit, so the government's PPP scheme will need some subsidy, just to stop the system collapsingTransport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's latest commitments on the future funding of London's transport system face the same problems as Frank Dobson's and everyone else - right in the middle of all of them is a huge funding gap. To meet it, either travellers pay a lot more for their tickets or taxpayers at large put in extra subsidy. Even if they do, at best the tube will be prevented from collapsing. Forget major improvements and decongestion.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's latest commitments on the future funding of London's transport system face the same problems as Frank Dobson's and everyone else - right in the middle of all of them is a huge funding gap. To meet it, either travellers pay a lot more for their tickets or taxpayers at large put in extra subsidy. Even if they do, at best the tube will be prevented from collapsing. Forget major improvements and decongestion.

Since the 1930s, the tube has been in public ownership and run as a service, not a commodity that makes a profit. Railways and metro systems the world over are unable to generate sufficient revenues to cover their costs and give a return on capital to their owners. This is why they have been publicly owned everywhere and paid for, or heavily subsidised by, national and local taxes.

The Blair government's PPP (public-private partnership) says three private sector infrastructure companies will take responsibility for, but not own, the infrastructure - the tracks, stations and rolling stock. The companies will carry out day-to-day maintenance and catch up on the £1.2bn backlog of investment in the system. London Underground is to pay the PPP companies an annual charge that enables them to make a return to their providers of finance.

Despite popular misconceptions, the tube does not make a surplus. So there will be a funding gap of between £110m and £175m a year between what the PPP will cost and what the tube can afford to pay. Also some critical assumptions have been built in: the PPP assumes use will rise by 40% and costs will continue to fall. Furthermore, while the concessions will run for 30 years, the annual charge will be renegotiated every seven to eight years, to take account of changed circumstances - a licence to print money. The tube's financial travails are far from over.

How is the gap to be filled? With fares at £1.50 for a single walk-on fare in the inner zone compared with £1 in New York and 50p in Paris for journeys of any length, fare increases above the rate of inflation are not on. That means the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions pays a subsidy or the Greater London Authority steps in - even though neither mayor nor assembly has been party to the decision-making process leading to the creation of the PPP.

The mayor could divert the proceeds of congestion taxes to pay off the PPP's bankers. But congestion charges aimed at reducing traffic, already deeply unpopular, may not bring in money. People might walk, cycle or work from home. Businesses might relocate. If revenues from road taxes became the main source of funding for transport other than fares, then other measures for reducing traffic that did not yield revenue - such as pedestrianisation, speed limits and restrictions on vehicular access - would be ignored. The need for revenues to fund the subsidy could end up driving policy.

The tube has already been split into four - which the government acknowledges imposes extra management and monitoring costs. This has implications for planning, co-ordination and safety. The fragmentation and privatisation of the national railways has given passengers ample foretaste of the chaos, inconvenience and worse that might follow.

Even if the subsidy gap is covered, all that the investment proposals on the table would do is stop the tube network collapsing. How are the new lines needed to relieve overcrowding to be planned, financed and built? No plans have been announced. Legal arrangements for the new companies are complex. There is a bargaining question, too, for if the infrastructure companies are preferred bidders for new lines, they will have London Underground over a barrel.

The PPP companies (like the companies that build and run hospitals, schools and prisons under the private finance initiative) are special purpose vehicles (SPVs). That is to say they are consortia of real companies which exist only because of the London Underground concession and attached revenue stream. The assumption has been built in that there will be implicit or explicit underwriting or guarantees by the public of any debt the SPVs incur before the financial institutions and markets will look at them.

As such, the PPP constitutes a new form of ownership. Instead of owning bricks and mortar, the PPPs and their financiers will own a future revenue stream that will be the first charge on the tube's income. Everything else must be subordinated to ensure that this commitment is met.

It is not that other forms of finance - London Transport bonds for example - do not face similar problems. Bonds may be cheaper, but servicing them will also require the mayor to find money to pump into the capital markets. Yet there is a particular dishonesty about the PPP. The government says it is a mechanism for ensuring that the underground is "publicly run, publicly controlled and properly financed". It is not.

Every year, the PPP - yes, and bonds - would require some combination of national and local funds to subsidise maintenance of the tube, with nothing left over for much-needed expansion. This will necessarily be more than the pittance the tube now gets. Thus the PPP companies - or the bond financiers - would gain effective control over transport policy. This is a fundamental and unwanted change in our public services.

Jean Shaoul is in the school of accounting and finance at Manchester University and co-author with Declan Gaffney and Allyson Pollock of Funding London Underground: Financial Myths and Economic Realities

webTitle: Fayed agrees oil deal with Libya

fields.headline: Fayed agrees oil deal with Libya
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods, is going into business with Libya's state-owned oil company.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods, is going into business with Libya's state-owned oil company.

The move could put him on a collision course with the American authorities. Tough US sanctions remain in place against companies dealing with the regime of Colonel Muammar Gadafy.

Mr Fayed said yesterday that, as well as helping develop three oil concessions, his Harrods Petroleum offshoot would help the Libyans set up a free zone in which companies would be offered tax breaks to invest in trade and industry. Other joint projects between Harrods and the Libyans, including tourist projects in the country, will be explored.

Britain last year lifted all Libyan sanctions, other than those covering arms, after the Tripoli authorities handed over for trial the suspects in the 1989 Lockerbie airliner bombing and admitted responsibility for the 1984 killing of Yvonne Fletcher, a police officer on duty outside the Libyan embassy in London.

But the US retains the strict 1996 Iran Libya Sanctions Act (Ilsa), which provides a range of penalties against companies doing business with the two countries.

These could include action against any Fayed assets in the United States.

Furthermore, Mr Fayed's plans to build a Harrods in Las Vegas could be frustrated.

Yesterday the US embassy in London confirmed that Ilsa had not been repealed and that relaxations earlier this year applied only to trade in carpets and almonds.

Harrods Petroleum is a recent venture and has hitherto operated only in the Gulf of Thailand. But Mr Fayed's links with the oil industry go back 30 years.

Mr Fayed is "quite excited about the prospect of opening in Libya", according to his spokesman, who added that the Harrods owner believed the large number of British ex-pats in the country provided a valuable pool of skills on which to draw.

Yesterday's announcement followed talks between Mr Fayed and Abdulah Albadri, secretary of the Libyan National Oil Corporation.

The free zone will be developed jointly with the Libyan Arab Foreign Investment Company (Lafico), a state-owned investment vehicle.

It was to Lafico that Mr Fayed's arch-enemy Tiny Rowland, head of the trading group Lonrho, turned in 1992 when looking for a buyer of a one-third share in Lonrho's Metropole Hotels chain. The £177m sale of Lafico caused a storm of protest and may have hastened Mr Rowland's departure from Lonrho in 1995.

fields.headline: Better the devil we know
fields.standfirst: Elected mayors are losing their glamourThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Even as they foresee the coming triumph of the candidate they least wanted, Tony Blair and his closest colleagues can take some comfort from the drama and excitement of the London mayoralty campaign. For when did we last hear words like drama and excitement being deployed in the context of local government - not to mention colour; enthusiasm; and fun?
fields.body:
Even as they foresee the coming triumph of the candidate they least wanted, Tony Blair and his closest colleagues can take some comfort from the drama and excitement of the London mayoralty campaign. For when did we last hear words like drama and excitement being deployed in the context of local government - not to mention colour; enthusiasm; and fun? They aimed to pump some life back into moribund local government, and they seem to have succeeded. Even the Livingstone factor has not dampened their eagerness to see elected executive mayors in all our great cities. But what they cannot have bargained for is the state of affairs disclosed by our ICM poll today. Asked if they'd like to see other great cities adopting the London pattern, just 22% said yes; 61% said they would rather keep local government as it is now. Contrast this with an ICM poll in February: when asked if they would welcome the chance to elect a mayor or leader for their own local authority, 59% said they would, only 32% said they would not. If it isn't the London experience producing this change, what is it?

It is easy to underestimate how badly the London example has been playing across the rest of the country. Some contemplate with boiling resentment the media's apparent obsession with a contest which has nothing to do with them. Perhaps they also regard London's response as characteristically self-indulgent, with voters pledging themselves to vote Livingstone for reasons which have little to do with good local governance: wiping the smirk off Tony Blair's face, for example, or simply wanting a bit of fun.

The government's three options for new patterns of local government exclude the status quo. All have the effect of concentrating power into far fewer hands, with public debate and scrutiny put at risk in the interests of more dynamic executive action. Many councillors, demoralised by the steady erosion of local government power and responsibility and the relentless advance of central intervention, fear the new systems will leave them sidelined while oligarchs run their towns. The government complains, with some justice, that such people are too attached to a cosy status quo. But it will no doubt come as a comfort to such municipal stalwarts, as well as a wild surprise, that so many of their customers are beginning to treasure the present system just as we are abandoning it.

fields.headline: Nomura bails out Hyder
fields.standfirst: Japanese bank's £402m bid yesterday highlights changing attitudes towards utility ownership
fields.trailText: When Nomura International, the Japanese investment bank, yesterday made its agreed £402m bid for Hyder, formerly Welsh Water, everyone in government and City circles heaved a sigh of relief.
fields.body:
When Nomura International, the Japanese investment bank, yesterday made its agreed £402m bid for Hyder, formerly Welsh Water, everyone in government and City circles heaved a sigh of relief.

Yet some 10 years ago, Peter Lilley, the then trade and industry secretary, was issuing dire threats against foreign companies contemplating buying large chunks of Britain's water industry.

The change in attitude is simple to explain. Hyder is in deep trouble and its ambition to become the one-stop shop for utility services in Wales is in tatters.

In the years following privatisation of the industry in 1989, the big 10 water companies, including Welsh Water, were regarded as money-making machines for shareholders and directors.

Unlike the other privatised utilities the water companies were allowed to increase prices to fund the urgently needed investment in their pipelines and plants, which had been neglected during years of state ownership.

The government had offered fat dividends as an incentive to persuade investors to take the industry and its investment liabilities off its hands.

But the industry has been swimming in turbulent waters since Labour came to power.

It was hit first by the windfall levy, then by government demands for huge extra environmental spending and finally by a new price regime involving big price cuts this year. Hyder had borrowed heavily to fund its investment programmes and its ambitious expansion into the electricity and gas industries.

The company had run up debts of £1.9bn.

It is now faced with a £1.3bn investment programme over the next five years, and this year alone it has to cut domestic water bills by 10.5% and electricity tariffs by 26%.

Ironically Hyder's chief executive, Graham Hawker, was regarded as having good New Labour credentials and Labour used to cite the company as proof that it could "do business with business".

But Hyder's share price indicates that the firm could not do business with Labour, at least not to its advantage.

Its shares, which rose steadily from its offer price of £3, peaked at £10.50 in mid-1998, and have since plunged to less than £2.

Bid rumours lifted the price a bit in recent months but Nomura's £2.60 a share bid is still well below the price at which the shares were first offered to the public in 1989.

City pressure forced the group to undertake a wide-ranging review of all its operations. Options included sale of part of its business, such as the electricity supply operation, or sale of the whole company.

In the end the directors have opted for the latter, leaving Nomura to sort out the mess.

The Nomura bid is the work of the bank's London-based principal finance group headed by Guy Hands.

It is a measure of Hyder's problems that it should have attracted Mr Hands' attention.

He specialises in buying distressed or underperforming assets to turn them around with new management and investment - before selling at a tidy profit.

Mr Hands said: "Hyder's core utilities operations have impressive strengths and benefit from their experienced employees.

It also has exciting opportunities through growing its non-regulated businesses, an area which particularly attracts us."

He is bringing in Mike Kinski, the former head of the Stagecoach transport business, to succeed Mr Hawker as the chief executive.

Mr Kinski, who is a director of Scottish Power, built up a reputation as a cost-cutter during his time at Stagecoach.

Mr Kinski said he did not expect any further job losses and added that Hyder's head office would remain in Cardiff.

His comments will take some of the heat out of the local political situation. There were fears that a new owner would move the utility business out of the principality and impose further cutbacks on the workforce.

Hyder has already announced the loss of 1,000 jobs in a bid to meet the productivity levels demanded by the latest water price review.

Mr Kinski said Nomura saw Hyder as a long term investment. "Hyder has an ongoing efficiency programme at the moment," he said. "We don't see the need for job losses over and above those being assessed by Hyder."

Nomura would aim to grow Hyder's regulated utilities business, but would be examining its non-regulated operations. "How we grow them [the non-regulated businesses] and what structure they become part of will become evident in the next couple of months," Mr Kinski said.

There has been speculation that the electricity supply business could be sold.

Hyder itself is no stranger to controversy. When as Welsh Water it moved into the private sector, it was much criticised for its diversification into hotels, country clubs and restaurants. It was also thought to have paid top price when it bought South Wales Electricity for £893m.

Following that acquisition, Welsh Water changed its name to Hyder - the Welsh word meaning confidence.

In retrospect, it was not an entirely appropriate choice.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Funeral tribute to stabbed fan
fields.body:
Funeral tribute to stabbed fan

Fans made a guard of honour in Leeds United kit yesterday for the funeral of Christopher Loftus, 35, a victim of the Istanbul stabbings. More than 1,000 people attended the service at Leeds parish church, a day after that of Kevin Speight, who also died the night before the Leeds Uefa Cup semi-final tie with Galatasaray.

National Front march banned

Jack Straw agreed yesterday to ban a National Front march in Worcester on St George's day, Easter Sunday. The city council and West Mercia police applied to the home secretary after objections by ethnic minority groups and church leaders.

Shopkeeper murder charge

William Morgan, 57, appeared before Port Talbot magistrates yesterday accused of murdering shopkeeper Santokh Singh Sand- hu, 42. He was remanded to appear before Swansea magistrates tomorrow.

Darwin's stones top museum

Stones from Down House, the Kent estate where Charles Darwin developed his scientific theories, were yesterday placed on the roof of a new £27m building at the Natural History museum to mark the first stage of its development.

Something to sing about

The only golden eagles nesting in the wild in England, near Haweswater, Cumbria, are incubating at least one egg, the RSPB said yesterday. Meanwhile a British Trust for Ornithology survey revealed 1,170 singing male nightingales in Kent last year, the most of any English county.

National Front march banned Jack Straw agreed yesterday to ban a National Front march in Worcester on St George's day, Easter Sunday. The city council and West Mercia police applied to the home secretary after objections by ethnic minority groups and church leaders. Shopkeeper murder charge William Morgan, 57, appeared before Port Talbot magistrates yesterday accused of murdering shopkeeper Santokh Singh Sand- hu, 42. He was remanded to appear before Swansea magistrates tomorrow. Darwin's stones top museum Stones from Down House, the Kent estate where Charles Darwin developed his scientific theories, were yesterday placed on the roof of a new £27m building at the Natural History museum to mark the first stage of its development. Something to sing about The only golden eagles nesting in the wild in England, near Haweswater, Cumbria, are incubating at least one egg, the RSPB said yesterday. Meanwhile a British Trust for Ornithology survey revealed 1,170 singing male nightingales in Kent last year, the most of any English county.

webTitle: Hands mans the helm at PFG

fields.headline: Hands mans the helm at PFG
fields.trailText: In the five years since Oxford-educated Guy Hands founded PFG he has waded into British business, buying underperforming companies.
fields.body:
In the five years since Oxford-educated Guy Hands founded PFG he has waded into British business, buying underperforming companies.

At one point he was the UK's biggest pub landlord, with more than 4,000 under his control, and its biggest private property landlord - after the purchase of 57,000 former MoD properties. His unit has also owned a third of the country's train rolling stock and Britain's second biggest bookmaker, William Hill.

"We seek out large businesses others do not find at tractive," he explained recently. "They normally appear to lack growth potential even though there cash flow is stable. They are neglected and undervalued by the market".

The string of deals have made him one of the City's best rewarded businessmen. Hands, who started his business career with an art shop in his time at Oxford, is now undertsood to be paid in line with PFG's annual profits, so when he made a £400m profit on selling the train company, for instance, he walked away with £40m.

Mr Hands, 40, who is dyslexic, works hard and is spending hard too, renovating a Kent home that once belonged to Winston Churchill.

webTitle: Nobody is leaving at the double

fields.headline: Nobody is leaving at the double
fields.standfirst: Notebook: Budget tax scare is unfounded
fields.trailText: The Confederation of British Industry and a host of heavy City hitters will be delivering their last-minute warnings to the government today about the foolishness of that hidden Budget nasty - the move to reform the treatment of double taxation which threatens to undo the carefully crafted tax avoidance measures of so many multinationals operating here.
fields.body:
The Confederation of British Industry and a host of heavy City hitters will be delivering their last-minute warnings to the government today about the foolishness of that hidden Budget nasty - the move to reform the treatment of double taxation which threatens to undo the carefully crafted tax avoidance measures of so many multinationals operating here.

But as the deadline for consultation runs out this evening and the predictions of Britain turning into some sort of economic wasteland reach a peak, those predicting that many companies will up sticks and head for the nearest Channel port should know better.

Indeed, there was a good deal of farce surrounding the issue yesterday as one company said to be heading for a softer (if duller) fiscal climate as a result of the planned tax changes - the insurer Allied Zurich - was backtracking madly.

Allied Zurich, half made up of the old BAT Industries financial wing, taking in Allied Dunbar, Eagle Star and Threadneedle Street Asset Management, said it had made its decision to return to Zurich before the chancellor took to his feet last month.

At the same time, the fact that a figure of £126m was being bandied about earlier as Allied's likely "hit" from Mr Brown's tax changes fuelled the belief that they had at least reinforced its decision.

The Treasury has claimed that the tax changes will cost companies overall around £300m, adding that this is only part of a package of measures that will attract new international businesses to Britain.

Accountantcy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, on the other hand, has said the double taxation measure might cost a group of 20 companies it surveyed up to £2bn. The inland revenue hotly denies this but the squabble over figures goes on.

The fiscal changes are designed to clamp down on multinationals trying to shield their low-taxed foreign profits from UK tax. In theory, the move has a lot to commend it, being part of a wider international move among the leading OECD companies to plug the hole, in the form of off-shore financial havens, through which so much corporate profitability disappears.

But this side of the argument - which is as complex as it is important - has not been properly explained, let alone debated. Instead, big business, having been given the impression that earlier proposals had been dropped, was suddenly landed with the new measures - or, rather, had to discover the changes in the budgetary fine print after Mr Brown had sat down.

In short, whether it is the treasury's fault or the inland revenue's, the result is a public relations balls-up, where apprehension over the longer-term stability of the country's tax system is spreading fast. In the process, the government's much-vaunted commitment to making the UK competitive has been undermined.

Test of strength

Nissan's public warning about the strong pound shows that it is not just industrial laggards that suffer the pain of high sterling. No one could question the Japanese car manufacturer's productivity, but the squealing begs the question of what exactly Britain's monetary authorities are supposed to do.

The Bank of England has weighed up the pros and cons of intervening on the forex markets to drive sterling down and rightly concluded it would be a mistake. Huge sums of money are needed to take on the market and there is no guarantee of success (ask Norman Lamont) or even control over when a currency might stop falling.

An alternative would be for the government to switch to a combined inflation/exchange rate target, but British economic history is littered with governments chopping and changing their monetary policy rules when the going gets tough. To change tack now, just a few years into the new monetary regime, would put such a dent in this government's credibility it might have to be taken off the road.

The only workable course of action to bring down sterling would be to pre-announce an entry level for sterling to go into the euro zone. By saying that it believes the current sterling/euro exchange rate is too high and suggesting a fairer value, the government might be able to persuade the markets to do the rest.

But this course of action presupposes that the government does want to join the euro. Despite the existence of a national changeover plan, the mood music from Whitehall suggests no enthusiasm for ditching the pound.

Another approach would be to pray that last week's market wobble turns into something altogether more deflationary - weakening the dollar and taking sterling with it, leaving the euro to rally into the vacuum.

Clearly, there are quite a few levels to this old economy/new economy rivalry thing.

webTitle: Reuters feeds as the blood spills

fields.headline: Reuters feeds as the blood spills
fields.trailText: Stock market bloodbaths are good news for Reuters, the global information provider. Volatility means people need more facts at their fingertips and more shares are traded, boosting revenue at Instinet, Reuters' online brokerage - especially as it provides dealing services on the US tech stocks index, Nasdaq.
fields.body:
Stock market bloodbaths are good news for Reuters, the global information provider. Volatility means people need more facts at their fingertips and more shares are traded, boosting revenue at Instinet, Reuters' online brokerage - especially as it provides dealing services on the US tech stocks index, Nasdaq.

Instinet was the star performer in Reuters' first-quarter trading statement yesterday: revenue leapt 58% to £197m while overall sales edged up 8% to £832m.

The number of transactions on Nasdaq jumped 67% in January and 107% in February. The trend should continue this month, as investors react to huge variations in share prices.

Despite this Reuters' own stock has weakened lately - it rose 28p to £10.08 yesterday against a peak of more than £16 last month.

This is largely due to a decline in the value of Tibco, the American software business in which Reuters has a 63% stake.

Tibco's shares have suffered from the general dot.com malaise, slumping by two-thirds in recent weeks, which means Reuters' investment has fallen from $8bn to $3.5bn.

Tibco is still a substantial chunk of Reuters' worth - the group as a whole has a market capitalisation of just over £14bn.

A back of the envelope calculation suggests that this is low, given Reuters' collection of other internet associates.

Chief executive Peter Job has been talking about a spin-off of the Greenhouse Fund, an incubator with investments in dot.com start-ups, which could attract a price of more than £1bn.

Then there is Multex Investor Europe, a portal for private investors, and Aether Systems - an American firm involved in delivering information to mobile phones.

Reuters has its finger in many pies, a fact highlighted yesterday by the EC clearing its venture with the Dutch networking company, Equant, to provide high security computer link-ups between financial institutions.

Patrick Wellington at Schroders reckons Reuters is worth £12bn, even without Tibco. But its shares are likely to remain volatile, given their dot.com status. Underlying sales of Reuters data is healthy, up 3% at £417m.

fields.headline: Associated British Foods
fields.trailText: Associated British Foods, one of the "old economy" firms dumped from the FTSE 100 last month, yesterday announced a fall in profits, in part blaming the price wars which broke out among the big supermarkets last year.
fields.body:
Associated British Foods, one of the "old economy" firms dumped from the FTSE 100 last month, yesterday announced a fall in profits, in part blaming the price wars which broke out among the big supermarkets last year.

The food company - whose labels include Silver Spoon, Kingsmill, Allinsons, Ryvita and Twinings - said underlying operating profits rose 6%, but the bottom line was 8% down at £170m. Much of that fall was actually due to a diminished cash pile after the payment of a special dividend last year. But the group is also being squeezed by the big supermarkets, excess capacity in the bread and milling business and sterling's effect on its sugar operations.

The slip in profits came from investment income - cut to £23m from £48m as the cash pile was cut to around £900m after the payout to shareholders last May of £448m.

The strength of sterling wiped £10m off the group's sugar profits - its British Sugar offshoot provides a third of the group's profits but is suffering from European prices being set in euros.

Analysts had hoped to hear news that the group might be considering a flotation for its 100-outlet Primark discount clothing business, or maybe selling off its milling and baking units. But there was no such luck: the shares closed down 9p at 376p - up from their 298p low, recorded only a few weeks ago, but still well down from their peak of 660p two years ago.

"There were no nasty surprises in the results but there was an expectation of some corporate action to release value within the group," said David Lang at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite. Chief executive Peter Jackson described the results as "robust" at a time when supermarkets were applying increasing pressure.

Some analysts rate the shares a buy, but others say its ownership - 60% controlled by the Weston family and chairman Garry, 72, is recovering from a stroke - will deter any strategic steps.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.standfirst: Blue chip technology, media and telecommunications stocks burst back into favour yesterday encouraged by strong early gains on New York's Nasdaq exchange.
fields.trailText: Logica , the IT consultancy, led the way with a 136p advance to £17.91 on the back of a lucrative contract from ScottishPower and a tip from stockbroker Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.
fields.body:
Logica , the IT consultancy, led the way with a 136p advance to £17.91 on the back of a lucrative contract from ScottishPower and a tip from stockbroker Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

ARM Holdings , up 102p at £31.70 was helped by a strong rally in semiconductor issues and news of an upgrade for Intel, one of ARM's customers, from Morgan Stanley.

But Monday's good technology gainers on the Lon don market were shunned, with Baltimore Technology down 226p at £56.04, and Psion off 24p at £27.78.

On the telecoms side, heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch gained 17p at 303p, Kingston Communications firmed 28p at 715p, and Thus added 12p to 369p.

Media issues also did well, with Emap leaping 141p to £11.00, Pearson adding 46p at £19.09 and Carlton Communications gaining 20p at 697p.

At the close the FTSE 100 index was 79.4 points firmer at 6,074.0 - just below its late day peak of 6,084.2, and well above a mid-morning low of 5,951.7.

Broader FTSE indices were in positive territory, with the Techmark up 76 points at 3,466.83, aided by Nasdaq, up again after its largest points gain on Monday.

Volume was strong, with 1.73bn shares changing hands in 129,594 trades.

One of the surprises was John Mansfield, the former shell company taken over by Stuart Wallis, which at one stage toppled Vodafone as the most widely traded stock. John Mansfield , unchanged at 4p, is being transformed into an information management company.

Among the largest gainers was business services company the Capita Group , which rebounded 211p to £14.20. It was helped by first quarter trading being significantly ahead of last year.

In the banking sector, HSBC gained 11p at 704 as players digested news of its online link with Merrill Lynch. The new entity will boost their presence in the private client market.

"New" Schroders, which began trading following the disposal of its investment banking operations, topped the list of FTSE 100 risers, up 141p at 992p.

But Lloyds TSB stayed dull, off 3p at 625p, and Halifax remained on offer, down 5p at 581p, despite a positive update. BP Amoco was the biggest blue chip faller, shedding 21p at 506p following the long-delayed completion of its takeover of Arco.

fields.headline: Nissan trims
fields.standfirst: Car company blames strong pound for planned cuts
fields.trailText: Nissan yesterday joined other car makers in warning that the strength of sterling is making production in Britain increasingly unprofitable.
fields.body:
Nissan yesterday joined other car makers in warning that the strength of sterling is making production in Britain increasingly unprofitable.

Although it fell well short of saying its Sunderland plant, was at immediate risk, the British boss of the troubled Japanese company - now in alliance with Renault - said costs would have to be cut and output increased further to secure a future.

John Cushnaghan, managing director of Nissan Motor Manufacturing UK, said the three-model plant, which employs 5,000 people, was struggling to compensate for the high value of the pound against the euro. Around three-quarters of production is exported, chiefly to the continent.

Costs would have to be slashed by 30% in under two years - 10% more than in a recent Nissan global survival plan.

Many firms blame the Bank of England for driving up interest rates and pushing up the pound. But a senior Threadneedle Street official said last night that there was nothing the Bank could do to influence the pound's level.

"The exchange rate is not the objective of monetary policy," John Vickers told a meeting of agricultural engineers yesterday. "The objective is price stability as defined by the inflation target."

Mr Vickers said that it was impossible for the Bank to use interest rates both to control inflation and influence the level of sterling.

This month a senior director of Toyota, which has an assembly plant near Derby, said that the company was not selling cars in Europe because of the strength of the pound.

fields.headline: Eurozone misses 2% target
fields.trailText: Inflation in the euro zone crept above the European Central Bank's 2% target for the first time in March, reinforcing expectations of further interest rate rises.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Brussels and Mark Atkinson
fields.body:
Inflation in the euro zone crept above the European Central Bank's 2% target for the first time in March, reinforcing expectations of further interest rate rises.

Figures published yesterday by the European Commission's statistical agency, Eurostat, showed the annual rate of price increases was 2.1%, the first time it has been above the ECB's target since the euro was introduced in January 1999.

Gerassimos Thomas, a commission spokesman, played down the significance of the data, saying the commission was confident inflation would retreat below 2% in the second half of the year.

But economists said the data underlined the view that the ECB would almost certainly raise borrowing costs again soon to make sure it did not accelerate.

The rate of price increases has drifted upwards in recent months due to the lagged effect of past increases in the oil price and the weakness of the euro, which is boosting import costs.

The inflation rise was most marked in Ireland where a booming economy has pushed up prices. The rate there was registered at 5%.

The Irish government, which uses a different calculating method, reported a rate of 4.6% on Tuesday, a 10-year high.

The EU has warned that planned tax cuts in Ireland could bring more overheating.

Taking in the four member nations yet to adopt the euro, EU inflation remained stable at 1.9 % That was largely due to a fall in Britain to 0.7% from 1% in February. Britain has the lowest inflation rate in the EU.

Eurostat said the EU rates compared to 3.7% in the United States.

Across the euro zone, Eurostat released the following national inflation rates for March, with those for February in parentheses:

Portugal, 1.4% (1.6%); Netherlands, 1.6% (1.5%); France, 1.7% (1.5%); Austria, 2% (2%); Germany, 2.1% (2.1%); Belgium, 2.5% (2.1%); Italy, 2.6% (2.4%); Spain, 3% (3%); Luxembourg, 3% (2.6%); Finland 3.2% (2.7%); Ireland 5% (4.6%).

The following were the rates for the other EU nations:

Britain, 0.7% (1%); Sweden, 1.4% (1.4%); Greece, 2.8% (2.6%); Denmark, 3% (2.8%).

webTitle: Inflation drops as high street fight drags on

fields.headline: Inflation drops as high street fight drags on
fields.standfirst: Bank likely to keep interest rates on hold
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's preferred measure of price pressures in the economy has fallen to the lowest level ever recorded, raising hopes that the monetary policy committee may spare homeowners and firms further increases in the cost of borrowing.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's preferred measure of price pressures in the economy has fallen to the lowest level ever recorded, raising hopes that the monetary policy committee may spare homeowners and firms further increases in the cost of borrowing.

Inflation figures released yesterday highlighted the cutthroat competition on Britain's high streets, where prices are falling year on year for the first time since the Office of National Statistics started keeping records.

Deep discounting on high streets helped drive down inflation, excluding housing costs, to an annual rate of 2% last month, the smallest increase since the series began in January 1987, according to the ONS.

Inflation on this measure has now been below the government's target of 2.5% for twelve months in a row, making it harder for the Bank to justify further increases in interest rates.

"With inflation well below the official target, the Bank does not feel that it is under a lot of pressure to raise rates - even though there are now some signs of potential inflation pressures building," said Michael Dicks, UK economist at Lehman Brothers.

While core goods prices have been negative territory for some time, yesterday's figures showed that prices of all goods fell 0.2% in the twelve months to March.

Particularly sharp falls were recorded in the food and other goods categories where prices are now falling by more than 2% a year.

But inflation in the services sector remains stubbornly high at 4.2% a year, which some analysts believe could spark at least one more rate rise from the Bank.

"Overall, the data underline the ongoing divergence between the manufacturing and service sectors of the UK economy," said Jeremy Hawkins, economist at Bank of America.

"This leaves the Bank of England in a real dilemma, but at the end of the day it is services that dominate gross domestic product. We still just about see a 25 basis point hike in interest rates next month."

Also alarming for the Bank will be the news that the annual headline measure of inflation, which includes housing costs, leapt to 2.6% last month, from 2.3% in February. Pay deals are targeted on headline inflation, and the higher number can be expected to push up wage claims.

The Bank has raised interest rates four times in the past eight months in an attempt to slow down the economy. While cheaper imports as a result of the pound's strength have helped cut goods prices, inflation in the services sector, which is less exposed to domestic competition, has remained alarmingly high.

"The continued stubbornness of domestically generated inflation in the services sector will do little to calm the MPC's nerves over the possibility of a fall in the pound which could see the downward pressure on goods prices fade," said Jonathan Loynes, UK economist with HSBC markets.

The Bank of England believes a lot of the pound's strength is not explained by any underlying changes in the British economy and it could easily be reversed.
