fields.headline: Clinging to colonialism's wreckage
fields.standfirst: Mugabe's rhetoric is outdated, and masks the real problemsZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe celebrated the 20th anniversary of her independence yesterday with the murder of a second white farmer. This was another government-inspired outrage on the way to what threatens to be a deliberate descent into a more general, armed conflict over Zimbabwe's colonial legacy.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe celebrated the 20th anniversary of her independence yesterday with the murder of a second white farmer. This was another government-inspired outrage on the way to what threatens to be a deliberate descent into a more general, armed conflict over Zimbabwe's colonial legacy.

Two decades ago, Mr Mugabe subscribed to a different vision - that of a nation in which, despite the years of war and repression, the former colonisers and colonised were, if not reconciled, at least mutually tolerant.

It may have been a vision forced upon him, but it made a certain sense. The white colonisers would retain some of the privileges that had come with the land grab that was colonisation, but they would, at least, continue to contribute to Zimbabwe's economic wellbeing. An orderly process of land reform would satisfy the demand for social justice without creating fresh injustice to fuel incipient conflict.

Twenty years on, Mr Mugabe is trying to present his Zimbabwe as a nation still in the throes of the anti-colonial struggle, in which the poorest have yet to reap the rewards of their sacrifice. Land is legitimately an emotional issue in Zimbabze - as late as 1969, the Smith government reserved half of it for whites. Distribution is still grossly unfair with more than half of the best land still owned by only 3% of the population. With some 4,000 white-owned farms accounting for more than two-thirds of the best farming land, reform is certainly overdue.

But land reform was envisaged in the 1979 Lancaster House discussions. Mugabe has ruled Zimbabwe ever since. If it was an issue of such importance to him, why has it progressed so little?

Before this wave of occupations, the government redistributed land from some 270 white-owned farms, but the land was not given to war veterans or to the rural poor. Among the 400 beneficiaries were several notable Zanu-PF figures, including such implausible claimants as the attorney general, the mines and tourism minister, the speaker of the parliament, two high court judges and a retired general - none of them conspicuously either subsistence farmers or landless peasants.

With his country on the brink of economic collapse and mired in the war in the Congo, with inflation out of control and Aids afflicting one in four of the young adult population, this is the last throw of a dictator who failed, two decades ago, to fulfil the promise to give a field and a cow to each of his supporters and who now faces electoral defeat.

Humiliated in the referendum that would have allowed him to retain power and unable to present any hope for the mass of unemployed and increasingly desperate people, Mugabe has ditched the model of the nation he has lived with for 20 years - a model that demands he submit to democratic judgment.

Farmer David Stephens may have died on Saturday as much because he was active in the opposition Movement for Democratic Change as because he was a farmer. The day he died, two black MDC activists were burned alive in a firebomb attack. The MDC argues that the so-called war veterans - most of whom are too young to have been anywhere near the war - have been placed strategically to ensure that the party cannot function in certain key areas.

Today Mugabe's brand of nationalism depends on the anti-colonial rhetoric of two, even three decades ago. It is rhetoric that still commands some support in Africa, combining as it does an acrimonious dialogue with the old colonial power and a conspicuous legacy in the white farmers or the injustices of the past.

But it masks the real question of what kind of nation Mugabe is inviting his people to build and whose interests are really served by this episode.

Other African statesmen have been ambivalent about Mugabe's actions. It is time they spoke out and showed that they recognised the difference between the two national models on offer. The land battle is a damaging and tragic business, but there is something even more important.

Given a chance to express their opinions in the recent referendum, the people of Zimbabwe showed that they were not persuaded by Mugabe's rhetoric, and that they realised that even if every white-owned farm was to be occupied by war veterans (or Zanu-PF followers masquerading as such) it would only make the crisis that Zimbabwe faces worse.

What matters now is that Zimbabweans hold on to that perception. So far, the opposition has remained coolheaded. British ministers would do well to do the same. Mugabe has picked this quarrel for his own reasons. There is little that Britain can do or say that will not add fuel to his explosive argument and give him the final excuse to cancel the elections.

fields.headline: Rich pickings
fields.standfirst: How the experts grow money
fields.trailText: What can "higher net-worth" investors get for their money?
fields.body:
What can "higher net-worth" investors get for their money?

£10,000 Basic portfolio management services start at this level, led by Rothschild Asset Management, which will select funds for you and send half-yearly reports for a 1.5% annual fee.

£20,000 Step up to directly held shares with an advisory investment service from brokers such as Killick & Co.

£100,000-£250,000 True private client territory with a portfolio of directly held shares and overseas investments offered by brokers such as Prudential Bache and investment manager Quilter & Co. At this stage some might also begin dabbling in currency speculation, with a £100,000 investment allowing purchase of £1m in currency on margin trading.

£500,000 The minimum to become a client of Coutt's, the Queen's bank, offering the full range of bespoke "wealth management services" including one-to-one meetings with an adviser on request, monthly reports and entry to hedge funds. Coutt's hedge fund has a minimum investment of £250,000.

£1m Accountants KPMG will offer a tax and strategic investment service, setting up trusts and minimising tax liabilities, with a personal adviser based usually in Switzerland, the UK or US.

£10m Rothschild will set up your own private unit trust.

£10m+ A personal investment and tax adviser, probably paid £100,000 a year manages affairs on a day-to-day basis.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Human Desire | Men In Black | The Fisher King | This Sporting Life
fields.body:
Human Desire

(Fritz Lang, 1954)

2.45pm, Carlton Cinema

Strange and steamy railyard-set film noir, with good guy engineer Glenn Ford, just back from the Korean war, getting sidetracked into trouble by bad blonde Gloria Grahame. After her husband bumps off her lover onboard a train, she must distract Ford from passing the murder scene. But once she's got his attention, she decides to pour on the poor-me's in an attempt to turn Ford's affections into deadly intentions. Diana DeLaire plays the daughter of his co-worker who wants to set him straight.
Teri Grenert

Men In Black

(Barry Sonnenfeld, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

In Sonnenfeld's very hip, very funny sci-fi spoof the world is full of aliens living (mainly) peacefully incognito, and the Men in Black are interstellar immigration officers. It is their reactions to the various space beasts that give the film its buzz. Tommy Lee Jones borrows a deadpan, seen-it-all-before expression from Bill Murray in Ghostbusters; Will Smith is all wide-eyed, gobsmacked incredulity.

The Fisher King

(Terry Gilliam, 1991)

8pm, 2.05am, Sky Cinema

Gilliam's attempt at urban myth-making is a pretty honourable failure. Two burnt-out cases - Jeff Bridges' crumpled ex-DJ; Robin Williams's mad ex-professor - cross paths in New York and find salvation in the latter's quest for the Holy Grail. (He is barking.) While it looks great - the city is dark and deeply gothic - you can work too hard at being whimsical, and Williams's twinkling life-affirmations are, well, depressing.

This Sporting Life

(Lindsay Anderson, 1963)

10.20pm, FilmFour

Anderson knuckles down to capture the full earthy flavour of David Storey's bleak, woeful novel. Hardnut Richard Harris batters his way through as Frank Machin, miner turned rugby league star in the days before big salaries and Antipodean sunshine transformed the game. This is dour, and cold, the "sporting" deeply ironic as the foolish Frank spurns the plain love of widowed Rachel Roberts. With Alan Badel, Colin Blakely, Arthur Lowe.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Guinness plans to axe 100 staff
fields.body:
Guinness plans to axe 100 staff

Diageo, the world's largest drinks company, is cutting 100 jobs at its Guinness brewery in Park Royal, west London. The group met unions yesterday to discuss the redundancies, which are part of a reorganisation of production and kegging at the site. The Park Royal brewery employs 1,200 people and produces 400m pints of Guinness a year.

L'Oreal in US shopping spree

Cosmetics group L'Oreal said yesterday it was making two major US acquisitions, buying the Kiehl's cosmetics firm in New York and Matrix Essentials, North America's biggest maker of professional haircare products.

The Paris-based group did not disclose the terms of the deals, which will be completed later this year.

Pru persists with Egg float

Prudential is to go ahead with plans for partial flotations of its internet bank Egg despite the recent stock market rout in e-commerce companies.

Releasing first-quarter figures, the Pru admitted Egg had lost £228m of funds during the period, taking the retail deposits of it and its Pru-branded bank to £7.8m. The insurance group's banking operation sold £1.8bn of mortgages and ran up £464m of credit card balances.

In its retail sales operation, a 36% fall in its direct sales force contributed to a 15% drop in sales to £494m, prompting analysts at Charterhouse Securities to question the Pru's "end game" for the unit. Overall, the Pru reported a 54% increase in sales of insurance and investment products.

MoD warns of job cuts

Trade union officials yesterday said thousands of civilian jobs could be lost as a result of Ministry of Defence plans to deal with overcapacity at the naval dockyards.

The warning came after MoD officials told union representatives that it was considering increased use of outside contractors at the Devonport, Portsmouth and Faslane naval bases.

The unions were told this could mean "involving the private sector right up to, and sometimes beyond, the waterfront".

Halifax meets share target

Halifax hit its target of snatching a 10% share of the mortgage market in the first part of the year.

James Crosby, the chief executive, yesterday said the firm had suffered a small reduction in savings balances but described its profit margin as robust despite intense competition.

He said the bank would launch Halifax-branded online savings, loans, insurance and credit cards in addition to its plans to roll out its separately branded Intelligent Finance bank and Esure insurance arm later this year.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What people in advertising are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What people in advertising are watching on TV.
fields.body:
Jim Daly: "I like to watch a lot of daytime TV because I think, on the whole, it's better than evening television - a lot more honest, a lot more direct. People like Fern Britton and the girls on Loose Women are a better reflection of our life today than some of the so-called serious programmes like Dispatches and Cutting Edge."

Erin Beach: "Do I watch docu-soaps? The bane of my life, dear. How many clients want a "real life" advert when they just want shaky camerawork and inexpensive actors? Too many. Shane Ritchie - that sort of thing. I think most TV is rubbish, bad, bad stuff. I find adverts better than the programmes, I really do. Favourite? Hahahah! One I didn't work on? All right, the one for British Gas, prices lowering. They've made a modern advert about gas that's friendly and cheering - but if you look closer it says that Gas is sexy, because all these inanimate objects are vibrating so much they're slipping off surfaces. It's very rude, hahaha."

Ben Knight: "I like after the watershed, because I think television becomes more interesting, and the variety of people and advertising you see is obviously wider. I like Ali G and Chris Morris's Jam. I think it's deeply - no, not disturbing, deeply strange, but it's got on TV. I think Morris is a genius."

Carley Henfield: "Never watch it. Apart from The League Of Gentlemen, and a bit of darts. Honestly, I do like the darts, reminds me of when TV was full of darts. And Cheggars Plays Pop. He's up for doing any commercial now, sad isn't it?"

Sam Dawes: "I think TV would be nothing, actually, without the adverts. They place the programme, they give comment, they provide a break. Even though we're all meant to be very pro-public service broadcasting in this country, we are absolutely so fond of adverts. Ads are like the Royal Family - we love them. Oh, and as you're asking what my favourite programme is, it's the Royle Family. Just reminded me."

fields.headline: Stern & son barred from boardrooms
fields.trailText: William Stern - the property tycoon whose £118m bankruptcy in 1978 set a record - was yesterday disqualified for 12 years from serving as a company director following the £11m collapse of his second commercial empire. The 64-year-old Belsen survivor was ruled in the high court to be unfit for any boardroom position.
fields.body:
William Stern - the property tycoon whose £118m bankruptcy in 1978 set a record - was yesterday disqualified for 12 years from serving as a company director following the £11m collapse of his second commercial empire. The 64-year-old Belsen survivor was ruled in the high court to be unfit for any boardroom position.

Mr Stern had fought the attempt to ban him from company office, representing himself in court "out of necessity, not choice".

His son Mark, 39, was also disqualified, but for just four years.

Among allegations proved against them was the drawing from company accounts of sums totalling about £1.5m between 1990 and 1994, which the court ruled had been a misapplication of corporate funds.

Furthermore, "Crown monies" - collected or received on account of tax liabilities - had been misused to pay creditors.

Mr Justice Lloyd said Mr Stern had lied in parts of his evidence and in other respects had displayed arrogance and a fundamentally irresponsible attitude to his duties as a director.

Mark Stern, described as an honest and frank witness, knew little of what was going on and never really undertook the role of director, the judge said; he had wrongly abdicated his responsibilities to his father.

Yesterday's ruling is the latest twist in the extraordinary saga of Mr Stern's business career. Arriving in Britain as a refugee, he took control of Britain's largest private sector landlord, the Fresh Water group, in the 1960s, but his property empire collapsed in the 1974 crash with debts of about £143m. In 1978, Mr Stern was personally bankrupted with debts of about £118m, a record surpassed only by Kevin Maxwell's £406m bankruptcy in 1992.

Discharged in 1985, Mr Stern and his family took a 24.5% interest in Dollar Land Holdings, a property company 75.5% owned by a Panamanian company, Keristal Investment and Trading.

Dollar's management company, controlled by the Sterns, was Kensington Management Services, which went into liquidation in February 1993. Its functions were immediately taken over by what the court ruled was a "phoenix" company, Westminster Property Management, which was wound up in October 1994.

fields.bodyText: William Stern - the property tycoon whose £118m bankruptcy in 1978 set a record - was yesterday disqualified for 12 years from serving as a company director following the £11m collapse of his second commercial empire. The 64-year-old Belsen survivor was ruled in the high court to be unfit for any boardroom position. Mr Stern had fought the attempt to ban him from company office, representing himself in court "out of necessity, not choice". His son Mark, 39, was also disqualified, but for just four years. Among allegations proved against them was the drawing from company accounts of sums totalling about £1.5m between 1990 and 1994, which the court ruled had been a misapplication of corporate funds. Furthermore, "Crown monies" - collected or received on account of tax liabilities - had been misused to pay creditors. Mr Justice Lloyd said Mr Stern had lied in parts of his evidence and in other respects had displayed arrogance and a fundamentally irresponsible attitude to his duties as a director. Mark Stern, described as an honest and frank witness, knew little of what was going on and never really undertook the role of director, the judge said; he had wrongly abdicated his responsibilities to his father. Yesterday's ruling is the latest twist in the extraordinary saga of Mr Stern's business career. Arriving in Britain as a refugee, he took control of Britain's largest private sector landlord, the Fresh Water group, in the 1960s, but his property empire collapsed in the 1974 crash with debts of about £143m. In 1978, Mr Stern was personally bankrupted with debts of about £118m, a record surpassed only by Kevin Maxwell's £406m bankruptcy in 1992. Discharged in 1985, Mr Stern and his family took a 24.5% interest in Dollar Land Holdings, a property company 75.5% owned by a Panamanian company, Keristal Investment and Trading. Dollar's management company, controlled by the Sterns, was Kensington Management Services, which went into liquidation in February 1993. Its functions were immediately taken over by what the court ruled was a "phoenix" company, Westminster Property Management, which was wound up in October 1994. Mr Stern lives in a £4m six-bedroom mansion in West Heath Avenue, Hampstead, and has a home in Jerusalem and a villa in the south of France.

fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: An employment tribunal lawyer writes.
fields.body:
In some of the photographs, the sow is on her own, spread out on her side, head thrown back and mouth open like a murder victim. Her teats are lined up in front of her like pints on a bar.

In other photographs, her piglets are active around her, impossibly perky and clean and pale fondant pink. She is not really looking at them.

I am looking at these photographs in conference with a pig expert because an upcoming case turns on the proper method of dealing with sows in "farrowing crates". A farrowing crate, it turns out, is where the sow lives while she is waiting to give birth, while she is giving birth and after she has given birth to her piglets.

The farrowing crate is a sort of rectangular pen not much bigger than the sow, made up of metal tubes and fastened to the floor at the corners. The sow can stand up in it or lie on her side in an exhausted-looking way but she cannot move anywhere. There is an arrangement at one end which "allows piglets to be born but not right against the bars".

A problem which arises with these farrowing crates, and which is an important point in our case, is that the sow's urine and dung can build up and corrode the metal posts at the corners of the crate. A strong sow might then be able to pull the crate from the floor and walk around with it on her back. This leads, in a somewhat obscure manner, to my client's accident.

So we are sitting around a table: expert, client, solicitor, me, looking at these photos and discussing the sows as if they were car parts or cabbages being processed. After the farrowing process the dancing piglets are taken off to some other part of the piggery, to be "finished".

My client says rather sadly: "I have been interested in pigs all my life, and now I can't work with them any more." The expert clearly also has an interest in pigs. I am having difficulty understanding what kind of interest it is.

After the conference, a friend rings up to say that she is pregnant. Involuntarily, I imagine her lying on her side in a metal crate, giving birth to her baby against the bars and then lying in her own urine and dung until her baby is taken away to be finished.

Which leads me to think that I will have to restrict my pig practice severely on the grounds that I am emotionally unequipped to deal with pig pictures and cannot help looking forward to the day when all the sows rise up with their farrowing crates on their backs and roam free in the fields with their piglets. Although no doubt the pig expert could tell me any number of reasons why that would be an undesirable arrangement.

fields.headline: The killing fields
fields.trailText: Lone Star Hate | Streakers
fields.body:
Is there a scarier place on earth to be gay than Tyler, Texas? Amid the Baptist churches where the preacher asks God to help him recognise "that if the enemy comes into my life, that's an opportunity to kick his butt", the cheerleaders, the guns, the endless flat green spaces punctuated by colonial-style homes and the trash of trailers, it must be hard not to wonder when you're cruising whether the next pickup truck dragging round the corner is coming for you.

Lone Star Hate (C4) was about how "the normal pain of being gay in a conservative area" culminated for Nicolas West, a slight, pretty 23-year-old, in being marched to some gravel pits, battered and then shot to death in the red earth.

Two of his killers, who had apparently just picked him up for a bit of robbing and queer-bashing, were on death row already. "It got outta control" said Henry Dunn laconically. Donald Aldrich blamed Dunn. A wrecked-looking woman in front of a wrecked-looking trailer said Aldrich couldn't have been responsible. Aldrich claimed he was himself bisexual. Nothing made sense.

The third participant, David McMillan, who was 17 at the time, was standing trial. By most accounts, someone who wanted to be a part of something, a follower, he was a blank high-school year-book face with glasses, a soft-voiced mystery.

Robert De Niro could play McMillan's greasy-ponytailed attorney in the bigscreen version. He obligingly demonstrated the different guns involved in the killing for the camera. Like George Bush Junior and a taxi-driver I met in New Orleans, he thinks the answer to crime is more guns: "if Nicolas West had had a gun on him, he probably wouldn't be dead today". The interviewer asked him about the death penalty: "Do you believe in it?" "Absolutely." "For what reason?" "Retribution." The desk in front of him was littered with guns.

But nothing was fully explored in this crammed but rather lazy slice of Southern Gothic. We had a quick look at the gurney in the execution chamber on death row. In Texas they are killing people faster and in greater numbers than anywhere in the US. The programme couldn't really pause to think about that.

There were unpursued hints of familial abuse and deprivation in Dunn and Aldrich's backgrounds. A few Baptist nutters earnestly saying that homosexuality is a sin made the facile link between fundamentalism and hate crime. In fact only McMillan had really touched on his religious beliefs, such as they were ("I can't agree with 'em when they say God made 'em that way. Why's God gonna make something contrary to what the Bible says?") But it's more complicated than the programme suggests - this frontier country where gays would be the new blacks, except that blacks are still the old blacks.

And a lot of time was simply wasted on sensationalist thriller effects - again and again the red outline of the body in the red earth, some car headlights at night, the camera walking over and over West's path to death, as if we really needed persuading of his terror.

Over to Channel 5 for some mindless nudity in Streakers - the happily flapping cocks of the 70s variety, bodies white as bacon fat, the Essex bronze of the modern tabloid slappers for whom streaking is a hygienic alternative to shagging footballers.

"Tracy did lawn bowls a big favour", said lawn bowls champion Dave Gourlay, and to be sure it looked as if Christmas had come early for the wrinklies as she descended voluptuously on the contestants at the world championships. ("Best four pound I ever spent", said one grateful Bert or Alf.)

For streakers, it's a "moment of feeling what it's like to be the Rolling Stones", for sports fans, a harmless comedy of boobs, bums and bits. Then there was Vincent Bethel, leader of the Freedom To Be Yourself Campaign to legalise non-sexual nakedness. You may remember him perching naked up a lamppost last year for his gloriously titled "protest naked for the freedom to be naked in public" event.

"Penis, willy, testicles" said Vincent on a note of rising hysteria during a recent strip. "He said I was nutty, hah", he called excitedly to the filmcrew as a bunch of plods bundled him into a van.

I worry about Channel 5, though. Someday soon they must come to the end of the high quality televisual entertainment which can be extracted from the topics of sex and nudity. What then?

fields.headline: No: 1618
fields.standfirst: Britney Spears
fields.trailText: Britney Spears
fields.body:
Age: 18.

Appearance: Corn-fed all-American prom queen.

Aha, I know her - she's a popular musician! Quite. Her frothy first single sold half a million copies in its first week of release - the biggest chart debut in British history.

How did it go again? "Hit me baby one more time."

A bit risque, isn't it? You should have seen the video. All school uniform and nubile flesh. Or the Rolling Stone cover, on which the nymphet reclined revealingly with a Teletubby under her arm.

Lucky Tinky-Winky. The relationship is innocent, explains Britney. "In LA it tends to be hotter, so you wear less clothing."

LA? A big celeb, is she? Sure is. Her new single Oops! I Did It Again this week became the most requested song in US radio history.

Any other talents? Ms Spears began as a child star on TV's Mickey Mouse Show, as did fellow bubblegum-popster Christina Aguilera and boy band N'Sync. And movie moguls have just cast her in a new sequel to Grease.

She's the one that they want? Ooh, ooh, ooh.

Tell me more, tell me more. Well, her T-shirt looks tight.

Eh? Britney's career has been plagued by rumours that her ample bosom isn't as God intended. A website exists - the Britney Spears Chest Pump - which allows users to inflate and burst the starlet's breasts.

She's got her knockers, then? She has illustrious admirers, too - among them Prince William, with whom Britney is said to enjoy an intimate affinity.

Egads! The heir to the throne! Fear not. "He's very cute," purrs the popstress, "but people blow things out of all proportion. We're just friends."

Don't say: Happy and glorious/ Long to reign o'er us/God save Queen Britney...

Do say: Open the soda pop, bop shu bop shu bop/The clock is ticking and we can't stop, no!

Not to be confused with: Albert Speer, Shakespeare, Dolly Parton.

webTitle: More thoughts on heaven and hell

fields.headline: More thoughts on heaven and hell
fields.trailText: As a philosopher, Shaun Joynson (Letters, April 18) objects to RE. I went to a C of E primary school, where during RE lessons I learned about Judaism and the status of the Adam and Eve story in mainstream Christianity (allegory).
fields.body:
As a philosopher, Shaun Joynson (Letters, April 18) objects to RE. I went to a C of E primary school, where during RE lessons I learned about Judaism and the status of the Adam and Eve story in mainstream Christianity (allegory).

At my supposedly secular secondary school another wise amiable headmaster annoyed us with facile sermons meant to prove the truth of evangelical Protestantism, and many of my fellow pupils resented our being forced to recite prayers in assemblies. However, we were at least made to engage with the claims of religion and to formulate our own critiques.

In my experience, only classics (now widely abolished, despite Thucydides' and Suctonius' powerfully contemporary critiques of politics) and RE actually led me to question the values and expectations of our consumer society.

RE provides an inoculation against fundamentalism (which thrives on ignorance of religion) and helps to nurture the reflexivity which is at the beginning of philosophy.
Richard Bartholomew
Hastings, East Sussex

 Phil McNally (Letters, April 17) rightly condemns as a form of child abuse the religious indoctrination of the young. While we ponder the banning of smacking children's bottoms, we should also be considering what damage religious fantasies do to their minds. A smack can be forgiven and forgotten. But the corruption of the innocent mind can be forever.

Anyone, including the Evangelical Alliance, who wants to condemn millions of people (or even one person) to everlasting torture, is sick in the head. How can any loving, forgiving, caring Christian accept such disgusting nonsense? What rational adolescent will forgive the lies they were told about eternal damnation?

On the same day you list the numbers of selective church schools in England. Two thousand Roman Catholic and 5,000 Church of England, where such pernicious myths are planted in young and defenceless minds. Is there no law against child abuse?
Maurice Hill
Jávea, Spain

 If hell exists, we must liberate its prisoners and try God for crimes against humanity.
Richard Tobin
Edinburgh

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In the programme for its match against Chelsea on April 15, Sheffield Wednesday football club published a half-page tribute marking the anniversary of the 1989 tragedy at its Hillsborough ground in which 96 people died. Our match report, published page S3, Sport, April 17, had said the programme failed to mention the anniversary.
fields.body:
In the programme for its match against Chelsea on April 15, Sheffield Wednesday football club published a half-page tribute marking the anniversary of the 1989 tragedy at its Hillsborough ground in which 96 people died. Our match report, published page S3, Sport, April 17, had said the programme failed to mention the anniversary.

A story about a national competition and TV gameshow coming on Channel 4 - The E-Millionaire Show - outlined how the proceeds would be carved up if a winner's idea for an internet start-up business proved a success (main story, New Media, April 17). The text and panel box should have said that the new entrepreneur would keep a 65.7% share. The 33% referred to was roughly the share to be retained by the consortium of investors in the project.

The former Arsenal football player Steve Bould is now with Sunderland, rather than - as stated on page 32, Sport, yesterday - Middlesbrough.

In a story headed Patients 'as happy to see nurse as GP', page 5, April 14, Jane Salvage was misidentified as the editor of Nursing Times. She is nursing director of Emap Healthcare, which publishes Nursing Times.

An obituary, page 24, April 14, stated that Friedensreich Hundertwasser "died aged 71 on board the Queen Elizabeth II". A concerned reader points out that the vessel carrying the Austrian architect at the time of his death was the Queen Elizabeth 2.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Nuclear safety questions
fields.trailText: So, BNFL thinks that Dr Chris Busby's research linking cancers to nuclear plants can be dismissed on the grounds that he is "a well-known anti-nuclear activist" whose "previous research cannot be trusted"? ('Cancer link' to nuclear plants, April 13).
fields.body:
So, BNFL thinks that Dr Chris Busby's research linking cancers to nuclear plants can be dismissed on the grounds that he is "a well-known anti-nuclear activist" whose "previous research cannot be trusted"? ('Cancer link' to nuclear plants, April 13).

Coming from a company with the appalling environmental and safety record of BNFL, which - by its own admission - fabricated data in the recent Japanese plutonium shipment scandal and which, according to last Thursday's Guardian, embarked on a dirty tricks campaign to unsettle, discredit and mislead MPs and government ministers, that is rich indeed.

The US government - in stark contrast to the British - has acknowledged, after decades of official denial, responsibility for radiation - induced cancers and diseases contracted by its nuclear workers. All of us in Britain should be asking two hard questions.

Can Britain's nuclear industry ever be trusted to come clean on sensitive issues involving radiation and public health and safety? And in light of Tony Blair's mystifying silence on the above revelations and continued support of BNFL and all things nuclear, who leads the government's front bench on matters concerning nuclear power and the environment - Tony Blair or the nuclear industry?
David Miller
Radcliffe-on-Trent, Notts

 There is an easy answer to Sellafield's image problem. Just change the name to Windscale.
Peter Nias
Telford, Shropshire

fields.headline: From Russia without love
fields.trailText: Hugo Young bemoans Tony Blair's "aura of empty piety" in his soft approach to Vladimir Putin's relentless bombing campaign in Chechnya (A welcome for Putin, the butcher of Chechnya, April 18). He is being naive.
fields.body:
Hugo Young bemoans Tony Blair's "aura of empty piety" in his soft approach to Vladimir Putin's relentless bombing campaign in Chechnya (A welcome for Putin, the butcher of Chechnya, April 18). He is being naive.

Blair sees a business opportunity for UK firms in a Russia under a firm pair of hands. He can spout as much rhetoric as he likes but at the end of the day his helmsmanship of a capitalist economy inevitably drives him to put economic considerations before an ethical foreign policy.

It is pointless to suggest that Putin can be pulled along the desirable path of nuclear disarmament when the UK is refurbishing its Trident warhead capacity and acceding to the US's new missile defence system in Yorkshire.
Nigel Wade, Dalrymple, Ayrshire

 Haven't you gone overboard with your characterisation of Tony Blair's meeting with Vladimir Putin as "shameful, unseemly and surprisingly old-fashioned" (Leader, April 17)? There is only one way to get to know what is going on in the mind of another, whether friend or enemy - the old-fashioned method of dialogue.
Sir Sigmund Sternberg, London

 Given that 80% of young Russians are learning English, given the great depth of goodwill towards this country that persists in Russia, maybe it is not so surprising that the prime minister has invited the new Russian president to make his first official visit abroad to Britain.
Bryan Woodriff, Hampton, Middx

webTitle: Bridget Jones habit of rewards helps increase alcohol intake

fields.headline: Bridget Jones habit of rewards helps increase alcohol intake
fields.trailText: British women are hitting the bottle as never before, with the "Bridget Jones" habit of balancing "vg" or very good sessions of abstinence against later consumption helping to increase alcohol intake, a report suggested yesterday.
fields.body:
British women are hitting the bottle as never before, with the "Bridget Jones" habit of balancing "vg" or very good sessions of abstinence against later consumption helping to increase alcohol intake, a report suggested yesterday.

Their drinking is expected to accelerate faster than in many other countries as young professional women follow the male habit of an after work drink to wind down from a stressful day.

Women in their late teens and early 20s are increasingly turning to premium bottled lagers and pre-mixed spirits, instead of the pints of pumped beer and hard liquor shorts favoured by men, according to the market analyst Datamonitor.

The report said the rise of women in higher education and employment had created a different generation of drinkers. The conversion of bars and pubs from predominantly male haunts into unisex areas serving food had helped women to feel comfortable in going for a drink without male company.

Using the standard measure of an alcoholic unit, equivalent to a pub measure of spirits, half a pint of beer or a small glass of wine, Datamonitor surveyed the drinks industry in Britain, seven other EU countries and the US.

Consumption of alcohol by British women was 9.4 units a week - still behind France, Germany, Italy and Spain. But by 2004 consumption was expected to be 11.8 units, behind only Germany on 14.3 and France on 12.9.

The company's drinks analyst, Richard Robinson, said the research indicated that "many consumers follow a 'debits and credits' system which sees them feeling that one session of 'being good', such as going to the gym, earns them an indulgence such as an alcoholic drink. Consumers feel more comfortable about their alcohol intake as they feel able to justify it to themselves."

Bridget Jones, heroine of Helen Fielding's book, weighed up 'vg' against 'v.bad' days for drinking, smoking and weight gain or loss.

Mr Robinson said: "There has been a bit of a flip in attitudes, with people saying they are not going to devote all their energies to getting a body beautiful but want to enjoy themselves at the same time."

Grahame Goodwin, spokesman for the Portman Group, the alcohol industry's body that promotes sensible drinking, said women still lagged far behind men in their consumption. But many people appeared unaware that the government had changed its health guidelines from 14 units a week to two or three a day.

"People trying to be sensible are saving up units for Friday or Saturday night, or both."

webTitle: 'Laddish ideal' helps drive men to suicide as more women turn to drink

fields.headline: 'Laddish ideal' helps drive men to suicide as more women turn to drink
fields.standfirst: Psychologist blames 'false hope' offered by magazines
fields.trailText: Lad magazines are contributing to the rising suicide rate among young men by offering a false hope that they could live up to the image of laddish culture instead of adapting to the real world, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Lad magazines are contributing to the rising suicide rate among young men by offering a false hope that they could live up to the image of laddish culture instead of adapting to the real world, it was claimed yesterday.

The "men behaving badly" culture celebrated in magazines like Loaded and Maxim is 40 years out of date, according to psychologist Trefor Lloyd of the Men's Health Forum, an umbrella group of organisations tackling male health issues.

Among men aged 15 to 24 the suicide rate has doubled in the past 25 years, and it has increased by 50% in men between 25 and 44, despite a fall in suicides across the population as a whole.

Last year 1,500 men under 34 killed themselves - more than died in car accidents.

The health forum report called for more effective strategies to tackle depression and suicide in men, including school lessons and youth programmes aimed at teaching boys how to deal with their emotions and encouraging them to explore their "maleness".

Mr Lloyd said: "These magazines reflect rather than lead in this area. Men find it difficult even to ask for directions when they are driving, so how do we expect them to ask for help with health or emotional problems?" He added: "For the first time next year, women will make up 51% of the workforce. Men have had to cope with losing their role as the only breadwinners, rising unemployment and a lowering of expectations.

"They have got to adapt to the modern world but this laddish culture offers them false hope. The laddish culture is looking back to how men were 30 or 40 years ago - life just isn't like that any more and men need to adapt and come to terms with that."

fields.headline: Under lock and key...
fields.trailText: I want to express my complete disgust at William Hague's proposal to herd all asylum seekers into detention camps (Tories step up asylum battle, April 18).
fields.body:
I want to express my complete disgust at William Hague's proposal to herd all asylum seekers into detention camps (Tories step up asylum battle, April 18).

I have taught many young asylum seekers and refugees in my career, and for the past eight months I have had the privilege of teaching Kosovan children in a school in north Manchester.

These children come to us usually very distressed, confused, separated from loved ones. They have no idea why they are here and miss home. Often conditions are hard, attitudes towards them hostile even when settled into a community.

The idea that they should be imprisoned is immoral. These children need some sense of normality, which is not going to be provided behind bars.

I challenge Mr Hague - and Jack Straw for that matter - to look into the eyes of a refugee child and try to justify their hardline policies.
Penny Hudson
Mellor, Lancs penny1hudson@hotmail.com

 How long before William Hague suggests giving all asylum seekers little identification badges to sew into their clothes? And perhaps a discreet tattoo somewhere on their upper arm just in case they can't afford to buy clothes with their vouchers?

As a way of stirring up racist hatred his methods can hardly be faulted, but as a serious contribution to political debate, he has proved himself woefully inadequate.
Simon Brilliant
London
brilliant@cableinet.co.uk

 To help William Hague sell his scheme to the public, perhaps he should consider commissioning a book detailing the more positive aspects of his idea using relevent examples from recent history. Somebody should forward David Irving's telephone number to Conservative Central Office as a matter of urgency.
Gareth D Roberts
Twickenham, Middlesex

 The Tories say they will build detention centres for all asylum seekers. Labour says it has already got them. The Tories say they will deport more people, more efficiently. Labour says it has sent more people "back" than the Tories did.

This is a country where where everyone is supposed to be presumed innocent until found guilty and whose inhabitants are all descended from migrants of one kind or another. In an increasingly mobile, globalised world, a rich country like ours should be welcoming people in need who flee here - at the same time as supporting those in need who are already here.
John Nicholson
Manchester
john@ukpha.org.uk

 The use of the emotive term bogus (Letters, April 17) is in itself entirely bogus and reprehensible. Anyone is entitled to come to the UK to apply for asylum according to the rules.

If a person fails to meet the asylum criteria for any reason, that does not render his or her application bogus or fraudulent; it is simply an application which has failed.

If I apply for a job, I do not become a bogus job seeker just because my application is rejected.
Paul Barber
Alton, Hants
plovers@gn.apc.org

 Can't the Conservatives see that every time they talk about Britain being a "soft touch for bogus asylum seekers" they are as good as issuing an invitation to precisely the sort of people they say they want to keep out?
Dr M Louise Pirouet
Cambridge

 Of course Britain attracts bogus asylum seekers. We have the most bogus asylum any country could wish to offer.
Tony Purcell
Chelmsford, Essex

fields.headline: Straw infight over security powers
fields.trailText: Lawyers for the home secretary yesterday began an unprecedented court battle to establish that he alone can decide what constitutes a threat to national security.
fields.body:
Lawyers for the home secretary yesterday began an unprecedented court battle to establish that he alone can decide what constitutes a threat to national security.

The case, in the court of appeal, concerns a Pakistani Muslim iman, Shafiq Ur Rehman, who Jack Straw tried to deport in 1998 because of allegations that he gave active support to an armed Kashmiri independence group.

The court's ruling will have far reaching consequences for the home secretary's discretion to deport other people suspected of supporting terrorist organisations abroad.

Mr Rehman challenged the deportation order and his was the first case to go to the new special immigration appeals commission last year. The commission decided that the home secretary had taken too wide a view of the meaning of national security.

After a four day hearing, it found that the term "national security" could not mean in the interests of good relations between the UK and another country, in this case India. It also ruled that the home secretary had failed to prove that Mr Rehman had been involved in terrorist activities.

During the hearing it emerged from an M15 witness that the security service had tried to recruit Mr Rehman under threat of deportation. He refused.

Yesterday Mr Straw appealed against the commission's ruling before Lord Woolf, the master of the rolls, sitting with Lord Justice Laws and Mr Justice Harrison.

Mr Rehman, most of whose family live in the north of England, came to Britain in 1993 and he was given leave to remain until February 1997 to study to become an iman. He is now a priest at an Oldham mosque and has two children born here.

In March 1997 he applied for indefinite leave to remain. This was refused.

The Home Office claimed he was involved in fundraising and recruiting rebels for the armed mujahideen group Lashkar Tayyaba - which is fighting the Indian army in Kashmir - as well as its legal political wing Markaz Ud Dawawal Irshad (Centre for Invitation to the Divine Teachings).

He admitted only sending money for building hospitals and schools in Pakistan.

Philip Sales, counsel for the home secretary, said Mr Rehman's activities led directly to the presence in the UK of individuals who were highly committed to a cause, indoctrinated in extremist beliefs and trained in weapons handling.

They were people "who may at some future time or in response to some future perceived provocation, attack other similar groups within the UK with whom they disagree."

He said the phrase national security had never been defined in statute because "it is a protean concept, designed to emcompass the many, varied and unpredicatable ways in which the security of the nation may best be protected."

The courts, he said, have always allowed the home secretary to be the judge of threats to national security.

"It is the secretary of state and the government who have the heavy political responsiblity of protecting national security.

"It is right and proper that the courts, including the commission, should not substitute their view of what national security may require."

Sibghat Kadri QC, Mr Rehman's counsel, said the commission had been right to decide that Mr Rehman did not pose a threat to UK national security.

"It was entitled to say that the the secretary of state had got it wrong," he said.

The hearing continues today.

fields.headline: Going for gold
fields.standfirst: Football can make you seriously rich
fields.trailText: Professional footballers over the age of 20 are now paid 20 times more than average earnings, according to a survey in the Independent. Some 36% earn over £500,000 and 9% - about 100 players - earn over a million. And that's without counting in sponsorship income.
fields.body:
With £409,000 you could buy a big house in London, a small village in some of the depressed mining regions - or one Premiership football player for a year. Professional footballers over the age of 20 are now paid 20 times more than average earnings, according to a survey in the Independent. Some 36% earn over £500,000 and 9% - about 100 players - earn over a million. And that's without counting in sponsorship income.

The odd thing about football's gravy train is how few actually complain about it - even those poorer supporters who can barely afford to go through the turnstiles. Translate the same earnings to the boardroom and it is another matter. Directors are pilloried for feathering their nests and rewarding themselves with salaries that appear to bear no relation to the skills and effort put in. Football - one of the few areas of the economy where there is a free market in people - is different. Supporters will boo if their players do badly - but that is usually irrespective of what they earn. If high earners contribute to the tribal success of their clubs they are applauded - possibly because supporters can see a link between pay and performance.

But the free market is also creating a dangerous "winner-takes-all" atmosphere. The rewards for being at the top of the league are so big (entry into Europe) and the pitfalls of being at the bottom so dreadful (dropping into a lower division with a big loss of television income) that clubs are prepared to spend millions just to secure the extra three or four goals that could make all the difference. Players justify high salaries because their playing lives are short. The plight of the great Brazilian Ronaldo, his career possibly finished by injury at 23, is evidence of that. But their lives don't suddenly end. If they do not land jobs in football management or the media, they can still go back tothe sort of employment that their supporters put up with. Football is a game of two extremes.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • There seems, I'm very sad to report, no low to which the Tory party will not stoop in its attempts to make capital out of asylum-seeking refugees in this country. Only yesterday, on the front page of this very newspaper, a "senior Tory source" attempted to rope in The Sound of Music as evidence of how to sort out "bogus" asylum seekers.
fields.body:
 There seems, I'm very sad to report, no low to which the Tory party will not stoop in its attempts to make capital out of asylum-seeking refugees in this country. Only yesterday, on the front page of this very newspaper, a "senior Tory source" attempted to rope in The Sound of Music as evidence of how to sort out "bogus" asylum seekers.

Genuine refugees, the Tory said, are happy to seek asylum in the first country they come to: "Look at the von Trapps - did they worry where they went to when they fled the Nazis?" Now, it's all too easy to think the Tories have gone totally crackers, what with William Hague's wacky plan to lock up all refugees in camps for a few weeks before booting them out of the country.

So my colleague Kate Morris rings Johannes von Trapp, the youngest of the von Trapp children, now living in the US, to see how he feels at being a part of formulating Conservative policy. "It is the movie von Trapps they are talking about, so they can say what they like. Our situation was different," said Johannes. "Other than that I do not want to comment." Next week: a Tory source explains why Victor Lazlo should have stayed put in Casablanca.

webTitle: Clinton offers Taiwan watered-down weapons package

fields.headline: Clinton offers Taiwan watered-down weapons package
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration's policy of engagement with China faces two congressional defeats in the coming weeks as support grows in congress for a tougher stance in defence of Taiwan and the rejection of normal trade relations with Beijing.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration's policy of engagement with China faces two congressional defeats in the coming weeks as support grows in congress for a tougher stance in defence of Taiwan and the rejection of normal trade relations with Beijing.

After weeks of lobbying by groups for and against Beijing, the White House announced yesterday that it intends to sell Taiwan upgraded versions of three medium-range air-to-air and air-to-ship missiles, as well as a new long-range "Pave Paws" radar system designed to give early warning of hostile missile and aircraft attacks launched against the island from deep inside the mainland.

The carefully calibrated decision is seen as too much by China and too little by Taiwan. Republican congressional leaders have also condemned it as inadequate, given the recent signs of a more aggressive Chinese military posture towards Taiwan.

The US critics, led by Jesse Helms, chairman of the senate foreign relations committee, also want the US to sell Taiwan four hi-tech Aegis destroyers, which are equipped with missiles and radar systems that can track up to 100 targets simultaneously.

The Taiwanese and Chinese governments have mounted massive congressional lobbying efforts for and against the sale of the Aegis ships, which cost $1.1bn (£696m) each.

"I am extremely disappointed to learn that the Pentagon has apparently succumbed to pressure from the state department and the White House to sacrifice Taiwan's security in order to appease the dictators in Beijing," Mr Helms said.

Republican leaders signalled yesterday that they will vote either to add the Aegis ships to the weapons package, a move which would almost certainly be vetoed by President Clinton, or to build the ships anyway for the US navy, so that they could be deployed in north Asian waters to fulfil the same deterrent purpose.

The package approved by the administration for sale to Taiwan represents a partial victory for Beijing.

It is also a clear sign that the White House remains intent on improving relations with Beijing and liberalising trade rather than making moves which could escalate a crisis over Taiwan in a US election year.

But its hope of securing the passage of its China trade bill, scheduled for a crucial vote in the house of representatives on May 22, which will give China permanent trading partner status, suffered a serious blow last night when the house Democratic leader, Dick Gephardt, announced that he would oppose it.

His decision could sink the bill, which is the centrepiece of the administration's legislative effort on Capitol Hill this spring.

webTitle: Question of poll priorities taxes Tories and Lib Dems

fields.headline: Question of poll priorities taxes Tories and Lib Dems
fields.standfirst: Romsey byelection Hague insists euro and asylum seekers are the issues, Kennedy's troops focus on threat to post offices and green belt
fields.trailText: Half a millennium is a long time in politics, but not long enough to stop a politician on the campaign trail grabbing a convenient historical parallel. The Hampshire town of Romsey, backdrop for a byelection next month which will see the two main opposition parties go head to head in search of a mid-term triumph, was yesterday treated to a reminder from shadow chancellor Michael Portillo of its proud record in standing by its priorities.
fields.body:
Half a millennium is a long time in politics, but not long enough to stop a politician on the campaign trail grabbing a convenient historical parallel. The Hampshire town of Romsey, backdrop for a byelection next month which will see the two main opposition parties go head to head in search of a mid-term triumph, was yesterday treated to a reminder from shadow chancellor Michael Portillo of its proud record in standing by its priorities.

"Five hundred years ago, the people of Romsey came together in a big group to keep their abbey," Mr Portillo told a bedraggled, Barbour-clad crowd attending a Tory Save the Pound rally, a stone's throw from the Norman edifice bought up by Romsey townsfolk at the dissolution of the monasteries. "Today," he added, as balloons emblazoned with anti-European slo gans bobbed damply, "they have come together in a big group to keep the pound."

Romsey residents purchased their abbey church for £100 in 1544; today the agenda is less cash for convents than the need to preserve post offices from closure and the green belt from the developers' bulldozers. For the Tories, aiming to hold a largely rural seat after the death in a house fire of MP Michael Colvin, the contest is also a test of the party's hard-line policies on asylum seekers and euro entry: issues canvassers claim are a constant theme on the doorstep.

Both William Hague, in the constituency yesterday, and Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, who makes his second visit today, are facing a personal leadership test in the May 4 poll, the first race directly between the two parties since the general election. The sprawling Romsey seat, stretching from Andover in the rural north down to the Southampton fringes, is traditionally safe Tory territory, held by Mr Colvin in 1997 with an 8,500 majority over the Lib Dems. Mr Kennedy's party is "throwing the kitchen sink" at the contest, hoping local candidate Sandra Gidley can contrive a mid-term upset along the lines of pre-'97 victories in Christchurch and Newbury.

On a relentless rainy Tuesday, the gentlemanly Tory candidate Timothy Palmer, a 47-year-old Eton educated Dorset farmer, was afforded the backdrop of the Conservatives' Save the Pound lorry as Mr Hague and his shadow chancellor combined byelection campaigning with the latest leg of their round-Britain anti-euro tour.

After Mr Portillo's warm-up, Mr Hague took the microphone to warn fewer than 200 shoppers and Tory activists that, left to Labour or the Lib Dems, the nation would stumble into the euro, paying the price in higher taxes, lost jobs and struggling businesses. He pressed on to asylum seekers, only to find that his mild preamble ("Britain has a proud record of offering sanctuary to genuine victims of persecution") received warmer applause than his calls for tough action.

The Lib Dem candidate, a pharmacist and former Romsey mayor scores strongly as a local contender, while the Tories' Mr Palmer lives across the county border in Dorset, the Lib Dems say. They counter Tory claims that national issues, such as the euro, are figuring on the doorstep, insisting voters are more concerned to see investment in health and education, to boost pensions and to preserve green field sites and post offices.

Lib Dem talk of securing tactical votes is fiercely rejected by Labour candidate Andrew Howard, who argues he would never have given up the chairmanship of Croydon and Surrey Downs Community NHS Trust to fight the byelection if his party were not taking the contest seriously.

fields.headline: 'New era' BNFL axes directors
fields.standfirst: Tighter safety includes retraining all plutonium fuel staff
fields.trailText: Sweeping management changes at British Nuclear Fuels, including the replacement of nine directors and retraining of all staff involved in making plutonium fuel, were announced by the company yesterday.
fields.body:
Sweeping management changes at British Nuclear Fuels, including the replacement of nine directors and retraining of all staff involved in making plutonium fuel, were announced by the company yesterday.

The entire company, not just the Sellafield works in Cumbria, is being reorganised to help BNFL recover from problems which were "the most serious that the company has ever experienced", according to the new chief executive, Norman Askew. He took over last month after his predecessor, John Taylor, resigned in the wake of critical reports from the government watchdog, the nuclear installations inspectorate.

Seventy new jobs will be created to ensure safety - including an executive director of health, safety and environment, and a new safety audit support team.

Among those leaving the company "by mutual agreement" are the director of safety, David Coulston, human resources director Roger Leek, and finance director Ross Chiese. All six non-executive directors will also be replaced.

The company, which has suffered a series of reverses since it admitted that its workers had falsified quality control records for plutonium fuel destined for Japan, remained determined that its business would otherwise continue unchanged. Although spent fuel shipments to Sellafield have been suspended from Switzerland and Germany, BNFL believes the changes will restore confidence.

There are no thoughts of ending reprocessing of spent fuel, as the Irish and Danish governments have demanded. Manufacturing of plutonium fuel for export will resume as soon as the company can get permission from the safety inspectors, the company insisted, and it still hoped to be part-privatised.

But the new director of operations for the Sellafield site, Brain Watson, admitted: "We know we have a long way to go to restore confidence in the government, but we have the assets and £10bn in existing reprocessing contracts, and we are looking for new business."

Laurence Williams, chief inspector of the NII, said the plans provided "a good foundation to deliver the necessary safety improvements".

Helen Liddell, the energy minister, made it clear that provided everything went well, the government was still intent on part-privatisation of the company - although this has been postponed until after the next general election.

Decommissioning and clean- up is the largest potential area of new business and the green groups believe this is the company's future.

Mark Johnston, nuclear campaigner at Friends of the Earth said: "BNFL cannot move forward safely if it is going in the wrong direction."

Greenpeace's nuclear campaigner Helen Wallace said: "The fundamental problems with BNFL's business are not addressed in this report."

webTitle: Police reveal new suspect in hunt for Dando killer

fields.headline: Police reveal new suspect in hunt for Dando killer
fields.trailText: Police hunting the killer of Jill Dando are looking for a man wearing a trilby hat and an ill fitting suit who was seen loitering near the television presenter's house in the weeks leading up to her death.
fields.body:
Police hunting the killer of Jill Dando are looking for a man wearing a trilby hat and an ill fitting suit who was seen loitering near the television presenter's house in the weeks leading up to her death.

The man, said to be in his thirties or forties, tall and with dark hair, was spotted by on least 12 occasions in the area of Fulham where Ms Dando, 37, lived.

Detective Inspector Hamish Campbell said police believed all the witnesses had identified the same man, even though their descriptions varied slightly. At least three said he had a trilby on, while others said he wore large glasses and a baggy suit.

Det Insp Campbell said the man was likely to be a loner, emotionally isolated, and may have shown an interest in Ms Dando or been infatuated with other women in the past.

The Crimewatch presenter was killed by a shot to the back of the head on April 26 last year outside her home on Gowan Avenue. Despite one of the biggest hunts in Metropolitan police history, nobody has been arrested for the crime.

Detectives are believed to have all but discounted the theory that Ms Dando was the victim of a professional hitman, after a £250,000 reward offer and hundreds of inquiries among underworld sources failed to produce a lead.

The new clues to a possible killer feature in an appeal on Crimewatch on BBC1 tonight to mark the anniversary of her death. The programme also features an interview with Ms Dando's father, speaking publicly for the first time about her death.

Jack Dando, 82, of Westonsuper-Mare, Somerset, told the programme: "I've come to the conclusion that they will get somebody one day [for the murder] - I'm living in hope that one day he will be caught."

The man police are hunting was spotted by a workman on three occasions. On Monday April 12 he noticed the man standing outside a nursery school on Munster Road, and he was still there when he came out of a cafe 35 to 40 minutes later.

The following Monday, April 19, the workman spotted the man on the corner of Waldon Avenue and Sidbury Street, and he saw him again on Wednesday April 21 at about 11am.

He said the man, who was walking down Sidbury Street, became agitated when he noticed that he had spotted him and tried to hide his face by looking at the pavement.

Police believe the killer must have an intimate knowledge of firearms because of the way the bullet, a Remington made in or after 1994, was "crimped" to hold it into the cartridge. Det Insp Campbell said the man must have used or handled guns in the past.

Mr Dando told the programme that the last time he saw his daughter was when he went to London to see a specialist about having an eye operation. "My eyesight was getting steadily worse, so Jill arranged for me to have a private consultation.

"One of the main reasons was the wedding, and I thought that I was going to have my eyesight much better so I could have walked her up the aisle; but it didn't work out that way."

Describing the moment he heard his daughter had been murdered, he said: "I was having my lunch. I didn't have the radio on. Then the telephone went, and it was Doreen, my next door neighbour.

"She said: 'Oh Jack, I got some terrible news.' Oh, I said, What's that? And she said: 'I've just heard on the news, the one o'clock news, that Jill has been murdered.'

"I still had the operation because I had to think about the memorial service."

webTitle: Teachers warn of test stress danger to pupils

fields.headline: Teachers warn of test stress danger to pupils
fields.trailText: The government drive to raise education standards is putting children under such pressure that it will not be long before schools report test-induced pupil suicides, the Association of Teachers and Lecturers warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The government drive to raise education standards is putting children under such pressure that it will not be long before schools report test-induced pupil suicides, the Association of Teachers and Lecturers warned yesterday.

The association's annual conference in Belfast unanimously passed a motion objecting to the "factory farming" of children and demanding research into the space needed for teaching.

Hank Roberts, a north London secondary teacher, said pressure on staff to meet school targets was transmitted to pupils, causing anxiety, irritability and short tempers.

"This government is treading a route to child suicide, as in Japan, because of the intolerable hothouse pressures put on children's learning," he said.

Last year there were 192 suicides of children under 16 in Japan - a 44% increase on the previous year that was attributed in part to academic pressures.

Mr Roberts, a teacher at Copland community school in Wembley, said pressures on children were driven by the government's need to achieve its education targets to secure another Labour victory at the next election.

Ministers wanted to extend the school day to 5pm and were promoting after-hours homework clubs, Saturday schools and holiday revision classes.

"It's time to end factory farming and give our kids a bit of free range," he said.

Pat Bennett, a Lambeth primary teacher, said classrooms needed more space to meet the expanding requirements of the national curriculum. Instead, children were squeezed into a smaller area and that made them more volatile.

Peter Smith, the association's general secretary, said: "Obviously it is right children should be put under some pressure to do their best.

"But we have to make a sensible judgment about the point at which it becomes counter-productive."

Peter Wilson, director of Young Minds, a mental health charity, said: "Children respond differently to the testing regime.

"Some rise to it, but our education system doesn't take into consideration children grow up with different levels of ability. For some, testing is demanding and disturbing.

"There are now significant mental health problems for many children who don't have the ability or readiness to cope."

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said the teachers were exaggerating.

"I don't accept the country is full of children who are in credibly anxious about their Sats tests after Easter. For ages we put pressure on some of our 11-year-olds because they could not read or write.

"It does mean hard work and a bit more study on the part of the kids, but the bottom line is they go to secondary school with the basic skills they need," she said.

 The government yesterday promised £60m to renovate secondary school science labs after a warning from the office for standards in education that 750 do not have the facilities needed to teach the national curriculum.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said 400 secondaries would receive cash from the government's capital modernisation fund over the next two years.

Ms Morris also announced a £70m grant to give performance incentives to head teachers, deputies and advanced skills teachers.

Another £10m will be spent on experimental bursaries for classroom teachers to develop their professional skills.

Ms Morris, Labour MP for Yardley, Birmingham, also said Rover car workers at Longbridge would be encouraged to retrain as teachers.

The association's annual conference in Belfast unanimously passed a motion objecting to the "factory farming" of children and demanding research into the space needed for teaching. Hank Roberts, a north London secondary teacher, said pressure on staff to meet school targets was transmitted to pupils, causing anxiety, irritability and short tempers. "This government is treading a route to child suicide, as in Japan, because of the intolerable hothouse pressures put on children's learning," he said. Last year there were 192 suicides of children under 16 in Japan - a 44% increase on the previous year that was attributed in part to academic pressures. Mr Roberts, a teacher at Copland community school in Wembley, said pressures on children were driven by the government's need to achieve its education targets to secure another Labour victory at the next election. Ministers wanted to extend the school day to 5pm and were promoting after-hours homework clubs, Saturday schools and holiday revision classes. "It's time to end factory farming and give our kids a bit of free range," he said. Pat Bennett, a Lambeth primary teacher, said classrooms needed more space to meet the expanding requirements of the national curriculum. Instead, children were squeezed into a smaller area and that made them more volatile. Peter Smith, the association's general secretary, said: "Obviously it is right children should be put under some pressure to do their best. "But we have to make a sensible judgment about the point at which it becomes counter-productive." Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said 400 secondaries would receive cash from the government's capital modernisation fund over the next two years. Ms Morris also announced a £70m grant to give performance incentives to head teachers, deputies and advanced skills teachers. Another £10m will be spent on experimental bursaries for classroom teachers to develop their professional skills. Ms Morris, Labour MP for Yardley, Birmingham, also said Rover car workers at Longbridge would be encouraged to retrain as teachers.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Undercover Libraries | Disaster In Waiting
fields.body:
"Why is there not a Majesty's library in every county town? There is a Majesty's jail and gallows in every one", wondered Thomas Carlyle back in 1832. Because knowledge is power and that is why Conservative MPs fought so hard to stop the Public Libraries Act from becoming law. Fortunately, they failed, and a year later William Ewart's Bill providing books for free made it onto the statute books. Undercover Libraries (Radio 4, 11.0am) celebrates the 150th anniversary of the Act by looking at libraries ancient and modern.

Famines and floods, earthquakes and volcanic eruptions are always with us, yet the world is never prepared for nature's periodic wrath. Disaster In Waiting (Radio 4, 9.0pm), presented by disaster expert and risk analyst Professor Bill McGuire, looks at what we can learn from past catastrophes and why people fail to heed lessons learned from human tragedy.

webTitle: The lively art of defying death

fields.headline: The lively art of defying death
fields.standfirst: Guinness renews its search for the world's most senior citizens
fields.trailText: Since the world's oldest person died three days before the turn of the millennium the Guinness Book of Records has been trying to verify new candidates for the title.
fields.body:
Since the world's oldest person died three days before the turn of the millennium the Guinness Book of Records has been trying to verify new candidates for the title.

Officially England has the two oldest people in the world: Eva Morris, 115, and Harry Halford, 109. But Guinness is investigating the claims of several older contenders who live in the developing world.

In its search, the tiny island of Dominica in the West Indies has emerged as potentially the home of world's female longevity leaders.

No one was sure how old Elizabeth Israel, better known as "Mampampo", was when she entered hospital last November.

She was certainly over 100, for as one elderly neighbour put it: "I'm 68, and when I was a little pickney [child] she was already an old woman."

But when local church records were searched, it emerged that she was 125: not only the oldest person living, but the oldest ever recorded.

Four doors down from Ms Israel, Jollina James heard the news and started wondering about her great-great aunt Rose Peters, a friend and colleague of Mampampo's for more than 100 years. Her entry was also found in the church registry: February 25 1883, making her 117 and the second oldest person alive.

Both women worked on a local plantation picking vegetables well into their hundreds; Ms Israel, whose mother was born a slave, was a foreman.

The church registry looks unimpeachable: volumes of meticulously typed records copied from originals damaged by Hurricane David in late 1979.

The parish priest, Father Charles Martin, says they could not have been tampered with. If they have been, then so have tens of thousands of other names in the 14 volumes kept in the church safe, he says.

Ms Israel is frail but her mind is as clear as a bell. She remembers Queen Victoria dying - "There was a lot of fuss, but I wasn't that bothered".

Despite her 117 years, Ms Peters is also quick of mind and full of energy. She attributes her age to her diet and hard work. Dominica's plentiful water is so pure it needs no treatment and both women still live on vegetable-based diets.

Ms Israel has never touched a drop of liquor.

"It makes you mad," she says. She too attributes her longevity to a strong work ethic.

"Hard work never killed anybody. It's laziness that kills."

Daniel Nathaniel Harekeb may live 3,000 miles away but he is likely to appear next to Ms Israel in the Guinness Book of Records as the world's oldest man.

At 112 he is the oldest person in Namibia, but to everyone in his home town of Karibib he is a very naughty man.

"Take some cold beers and he'll be pleased to see you," one local says. "But he's very naughty."

Mr Harekeb, a San bushman, emerges from his home shaking a stick and shouts: "Who's disturbing me?"

Holding a cold beer, he explains his philosophy for a long life.

"I just put my faith in God. I eat maize porridge in the morning, followed by fruit, and never eat after it gets dark. I drink when I can - it makes me feel young again. And whenever I see a woman," he grins, "I have her."

"I do feel very old. But it rained the other day, and when it hit my face my skin tingled and my heart felt strong."

His earliest memories are of running away from mission school, at about the time the Germans arrived in Namibia. After that he worked as a shepherd.

He has vague memories of the German-Herero war of 1904-07, but says: "They are just a blur. Everything seems a long way away."

In nearly 100 working years he made ice cream and worked in construction before starting on a German's farm in Karibib, about 80 miles north-west of the capital Windhoek. Ever since he, his children - he has none of his own but adopted his siblings' children after their parents died - and grandchildren have lived on the farm.

He worked past his 100th birthday.

Last year he was summoned to a government house in Windhoek by the Namibian president, Sam Nujoma, who told him he was the oldest man in the country. Whether he will be named the oldest man in the world depends on Guinness's verification process, which requires a valid birth or marriage certificate, or a census report.

After much persuasion, Mr Harekeb whispered the secret location of his documents to a grandson, who went to retrieve them. "I don't want you bastards stealing my pension!" he snarled at his relatives.

Along with a pension book was an identification card, issued after a census, giving his birthdate as August 10 1888.

Draining the last from another bottle of beer he stands up, clutching his documents. "Right, I've had enough. I want everyone to fuck off because I'm tired."

He walked off, leaving a little pile of empty beer bottles and two cigarette ends, marking his place in time.

webTitle: Noye to appeal against murder conviction

fields.headline: Noye to appeal against murder conviction
fields.trailText: Kenneth Noye, who was sentenced to life imprisonment for the road rage murder of Stephen Cameron last Friday, is planning to appeal against his conviction.
fields.body:
Kenneth Noye, who was sentenced to life imprisonment for the road rage murder of Stephen Cameron last Friday, is planning to appeal against his conviction.

Lawyers acting for Noye will visit him in prison tomorrow to discuss his options following the Old Bailey verdict.

Henry Milner, Noye's solicitor, said yesterday there would be an appeal, but he could not yet give any details.

Noye, 52, could appeal on a point of law if, for instance, his lawyers felt the prosecution had failed to disclose important evidence, or if there was a breakdown in legal procedure during the 12-day trial.

Noye's insistence that he could never get a fair trial in this country because of his reputation as a crime lord, might also be an issue.

In evidence, Noye said his treatment by the press following his acquittal 15 years ago of murdering Detective Constable John Fordham, who was hiding in his garden on covert surveillance, was "scandalous".

He said he fled to Spain after he stabbed Mr Cameron, 21, because the police "detested" him and would never believe he had used a knife in self-defence.

Noye took the risk of disclosing to the court he was acquitted of DC Fordham's murder and that he was subsequently jailed for dishonestly handling gold stolen in the Brink's-Mat bullion robbery.
