fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge.
fields.body:
Well, it's been another successful week in the judicial minefield for Oprah Winfrey, with a Chicago judge upholding the legality of the lifetime confidentiality agreements her minions are obliged to sign before joining the payroll.

The decision comes after Sarah Coady, a former underling, attempted to overturn her own speak-no-evil clause in time to write an unauthorised biography of her erstwhile boss; sadly for her, the beak concluded said agreement didn't infringe the First Amendment and, hence, was fair business practise. "There's no sense of justice here", complained Coady, while Winfrey - who recently declared "Free Speech Rocks!" upon escaping charges of slandering the US cattle industry - had no comment whatsoever. Funny that.

No such good news for Francis Ford Coppola, whose lawsuit against the estate of sci-fi author Carl Sagan was dismissed at California Appeals Court last week. The source of Coppola's chagrin goes back as far as the mid-70s, when - he claims - he and Sagan collaborated on an unlaunched TV show called First Contact: unlaunched, so he says, until Sagan lifted the idea for his bestseller Contact, and Warners banged out a (very, very poor) movie of the same name. Unfortunately for the director, however, the appellate court re-affirmed the 1999 verdict that his claims had been filed too late for any further action - a sentiment echoed by Sagan family lawyer Scott Edleman, who said: "After waiting 20 years, he sued Sagan's widow six days after her husband died."

Which just leaves time to mention Bo Diddley, and his lawsuit against Nike for using his image (beneath the legend "You Don't Know Diddley") on T-shirts. Having turned down the offer of a one-off royalty payment of around $10,000, Diddley's attorney Margo Lewis remarked that "this is a clear case of the big bully picking on the little guy". Where's your magic bus now then, Bo?

webTitle: Innocent catch flak in dirty war

fields.headline: Innocent catch flak in dirty war
fields.standfirst: UN accuses the Colombian army of helping paramilitaries to get away with murder in battle against leftwing rebels
fields.trailText: The paramilitaries stormed the village of Buenos Aires one Sunday evening just as the locals were leaving church. Brandishing assault rifles and machetes, around 200 of them herded the villagers into the square, where they announced that they were hunting for leftwing rebels.
fields.body:
The paramilitaries stormed the village of Buenos Aires one Sunday evening just as the locals were leaving church. Brandishing assault rifles and machetes, around 200 of them herded the villagers into the square, where they announced that they were hunting for leftwing rebels.

When they left, two local men lay dying in the street. What nobody can understand is how the paramilitaries made their getaway. They marched out of the village, 40 miles north of the city of Cali, at sunrise, down the road towards an army unit sent to intercept them - but military commanders say their troops never saw them.

"How do you explain that? 200 armed men don't just disappear," said a Colombian human rights official, who asked not to be named. He believes the army saw them and let them go.

As the US edges towards approving $1.6bn (£1bn) in mostly military aid to Colombia, the United Nations has released a report alleging that members of the Colombian army tolerate - or even collaborate with - the illegal paramilitary groups responsible for much of the violence in the country's dirty war.

It follows equally damning studies by the US state department and the monitoring group Human Rights Watch blaming the government of President Andres Pastrana for the growing strength of the paramilitary groups, which are now believed to field around 7,000 fighters.

"The state bears the responsibility for the present proportions and complexity of the paramilitary problem," the UN report says. "The direct and indirect aiding and abetting of paramilitarism is aggravated by the absence of any effective policy to combat it."

Colombia's rightwing militias are a hybrid force, combining the private armies of powerful landlords and drug dealers with the now-outlawed rural intelligence networks set up by the government to combat leftwing guerrillas.

Unarmed targets

Loosely allied as the United Self-Defence Groups of Colombia (ACCU), the paramilitaries rarely attack rebel groups - such as the leftwing Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) - preferring to go for unarmed civilians they accuse of sympathizing with the guerrillas.

Mr Pastrana has repeatedly promised to crack down on both the paramilitaries and their allies in the armed forces. Last year he cashiered several high-ranking officers accused of collaboration, but human rights groups say he has failed to make good many of his promises. In 1998 Mr Pastrana promised to create a special army taskforce to fight the paramilitaries, but it has yet to materialise.

Monitoring groups acknowledge that the army has greatly improved its human rights record and say that most abuses are now committed by the paramilitaries.

According to the US state department some servicemen help the paramilitaries by providing ammunition or intelligence. Others merely look the other way when the militias pass by.

With witnesses often too scared to speak out, allegations of links with the military are almost impossible to prove, said a western diplomat. "It's like abortion in a Catholic country. Everyone knows it's going on but nobody sees it happen."

The region worst hit by the paramilitary onslaught is in the Andes, north of Cali - until last year a Farc stronghold.

The "Calima Front" of the ACCU an nounced its arrival in the area with the murder of a farmer and his daughter in July. It issued fliers giving locals three options: leave the region, fight with the rebels, or die. Since August the group has killed 94 people, mostly community leaders and union activists. At least 2,000 people have fled their homes.

Marlene Correa lived through the in cursion in Buenos Aires on September 12 last year. Her son Luis, 23, did not; he was shot and killed by paramilitaries

"They made the women kneel down, and the boss ran his knife under our throats. He told us it was for gouging out guerrilla eyes. It was like a nightmare, but one of those nightmares you never wake up from." she said. "But what happened to the troops? They never arrived."

The troops reached the village on Monday morning, just hours after the paramilitaries had left. Local police and army officials deny reports from villagers that military helicopters flew overhead constantly in the days before the raid, dropping off uniformed men in the mountains nearby - but they concede that they are the only group with aircraft.

Assassination

After burying her son, Mrs Correa fled with more than 700 other villagers to the nearby town of Buga. Many of them are living in makeshift lodgings in a sports hall. They still fear for their safety. A local lawyer who took up their case was shot dead in January.

Their suspicions were further aroused when a known paramilitary spy was sighted on the local army base.

Lieutenant-Colonel Rafael Jani of the Palace Battalion in Buga admits that an ex-guerrilla turned informer regularly visits him with information on rebel movements. "If someone comes to my office and informs to me it doesn't mean he's my subordinate. And let's not be disingenuous - an informer isn't usually a champion of honesty," he said.

No suspects have been arrested in connection with any of the murders: state investigators say that the region is too dangerous for them to work in, and the military says it cannot catch the militias while they hide out in the mountains.

But locals say that the Calima Front has set up a permanent base in the abandoned village of Buenos Aires. "[They] are living in our homes," said Mrs Correa. "They have dances and cock fights up there. What more information does the army want?"

fields.headline: Lights, camera, inaction
fields.standfirst:
The makers of the Harry Potter film are in a flap. Why? Because it's so far behind schedule, it almost certainly won't arrive in cinemas before 2002. Just why does it take so long to make a movie? Mark Morris investigates
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The makers of the Harry Potter film are in a flap. Why? Because it's so far behind schedule, it almost certainly won't arrive in cinemas before 2002. Just why does it take so long to make a movie?
fields.body:
Pity those Harry Potter obsessives. It looks increasingly likely that they are going to have to wait until 2002 to denounce the Harry Potter film as the heretical, Americanised trash that they just know it will turn out to be. They've been getting worked up for the last couple of months now: because the film was going to be directed by Steven Spielberg, because it wasn't, because it will be directed by Chris Columbus and worse still, the film will use the first book's American title, Harry Potter And The Sorcerer's Stone. And after all that, the Potterites are going have to nurture their bile for another two years. More worryingly for the makers, the delays mean that it will be virtually impossible get the film onto the screens for the crucial summer 2001 school holiday period.

What knocked it off schedule was Spielberg's inability to decide whether to tackle Harry Potter, or the long-discussed Minority Report, or take up his newly assumed role as Stanley Kubrick's heir by directing AI. Steven's overloaded in-tray is typical of the convoluted business of Hollywood scheduling.

Ever wondered why it takes the movies so long to catch up with last year's big thing, or even a cultural juggernaut like Harry Potter? Say you're a producer who wants to make a movie about someone who loses a fortune on a internet scam. You get a writer to knock together a script. Then you start looking for a director and stars. You get lucky: Brad Pitt's people tell you he's really, really interested. But he's committed to two projects. You can't wait, so you move on to Johnny Depp and so on down the line. You end up with Billy Crudup, who can do it now but the director he's got a good relationship with won't be free for a year. Then Brad Pitt's two deals fall through and he's available, only by this time the technology has moved on and your story is looking stale.

Or forget the hypotheticals and take a glance at John Gregory Dunne's Monster: Making A Living Off The Big Screen, which is just out in paperback.

After six years of churning out draft after draft of Up Close And Personal for Disney, Dunne and his wife Joan Didion were suddenly forced to do a couple of months of frantic rewrites because Robert Redford had a gap in his schedule. The film - which had been vaguely relevant when first mooted in 1988 - was released in 1996 and sank without trace.

In the glory days of the studio system, none of this happened. It's not exactly true that stars did as they were told, otherwise George Raft wouldn't have been in a position to turn down every one of what became Humphrey Bogart's great roles. But the Warners and Louis B Mayer had the power to make things happen, and were working in a context where directors such as George Cukor and Michael Curtiz were making two films a year. And since barely anything was shot on location, it wasn't necessary to wait for the right local weather conditions on the Mediterranean coast. These were the working habits which made it possible to get the propaganda-packed Casablanca onto the screens while the war was going on, something that would be almost impossible today.

Vestiges of the old mentality live on in the porn industry, with its admirable dedication to the protestant work ethic, and Miramax's hor ror-film wing Dimension, which is the heir to Roger Corman's old crank 'em out quick and cheap policy.

Occasionally, the big players like to air their spontaneous side. When underwater sci-fi turkey Sphere was postponed, Dustin Hoffman and director Barry Levinson took the couple of months grace to make Wag The Dog. As soon as they had cast the film they went straight into rehearsals, and shooting took under a month. The film was in the cinemas by the time the Lewinsky scandal - which the film anticipated in various details - broke. And it made that other Clinton satire, Primary Colors - which had lumbered into existence at the usual Hollywood pace - look redundant when it released soon after.

More spontaneous still was Blue In The Face. Wayne Wang had finished shooting Smoke a week ahead of schedule. With a set and star Harvey Keitel available, he and writer Paul Auster decided to make another film while they were at it. A few phone calls to some mates were enough to get Madonna, Roseanne, Michael J Fox, Jim Jarmusch and Lou Reed to pop along for a day or so, and spliced together these sketches with a bit of hastily shot documentary to make a ramshackle but entertaining film.

And ever since the power moved from the studios to the agents, it's been harder to get everyone you need in the same place at the same time. Ever wandered why so much of Ewan McGregor's ropey performance is left in Velvet Goldmine? He was only there for the first couple of weeks of shooting: they couldn't go back. Throw in complex special effects needed for a film like Harry Potter, and you've got a chain of delays waiting to happen. Which is before you even think about trying to squeeze it into the cinemas.

The only consolation for the Potter-loving hordes is that Spielberg turned down the film: now that he's channelling Kubrick's spirit, it could have taken a decade.

webTitle: Sect head denies link to Ugandan massacre

fields.headline: Sect head denies link to Ugandan massacre
fields.trailText: The leader of the Australian Catholic sect alleged to have provided perverse inspiration to the Ugandan doomsday cult yesterday rejected any connection with the group.
fields.body:
The leader of the Australian Catholic sect alleged to have provided perverse inspiration to the Ugandan doomsday cult yesterday rejected any connection with the group.

William Kamm, the self-styled head of the Order of St Charbel in New South Wales - also known as the Marian Workers of Atonement - admitted preaching in Uganda in 1989 but said he would not know Joseph Kibwetere "from a bar of soap".

The leader of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God disappeared last month after a fire at a compound in Kanungu in which more than 330 people died. It is thought that throughout Uganda up to 900 followers may have been killed.

But Mr Kamm, who calls himself "Little Pebble", said: "Our teaching is nothing like what they proceeded to do, because they took their lives. Our teaching is to preserve life, so therefore what eventuated there, as far as I am concerned, is very, very sad."

Mr Kamm, 49, says he is one of a network of seers communicating with the Virgin Mary. He also says that after "mass" at his headquarters at Nowra, 130 miles south of Sydney, Mary regularly appears and that the Pope has given approval to his church.

However, the Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne, George Pell, has distanced the church from the controversial teachings of Little Pebble.

Mr Kamm said he went to Uganda in October 1989 and spoke on national radio and television for four days "non stop". He said there were 5,000 people at rallies each day, but he did not meet Mr Kibwetere.

"The media already for so many years have been trying to link us with all these doomsday groups, which is totally idiotic, because our group has nothing to do with doomsday," he said.

But the Rev David Milliken, an expert on cults in Australia, said: "Kamm has made a whole series of prophecies over the years about the end of the world and all of them have proved false, and he seems to just power on regardless."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: I'm not scum, says Haider
fields.body:
I'm not scum, says Haider

Jörg Haider, de facto leader of Austria's far-right Freedom party, admitted yesterday that his dream of becoming chancellor had shattered under the weight of international pressure.

Breaking his silence since his resignation as party chief seven weeks ago, Mr Haider, 50, told the Kleine Zeitung that he had been unjustly portrayed as the "scum of the earth".

Other EU states imposed sanctions on Austria in February when the Freedom party was sworn into government with the People's party.
Kate Connolly, Prague

343 immigrants found off Italy

Italian naval authorities intercepted a ship carrying 343 illegal immigrants yesterday after a distress call was sent out about a pregnant woman on board.

The ship was escorted to the port of Reggio Calabria, from where the passengers, who were mostly Kurds, were taken to detention centres, a port official said.

The pregnant woman was taken to hospital and the vessel's six crew were arrested.
AP, Reggio Calabria

Man held for jeep killings

The Indian police have arrested a key suspect for the murder of an Australian missionary and his two sons in the eastern state of Orissa last year, officers said yesterday.

According to the police, villagers stopped sheltering Abhi Ram Mohanta, 30, earlier this month after the arrest of the alleged ringleader of the mob that burned to death Graham Staines and his young sons as they slept in their jeep.
AP, Bhubaneshwar

16 Tamil Tigers die in raids

Sri Lankan troops killed 16 guerrillas during raids on Tamil Tiger hideouts, officials said yesterday.

The attacks on Monday on the Jaffna peninsula were aimed at driving the rebels back into the jungles, defence ministry spokesman Major Asiri Idunil said. The guerrillas stepped up their attacks in November to take back their former stronghold.
AP, Colombo

Envoy quits as tension grows

A leading Russian envoy in Chechnya resigned yesterday amid tension over the move towards a negotiated settlement in the region.

Bislan Gantamirov, a convicted embezzler, announced his resignation as signs that Moscow might be preparing to negotiate with the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, strengthened. Mr Gantamirov has always opposed such talks.
Amelia Gentleman, Moscow

4.2m S Africans have HIV

South Africa's ministry of health said yesterday that an estimated 4.2m people, just under 10% of the population, were infected with HIV.

The figures were extrapolated from a national survey of women attending public antenatal clinics, which showed that 22% of the pregnant women tested were HIV positive.
Reuters, Johannesburg

Cuba hits back at UN vote

The UN Commission on Human Rights yesterday adopted a resolution denouncing Cuba for repressing political dissent and religious groups.

The resolution, put forward by the Czech Republic and Poland, was backed by the United States. Cuba's Communist party said 100,000 Cubans would be marching on the Czech embassy in Havana.
Reuters, Geneva

Belgian rail crash injures 15

About 15 people were injured yesterday when two trains collided in Belgium.

Television reports said a passenger train apparently derailed by a concrete block on the track was hit by a freight train near Charleroi. Three of the victims were seriously hurt.
AP, Brussels

webTitle: Sheep droppings blamed for stomach upsets

fields.headline: Sheep droppings blamed for stomach upsets
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Sheep grazing near a reservoir have been blamed for an outbreak of cryptosporidiosis which caused stomach upsets for hundreds of people in the north-west.
fields.body:
Sheep grazing near a reservoir have been blamed for an outbreak of cryptosporidiosis which caused stomach upsets for hundreds of people in the north-west.

Infected sheep droppings were responsible for contaminating the Thirlmere reservoir in the Lake District - which serves 620,000 homes in south Cumbria, Lancashire and Greater Manchester.

More than 300 people were affected by cryptosporidiosis and suffered from diarrhoea and gastro-intestinal illness in April and May last year.

North West Water is now investing £300m in additional monitoring for the cryp tosporidium organism and a mixing system which will effectively stir the reservoir.

Paul West, head of quality regulation at the water company, said: "The most likely explanation for the outbreak was sheep grazing alongside the reservoir which led to contamination of the water by sheep droppings.

"Heavy rainfall at the same time led to the droppings short circuiting part of the reservoir and getting into an intake point."

In the UK as a whole, there were an estimated 5,000 cases of cryptosporidiosis last year. The bug is resistant to chlorination and the most effective way to kill the organism is by boiling water.

fields.headline: Peter Willmott
fields.standfirst: Forging a new kind of sociology amidst the working-class communities of east London
fields.trailText: Peter Willmott, who has died aged 76, was a pioneer of a new kind of sociology, which has had a worldwide influence. For much of his working life, he had the advantage of being not at a university but at a small, independent research unit, the Institute of Community Studies in Bethnal Green, east London. Thus, he was doubly close to the working-class people he wrote about - close to them in space, and close to them in spirit.
fields.body:
Peter Willmott, who has died aged 76, was a pioneer of a new kind of sociology, which has had a worldwide influence. For much of his working life, he had the advantage of being not at a university but at a small, independent research unit, the Institute of Community Studies in Bethnal Green, east London. Thus, he was doubly close to the working-class people he wrote about - close to them in space, and close to them in spirit.

The empathy came from his own past. Willmott was born in Adderbury, near Banbury, where his engineer father owned a garage and ran a rural one-bus service. When the family moved to Luton, Peter became an engineering apprentice in a car factory, although he did not always get on well with his foreman. On one occasion, he made a mistake on his lathe. The foreman was standing over him. "I do apologise," said Peter. "Are you trying to be fucking funny with me, eh?" replied the foreman.

During the second world war, Willmott was a Bevin boy, working down a mine in the Rhondda valley. He never had good eyesight. Hacking away in narrow seams and peering through the clouds of dust and sweat that coated his glasses, he developed the miners' disease, nystagmus, and was declared unfit for further work below ground. After that, he worked with the Quakers - in the Friends Relief Service and the Friends Ambulance Unit - before getting a place at Ruskin College, Oxford.

Not long after that came the most important event in Willmott's life; he met his wife, Phyllis Noble, In the fourth volume of her marvellous autobiography, Joys And Sorrows, she describes how their love was sparked shortly after the end of the war. By then, Peter was working at a Methodist homeless hostel; Phyllis, on her way to becoming an almoner, wanted to find a place for a tramp.

"At first sight of him through the glass panelling, I knew that Peter Willmott seemed less attractive in the flesh than that agreeable voice of his on the telephone had led me to hope," she wrote. "Yet within 10 minutes I was beguiled by his eloquence, in half an hour by his easygoing good humour and charm; and, as I left, I caught myself thinking, I could be happy living with this man . . .

"Ridiculous, really, I thought gloomily. I looked out of the train window, as we clanked along and swerved around the curving track past the shops in Lee High Road, and got ready to get off at the next stop. It was ridiculous, because why should I ever see this man again? Well, I decided I could at least scribble a note to thank him for the visit."

She risked it and, from that time on, Phyllis was, alongside her solo work, Peter's collaborator and chief support. While Peter was working on Family And Kinship In East London (1957), the first of the Bethnal Green books, he and she lived for three years in the attic of the institute. Their children, Lewis and Michael, went to local schools.

Phyllis took them there, and collecting them at the schoolgates and chatting to other mums, she became a sharp observer of the people around us. She was the ethnographer-in-chief, while Peter and I interviewed random samples of the local population. She kept a daily journal, as she has continued to do ever since.

Later on, Peter and she, when poverty on its up-and-down cycle had become popular again, directed a large survey of poverty in Europe. While Beatrice and Sidney Webb were the great advocates for the Soviet Union, Phyllis and Peter Willmott were devoting themselves to make something of social democracy in Britain and Europe.

Peter came into my life in 1947. He saw a note in the Observer about a Labour party pamphlet I had written, entitled Small Man, Big World. He wrote to me about it and was soon in the party's research department, of which I was secretary, for a time being in charge of propaganda as well as research.

He was a natural writer. He became the author and editor of a fortnightly pamphlet, with the jazzy title of Talking Points, which aimed to post useful "ammunition" (one of our much overused words at the time) to MPs and party workers around the country. Almost the only way we were like the more professional spin doctors of today was in our enthusiasm. We were spin nurses, perhaps influenced too much by Clement Attlee, who in 1945, in his final appeal to the nation, wrote his own script and read it out from his own handwriting into the BBC microphone.

It did not seem such a large step from socialism to sociology, which in Britain was then in its trampolining infancy. For one thing, the words were so similar. We were young and naïve enough to believe that, if we could report, in a convincing way, on the needs and hopes of Labour supporters, even if only in one working-class district, it would help to "bridge the gap" (another of our favourite platitudes) with the leadership - and that the leaders might take note.

As Peter put it, less party-politically: "The aim of the institute which we founded was to undertake research, which would both add to basic knowledge about society and illuminate practical questions of social policy, and to publish the findings in a form which would interest the layman as well as the specialist." We were ambitious as well as naïve.

Family And Kinship In East London was the first book by Willmott and me. Others followed, including Family And Class In A London Suburb (1960) and The Symmetrical Family (1973); there was also The Family Life Of Old People (1957), by Peter Townsend, and Widows And Their Families (1958), by Peter Marris.

The Evolution Of A Community (1963) was the first of Willmott's solo books. It was about Dagenham, the largest housing estate in the world, and probably the most dreary. Mrs Adams, one of Peter's informants, remembered how it was in the 1920s: "I went out for a walk and, when I came back, all the houses looked alike to me. I was in a terrible state, in tears. The workmen said: 'What's the matter ducks?' I said: 'I can't find my house'."

Another resident, Mrs Hamilton, described how "there were awful muddy holes in the road, and the women used to pick up bricks from the building site and drop them in the holes to give us stepping stones for our feet on the way back."

Peter Willmott had a much better story to tell about the 1960s. Dagenham had, in the course of time, become about as stable and settled as Bethnal Green, with extended families almost as thick on the ground, and residents thinking that, on the same unprepossessing site -and with houses as uniform - it was a "lovely place".

His second book on his own was Adolescent Boys Of East London (1966). It was partly about crime, which was (and is) widespread there. An 18-year-old said: "We used to thieve now and again, same as anyone else, but I don't think we was bad - it was just a normal thing we used to do."

A 16-year-old was, in Peter's view, exaggerating only slightly when he said: "There's not a boy I know who hasn't knocked something off at some time or another" - they knocked off more than they knocked down.

These quotations illustrate one feature of Peter's method. He could talk to anyone, and get them to talk to him. This belonged to the anthropology of the institute in its community studies (the other side was the statistical). We considered the qualitative method essential; indeed, it was the only way to touch on the individual experience.

But surveys of random samples were (and are) needed too. The individual's experience has to be put into a context to show how far anyone's experience is, in some way, typical or not. Without random samples, one cannot normally generalise about anything; without picking out individuals, the results of the random sampling can be lifeless.

The third feature of our method was to be readable. Since Peter, all members of the "Bethnal Green school" have to avoid the jargon which is the curse of sociology. Peter continued in the same vein when, later on, he joined the Policy Studies Institute, and with his further work on communities and the role of friendship, as well as families within them.

All Peter's work reflected his personality. He hated bullshit, perhaps especially when it came from academics. He was humorous, and had a lovely laugh. He was intensely interested in all sorts of people. Flim-flam made him roll his nystagmic eyes and smile at the same time, especially if he thought the person he was with would understand the rolling eyes.

He mocked the pretentious. Popular beliefs - for example, that the extended family had disappeared, or that "the family" was on its way to disaster, or that politicians were a bad lot - were dismissed by him. He did not make loose generalisations. He was commonsense incarnate.

He liked good food and, even more, good wine. He made nothing of having been a professor at the University of Paris, the University of London or the University of California. He loved Arsenal. He leaves Phyllis, Lewis and Michael.

"Yet within 10 minutes I was beguiled by his eloquence, in half an hour by his easygoing good humour and charm; and, as I left, I caught myself thinking, I could be happy living with this man . . . "Ridiculous, really, I thought gloomily. I looked out of the train window, as we clanked along and swerved around the curving track past the shops in Lee High Road, and got ready to get off at the next stop. It was ridiculous, because why should I ever see this man again? Well, I decided I could at least scribble a note to thank him for the visit." She risked it and, from that time on, Phyllis was, alongside her solo work, Peter's collaborator and chief support. While Peter was working on Family And Kinship In East London (1957), the first of the Bethnal Green books, he and she lived for three years in the attic of the institute. Their children, Lewis and Michael, went to local schools. Phyllis took them there, and collecting them at the schoolgates and chatting to other mums, she became a sharp observer of the people around us. She was the ethnographer-in-chief, while Peter and I interviewed random samples of the local population. She kept a daily journal, as she has continued to do ever since. Later on, Peter and she, when poverty on its up-and-down cycle had become popular again, directed a large survey of poverty in Europe. While Beatrice and Sidney Webb were the great advocates for the Soviet Union, Phyllis and Peter Willmott were devoting themselves to make something of social democracy in Britain and Europe. Peter came into my life in 1947. He saw a note in the Observer about a Labour party pamphlet I had written, entitled Small Man, Big World. He wrote to me about it and was soon in the party's research department, of which I was secretary, for a time being in charge of propaganda as well as research. He was a natural writer. He became the author and editor of a fortnightly pamphlet, with the jazzy title of Talking Points, which aimed to post useful "ammunition" (one of our much overused words at the time) to MPs and party workers around the country. Almost the only way we were like the more professional spin doctors of today was in our enthusiasm. We were spin nurses, perhaps influenced too much by Clement Attlee, who in 1945, in his final appeal to the nation, wrote his own script and read it out from his own handwriting into the BBC microphone. It did not seem such a large step from socialism to sociology, which in Britain was then in its trampolining infancy. For one thing, the words were so similar. We were young and naïve enough to believe that, if we could report, in a convincing way, on the needs and hopes of Labour supporters, even if only in one working-class district, it would help to "bridge the gap" (another of our favourite platitudes) with the leadership - and that the leaders might take note. As Peter put it, less party-politically: "The aim of the institute which we founded was to undertake research, which would both add to basic knowledge about society and illuminate practical questions of social policy, and to publish the findings in a form which would interest the layman as well as the specialist." We were ambitious as well as naïve. Family And Kinship In East London was the first book by Willmott and me. Others followed, including Family And Class In A London Suburb (1960) and The Symmetrical Family (1973); there was also The Family Life Of Old People (1957), by Peter Townsend, and Widows And Their Families (1958), by Peter Marris. The Evolution Of A Community (1963) was the first of Willmott's solo books. It was about Dagenham, the largest housing estate in the world, and probably the most dreary. Mrs Adams, one of Peter's informants, remembered how it was in the 1920s: "I went out for a walk and, when I came back, all the houses looked alike to me. I was in a terrible state, in tears. The workmen said: 'What's the matter ducks?' I said: 'I can't find my house'." Another resident, Mrs Hamilton, described how "there were awful muddy holes in the road, and the women used to pick up bricks from the building site and drop them in the holes to give us stepping stones for our feet on the way back." Peter Willmott had a much better story to tell about the 1960s. Dagenham had, in the course of time, become about as stable and settled as Bethnal Green, with extended families almost as thick on the ground, and residents thinking that, on the same unprepossessing site -and with houses as uniform - it was a "lovely place". His second book on his own was Adolescent Boys Of East London (1966). It was partly about crime, which was (and is) widespread there. An 18-year-old said: "We used to thieve now and again, same as anyone else, but I don't think we was bad - it was just a normal thing we used to do." A 16-year-old was, in Peter's view, exaggerating only slightly when he said: "There's not a boy I know who hasn't knocked something off at some time or another" - they knocked off more than they knocked down. These quotations illustrate one feature of Peter's method. He could talk to anyone, and get them to talk to him. This belonged to the anthropology of the institute in its community studies (the other side was the statistical). We considered the qualitative method essential; indeed, it was the only way to touch on the individual experience. But surveys of random samples were (and are) needed too. The individual's experience has to be put into a context to show how far anyone's experience is, in some way, typical or not. Without random samples, one cannot normally generalise about anything; without picking out individuals, the results of the random sampling can be lifeless. The third feature of our method was to be readable. Since Peter, all members of the "Bethnal Green school" have to avoid the jargon which is the curse of sociology. Peter continued in the same vein when, later on, he joined the Policy Studies Institute, and with his further work on communities and the role of friendship, as well as families within them. All Peter's work reflected his personality. He hated bullshit, perhaps especially when it came from academics. He was humorous, and had a lovely laugh. He was intensely interested in all sorts of people. Flim-flam made him roll his nystagmic eyes and smile at the same time, especially if he thought the person he was with would understand the rolling eyes. He mocked the pretentious. Popular beliefs - for example, that the extended family had disappeared, or that "the family" was on its way to disaster, or that politicians were a bad lot - were dismissed by him. He did not make loose generalisations. He was commonsense incarnate. He liked good food and, even more, good wine. He made nothing of having been a professor at the University of Paris, the University of London or the University of California. He loved Arsenal. He leaves Phyllis, Lewis and Michael. Peter Willmott, sociologist, born September 18 1923; died on April 8 2000

webTitle: Tottenham turns out in style for Bernie Grant's funeral

fields.headline: Tottenham turns out in style for Bernie Grant's funeral
fields.trailText: The Labour MP, Bernie Grant, was buried yesterday in a style befitting him.
fields.body:
The Labour MP, Bernie Grant, was buried yesterday in a style befitting him.

His funeral procession through Tottenham towards a service at Alexandra palace was respectful, affectionate, multicultural and not a little flamboyant, as his wife Sharon was greeted by fellow mourners and well-wishers.

An estimated 3,000 people, including many of the 56-year-old MP's constituents, turned out to salute the black radical. There were dancers and singers, a Highland piper and African drums.

Also present were home secretary Jack Straw, Chris Smith, culture secretary, Clare Short, minister for international development, and Paul Boateng and Keith Vaz, Britain's most senior black ministers.

The procession paused as it passed the Broadwater Farm estate where PC Keith Blacklock was murdered in 1985 and Mr Grant won notoriety for saying that local youth believed the police had deserved "a bloody good hiding". But he went on to become the local MP in 1987 and a statesmanlike force for healing.

Mr Grant was an immigrant from Guyana who turned out to be a monarchist, albeit a leftwing one. Mr Boateng explained at the service that Mr Grant had said "he didn't want anything stuffy or anything churchy. Well, Bernie, this isn't stuffy and this isn't a church - this is a palace".

fields.headline: Professor David Crighton
fields.standfirst:
A brilliant mathematician and aeroacoustic theorist, his dynamism inspired researchers at Leeds and students at his Cambridge college

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Professor David Crighton, head of the department of applied mathematics and theoretical physics (DAMTP) at Cambridge University, and master of Jesus College, who has died of cancer aged 57, was for the last decade the undisputed leader of the applied mathematics community in Britain.
fields.body:
Professor David Crighton, head of the department of applied mathematics and theoretical physics (DAMTP) at Cambridge University, and master of Jesus College, who has died of cancer aged 57, was for the last decade the undisputed leader of the applied mathematics community in Britain.

He was a major figure in the theory of aeroacoustics (aircraft and engine noise and how to control it), linear and nonlinear waves, and structural vibrations; he pioneered research council initiatives for the funding of research in applied nonlinear mathematics; he was instrumental in bringing together all the mathematical organisations in the country so that they could speak with one voice; he initiated a campaign with mathematical educationalists to improve the image of mathematics in schools (the highlight was the "Pop Maths Roadshow"); and he led his department and college with immense energy and vision.

Yet despite these ever-increasing activities and, recently, his developing illness, he invariably had time for all who wanted to see him, and everyone left feeling valued and strengthened.

Crighton was born in Llandudno, where his parents had been moved to escape the bombing of London. His education, at Watford grammar school, took a remarkable change of direction in the lower sixth form when a master observed that "whatever else, he will never be any good at mathematics". Never fearful of a challenge, Crighton abandoned A-levels in classics for double mathematics and physics.

He entered St John's College, Cambridge, in 1961 and went down three years later with firsts in parts I and II of the mathematical tripos. He then made the conscious decision not to stay on for part III, but to join the staff of Woolwich Polytechnic (now the University of Greenwich). There he taught a broad spectrum of mathematics for up to 23 hours a week, and learned the techniques of crowd control - the evening class on subsidiary mathematics for engineering included several leather-clad "mature students" bearing knives).

Then, by chance, Crighton met John Ffowcs Williams, reader in mathematics at Imperial College, London, and an expert in aeroacoustics, and became his research assistant (at less than a quarter of his salary as a senior lecturer at Woolwich). His PhD at Imperial College followed in 1969, and he remained there until 1974, when he became a research associate in the department of engineering at Cambridge.

Crighton visited the engineering department only once, however, as he was immediately appointed, at the instigation of Sir James Lighthill, the founder of aeroacoustics, to be professor of applied mathematics at Leeds University - at the age of 32.

This was in succession to TG Cowling, a great scientist but not good at encouraging younger staff. Crighton immediately made a difference, motivating his colleagues to become active in research, raise funds and take on students (he himself had 15 research students in his time at Leeds). When he had been there only about a year, a new research student asked if they could fix a time for a regular weekly meeting. David looked at his diary and said: "How about Mondays at 7 o'clock?" "Am or pm," the student inquired - to which the reply was: "Whichever you prefer".

By the time David left Leeds in 1986 his department had risen to be one of the top three or four in the country, a position it retains to this day. His spells as head of department, chairman of the school of mathematics and chairman of the science board (effectively dean) left indelible marks of his imagination, energy and effectiveness.

In 1986 Crighton succeeded the late GK Batchelor (Obituary, April 12) as professor of applied mathematics at Cambridge; he took over the headship of DAMTP in 1991. His tenure of this position was characterised by his fierce determination that the department should not only remain by far the strongest mathematical sciences department in Britain and Europe, but that it should rank at least equal with the much more generously funded departments in America.

He persuaded the university to create new chairs and attracted eminent scientists to fill them; by the summer of 1999, for example, the staff included 15 fellows of the Royal Society. But the building was very crowded, and David and his colleagues have raised almost all the funds for a new centre to house the whole faculty of mathematics, in a building to be completed in 2002.

All this activity was on top of his work as chairman of many national and international committees (he succeeded Batchelor as chairman of the European mechanics committee and oversaw its transformation into a society of which he was the first president); of his extensive editorial work (he also succeeded Batchelor as editor-in-chief of the Journal of Fluid Mechanics, and was editor of the Cambridge Texts In Applied Mathematics from 1986; and, since 1997, of his mastership of Jesus College.

Moreover, David had a full scientific career of his own, with one book and well over 100 published papers in major journals. Highlights of his research career include the creative coupling, with FG Leppington, of two sophisticated mathematical methods (the method of matched asymptotic expansions and the Wiener-Hopf technique) to analyse the scattering of sound waves by solid bodies; the study of how the vortices that arise in the flow behind jet engines interact with the solid boundaries to generate noise; the analysis of the modes of vibration of a fluid-loaded ribbed plate (Crighton was a powerful mathematician, but his theories were always deployed to solve real engineering problems); prediction of the noise made by many-bladed propellers (as in the new generation of prop-fan engines); and a more general theory than previously available of the development of shock waves. He received many prizes and honours, including fellowship of the Royal Society in 1993 and three honorary doctorates.

Outside his work and his family, David Crighton had a passion for music, especially opera. He was an authority on Wagner and wrote for an international magazine. He attended the Bayreuth festival annually, and held firmly to the view that there was only one thing better than a good performance of a favourite opera, and that was two good performances - or, in the case of Pfitzner's Palestrina, as performed at Covent Garden in 1997, all six.

A few weeks before his death, Crighton conducted the Jesus College orchestra in a performance of the overture to Tannhauser. Earlier, he sponsored the Russian pianist, Tatiana Nikolaeva, arranging for her to play at a Cambridge concert to celebrate his 50th birthday; once he could be heard giving a live Radio 3 interview about her, in the middle of a weekday afternoon.

What everyone remembers about David was his unique ability to combine tremendous hard work with wonderful warmth and good humour. He took a deep interest in every individual and will be terribly missed. In 1969, he married Mary West, with whom he had two children. The marriage was dissolved in 1985 and, in 1986, he married Johanna Holwith.

David George Crighton, mathematician and academic, born November 15 1942; died April 12 2000

fields.headline: Return of the wanderer
fields.standfirst:
Fanny Burney was one of the great writers of her time, admired by the likes of Sheridan and Byron. Now she's making a comeback. By Kate Chisholm
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fanny Burney was one of the great writers of her time, admired by the likes of Sheridan and Byron. Now she's making a comeback.
fields.body:
When the memorial to Fanny Burney is unveiled in Westminster Abbey in June 2002, to mark the 250th anniversary of her birth, she will join Jane Austen, George Eliot and the Brontë sisters as the only women to be commemorated in Poets' Corner. But who reads Burney now? Pride and Prejudice, Middlemarch and Jane Eyre still sell millions of copies around the world, but who knows of Burney's novels, such as Evelina, Cecilia or The Wanderer? And yet Burney was a sensation in her lifetime.

In 1778, when Burney's first novel, Evelina, was published, everyone wanted to know who had written such a wickedly funny satire on fashionable society. Joshua Reynolds, Edward Gibbon, Edmund Burke and Dr Johnson all praised the novel. And when her last book, The Wanderer, was advertised for publication in 1814, Byron rushed to the printers to read it while it was still in proof.

So why has Burney been forgotten? And why is her reputation at last being resurrected? Because Burney was not only a novelist, but also a diarist, ranking alongside Pepys for her insights into the world in which she lived. And, as we have recently discovered, she was also a secret playwright. Burney's comedy A Busy Day, or An Arrival from India is now being given its first-ever full-scale production by the Bristol Old Vic before transferring to the West End.

Burney wrote A Busy Day in 1800 while living in Surrey with her husband, General d'Arblay, a penniless exile from the French Revolution. She was desperate for money and thought that perhaps she could emulate Sheridan, who had made over £15,000 (worth about £750,000 now), from The School for Scandal. Indeed, when Sheridan was running the Theatre Royal in Drury Lane, he once asked her to write a play for his next season after reading Evelina.

A Busy Day begins when the young heiress, Eliza, arrives back in London from the British trading post of Calcutta to be confronted by her long-lost family. They have come up in the world, having made lots of money in the City, but they are ill at ease in the circles in which they now move. Further misunderstandings and farcical meetings occur when Eliza's family are introduced to the haughty parents of her husband-to-be.

Burney, however, never saw her play performed. Before she had the chance to finish it, d'Arblay returned to Paris to recover his lost fortunes, taking advantage of the peace that had been declared between France and Britain. Burney and their son Alex followed, and were then trapped on the other side of the Channel when war broke out again. They did not settle back in Britain until after the defeat of Napoleon in 1815.

The experience gave Burney brilliant material for her diaries, and her account of being in Brussels as the troops marched off to Waterloo was used by Thackeray when he came to write Vanity Fair. But it did nothing to advance her ambition to work in the theatre.

D'Arblay died not long after their return to Britain, and although Burney went back to live in London, where she had grown up, she never attempted to have her plays staged. She once wrote that writing plays was what "I have all my life been urged to, & all my life intended - I thought the field more than open". But this was the beginning of the 19th century and the theatre was an unsuitable occupation for ladies of a certain class.

The re-emergence of A Busy Day began in the 50s, when the great Burney scholar Joyce Hemlow discovered the manuscript in the New York Public Library. Hemlow realised that not only had Burney completed her play, she had also prepared it for production, even noting her ideal cast.

Hemlow recognised immediately its quality as an 18th-century comedy to rival anything written by Sheridan, and encouraged its publication. But it was not until 1993 that A Busy Day was given its first public performance, at the Hen and Chicken pub theatre in Bristol. It was a sell-out, and yet, as Alan Coveney, the director of that production recalls, he did little to update the text other than cut it. Reviewers were surprised at the sharpness of Burney's wit, and the success of its satirical take on society, which some compared to Oscar Wilde. As Coveney explains, "Because she does not rely on gags for comic effect, but on the interplay between the characters, her comedy is as relevant today as it was when she wrote it."

This is the same talent that makes Burney's novels and diaries such an entertaining read. As Jonathan Church, the director of the new production, says, "The characters are so well drawn that everyone recognises immediately who they are meant to be." And it is this that still makes us laugh out loud.

 A Busy Day is at the Bristol Old Vic (0117-987 7877) till May 6, then transfers to the West End. Kate Chisholm's biography Fanny Burney: Her Life, 1752-1840 is published by Vintage, price £7.99.

fields.body:
Two men who set up a hi-tech company in their garden shed could be worth up to £40m each when their internet firm floats on the stock market.

Kevin Grumball, 43, and his former lodger, Chris Barling, 44, started Actinic four years ago with £80,000 in a hut used to rear poultry on land at their home near Stratford-upon-Avon, in Warwickshire.

Their company is to be listed on the stock market with a value of more than £250m.

Mr Grumball and Mr Barling each have a 25% stake, but new share issues will push their stake down to 17%, leaving them a share value of about £40m each.

Actinic employs 40 people and provides website services, selling CDs that allow small businesses to set up their own e-commerce websites and credit check customers.

Its 5,000 customers range from one-man businesses to bigger organisations, including the London Symphony Orchestra, Hasbro, the Royal Opera House and Fulham Football Club.

Last year the company began operations in the US.

webTitle: Now that's what I call white noise

fields.headline: Now that's what I call white noise
fields.standfirst: Manhattan Research Inc
fields.trailText: Raymond Scott is a rare case of a musician who was rediscovered twice. The first Scott to re-emerge was the jazz bandleader of the 30s and 40s. The other Raymond Scott is a very different figure.
fields.body:
Raymond Scott is a rare case of a musician who was rediscovered twice. The first Scott to re-emerge was the jazz bandleader of the 30s and 40s, composer of such numbers - absolutely living up to their titles - as Reckless Night on Board an Ocean Liner, Dinner Music for a Pack of Hungry Cannibals, and Boy Scout in Switzerland. This Scott, whose themes were recycled in many a vintage Warner Bros cartoon, has been much celebrated over the past few years, his compositions recorded by the Kronos Quartet, sampled by Soul Coughing, lionised by John Zorn, and programmed in the Meltdown festival by Elvis Costello.

The other Raymond Scott is a very different figure. From the 40s on, Scott devoted himself increasingly to developing electronic instruments, and the eccentricity of his jazz compositions took a sharp left into another time zone, acquiring the textures of extreme futurism. This Scott was first unearthed in 1997, when the Basta label reissued his three albums of music for infants, Soothing Sounds for Baby - "soothing" being something of a misnomer for their eerie keening and metronome rhythms.

The baby music brought Scott belated acclaim as a godfather of minimalist repetition and ambient soundscaping, but the definitive proof of his innovative imagination is now available on Basta's elegantly packaged two-CD set Manhattan Research Inc, named after the company Scott founded in 1946. Manhattan Research was at once a workshop for creating new instruments, a think-tank for speculating on new musical languages and - at bottom dollar - a factory for ad music and jingles, written for clients that included Nescafé, General Motors and Vim.

The CDs feature many of the instruments devised by Scott: the rhythm-generating Bandito, the Clavivox, the Circle Machine and the Electronium, a "composing machine". Unearthly, grating and, indeed, archaic as some of the sounds are, Scott is far more than a whimsical exotic to file away condescendingly under Incredibly Strange Music. His explorations occupied a particular space at the juncture of commerce, science and utopian ideology, where avant-garde thought about sound met mainstream functionalism. The very name of his company combines the image of Manhattan (urban speediness and Madison Avenue, hub of the US ad industry) with that of research (lab coats, circuit diagrams, the dream of manufacturing a better tomorrow). The music embodies a conviction that if only the right sounds could be developed, then the world would be a better place. Not only would babies sleep more soundly, but Auto-Lite spark plugs could be marketed more effectively, oiling the wheels of industry, boosting the economy, and moving us all towards a point where, as Scott's clients Bendix ("The Tomorrow People!") confidently forecast, we would soon be visiting hotels on the sea bed or sightseeing on the moon.

The urge was, as the Bendix ad put it, "To research! To discover! To develop!" There was also a desire to educate, as seen in Scott's collaborations with Muppets creator Jim Henson; in Henson's short film Limbo: The Organised Mind, a stoned-sounding beatnik dude offers a tour, both pedagogic and psychedelic, of his own brain, accompanied by Scott's rhythmic creaks and gurgles.

Some of Scott's sound montages are as evocative and densely structured as short films in their own right. One track collaging disparate snatches of sales sloganeering was designed to illustrate the flexibility of Scott's music for commercial purposes. Instead it subverts the ideolog ical confidence of early-60s American advertising in a way that Mad magazine, or a contemporary Soviet satirist, would have envied: "Don't beat your wife every night - chew Wrigley's, that's a Griffin shine!"

The Manhattan Research collection obviously carries a powerful nostalgic charge. It makes you yearn, on one hand, for a suburban sci-fi world in which every spaceman - and even "space girls" (sic) - knew that "You've just gotta have Hostess Twinkies along!"; and, on the other, for a DIY age in which electronica couldn't just be bought as ready-wrapped software, but was something to which you had to devote time, space and thousands of feet of wiring. Some of this gee-whiz, frontier-spirit futurism is now being rediscovered by artists such as Mouse on Mars, Add N to (X) and Appliance, electronica acts either devising new gizmos or excavating the future dreams dormant in obsolete technology.

Listening to Scott's music now, you could almost believe he invented just about everything electronic that followed. There are fleeting premonitions here of drum'n'bass, of dub reggae, of Stereolab, Devo, Pere Ubu; there's even the keyboard riff of Stevie Wonder's Higher Ground 12 years before its day (in the 70s, Scott was hired to research for Motown with, supposedly, no discernable results). Scott's is a music out of time: in many ways, as wildly wrong in its predictions about sound as the Bendix Corporation was wrong about future lifestyles. Yet his music contains enough pre-echoes to suggest that, rather than having an influence as such, Scott simply travelled through certain points on the circuit board that other musicians would arrive at later. The real 2000 is nothing like the rocket-science utopia that Scott imagined, but his music has somehow become very much the sound of now.

fields.headline: The villain's repertory
fields.standfirst: We're used to seeing bad musicals in the West End. But, says  Michael Billington, we should get much more from Trevor Nunn and the National Theatre
fields.trailText: We're used to seeing bad musicals in the West End. But, says Michael Billington, we should get much more from Trevor Nunn and the National Theatre.
fields.body:
Watching The Villains' Opera last week at the Olivier, a number of questions popped into my head. Who sanctioned it? What did it cost? And would such a soft-brained piece of twaddle ever have passed through the sieving process if it hadn't come in the guise of a would-be popular musical, the holy Grail that these days we are all meant to worship?

Since we are now midway through Trevor Nunn's tenureship on the South Bank, it seems a good time not only to ask such questions but to look at the state of the National Theatre. If I am hyper-critical, it is because one has a right to expect more of this theatre than any other. It receives a larger subsidy - rising by six per cent in the coming year to nearly £13m - than any rival theatre. With that privilege come responsibilities. Rather than being a follower of fashion, the National should act as a beacon and standard-bearer to the rest of the British theatre. Is it currently discharging that duty?

In one sense, yes. In 1999 the National created a permanent ensemble, which led to a golden string of successes all directed either by Nunn himself or John Caird: Troilus and Cressida, The Merchant of Venice, Candide, Money and Summerfolk. For this, Nunn, the company, and individual performers such as Henry Goodman were showered with awards at the Olivier, Evening Standard and Critics' Circle ceremonies. So that's OK then? God is in his Heaven and all's right with the world. Well no, actually, not quite.

My first question concerns the NT repertory and its increasing reliance on musicals as an easy way to fill its nightly quota of 2,500 seats. By March 2001 the NT will have brought us no fewer than five musicals in less than two years: Candide (excellent), Honk! The Ugly Duckling (mediocre), The Villains' Opera (dire), with Singin' in the Rain to come this summer and My Fair Lady, in association with Cameron Mackintosh, next spring. Am I alone in finding this devotion to tune-and-toe shows somewhat excessive?

It is all a question of degree. The National's involvement with musicals goes back to the late 60s when Olivier and Tynan planned to revive Guys and Dolls, a classic of the American stage unseen in the West End for a generation. No one could deny that its ultimate realisation, in Richard Eyre's production, was a triumph. But there is all the difference in the world between occasional classic revivals and saturation bombardment. The NT's intensification of its musical programme also comes at a time when the West End itself is about to launch an unprecedented number: this year we look forward, with barely containable excitement, to The King and I, Notre Dame de Paris, Hard Times, La Cava, The Witches of Eastwick, The Beautiful Game and Napoleon, with shows about Dusty Springfield, Mario Lanza and Tammy Wynette rumoured to be on their way. What one craves from the National is some alternative to a musical-dominated commercial culture, rather than a duplication of it.

In the field of straight plays, one looks to the National to explore the international repertory in the way it is uniquely equipped to do. In the coming year, however, one finds it sticking to the well-trodden paths of the English-Irish-American repertory. With the exception of Pinter's version of Proust, which bodes well, the only work from the non-English speaking world is Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard. The conservative nature of Nunn's taste is summed up by a revival, in a joint venture with Sheffield Theatres, of The Heiress, based on Henry James's Washington Square. Even in 1949, critic TC Worsley classed this rep standby as "modern melodrama in mid-Victorian dress".

When it comes to new plays, the National has happily just struck lucky with Joe Penhall's admirable Blue/Orange. Not, one might say, before time. To date, the defining characteristic of Nunn's National has been to take previously admired living writers and then stage their worst-ever play. If you think I'm exaggerating, then you have only to call to mind Frank McGuinness's Mutabilitie, Hanif Kureishi's Sleep With Me, Stephen Poliakoff's Remember This and Nick Stafford's Battle Royal. The irony is that under Peter Hall and Richard Eyre new writing was the National's strongest card; under Trevor Nunn it has become its Achilles' heel. One just hopes that, with Penhall's success, a corner has been decisively turned.

But if the National, under Trevor Nunn, has enjoyed mixed fortunes, I suspect the answer may lie in the management structure. At the RSC, in the heady years from 1968 to 1986, Nunn enjoyed great success, not least because he surrounded himself with a brilliant team of associates and co-directors: Terry Hands, John Barton, David Jones, Howard Davies, Ron Daniels, Barry Kyle, to name but a few. But at the National, while one applauds Nunn's own Stakhanovite labours, there is no comparable sense of a ministry of all the talents; indeed, John Caird seems his sole permanent associate. What is striking is how many of the best directors of the next generation have either declined to work at the National or conceivably not been asked: no sign, for instance, of Declan Donnellan, Deborah Warner, Stephen Daldry, Sam Mendes, Tim Albery, Richard Jones, Mick Gordon or James Macdonald. Trevor Nunn is a very good director, but one of his duties is to nurture a potential successor, and I see no indication of that. Indeed, the current rumour is that Nunn, having sworn that he would take the job for five years, is now contemplating a second term.

If I seem critical, it is because I believe the National needs to be run with passion, flair and imagination. It is not enough to say that one has balanced the books or filled the requisite number of seats. The National should be at the centre of the debate about what kind of society we are: something it indubitably was when Richard Eyre staged the David Hare trilogy. It should also be dangerous and controversial: something it again was in the Peter Hall years, which gave us Pravda and The Romans in Britain. Once upon a time you might even have expected to find an event like the highly topical Snogging Ken at the National; now it goes, inevitably, to north London's compact Almeida. I wouldn't deny for a moment that Trevor Nunn has done some outstanding individual productions or that he has proved a safe pair of hands. But is that enough for a National Theatre that should be offering us blood, risk and adventure, and an inspirational lead to a theatre already sufficiently mired in caution?

webTitle: Police killing sparks violence in Lille

fields.headline: Police killing sparks violence in Lille
fields.trailText: Tension in the northern French town of Lille mounted yesterday as 61 people were jailed, including 24 minors, after a second night of violence sparked by the police killing a suspected car thief.
fields.body:
Tension in the northern French town of Lille mounted yesterday as 61 people were jailed, including 24 minors, after a second night of violence sparked by the police killing a suspected car thief.

Squads of riot police used teargas to dispel crowds of angry youths who rampaged through the city's depressed southern suburbs after midnight, hurling stones and molotov cocktails and setting fire to cars, public buildings and two metro stations.

The rioting followed a fraught but peaceful march through the city centre on Monday afternoon in honour of Ryad Hamlaoui, 23, a local man of Algerian origin who died late on Sunday night after being hit by a single bullet in the back of the neck.

Stephane Andolina, the officer who pulled the trigger, has been suspended from duty, jailed, and placed under formal investigation for manslaughter - the first time, according to police unions, that a French police officer has been jailed on suspicion of voluntary homicide.

"Of course such incidents are deeply regrettable," said Gerard Boyer of the Alliance-Police union. "But usually they are followed by a prosecution for 'violence without the intention to kill', not manslaughter. Jailing the officer was not necessary. It leaves a bitter taste - it's like the authorities wanted to act forcefully to appease the public."

But the public prosecutor, Claude Mathon, said: "The circumstances, and our inquiries, give reason to believe that the act can be qualified as voluntary." He added that the officer "fully realises the scale of what he has done".

"Two lives have been shattered. It is cataclysmic".

But the arrest of Mr Andolina, 27, as well as pleas for restraint from the victim's father and local Muslim leaders, have done little to calm tempers in the Lille suburbs, where unemployment among a largely immigrant population is up to five times the national average and clashes with police are frequent.

"This isn't a tragic accident, it's a racist attack," an elderly resident told French radio. "Ryad had no police record whatsoever and if he hadn't been an Algerian he would still be alive."

The killing was the fifth case of suspected manslaughter by the French police in the past three years. Nine officers are currently being investigated on suspicion of crimes ranging from armed violence to involuntary homicide. Police unions have denounced the harsh treatment meted out to Mr Andolina.

He and another officer had been called to deal with two suspected car thieves. Mr Andolina said a sudden gesture from Hamlaoui made him fear for his life, so he fired.

Martine Aubry, the employment minister and assistant mayor of Lille, said she was horrified by the killing.

"This has destroyed months of work on improving community policing in Lille," she said. "But we must look beyond the present situation, hope things calm down, and continue with our work."

webTitle: Czech Gypsies begin test case for pupils classed as retarded

fields.headline: Czech Gypsies begin test case for pupils classed as retarded
fields.trailText: The parents of 18 Gypsy children in the Czech Republic lodged an application with the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) in Strasbourg yesterday accusing the Czech state of practising racial discrimination and segregation in the education system.
fields.body:
The parents of 18 Gypsy children in the Czech Republic lodged an application with the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) in Strasbourg yesterday accusing the Czech state of practising racial discrimination and segregation in the education system.

In what could prove to be a landmark case for Europe's most deprived and fastest growing ethnic group, the parents of the nine- to 15-year-olds claim that their offspring face a lifetime of under-achievement because they were placed in schools for those with learning difficulties.

The European Roma Rights Centre in Budapest, which is representing the children - from the north-eastern city of Ostrava - said that the education ministry and local authorities had for decades "perpetuated a system which routinely brands disproportionate numbers of Gypsies as mentally retarded".

Human rights organisations have long argued that the education system is linguistically and culturally biased against Gypsies and that standard procedures give free rein to "conscious and unconscious racial prejudice".

A case was lodged with the Czech constitutional court last June, but was rejected in October when the judges ruled that they did not have the authority to make a decision based on statistical evidence.

In the district of Ostrava Gypsy children out number non-Gypsies in special schools by a proportion of more than 27 to one. Although they represent less than 5% of all primary school age students in the city, they constitute 50% of the special school population.

The Czech government has conceded that nationwide 75% of Romany children attend special schools, making up over half of the special schools' population.

The parents are demanding compensatory education for their children, as well as financial recompense and an official apology from the government, acknowledging that Gypsies are systematically under-educated in the Czech Republic because of their ethnic origin.

"I hope that if we win the case my daughter can go back into the mainstream system, but even if that happens she won't have won the battle against racism," Berta Cervenakova said. Her 11-year-old daughter Nikol was transferred to a special school three years ago despite achieving average marks at primary school.

James Goldston, the American lawyer representing the children, said if the case was successful it could contribute to educational reform throughout the region.

"I don't think we've ever seen this lawsuit as the one and only solution, but this is a contribution to a debate in a field where change needs to happen urgently," he said.

He added that the case would open the floodgates for similar lawsuits from Gypsies in the Czech Republic and other eastern European countries who were "similarly plagued" by the problems of their children being sent to schools for the mentally handicapped.

He said that the first case anywhere in post-communist eastern Europe to challenge systematic racism in education marked the "beginning of a long journey".

"In the United States it took more than 30 years and dozens and dozens of cases before the supreme court struck down racial segregation in schools, and we're turning to the ECHR to begin the same process here," he said.

The case could also add legal clout to the asylum applications of Gypsies going to Britain claiming racial discrimination, he added.

Gypsy children often start school with little or no knowledge of Czech or speaking an "ethnolect" - a mix of Czech, Slovak and Romany. That, plus the fact that their culture stresses oral rather than written skills gets them off to a bad start.

A psychological test taken on starting school establishes a pupil's IQ, and determines his or her suitability for mainstream schools. But the test fails to take into account cultural and linguistic barriers. Three-quarters of Romanies fail it and are widely expected to do so by teachers and education officials.

In one famous example a Romany boy was evaluated as mentally handicapped because he could not name "cutlery" as the common noun for "knife", "fork" and "spoon", although the word does not exist in Romany.

"Romany children simply do not have a high enough IQ to manage normal schooling," said Marta Tepla of the department of special schools in the Ministry of Education.

"If you studied anything about them, you would know that they stick together, they get married in those large families, and they have children with genetic problems.

"You can see this just by looking at their names," she added.

webTitle: Ministers relent on watchdog for long-term care

fields.headline: Ministers relent on watchdog for long-term care
fields.trailText: The government last night unveiled plans to regulate the rapidly growing insurance market for elderly people who need long-term care.
fields.body:
The government last night unveiled plans to regulate the rapidly growing insurance market for elderly people who need long-term care.

In a significant concession to pensioners' campaigners, the Treasury announced that it would accept the recommendation of the recent Royal Commission on the care of elderly people which called for the Financial Services Authority to oversee long-term care insurance.

The move was welcomed last night by the Labour peer Lord Lipsey who had led a backbench rebellion in the Lords against the government's refusal to accept the commission's proposal.

Lord Lipsey, a member of the commission, said: "This is only common sense. Thousands of pensioners will be enormously reassured by this."

The concession was announced by Lord McIntosh, the Treasury spokesman in the Lords.

He said that ministers would introduce measures to monitor the long-term care insurance market once the financial services and markets bill has passed through the Lords.The concession represents a significant victory for campaigners who had warned that the government's failure to act could lead to a scandal on the same level as pensions and mortage missellings of the 1980s and 1990s.

At the time of the royal commission report only 23,000 long-term care policies had been taken out. Since then this has increased to 30,000.

The industry will grow vastly if, as expected, the government recommends that wealthier people must pay privately for their long-term care.

Supporters of regulation say the elderly are at their most vulnerable when they need to enter private long-term care institutions, making them prey to poor insurance products.

The royal commission proposal was supported by the Personal Investment Authority and a group of loyal Labour peers, including the former director general of the office of fair trading, Lord Borrie.

The Treasury economic secretary, Melanie Johnson, told the rebel Labour peers last month that she was sympathetic to the case for regulation.

webTitle: Berlin to ask net hosts to censor anti-semite sites

fields.headline: Berlin to ask net hosts to censor anti-semite sites
fields.trailText: The German government is planning to ask the country's internet service providers to shut out extreme rightwing groups to stem their growing influence.
fields.body:
The German government is planning to ask the country's internet service providers to shut out extreme rightwing groups to stem their growing influence.

An intelligence service report made public earlier this month emphasised that neo-Nazi groups were increasingly using the net to propagate their views and dodge surveillance. Recently released figures suggest that German sites make up almost a quarter of the global total of sites run by far-right organisations.

The dangers they pose were highlighted by events surrounding a demonstration last weekend in the city of Göttingen. More than 1,500 people turned out for a march in protest at the activities of the far-right National-Democratic party of Germany (NPD, which had for weeks been using the net to call sympathisers to a counter-demonstration.

At the station, 37 people arriving for the counter-demonstration were arrested in connection with an assault on a 25-year-old immigrant on the train.

The following day Herta Däubler-Gmelin, the justice minister, told the Frankfurter Allgemeine newspaper that she was planning a meeting with internet service providers in July. She said her ministry was working on a blacklist of sites, which she planned to hand to the companies and ask them to block access.

Her initiative prompted a call for even more stringent measures. Wolfgang Zeitlmann, an MP representing the conservative Bavarian party, the Christian Social Union, criticised the minister for not calling a meeting earlier. "Children and young people ought to be protected from dangerous criminals and their violent influence," he said.

The freedom of speech issues which have inhibited action in other countries are not such an obstacle in Germany, where the dissemination of Nazi propaganda is a clearly defined offence. But the spokesman for Germany's in ternet service providers cast doubt yesterday on whether the minister's plans could be implemented

Professor Michael Rotert, the chairman of their representative body, said that filtering software would only bar access to a site's underlying address, its IP or internet protocol. "They can switch the IP every second, or half-second, or even faster," he said.

Steps could be taken to block off the site's URL, the address - typically beginning http://www. - which appears on an internet browser. "But if you change just one letter in the URL it has no effect," Prof Rotert added.

"You can stop access for a certain period for people who are just jumping in for a look, but you can't stop it altogether so long as you don't put people in prison and close down the server altogether."

Even that presents difficulties, though. The BVD, the equivalent of Britain's MI5, said in its recent report that, to minimise the risk of prosecution, the German far right had been placing their images and texts with servers located abroad, mainly in North America. It said membership of extremist rightwing groups in Germany had swollen by 11%in 1999 to 53,600. The number of far-right home pages it was monitoring had risen to 320.

Last week in Berlin, Rabbi Abraham Cooper of the Simon Wiesenthal Centre in Los Angeles put the worldwide total of "problem sites" propagating racism, xenophobia and anti-semitism at 1,426.
