webTitle: Italy's PM to resign in effort to rescue coalition

fields.headline: Italy's PM to resign in effort to rescue coalition
fields.trailText: The Italian prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, is expected to resign today to give his centre-left government a chance to rally around a new leader and avert an election which would almost certainly be won by Silvio Berlusconi's alliance of opposition parties.
fields.body:
The Italian prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, is expected to resign today to give his centre-left government a chance to rally around a new leader and avert an election which would almost certainly be won by Silvio Berlusconi's alliance of opposition parties.

Mr D'Alema will announce his resignation in parliament this morning and stave off a confidence vote, sources predicted. He offered to resign on Monday after losing heavily to Mr Berlusconi in the regional elections but President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi refused the offer and told him to seek a confidence vote.

Coalition partners fed up with Italy's first ex-communist prime minister threatened to defect, so Mr D'Alema is expected to quit irrevocably today.

Only speed and decisiveness in selecting a successor will avert the general election which Mr Berlusconi's centre-right alliance is demanding, a year early.

Mr Berlusconi, a media tycoon and former prime minister, sniffs blood after sweeping the north and key regions in the south with anti-immigration policies.

An early election would catch him on a roll and possibly stymie a May 21 referendum to abolish the vestiges of proportional representation, an electoral reform which Mr Berlusconi opposes.

The government hopes that by dumping Mr D'Alema it can find a leader to unite its eclectic grouping of greens, social democrats, ex-communists and centrists.

Observers were sceptical that the ruling parties, which have spent much of their 18 months in power gouging lumps from each other, could agree on a candidate.

The favourite was the treasury minister Giuliano Amato, a former socialist prime minister, who is respected for reining in a budget deficit.

Other possibilities are Lamberto Dini, the foreign minister and a moderate, Nicola Mancino, the senate president and a former Christian Democrat, and Antonio Fazio, the governor of the bank of Italy.

webTitle: Children seriously ill after swallowing drugs at home

fields.headline: Children seriously ill after swallowing drugs at home
fields.trailText: A year-old boy and his three-year-old sister were seriously ill in hospital last night after apparently swallowing drugs. An ambulance was called to their home in Blackburn on Monday night.
fields.body:
A year-old boy and his three-year-old sister were seriously ill in hospital last night after apparently swallowing drugs. An ambulance was called to their home in Blackburn on Monday night.

Paramedics found the boy suffering from breathing difficulties. He was resuscitated and taken to hospital.

An hour later a second ambulance was called for his sister who was also seriously ill. It is feared that the children may have swallowed some form of drug although tests are being carried out to establish what they took.

They were taken to Blackburn Royal infirmary and later transferred to Manchester children's hospital in Pendlebury, where they were said to be very poorly last night.

Police sources say the older child may not survive. The children's 24-year-old mother, who is pregnant and has not been named, was arrested on charges of neglect. Detectives are searching for their father.

Last night a policeman stood guard outside the family's home as detectives carried out house to house inquiries. Neighbours Nurbana Jaffer and her husband, Ibrahim, said they heard shouting from the house at 1am - 90 minutes before the first call to the emergency services.

"We both heard a lot of noise coming from the house," said Mrs Jaffer. "They are a nice family and we are friendly with them. This is terrible."

Her husband said: "I woke up and heard a lot of noise. I just hope they are okay."

Another neighbour, Abdul Karim, said: "They are a nice family and the children always seemed happy. I wouldn't think anything suspicious is involved."

Earlier this month, a year-old baby was taken to hospital in Edinburgh after accidentally swallowing an ecstasy tablet which he found in his mother's handbag. In January, the mother of a three-year-old boy who swallowed a bag of heroin in Glasgow was charged with neglect and drugs offences.

fields.headline: The best bovine scene
fields.standfirst: Lake Placid
fields.trailText: Lake Placid
fields.body:
Maine. Investigating a spate of mysterious disappearances on Lake Placid, local sherrif Hank Keough (Brendan Gleeson), Fish and Game Warden Jack Wells (Bill Pullman) and museum curator Kelly Scott (Bridget Fonda) stand on the edge of the water. Peering through binoculars at an isolated farm further up the bank, Wells's jaw suddenly hangs open.

"You've got to be kidding."

He passes them to Scott. Looking through them, she observes as farm-owner Delores Bickerman (Betty White) first blindfolds, then begins singing softly to a cow.

"What is she doing?"

Delores leads the cow to the edge of the water. Shifting her gaze to the lake, Scott notices that a vast crocodile is poised silently nearby, its mouth agape. She gulps.

"Oh."

"What?"

"Look. Ten feet into the water."

Keough seizes the binoculars. Delores lets the cow, still blindfolded, drink from the water. Taking a step backwards, she stares directly at the lake's most exotic creature.

"Come and get it!"

She slaps the cow's rump.

In one swift movement, the crocodile lurches forward, seizing the cow and dragging it into the lake. We cut to Scott - her face splashed with water as a tremendous moo erupts off-camera. She shudders. Keough shakes his head.

"Disgusting."

See also: Babe, The Killing Of Sister George, Heathers

Don't see also: Tumbling Tumbleweeds

Pointless trivia: Despite her on-screen activities here, Betty White is a spokesperson for PETA (People for the Ethical Treatment Of Animals).

More pointless trivia: Bill Pullman co-owns a cattle ranch in Montana.

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText: Boating lake gets a facelift
fields.body:
Boating lake gets a facelift

The return of pedalo and park rowing skiff to British culture was celebrated yesterday with the launch of a new series of lottery-funded boating lakes.

The first £4.2m project was launched in Bradford by a boatload of civic dignitaries, who circled three acres of fish-stocked and island-dotted water close to the city centre.

The Manningham Park lake has been restored, after 30 years of neglect, just in time to rescue from oblivion the boatkeeper's traditional cry: "Come in number 11, your time is up."

Local people voted overwhelmingly for a fresh start on the lake and disused boating pavilion as the top priority in restoration of the park.

The new lake will be followed this autumn by Britain's first Mughal water garden, a tribute to the large south Asian community in Manningham and modelled on formal hedges, flowerbeds and canals developed by India's ruling dynasty between 1527 and 1857.

Local people have advised on plantings, which will follow patterns laid out in Delhi, Agra and other Indian cities.

The park's original botanic garden and assorted statues of Victorian worthies will also be re stored in the final phase of the renewal in 2001. The 53 acres were sold to the city in 1870 for £40,000 by the velvet manufacturers, Listers of Manningham, on the condition that they would always form a public park. Martin Wainwright

Child killer faced rape charge

A father who murdered his two young sons before killing himself was due to stand trial for rape, it was revealed yesterday.

Frank Fairless, 36, was due to appear at Gainsborough magistrates court in Lincolnshire next month ac cused of a rape in December of last year.

Fairless was also due to stand trial on separate charges of assaulting his wife, Claire, 31, and her father, James Forrington, last Christmas.

Fairless killed his sons Christopher, nine, and Oliver, six, in their beds before hanging himself in the garage. Their bodies were discovered in the house in Scotter, Lincolnshire, on Sunday.

A postmortem examination on Monday confirmed the two boys had died from asphyxiation.

Fairless separated from his wife six months ago and the couple recently divorced.

The children were on their first overnight stay with their father after custody had been worked out when they were murdered in their beds.

They were found under the covers in separate bedrooms and Fairless was found hanging in the garage. A number of handwritten notes were found at the scene.

Court fight over album royalties

A widow and a girlfriend of two tragic pop figures are battling in the high court for a share of the royalties of an album they claim was compiled from live tapes taken without their knowledge.

Peter Ham and Tommy Evans were in the 70s group Badfinger and wrote the hit song Without You. Both hanged themselves, having received not a penny in royalties for the song.

Anne Ferguson, Ham's girlfriend, and Marianne Evans have joined with Badfinger drummer Michael Gibbins and manager Bill Collins against the group's guitarist and vocalist Joey Molland.

Molland left the band in 1974 with tapes of a live recording they made at the Agora Club, Cleveland, Ohio. After re-mastering the tapes in America 14 years later, he did a record deal which effectively cut out the other four from any royalties, deputy judge Lord Goldsmith was told.

Molland claims he made no secret of having the tapes, and that the other four should pay towards his expenses in re-mastering the tapes.

The ruling was reserved.

Footballer detained for assault

A Premiership footballer who headbutted a young woman was sentenced yesterday to eight months' detention in a young offenders' institution.

Derby County striker Marvin Robinson, 20, broke Mary Morris's nose outside the Canal Club in Wolverhampton, West Midlands, last September, the town's crown court was told. Judge Christopher Hodson, who was told that the player's club would stand by him, said the assault could only be marked by a custodial sentence.

Michael Anning, prosecuting, said Robinson, who pleaded guilty at an earlier hearing to assault occasioning actual bodily harm, attacked Miss Morris, 18, after she told his former girlfriend that he was seeing another girl.

Robinson had been ejected from the club after a confrontation with the two women and waited two hours for his victim to leave, the court heard. Mr Anning said: "The defendant emerged from an alleyway and said 'I am going to finish the job'. With that he went up to her and headbutted her."

Scrapyard search for body

Police have called in archaeologists in the search for the remains of a mother who they believe was murdered and bundled into a car which was then fed into a scrap shredder.

Forensic teams and staff from Manchester University's field archaeology unit are sieving dust and slurry from the shredder in Stoke-on-Trent in the search for Zoe Simpson, who disappeared in October 1996 from her home in Longsight, Manchester.

She would have had a substantial legacy from her father on her 25th birthday two months later.

Detectives from Greater Manchester police said yesterday they had extended inquiries to Ms Simpson's home town, Macclesfield, Cheshire.

Detective Superintendent Andy Tattersall said: "There may be people out there who assisted in the removal of her body and the subsequent destruction of her body.

"The net is closing in on them. The time to come forward is now, before we question them."

Ms Simpson was reported missing by her partner's mother, who cares for her children, Nicole, now 10, and Joseph, four. New information led police to search the scrapyard.
David Ward

Vitamin link to bowel disease

A link has been found between vitamin D deficiency and inflammatory bowel disease, it was disclosed yesterday.

Mice genetically engineered to have two human bowel disorders, Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, suffered worse symptoms when deprived of vitamin D. But given supplements of the vitamin for two weeks their condition improved.

The study, led by Margherita Cantorna at Pennsylvania State University in Philadelphia, is the first to demonstrate the connection.

Inflammatory bowel disorders are autoimmune diseases in which the body attacks itself.

Previous research has already shown a link between vitamin D and two other autoimmune diseases, arthritis and multiple sclerosis.

fields.bodyText: Boating lake gets a facelift The return of pedalo and park rowing skiff to British culture was celebrated yesterday with the launch of a new series of lottery-funded boating lakes. The first £4.2m project was launched in Bradford by a boatload of civic dignitaries, who circled three acres of fish-stocked and island-dotted water close to the city centre. The Manningham Park lake has been restored, after 30 years of neglect, just in time to rescue from oblivion the boatkeeper's traditional cry: "Come in number 11, your time is up." Local people voted overwhelmingly for a fresh start on the lake and disused boating pavilion as the top priority in restoration of the park. The new lake will be followed this autumn by Britain's first Mughal water garden, a tribute to the large south Asian community in Manningham and modelled on formal hedges, flowerbeds and canals developed by India's ruling dynasty between 1527 and 1857. Local people have advised on plantings, which will follow patterns laid out in Delhi, Agra and other Indian cities. The park's original botanic garden and assorted statues of Victorian worthies will also be re stored in the final phase of the renewal in 2001. The 53 acres were sold to the city in 1870 for £40,000 by the velvet manufacturers, Listers of Manningham, on the condition that they would always form a public park. Martin Wainwright Child killer faced rape charge A father who murdered his two young sons before killing himself was due to stand trial for rape, it was revealed yesterday. Frank Fairless, 36, was due to appear at Gainsborough magistrates court in Lincolnshire next month ac cused of a rape in December of last year. Fairless was also due to stand trial on separate charges of assaulting his wife, Claire, 31, and her father, James Forrington, last Christmas. Fairless killed his sons Christopher, nine, and Oliver, six, in their beds before hanging himself in the garage. Their bodies were discovered in the house in Scotter, Lincolnshire, on Sunday. A postmortem examination on Monday confirmed the two boys had died from asphyxiation. Fairless separated from his wife six months ago and the couple recently divorced. The children were on their first overnight stay with their father after custody had been worked out when they were murdered in their beds. They were found under the covers in separate bedrooms and Fairless was found hanging in the garage. A number of handwritten notes were found at the scene. Court fight over album royalties A widow and a girlfriend of two tragic pop figures are battling in the high court for a share of the royalties of an album they claim was compiled from live tapes taken without their knowledge. Peter Ham and Tommy Evans were in the 70s group Badfinger and wrote the hit song Without You. Both hanged themselves, having received not a penny in royalties for the song. Anne Ferguson, Ham's girlfriend, and Marianne Evans have joined with Badfinger drummer Michael Gibbins and manager Bill Collins against the group's guitarist and vocalist Joey Molland. Molland left the band in 1974 with tapes of a live recording they made at the Agora Club, Cleveland, Ohio. After re-mastering the tapes in America 14 years later, he did a record deal which effectively cut out the other four from any royalties, deputy judge Lord Goldsmith was told. Molland claims he made no secret of having the tapes, and that the other four should pay towards his expenses in re-mastering the tapes. The ruling was reserved. Footballer detained for assault A Premiership footballer who headbutted a young woman was sentenced yesterday to eight months' detention in a young offenders' institution. Derby County striker Marvin Robinson, 20, broke Mary Morris's nose outside the Canal Club in Wolverhampton, West Midlands, last September, the town's crown court was told. Judge Christopher Hodson, who was told that the player's club would stand by him, said the assault could only be marked by a custodial sentence. Michael Anning, prosecuting, said Robinson, who pleaded guilty at an earlier hearing to assault occasioning actual bodily harm, attacked Miss Morris, 18, after she told his former girlfriend that he was seeing another girl. Robinson had been ejected from the club after a confrontation with the two women and waited two hours for his victim to leave, the court heard. Mr Anning said: "The defendant emerged from an alleyway and said 'I am going to finish the job'. With that he went up to her and headbutted her." Scrapyard search for body Police have called in archaeologists in the search for the remains of a mother who they believe was murdered and bundled into a car which was then fed into a scrap shredder. Forensic teams and staff from Manchester University's field archaeology unit are sieving dust and slurry from the shredder in Stoke-on-Trent in the search for Zoe Simpson, who disappeared in October 1996 from her home in Longsight, Manchester. She would have had a substantial legacy from her father on her 25th birthday two months later. Detectives from Greater Manchester police said yesterday they had extended inquiries to Ms Simpson's home town, Macclesfield, Cheshire. Detective Superintendent Andy Tattersall said: "There may be people out there who assisted in the removal of her body and the subsequent destruction of her body. "The net is closing in on them. The time to come forward is now, before we question them." Ms Simpson was reported missing by her partner's mother, who cares for her children, Nicole, now 10, and Joseph, four. New information led police to search the scrapyard. David Ward Vitamin link to bowel disease A link has been found between vitamin D deficiency and inflammatory bowel disease, it was disclosed yesterday. Mice genetically engineered to have two human bowel disorders, Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, suffered worse symptoms when deprived of vitamin D. But given supplements of the vitamin for two weeks their condition improved. The study, led by Margherita Cantorna at Pennsylvania State University in Philadelphia, is the first to demonstrate the connection. Inflammatory bowel disorders are autoimmune diseases in which the body attacks itself. Previous research has already shown a link between vitamin D and two other autoimmune diseases, arthritis and multiple sclerosis. Dr Cantorna, who presented the findings at a conference on experimental biology in San Diego, California, said that the discovery might help in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

webTitle: My life as a teenage slob

fields.headline: My life as a teenage slob
fields.standfirst:
Comedian Harry Enfield has written a film about his unappealing teenage character Kevin - complete with gross-out jokes about erections, spots and puke. He talks to Will Hodgkinson
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Comedian Harry Enfield has written a film about his unappealing teenage character Kevin - complete with gross-out jokes about erections, spots and puke. He talks to Will Hodgkinson
fields.body:
It's the ultimate teenage nightmare. Not only are your parents going to thwart all your efforts at largin' it big time by joining you on your holiday to Ibiza, but they're going to have excruciatingly loud sex in the hotel room next to the one you share with your best friend. What's a would-be mixmaster DJ virgin to do? Kevin and Perry Go Large is an excuse to wallow vicariously in the misery of adolescence. Expanded from a series of sketches on Harry Enfield's Television Programme, it is the story of a grotty, self-deluding teen (Harry Enfield) and his hapless best (only) mate Perry (Kathy Burke) as they embark on a quest to lose their virginity and become superstar DJs into the bargain.

For any adult male it is a painfully accurate reminder of the nightmare of having balls that feel like they're about to explode, a face that is exploding on a daily basis, and parents who simply exist. For parents suffering the indignities of being told that their son is "not your slave" every time they ask him to pass the salt, it's at least a reassurance that they're not alone. There are gross-out, American-style gags about erections, spots and puke, and very British characters who think they're far cooler, smarter, and better-looking than they really are."Kevin came from me, really," says Harry Enfield who co-wrote and directed the film. "I woke up at 14 or 15 and realised that I was a genius with an encyclopedic knowledge of punk music, but my parents were concerned with trivial matters, like whether I picked my socks up or not. They were just ludicrous ignoramuses compared to me, and I became a Jesus-like figure in my own head. They were my Romans, out to persecute me." Kevin indulges in similar delusions of grandeur. He imagines his own funeral, surrounded by hysterical relatives and beautiful girls who wished they had realised his genius before it was too late; and he fantasises about being Anne Boleyn's executioner, saving her at the last minute and being rewarded with a shag.

Unlike most character comedians, who tend to keep their repertoire to half a dozen guises at the most, Enfield is known for doing such a broad spectrum of characters that it seems a strange choice to take one sketch and stretch it out into an hour and a half's worth of gags big enough to look good on 35mm. "I've always thought that I wouldn't do a film with any of my characters because it would be an extended sketch. But I really like working with Kathy, and the acting relationship we have is so good, that I thought if anything could work, it would have to be with her. I got together with Dave (Cummings, Enfield's co-writer) and we came up with the idea of doing an English rites-of-passage/gross-out film. Rather than taking British TV sitcoms that went to the big screen and didn't work as our precedent, like Steptoe and Son and On the Buses, we looked to American teen films like Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure and Wayne's World, and planned an English version of that, with all the English quirks that that means. But we got a call from LA [the film was backed by American company Icon Entertainment], saying 'push the envelope', which meant make it disgusting. Squeeze the spots, essentially."

The American influence is also there in the way that Kevin and Perry is, in its own suburban way, aspirational, with the acne-strewn teens ultimately escaping from their dirty-bedrooms-and-sticky-Kleenex mire. "I'm not a massive Mike Leigh fan myself," says Enfield. "The British tend to make films that are either a bit rainy or costume dramas. I wanted to do something where we got up and out into the sun and which was ultimately about international rites of passage - we're all like this, it's a hormonal, rather than a social thing." But there are certain aspects of our own culture that run too deep to ever be eradicated. "Films like Bill and Ted always feel about 10 minutes too long because they're only on one level, you're asked to suspend your disbelief when Wayne and Garth suddenly get these Hollywood babes. So we added that British sense of pathos by going one step further - Kathy's a woman and I'm 38. They're monsters, and the girls they go after are fairly monstrous too, and just as awkward. Although they end up being pretty, because I wanted a happy ending of course."

In the original sketches Kevin is relentlessly nasty, but in the film he gets so knocked back - mainly by girls, but also by the hideous Eyeball Paul (Rhys Ifans), Ibiza's top DJ - that he even starts being nice to his parents. "The boys are humiliated time after time," says Enfield. "They get vomited on in the nightclub, don't get the girls, and have to leave in disgrace."

The boys lose their cool entirely over Eyeball Paul: they clean his floor and carry his records, all in the hope that he will listen to their DJ mix tape, before telling them to fuck off. And no matter what he does to them, the boys always have the same response: "That Eyeball Paul's such a nice bloke!" "Though people in the music business tell me Eyeball Paul's just like X or Y," says Enfield, "he was based on my memories of punk gigs, going backstage and being told to fuck off, then walking away saying, 'He told me to fuck off!' It's that optimism that makes Kevin and Perry loveable."

But Kevin's only truly effective tormentors are his parents, who make his life a living hell by reminding him, night after night, how they brought him into the world in the first place. "My parents weren't like Kevin's in what they got up to," Enfield firmly points out. "But my relationship with them was like that, and in many ways it still is. My dad, Edward Enfield, is on telly a lot now doing holiday programmes, and I can't watch it, although I think he's really good, and attractive at what he does - I hate to use that word about my father, my backbone's gone all funny just having said the word. I turn into Kevin as soon as I watch him on television."

It's tempting to imagine what might have happened if Enfield had chosen to adapt any of his other characters for film. "Because of the relationship I have with Kathy I did have a story for Wayne and Waynetta Slob. It was about them splitting up and everyone mistaking Wayne for David Bailey, but it was one side of a piece of paper." The other characters that have made Enfield famous - Tim Nice But Dim, Tory Boy, even Stavros and Loadsamoney - seem very much confined to three-minute sketches, with the exception of one. Norbert Smith: A Life was a brilliant satirical one-off on the history of British cinema through the eyes of a genteel luvvie who had seen it all, from 30s Will Hay comedies through to swinging 60s thrillers. "That was the first thing I wrote," says Enfield. "It was very stylised stuff. A David Hemmings character saying to a girl, 'Come on you bitch, into the car.' Charlie Higson [his regular collaborator] was in that, and it's interesting seeing his Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased), which has that stylised feel to it."

Enfield is known for playing other people. Would he ever want to move away from sketch based-comedy to stand-up? "I'd been on Wogan one time, and the next day this bloke in the street said: 'You're a right cunt in real life, aren't you?' It doesn't bother me if people think like that, but it takes confidence not to do sketches."

The whole point of Kevin and Perry is that they're desperate to get laid. As their house anthem Big Girl goes, "All I want to do is do it". Needless to say, the film reaches a feverish climax. Can there be any future for them now? "It kind of depends on how much the film makes," says Enfield, who at the moment has no future plans, at all. "I suppose if it's really successful they could wake up and it was all a dream."

 Kevin and Perry Go Large opens on Friday.
